subject: how i'd start all over
body:
I became a man recently (I started listening to country music)
and feel like a brain-dead monkey for knocking it for the past 22
years.

That has nothing to do with this email, but I thought I’d let you
know anyway.

I’ve been going to this Latin Cafe to get a large cafe con leche
every morning.

On my way there today, I ran into a younger guy I’d spoken to
previously in the sauna (no homo).

He was heading in the same direction, so we walked together, and
he started asking about what I do and how this online marketing
stuff works.

It got me thinking about what I’d do if I had to start over.

Let’s say I never dropped out of college, and I’m getting my
worthless communications degree from Snowflake School in a month.

The looming fear of being a wagie cuck for the rest of my life is
growing, so I decide to give a stab at this online business
thing.

But I have no skills…

No connections…

And no personal brand…

I’m effectively a female, but I can’t cook or sell my body for
money.

Here’s how I’d start all over:

Step 1: Identify what I’m naturally good at and figure out how I
can make money with it.

I’ve always been a solid writer, so that’s where I’d start.

This copywriting thing can’t be too hard, can it?

Step 2: Get obsessed

The next few weeks would be spent learning everything I could
about copywriting. I’d watch Youtube videos, read books, buy a
course or two, etc.

Then I’d write a bunch of sample copy for brands or people that I
find interesting and make that my “portfolio.”

Step 3: Ask strangers if you can work for them.

This one’s pretty straightforward. I’d find people that are
selling things on the internet and I’d try to start a
conversation with them.

In the beginning I wouldn’t mind working for cheap or even free
to get some experience under my belt.

It’s really that simple folks.

If you’re in a position where you want to make money online and
you’re a decent writer, my friend Mason is hosting a free
copywriting class tonight.

He’ll teach you how to make a lot of money as a copywriter (even
if you look like a 12 year old boy and you need a step stool to
get into your truck).

​Register for the class here and tell him I sent you. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh0l0qqdhk/kkhmh6hldnk20qbl/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vd29ya3Nob3AtcmVnaXN0cmF0aW9uP2VsPWJlbg==
)​

Click that link you fucktard ^

Ben

subject: How to use your flaws to your advantage
body:
I really have to sneeze,

but I can’t.

So I just have this uncomfortable tingling feeling in my nose
right now.

As I start this email, it’s Monday at 11:11 am, and I’m sitting
on my balcony with my coffee mug beside me.

It’s a nice day in Miami. Not a cloud in the sky.

If you don’t have a pair of Birkenstocks, you should buy some
just for days like this.

I need to cut my toenails, though.

Isn’t it wild that it’s May 1st already?

I swear it was just January, and now we’re nearly halfway through
the year.

The other day I took an IQ test once and got an embarrassingly
low score, so I was seriously considering the possibility that I
am retarded.

I’ve never retained information very well (unless I get obsessed
with a topic).

And one time in college, I got lost on the way to the gym that
I'd driven to every day for a year.

In all seriousness, I don’t think I’m super intelligent
intellectually.

But I’ve always been able to connect with people.

I pick up on things that most people don’t.

I’m either empathetic or good at faking it.

And people seem to trust me easily.

You’re probably like, “okay, Ben I don’t really care about you,”
how does this relate to ME?

Give me one more minute, and I’ll explain…

Everything I’m doing in business right now correlates with the
skillset I described above.

I can relate to people well, so this helps me write copy.

I don’t want to crunch numbers all day and am not super
analytical, so I focus on angles, marketing, and offers more than
data.

I’m simply playing to my strengths.

And once you identify your strengths, business gets easier.

If you’re organized, good with numbers, and like stimulants…

…become an accountant for a drug cartel.

If you love talking to people...

…work at a call center and scam boomers out of their retirement
savings.

If you’re a hot 20-year-old girl with nothing but air between
your ears…

…stop reading this email and go sign up for only fans.

Life gets easier when you bend reality to your advantages.

Alright, I gotta go answer one of my clients' retarded questions.

He’s a good dude, and I love working with this guy, but I swear,
every day he’ll ask me one question that makes me want to reply,
“Google it, you fucking smooth-brained monkey buffoon.”

But I don’t say that.

I say, “Yeah, brother, great question! Let me fix that right away
👍🏼”

What a display of emotional intelligence.

Wait, last thing if you’re still here - reply to this email and
let me know what kind of content you want from me.

Do you like somewhat schizo rants like this?

More in-depth marketing/ copywriting stuff?

Porno’s?

Life-lessons where I use big words and pretend to have this whole
life thing figured out?

LMK bb

Ben

)

subject: how i went from full idiot to less idiot
body:
I was in a state of constant unease . I was going in the wrong direction but didn’t know where else to turn… I was completely lost. 

 I’m sitting in my childhood bedroom as I pull out my computer and start typing.

 For the last 6 months, I’ve been pretending to be someone I’m not.

 I’ve gotten so good at acting like I’m happy to the point that I’m starting to forget what it actually feels like.

 My fingers hit the keyboard as I write,

 “Never in my life have I felt this lost. I have always had something that I’m working toward, with an end goal in sight. This made it easy to get up every day and spend most of my time doing things that I thought would bring me closer to that goal. But what happens now?”

 I wrote this in January 2020 while on winter break, after finishing my first semester of college with a 1.1 GPA.

 About a year later, I got my first paying client for my lead gen “agency” - a basketball trainer in Long Island.

 Over the next 12 months, I built my brand as a marketer in the basketball training space when a trainer with a big personal brand asked me if I could help him sell his online products.

 I’d only run Facebook ads for local basketball training businesses at the time, a completely different (& easier) game than marketing for info-products.

 So naturally I said, “Sure, of course I can help. I’m an expert!” 

 I started running his Facebook ads, writing emails, and building funnels for him.

 And although I had little idea what I was doing…

 It worked. 

 I’d made him a few hundred grand over the next 6 months, which was a big win considering he had almost zero prior success with online training.

 This led me to start working with 3 of the other big personal brands in the space, and it’s how I learned the ins and outs of paid ads, copywriting, and all things info-product related.

 After a while, I started taking on clients outside of the bball niche.

 My first big wins for clients came through webinars and offer launches.

 Because I’ve built a versatile skillset, the scope of work changes from client to client, but in most cases, I built out a new funnel for a client, script their VSL or webinar, and then help them launch the offer to their email list & on socials.

 Depending on the offer and size of their personal brand, we may start running paid ads if it seems like a good fit after the initial launch.

 Most of my deals consist of an upfront investment anywhere from $5k - $15k and then around 10% of the revenue we generate.

 A year ago, my biggest client paid me $2,000 per month.

 Today, I’ve had singular clients pay me over $20,000 in a month.

 All because:

 I stopped working with broke people. I pick clients that have a lot of leverage I can help them capitalize on. Let me know if you liked this style of email and are more interested in learning more about how my business works.

 I kinda like spewing autistic nonsense better, but if enough of you reply with questions, I can make an appeasement.

 Happy sixo de mayo,

 Ben

 ​
​

 My first big wins for clients came through webinars and offer launches.

 Because I’ve built a versatile skillset, the scope of work changes from client to client, but in most cases, I built out a new funnel for a client, script their VSL or webinar, and then help them launch the offer to their email list & on socials.

 Depending on the offer and size of their personal brand, we may start running paid ads if it seems like a good fit after the initial launch.

 Most of my deals consist of an upfront investment anywhere from $5k - $15k and then around 10% of the revenue we generate.

 A year ago, my biggest client paid me $2,000 per month.

 Today, I’ve had singular clients pay me over $20,000 in a month.

 All because:

 I stopped working with broke people. I pick clients that have a lot of leverage I can help them capitalize on. Let me know if you liked this style of email and are more interested in learning more about how my business works.

 I kinda like spewing autistic nonsense better, but if enough of you reply with questions, I can make an appeasement.

 Happy Sunday,

 Ben

 ​
​

subject: how i actually make money (18 + 😉)
body:
Writing is a great way to close all of the tabs that are open in
the back of your head.

When you articulate these almost subconscious thoughts, it clears
up a lot of mental space and alleviates anxiety.

It’s 4:08 pm on this beautiful Monday, and sitting on my balcony
once again.

An anonymous Twitter account called Deju Ru said to fast today,
so I haven’t eaten and felt great.

I finished everything I needed to do for the day about an hour
ago and took a long walk in the sun after buying some Zyns.

Maybe I should listen to anonymous cartoon characters on Twitter
more often.

I was thinking about how my business breaks a lot of the rules of
a traditional marketing agency.

Most people would tell you to pick one skill to master and become
the go-to guy for that one thing.

It’s sound advice.

I’ve become more of a jack of all trades in my business.

We scale info-products and education businesses (fancy way of
saying course shillers) by doing… well, whatever it takes.

I script & run ads for clients.

I write & send their emails.

I built their funnels.

I script their VSLs and webinars.

I connect their software through Zapier.

And I’ve helped build & organize their CRMs.

Now I’m not doing each of these things for every client.

I do what’s necessary for them in their unique situation.

I wouldn’t really consider my business and agency.

Simply put, I’m a freelance marketer… or course-slinging, boomer
scamming, idiot monkey retard.

One of the two.

I don’t know if this is the best way to build a business, but
it’s worked for me so far.

I stacked a bunch of different skills, and I utilize each of them
as I see fit.

But if I had to boil my value down to one or two things – it’d be
understanding copywriting and direct response marketing.

Getting leads to take a desired action through words has made me
invaluable to clients.

I use it when writing scripts, ads, emails, webinars, landing
pages, etc.

THIS is what’s made my clients millions – and because I’ve
coupled it with supplementary skills like media buying, building
landing pages, setting up backend systems, etc…

I’m irreplaceable.

Well… I take that back.

They could replace me, but they’d need 4 different agencies to do
so.

This is I’m able to charge some of them $10k - $20k per month.

Fuck I wish I had my own course to plug here.

I’d love to start selling you idiots something so I can buy a
Rolex Presidential and a Porsche 911, but I got nothing for you
at the moment.

​Instead, click here and sign up for my friend Mason’s free
copywriting class on Thursday. (

)​

I usually make a short guest appearance, and Mason’s quite
entertaining on his own.

Did you like this email? LMK bb :)

Love you NAME,

Ben

​
​

subject: why i'm buying a bucket of rocks
body:
Reliance on routine makes you fragile.

I was watching the Lakers/ Warriors playoff game last night.

It’s the 4th quarter, and the Warriors looked like they were
about to take control of the game.

And then a guy that you’ve probably never heard of came off the
Lakers bench and nearly outscored the Warriors in the quarter by
himself while winning them the game.

His name?

Lebron James.

No.

Lonnie Fucking Walker (yes, that’s his legal middle name).

This dude scored 15 points in the 4th quarter after not playing
for the majority of the playoffs.

Do you think that’s the optimal way to get into a rhythm?

You’ve barely played for the last few weeks, and then you’re just
inserted into crunch time in your career.

Probably not an easy situation to be in.

This concept of being able to perform under changing
circumstances is something I consider a lot.

Sure, I have a routine, and I like sticking to it.

But I never want to be the dork that can’t function because his
whoop told him he had a low sleep score.

Those who win are the ones who are durable.

They don’t need perfect conditions.

They show up and perform, no matter the circumstances.

I could continue elaborating on this point, but I think you get
it.

Instead, I’m gonna transition to my disdain for grown men riding
scooters around Brickell.

Today, I was on a pleasant walk when some Apple-Watch-wearing
wagie cuck comes flying down the sidewalk.

There is a special place in hell reserved for these people.

Do your legs not work?

Can you not budget enough of your 401k from your $120k/year
salary to buy an S-Class?

You look like a child.

These are the people that proudly tell you they make “6 figures”
while riding around on a scooter like a fucking 12-year-old girl.

And why the fuck are you on the sidewalk?

At least go dodge traffic like a real man.

Ugh.

I’m gonna start leaving rocks on the sidewalks so they wipe out
and tear a hole through their J-Crew pants.

Anyway, don’t be a fragile optimizer that can only perform when
you’re at 100%.

Most of the time, you won’t feel great.

Cultivate your energy so that you can do what you need to do 100%
of the time, even when you’re running on fumes.

Gonna go find some rocks.

Ben

subject: are you dumb enough to trust yourself?
body:
As my email list has started to grow, I’ve found myself putting on a filter that wasn’t previously there. 

 This is an attempt to break through that filter. 

 Your self-image dictates your actions. 

 Everything you do,everything you think about, and everything you stress over, all point back to the person you believe you are when you look in the mirror. 

 I’ve noticed I’ve been second-guessing myself lately. 

 Living in Miami, there’s no getting away from the noise. 

 I have friends that are crushing it and mentors I can turn to. 

 My personal brand (although not huge) has given me this warped idea of the way people perceive me, so I’ve felt a need to stick within the lines of that perception. 

 But when I started my agency in 2021, I was a stupid little idiot – alone. 

 I didn’t have people in my ear telling me what to do. 

 And I wasn’t competing with friends or others on social media. 

 It was just me, my pea-sized brain, and an urge to build a better life. 

 Objectively, I’m way smarter, more experienced, and have more leverage than the 20-year-old beginner version of myself. 

 But that kid had something I’ve lost to an extent – he was dumb enough to trust himself. 

 This leads me to the question, 

 Where does certainty come from? 

 There are two types of certainty. 

 Type 1 is evidence-based. 

 When you’ve done something a million times, previous data leads you to a conclusion. 

 Simple right? 

 But the second type of certainty is the one that’s needed to maintain a healthy balance. 

 Type 2 is delusional confidence. 

 It’s guided by intuition. 

 And it knows it could very well be making a poor decision, but it’s okay with any outcome that comes its way. 

 The thing about this type of certainty is if you don’t use it, you start to lose it. 

 The ideas you used to have and your naive intuition start to get quieter. 

 You become a robot confiding within the lines of whoever you believe yourself to be. 

 And if that identity isn’t malleable, you find yourself in a box. 

 Within that box, you create your own limitations, and you lose the confidence in yourself to trust outside of them… 

 Maybe? 

 Idk. I’ve been blindly typing away on my computer for the last few minutes, so I’m gonna reread this email to see if it makes any sense. 

 Ok, I’m back. 

 My intuition told me to stop being a bitch and send this email, so I’m just gonna click the button and go watch a movie. 

 Gn (or gm if you’re reading this in the morning, which is honestly kind of offensive because I expect you to drop everything you’re doing and read my email no matter where you are at any time of day). 

 Efkbnehjwkfbnjlknfi, 

 Ben

subject: i drove a car through the white picket fence
body:
Hey Bo.

It’s been about a week since we chatted, and I’m starting to miss
you.

I wrote half of an email the other day and didn’t send it.

It was about “striking while the iron is hot.”

In short, the initial excitement you get about a new project will
carry you through the grunt work.

But if you wait to take action for too long - that excitement
fades, and you usually never start.

About halfway through, I got distracted and stopped writing.

Ironic right?

Anyway, I would've graduated this past week if I didn’t drop out
of college to scam boomers and little kids on the internet.

It’s interesting seeing people I went to school with “fall in
love” and get married.

Are they really in love?

Or are they just settling because they think they won’t be able
to do any better?

I don’t know.

It just seems so early.

What I can tell you is that if they are settling, it won’t last.

Over the next few years, the white picket fence will begin to
decay.

Those little cracks will get bigger.

And eventually, someone will probably cheat with the maid or pool
boy.

I don’t mean to be so doom and gloom.

But life gets dull when you’re not working on something new.

You start to wonder what else is out there.

Most cope with this by obsessing over things that don’t matter,
starting drama, and worshiping celebrities.

It’s an attempt to make their lives feel like they aren’t
pointless.

But what makes life worth living?

Am I doing it the right way?

I’m building businesses, cultivating lasting relationships with
amazing people, and working towards going through a pack of zyns
daily.

I’ve found a different outlet to occupy my time on this spinning
rock.

It feels right, but what’s the end game?

It’s only when I’m able to take a step back and zoom out that I
feel like I truly appreciate it.

18-year-old me would’ve given away his last pack of mango Juul
pods to be where I am now.

Still, most days still feel relatively monotonous.

That feeling is what I wanted to escape by taking this route.

Sure, it’s better than sitting in a cubicle with a bunch of
they/thems, taking orders from some schmuck who thinks they’re
the shit because they make $186,000 per year.

My average client will make more than your annual salary this
month, jackass.

But I don’t know if the feeling of monotony ever goes away.

Not matter how exciting things are,

No matter who you know,

No matter who you are,

You still have to get up every day, put your pants on the same
way you’ve done since you were 4, and get shit done.

Great things take time, and the work isn’t always fun…

But when you learn to enjoy the work, that’s when life begins to
matter.

Take the Lakers - 3.5 tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. In order to reach my peak schizophrenic state that I love so
much, I'm fasting until 7pm tomorrow. You should join. Reply if
you're in

Ok, I have a confession.

I might've had a slice of banana bread at 4 pm.

Sorry.

A lot of you replied to yesterday's email, so it gave me enough
of an ego boost to write again today.

But I don’t really know what to talk about.

Sometimes these emails come to me easily.

I start typing, my fingers seem to get taken over by my monkey
brain, and a few minutes later, I have a semi-coherent email.

Other times, I’ll write a sentence, think about how it’ll make
you perceive me, and talk myself out of it.

Am I oversharing?

Will this make me look weak?

Do I sound too homophobic or fatphobic? (I am genuinely scared of
fats).

But then I remember that you, too, are just some grown little kid
trying to figure things out.

Even if you’re making $300k a month.

It’s starting to become embarrassing that I’m not netting $100k a
month yet.

I almost deleted that sentence.

Ok, I’m out of thoughts – let's try something new.

Reply to this email with a question, and I’ll base my next email
around the best questions I get.

I don’t know why you would want any advice from some 22-year-old
child, but hey, let’s see what happens.

Everyone tries so hard to appear authoritative online.

I’m guilty of it.

But at the end of the day, I’m just a retard that figured out how
to make my clients millions by typing words on my laptop.

No one has it all figured out.

Ask me a question, and let’s figure it out together.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: Re: answering your stupid questions
body:
Yo.

This newsletter is growing a little bit, and it’s starting to
piss me off.

Is a day coming when I’m gonna have to filter my deranged
thoughts in order to protect myself from getting canceled?

I hope not.

Don’t share my newsletter anymore because I like it better when
it’s just me and you, Bo.

I should really build some stupid coaching offer to sell you.

Anyway, the other day I sent an email asking you to reply with a
question, and a bunch of you actually replied.

Now I feel obligated to answer them. Here we go:

(if you asked me something and I’m not answering it, it’s because
it was a stupid question. You should scroll down to the bottom of
this email and click ‘unsubscribe’)

1. What’s the Ben Bader story?

I figured I’d start here to help anyone that’s new get caught up.

Long story that I don’t have the mental capacity to recite. I’m
22 (and still waiting for my brain to fully develop). Here are
some recent highlights:

- Dropped out of College of Charleston after 2 years.

- Made my first $100k with a marketing agency for basketball
trainers.

- Transitioned to info-products, and now I help big personal
brands and “influencers” make more money with their courses and
coaching.

- Now living in Miami high rise with a bunch of other idiot
monkeys that make a lot of money.

- I also am severely addicted to Zyns.

2. How do you find clients to work for?

I talk shit on Twitter and have built a bit of a brand there. I
share results, and people come to me inbound.

I also get a lot of referrals and work with my close friends.

3. Since you can work from anywhere, why Miami? Long-term to
stay there or move somewhere else, or even buy a second
home/apartment somewhere?

All of my friends are here. Good weather. Parents have a condo an
hour and a half north. Great place to meet other young
entrepreneurs.

I'll likely be in South Florida for a while… not sure how long
it’ll be Miami.

Don’t think I’d get a second place any time soon unless it were
necessary for biz, or I fall in love with some random girl that
lives in bumble fuck Idaho or something lol.

4. If you were 19 years old and trying to get to $10-15k a month
as quickly as possible, what would you do?

If female: OnlyFans.

If male: Learn a high-value skill, pitch a fuck ton of people,
get a client, repeat.

It’s really that simple.

Send enough cold messages, connect with enough people, and hack
your way into different groups… you’ll find clients. You just
gotta look hard enough.

5. When you think about yourself 10 years in the past or 50 years
in the future, does that feel like “Ben at a different time” or
“This is a totally different person”?

Ben at a different time.

I thought differently.

I operated differently.

I had a different self-identity.

But at the end of the day, the current me was in there all along.

Okay, enough writing.

There actually were a few other decent questions, but this email
is already getting too long. So if I didn’t answer you, don’t
take it to heart.

Blame your fellow subscribers, actually. They have the attention
span of a gnat, so I know I’ll lose them if I keep rambling.

If you guys liked this lmk, I’ll make this Q&A a weekly thing.

Love you Bo,

Ben

P.S. I wrote a somewhat legible Twitter thread today. Read it
here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdlvqeltl/9qhzhnhp632egdf9/aHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9iZW5oYmFkZXIvc3RhdHVzLzE2NjE0MzAzMDY3NzQxNTUyNzI_cz0yMA==
)​

subject: i'm currently locked in a hotel room
body:
I’m sitting in a hotel room, leaning back in this dark leather
chair.

The carpet and paintings in here are a bit outdated, but It’s a
nice room with a spacious bathroom.

But I have a problem.

The balcony door won’t open.

I can’t decipher if I’m too dumb to figure out how to unlock it…

…Or if it’s truly broken.

So now I’m sitting here at the desk by the “sliding” glass door.

And I’m stuck, staring outside at the chairs on the balcony…
awaiting me.

Is this what it feels like to get cucked?

I swear I tried everything.

I turned the lock all the way to the left, right, up, down,
halfway… nothing.

I looking in all the cabinets and all the drawers, scouring the
room for a key...

...but found nothing.

Now I’m inside, miserable, looking at how perfect my life could
be outside.

I’m not appreciating the nice cool temperature in here.

Or the comfortable chair.

Or the fast wifi…

I’m ruining my time inside because I want to go outside.

But what I don’t know yet, is that the outside has its own list
of problems.

Maybe the chairs are uncomfortable, or the wifi doesn’t reach
that far.

Maybe a bird will poop on my computer and ruin this email.

Or maybe there will be a gust of wind, and I’ll get blown away
like a plastic bag.

But for now, ignorance is bliss.

I’m gonna keep dreaming about getting outside in the sun where
all my problems will go away.

And I’m gonna put myself in a perpetual state of misery until I
get there.

Because where I am now is not enough.

I’m not gonna accept it.

I'll get so caught up in the pursuit of getting to a place that
I'm not, that I'll forget to be present where I am.

So I'll fail to realize that the key to getting outside was on
the counter to my right all along.

Maybe if I weren’t so busy staring out the window, I would’ve
noticed that I already had what I needed.

I lean back in my brown leather chair, exhale, look at the key to
my right and type… if not now, when?

Ben

P.S. I didn’t actually find the key, and it’s still pissing me
off that I can’t go outside. Also, I wrote this with zero
caffeine or nicotine in my system, so if you hated it that’s why.
God Bless.

subject: Confidence
body:
One day during my sophomore year of high school, I was talking
about confidence with a teammate on my basketball team.

His name is Colin, and he’s probably reading this email along
with you.

In that conversation, he said something that stuck with me to
this day - hence the email.

I’d asked him how he seemed so unbothered when he missed shots.

He replied, “My confidence isn’t a rollercoaster.”

Colin went on to become the all-time leading scorer at our
school.

I was on a walk today thinking about this idea of unwavering
confidence.

As I write this email, I’m wrestling with where it comes from.

We can all agree that a large part of confidence is derived from
preparation – but it’s not that black and white.

I was obsessed with basketball throughout high school.

I put in as many hours as anyone.

But when I’d miss a few shots, I’d start to hesitate.

When I turned the ball over, I didn’t want it the next play.

My confidence didn’t run parallel to my preparation.

It fluctuated. And when I’d get into a rut, it’d be a downward
spiral.

But Colin was almost always emotionless.

Good game, bad game, didn’t matter.

He could miss every shot and still want the ball in his hands
with the game on the line.

Maybe the recipe for unwavering confidence goes as follows:

Preparation - emotion = confidence…

Eh. I still think there’s something missing.

There’s an element of confidence that doesn’t rely on
preparation.

It’s built on trust.

Ok, wait, that makes sense.

You just watched me hash this out in real-time, so thanks for
your patience.

People that have unwavering confidence aren’t prepared for every
situation – but they have enough trust in themselves to figure it
out.

I could go down the rabbit hole of where that trust comes from,
but that would take a lot more critical thinking on my end, and
you’re not really helping here.

This newsletter was never supposed to offer profound advice or
life lessons anyway.

There’s enough advice out there. I’d rather offer you my
perspective and let you agree or disagree.

Last thing I’ve internalized recently:

Your reality acts as a mirror of your self-beliefs.

It’s a common saying in sales that “whoever has the most
certainty wins.”

This couldn’t be more true, and it doesn’t just apply to sales.

If your beliefs about yourself aren’t strong, other people's
beliefs about you will start to manifest.

If you don’t feel respected by those around you, it's because you
don’t respect yourself.

Choose who you are, or let others choose for you.

Sounds simple, but something to consider in your own life.

That’s all for today.

Talk next quarter,

Ben

subject: reply for a chance to win a bag of dorritos
body:
Ok. 

 I’ve been staring at this blank page for 3 minutes now, so I just put a zyn in my upper right lip in hopes that I’ll have a nicotine-induced burst of creativity. 

 Um. 

 Ummmm. 

 Still nothing. 

 Why do I even write these? 

 I have nothing to sell you, and I get no benefit from this other than a slight ego boost when someone replies, “Wow, this almost sounded like it wasn’t written by an autistic toddler. Keep it up, Ben!” 

 The liberal-wagie-cuck army on tik tok is starting to get to me. 

 I’ve had a couple of videos go semi *viral* recently, and half of my comments are people calling me a trust fund baby. 

 The other half are girls commenting on my eyelashes. 

 Fuck off woman, no I don’t have a “lash tech,” and if I did, I wouldn’t refer you to them. 

 And to be fair, I did grow up in a great neighborhood, but every dollar I’ve made has been on my own. 

 I actively tell my parents and grandparents that I don’t want their money. 

 Business is going swimmingly right now. 

 Clients are crushing, and I’m getting close to being out of poverty (I can taste $100k a month). 

 But in all honesty, it feels a bit dull. 

 An extra $20k per month or so wouldn’t change much about my life right now. 

 Recently I’ve realized that money loses its value if you don’t utilize it. 

 My life now looks cool, but I was going out more and having more “fun” when I was making around $10k per month, living like a rockstar in a college town. 

 My favorite thing I’ve been able to do recently is impact people around me. 

 Roughly 6 months ago, this 18-year-old kid found me on social media and asked me to mentor him by sending me a dollar on Venmo. 

 I had some money sitting in my Venmo account, and I sent him $1k back. 

 Phillip used that money to buy a course from a friend of mine and is now making $10k a month in sales. 

 He’s moving out of his parent's house next month. 

 Another dude who I call Scooby, has been replying to my emails updating me on his life. 

 He was in a tough situation, so my friend Mason and I bought him a laptop to help him start making money online (love you scooby). 

 One of my best friends from college, Stevie, was born to be in sales. 

 This guy could make a brick wall laugh. 

 I helped him get into a great opportunity, and he closed his first deal (and made $500 in commission) today. 

 These 3 situations are some of the highest ROI things I’ve been able to experience recently, and they have nothing to do with me personally making more money. 

 Funny how that works. 

 Being a catalyst to help other people grow is really fucking cool. 

 Sorry for the jumpiness in this email, I guess the zyn worked. 

 Love you {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Ben

subject: I hope this went to spam
body:
Do you ever consider the possibility that we’re already living in
the metaverse?

I installed an app on my phone that makes me wait 5 seconds and
click a few extra buttons every time I want to use social media.

But I look at my screen time and see a number so large that I’m
ashamed to share it with you here publicly.

I guess I’m not perfect.

Every now and then, I’ll go to war in the sauna.

It’s the kind of war where if you were to spectate this
situation, you’d think I’m schizophrenic and belong locked away
in an asylum.

My inner dialogue becomes audible, and it turns into a screaming
match between the person I am and the person I tell myself I want
to be.

Right now, I’m battling comfort.

There are some things I want to change about my life – and
myself.

I’m stuck in the middle between desire and acceptance.

The desire hasn't been strong enough to elicit action.

But it IS strong enough to deter acceptance.

Does that make sense?

In any situation, you decide if you want to accept it or change
it.

If the cost of change outweighs the desire, you do nothing – but
it’s easy to fall into a trap where the desire is everpresent.

I don’t think it has to be this way, though.

There’s got to be a way where you can accept your current
circumstances and your current self while continuing to morph
into a new and improved version.

It’s a code I haven’t cracked.

And it’s dangerous.

If you only take action when your back is against the wall, your
life will become a seesaw.

You’ll only see progress after you reach a new low.

You go up and then right back down.

Or if you’re really unlucky, you’ll just stay floating in the
middle for eternity.

I don’t like being this vulnerable with you.

But I know if it’s something I’m struggling with, some of you may
be able to relate.

Acceptance.

I know the answer is acceptance.

But I’ve been operating on this seesaw for my entire life, and
it’s gotten me here.

I guess I’m not perfect.

Ben

subject: haaaaaaaapppppppiiinnneeeeeesssssss
body:
I like being alone.

It’s a superpower and a downfall.

If I wanted to, I could go months without talking to anyone but
myself and the 9 other personalities in my head.

Maybe some of you can relate to this -

If I spend a few days constantly surrounded by other people and I
don’t take an opportunity to reset, I lose my mind.

I start to forget who I am, and I become an extension of the
people I’m with.

So sometimes it’s nice just to turn the world off and be with me,
myself, and I.

I can hear myself best in solitude.

But I do understand this is a dangerous game.

Some Harvard dorks did an 85-year study on happiness.

Basically, they took about 800 people from around the world and
monitored their happiness levels every 2 years.

The strongest correlation to happiness wasn’t financial success.

Or career achievement…

Or even health.

The happiest people were those with the best relationships.

Looks like I’m doomed because I hate you fucks.

Hahahaha.

Maybe schizophrenic people are actually the happiest because they
always have someone to talk to.

You can only grow so much in isolation.

The depth at which you know yourself is limited by your
experience with the outside world.

Your relationships with others reveal your true relationship with
yourself.

And to have a truly happy relationship with yourself, you need to
have strong relationships with others.

I’m kinda figuring this out on the fly here, but I think that
makes sense, right?

No matter how great of a human you are or how much you THINK
you’ve grown – interacting with other real humans is the litmus
test.

And if you really are a good person, you’d be doing a disservice
to the universe by not sharing your gifts with the world.

So if you’re like me and you’re content being a hermit – be
careful.

(I say that as I sit on my balcony in the middle of Brickell,
where I am literally surrounded by people all the fucking time)

Gonna go get a Cuban coffee from the nice lady at the cafe.

Let’s talk more, I enjoyed this.

Ben

P.S. I plug each of these emails into chatgpt and ask it to
analyze them. The response it generates actually blows my fucking
mind - try it with some of your writing.

subject: a bunch of random thots
body:
Any time I open a blank doc like this, my brain starts to fire.

I’ll come up with an idea and map it out to see if I can turn a
thought into a coherent email.

Usually, I’ll churn through a handful of these half-baked
thoughts before I arrive at what I follow through with.

Here are some of the ideas I’ve had over the last 63 seconds:

1 - How you show up in one area of your life is reflected in
other areas.

If you’re hiding parts of who you are in one relationship, it
subconsciously manifests in other relationships.

It dictates your level of authenticity and the way that you
interact with the world as a whole.

I’d keep going, but I don’t want to get too personal. You’re a
stranger reading my inner dialogue, and I don’t know what you’re
thinking on the other side of the screen.

Next.

2 - Everything is a mental game.

I cold-plunged yesterday for the first time ever.

The first 5 minutes were torture.

I kept telling myself to get out.

But eventually, that voice got quieter. My body went numb, and 15
minutes later, I felt like a new man.

This mental fortitude shined through for the rest of the day in
my mental state and the way that I spoke to people.

I guess this relates to my first point.

3 - With enough input, your desired result will unfold.

Some of the pieces of content I’ve put out recently kinda
flopped.

Each of which I posted thinking, “This is a banger.”

Apparently, they weren’t.

But that’s okay.

Some of my favorite artists put out hundreds of songs before they
had one pop.

If your results dictate your consistency, you will fail before
you give yourself the chance to succeed.

Hmm.

Maybe all of these half-baked thoughts are intertwined.

Maybe this email was somewhat coherent.

I think there’s a deeper lesson in there, but I’ll leave it up to
you to connect the dots.

I’d continue on with this stream of consciousness, but it took me
3 tries to sound out the spelling of consciousness.

I think that means it’s time to turn off my brain.

Have a good week Bo,

Ben

subject: my first scam at 14 yrs old (fun! easy! simple!)
body:
Ding ding ding

The bell rings.

I grab my backpack and hustle out of the classroom so I can be
the first one out the door.

The teacher tells me to slow down on my way out.

I pretend not to hear her.

I get to bus #5 and walk down to row 16 on the left side by the
window, per usual.

Then I pull out my light blue iPhone 5 and start reading.

This was my routine every day for the past few years.

I subscribed to a newsletter from a guy named Taylor Allan.

His emails were absolutely incredible.

The vivid imagery he used made me feel like I was participating
in any situation he described.

He articulated my thoughts and my exact situation in a way that
connected the dots in my head.

I no longer felt alone.

This random stranger that sent me emails every day somehow
understood me and my problems better than my parents did

Maybe even better than I did.

He was selling an online basketball training product in the early
2010s.

I don’t remember how expensive it was, but one day I found a link
to get it for free.

So I put in my contact info and immediately got access.

Then I felt guilty.

I told my Mom what I did, and said that she could see me selling
an online basketball course one day.

She let me use her credit card to go back and pay for the course
so I could alleviate my guilt.

And now, I spam your email inbox and help people sell courses.

Such beautiful foreshadowing.

Anyway,

I’ve been getting a lot of replies to my emails recently, and I
just wanted to let you know I appreciate you

My goal is to write such bangers that you experience the same
excitement that I used to when reading Taylor’s emails.

Reply and let me know what kind of content you’d like from me
going forward.

Honestly, I’ll probably discard your suggestion – not because
it’s a bad suggestion but because I like to pretend that I come
up with all my ideas on my own.

You probably do that too.

Thanks for reading, Bo.

-Ben

P.S. Copywriting is the one skill I’ve used in every business
I’ve ever tried – it’s made me rich for a 22-year old

My friend Mason is one of the only people that I sometimes get
jealous of when reading his writing.

He’s fucking good, and he made a killing as a freelance
copywriter.

​If you’re interested in getting paid to click letters on your
keyboard like a retarded monkey, check out this free class. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h347exkfq/25h2hoh28mkn7lu3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vd29ya3Nob3AtcmVnaXN0cmF0aW9uP2VsPWJlbg==
)​

​

​

subject: quick story
body:
I was heading to my usual lunch spot today when someone who
looked familiar walked in ahead of me.

I stood behind him and 3 of his friends in line.

The person in front of him whipped out his phone and started
taking a video.

After about 30 seconds, I realized that two of the people he was
there with didn't speak English.

"He's buying lunch for random strangers he found on the street?"
I thought to myself.

This person is known to be extremely generous and commonly does
things like this.

Both registers were open, and I ended up next to him as I was
ordering.

I said "hola" to my friend behind the register and asked for some
tacos.

To my right, they rang up his order.

Before he could pull out his card, I put my Amex down on the chip
reader.

Honestly, I don't know why.

I wasn't trying to get something out of this and didn't expect
anything in return.

I figured he does a lot of nice things for people, and it's
probably been a while since someone did something nice for him

He gave me a sincere thank you, and we chatted for a bit.

He said that he'd actually flown out the people he was with from
Japan and that they were staying with him for a few days.

I sat down and enjoyed my meal.

That concludes my story on buying lunch for SteveWillDoit.

Sometimes you get random inclinations to do nice things for
people.

If you follow them, they usually open doors for you or, at the
very least, offer you some good karma.

Ben
​

​

subject: quick story
body:
I was heading to my usual lunch spot today when someone who looked familiar walked in ahead of me. 

 I stood behind him and 3 of his friends in line. 

 The person in front of him whipped out his phone and started taking a video. 

 After about 30 seconds, I realized that two of the people he was there with didn't speak English. 

 "He's buying lunch for random strangers he found on the street?" I thought to myself. 

 This person is known to be extremely generous and commonly does things like this. 

 Both registers were open, and I ended up next to him as I was ordering. 

 I said "hola" to my friend behind the register and asked for some tacos. 

 To my right, they rang up his order. 

 Before he could pull out his card, I put my Amex down on the chip reader. 

 Honestly, I don't know why. 

 I wasn't trying to get something out of this and didn't expect anything in return. 

 I figured he does a lot of nice things for people, and it's probably been a while since someone did something nice for him 

 He gave me a sincere thank you, and we chatted for a bit. 

 He said that he'd actually flown out the people he was with from Japan and that they were staying with him for a few days. 

 I sat down and enjoyed my meal. 

 That concludes my story on buying lunch for SteveWillDoit. 

 Sometimes you get random inclinations to do nice things for people. 

 If you follow them, they usually open doors for you or, at the very least, offer you some good karma. 

 Ben
​

subject: Kobe Bryant wasn't confident
body:
I planned this email out in my head earlier today.

But right now, I’m hesitating to write it.

I was gonna tell you about how the need for confidence becomes a
crutch.

I had a story prepared that demonstrated this example perfectly.

I was gonna tell you how I was sitting at lunch today when I saw
a pretty wooman walking by.

Instinctually I thought, “I should go up to her,” but I didn’t.

My brain came up with a thousand reasons as to why that’d be an
outrageous thing for me to do, and I talked myself out of it.

I told myself I didn’t have the confidence to do that right now.

I wasn’t wearing a watch.

I was dressed like a toddler.

It was a bad hair day.

Maybe I’ll do it another day when I’ve done the inner work to
build up my confidence, and I look a little more presentable.

So I let the opportunity pass me by, and now I’ll never be able
to impregnate this pretty stranger. She could’ve been my wife.

The thing is, it wasn't confidence that I was lacking.

It was courage.

And having the courage to act in the face of uncertainty is how
you build confidence.

It lets you use real-life examples to change the story you tell
yourself about who you are.

You give your brain data that says, "Bo you are this type of
person. Remember when you did XYZ even though you were nervous?”

When you stop relying on confidence, you’ll no longer need it.

Because no amount of inner work – no amount of money – no fancy
watch will magically turn you into someone that you’re not right
now.

Only actions can do that.

Last point to drive this home:

Every star basketball player has bad games.

There were times when Kobe would go 3/14 throughout a game.

He literally holds the NBA record for the worst single-game
shooting percentage when taking 5+ shots.

Yet he still wants the ball in his hands with one minute to go…
no matter how the previous 47 minutes have gone.

Not because he’s feeling extra confident to step up to the plate
that day.

But because in his world, confidence doesn’t exist.

It doesn’t matter.

And he doesn’t need it because he replaced it with courage.

Rip Kobe. Makes me sad just thinking about it.

Anyway, I’m not gonna send this email.

Instead, I’ll write a less personal email that makes me look like
a perfect, confident person.

If you received this, no, you didn’t.

Miss her man,

Ben

P.S. Good article that Kobe wrote about obsession (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hg387zwcm/p8heh9hz2e5oodhq/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cudGhlcGxheWVyc3RyaWJ1bmUuY29tL2FydGljbGVzL2tvYmUtYnJ5YW50LWFsbGVuLWl2ZXJzb24tb2JzZXNzaW9uLWlzLW5hdHVyYWw=
)​

P.S.S. Chat GPT graded my email a 7/10 because I spelled woman
with two O’s, and “impregnate this pretty stranger” wasn’t
professional. Fukk you, Chat GPT

​

subject: Why you should give up on your dreams
body:
You’re in a hallway.

It’s a narrow hallway with white walls and fluorescent lights.

There’s a row of wooden doors on both sides.

You’re looking for a golden key.

You try one of the doors on your left, but it’s locked.

In a moment of panic, you turn and start running down the hall,
past the other doors.

Eventually, you see a door with golden light shining from under
it at the end of the hallway.

You make your way down and open the door.

There’s an empty room with an arrow on the wall pointing toward a
new door on the right.

You walk to the new door and open it.

Another arrow and another door.

In the next room, you see the same thing.

You continue to follow the according arrows and open new doors.

Finally, you reach a room with glowing walls.

And on the floor in the center of the room, you find the key you
were searching for.

You grab the key and get out of the hallway.

On your way out, you look back at the hallway.

And you see all the locked doors that you’d run past on your way
to the first door were now open.

What I’m describing isn’t a psych ward or a never-ending maze.

It’s the law of surrender.

Many of the paths you take in life will lead you to the next path
– a better-suited path…

IF and when you’re ready.

But you can’t unlock the next path until you’re ready.

And if you spend too much time banging your head against the wall
in one path, the next one will never illuminate.

Let’s bring this back to earth a bit.

When I was a junior in high school, I gave up my lifelong dream
of playing college basketball.

I saw the signs that it wasn’t for me, and I listened.

I let that dream die.

A similar thing happened that led me to drop out of college and
dissolve my first business.

The thing is, I never got a direct tap on the shoulder telling me
it was time to move on.

The universe whispers, I had to be quiet enough to hear it and
surrender my control to trust it.

Looking back, I can see that those decisions led me right to
where I needed to be.

But this wasn’t evident until I got there.

I gave you this analogy to show you this:

There is power in knowing when to surrender your control and
follow your intuition.

When things aren’t working, no matter how hard you try to force
it, it could be a sign that you’re missing a key.

And to find that key, you’ll need to open a different door.

Allow life to surprise you. It always knows.

- Ben

P.S. If you’ve noticed I’ve been more consistent with these
emails, you’re right. This is a bit Hubermanesque, but I’ve built
a ritual for myself when I want to enter creative mode. Dim
lights, music in the background, lit candle & a zyn.

Try building a ritual for yourself when building a new habit.

P.P.S. Check out this podcast episode - trust me. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4eepngbp/g3hnh5h3lvpkolbr/aHR0cHM6Ly9vcGVuLnNwb3RpZnkuY29tL2VwaXNvZGUvMDllZFE0S21Udzdjek5udjJVS0pmUD9zaT00MjgwODFhZWFhODk0NjVh
)​

​

subject: life lesson from instagram models
body:
I recently made a video talking about how we all have seasons in our lives. 

 Sometimes we’re in grind mode. 

 Sometimes we’re more relaxed. 

 I’ve come to realize that it’s a bit more nuanced. 

 There are a multitude of seasons that you need to experience in order to keep things interesting. 

 For me, life has been very peaceful recently. 

 I’m working a lot, but mostly on things I enjoy doing. 

 For now, I like it this way. 

 But eventually, this stage will no longer serve me. 

 I’ll need more stress. 

 More chaos. 

 More unpredictability. 

 “Everything is temporary” 

 This is a quote that one in every five girls will put in their Instagram bio. 

 Scroll down, and you’ll see rows of bikinis pics. 

 That part's unrelated. 

 When we fight these seasons, things start to feel misaligned. 

 We start swimming upstream. 

 Our minds have an interesting way of telling us what we need. 

 When you’re anxious, maybe it’s because you’re stagnating. 

 You need to add more to your plate. 

 You need to move to a different city. 

 You need to make a change. 

 The key is to observe the way you’re feeling and accept whatever stage you’re in. 

 Maybe this is why women have menstrual cycles. 

 That was a joke - but actually, considering women seem to be more intuitive than men, maybe there’s some truth there. 

 Either way, listen to the way you feel. 

 When things just seem to be “off,” it’s time to make a change. 

 Or you’re pregnant. 

 Ok, that’s enough. 

 I ate an edible for the first time in a bit, and it’s starting to hit me. 

 Should I still be telling you this now that my email list has doubled in subscribers? 

 Maybe. 

 Everything is temporary, I guess. 

 (that makes no sense, but it just sounded right in my head). 

 Have a good night, {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you made it this far, reply and let me know if this email made any sense to you because I can no longer tell if my realizations are intelligent or if I'm just stoned.

 ​

subject: i'm in a rush
body:
I’m leaving to pick up my friend Mason at the airport in 6
minutes.

It’s highly unlikely that I’ll be able to give you anything worth
of value in our short amount of time here.

But I can’t miss this email today.

It’d be the 2nd day in a row.

And that would start a negative streak - which would make it
harder to write an email tomorrow.

So this email probably won’t change your life.

But if you learn anything, I guess it’s exactly that.

If you skip any habit you’re trying to build for 2 or more days,
it’s harder to start again.

I sound like I read the book Atomic Habits and made it my entire
personality.

But anyway I gotta go.

Jkwfnefljwbeidbewnjifdnw,

Ben

​

​

subject: Do you feel like you know yourself?
body:
I’ve been avoiding this all day.

I’m sitting here watching this cursor blink over and over.

It’s been 2 minutes now.

Why is my mind still blank?

Are my new subscribers gonna think I’m an idiot?

I just grabbed my mouse to click away to another tab.

But I stopped myself.

Not today, Satan.

I’m gonna sit here and write this fucking email no matter what.

Should I talk about the shitty coffee I had this morning? (I
cheated on my main spot).

Or should I talk about how failures make us who we are because
they–

Never mind, you’ve heard enough of that lately.

Ok.

The depth in which we know ourselves determines the depth in
which we interact with the world.

Let me say that in English:

When you’re aware of your motives, why you want what you want,
why you do what you do – you see with more clarity.

It lets you trust yourself more.

And that trust shines through in your relationships.

On a related note, my least favorite people are those who lack
self-awareness.

You may be reading this right now and thinking it’s ironic that
I’m saying that – but at least I’m aware enough to acknowledge
that possibility.

Those who lack self-awareness view themselves as someone they’re
not, and that creates misalignment in the way reality is viewed.

They’re the kind of people that you never see eye to eye with -
no matter how well you explain your perspective on a situation.

And this is created by a lack of introspection.

So if there’s anything of value that you take away from this –
find a way to “talk to yourself” more.

Could be journaling, walking, driving, or whatever else lets you
feel like you’re spending quality time with yourself.

Alriiiighty...

For whatever reason, this one’s been a struggle for me to write,
so if you’re still here, thanks for sticking with me.

Hopefully, my thoughts will be more coherent tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Watch this video if you want to feel like a stupid,
incompetent, pre-pubescent child (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukho3vgdwir/25h2hoh2ggeq76i3/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9Vek8zVG9KeUZWbw==
)​

P.P.S. Reply and let me know what you thought of this email if
you made it down here.

 You may be reading this right now and thinking it’s ironic that I’m saying that – but at least I’m aware enough to acknowledge that possibility. 

 Those who lack self-awareness view themselves as someone they’re not, and that creates misalignment in the way reality is viewed. 

 They’re the kind of people that you never see eye to eye with - no matter how well you explain your perspective on a situation. 

 And this is created by a lack of introspection. 

 So if there’s anything of value that you take away from this – find a way to “talk to yourself” more. 

 Could be journaling, walking, driving, or whatever else lets you feel like you’re spending quality time with yourself. 

 Alriiiighty... 

 For whatever reason, this one’s been a struggle for me to write, so if you’re still here, thanks for sticking with me. 

 Hopefully, my thoughts will be more coherent tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch this video if you want to feel like a stupid, incompetent, pre-pubescent child ​ 

 P.P.S. Reply and let me know what you thought of this email if you made it down here.

subject: 398 words that will help you
body:
Writing is the best skill you can learn. 

 I know some great salespeople that suck at writing, but I don’t know any amazing copywriters that suck at sales. 

 Case closed. 

 Here are 3 somewhat unique ways I’ve improved my writing over the years: 

 (I’m always cautious when giving tips about writing because it creates added pressure to be perfect). 

 1 - Daily journaling 

 I don’t journal as much as I used to – though I should. 

 But when I was really honing my writing skills, this is how I did it. 

 I’d write to my future self, updating them on my life and sharing lessons I’ve learned – very similar to the flow of these emails. 

 Writing a sales email is really not that different from *some* of my rant emails/journals. 

 Because there’s one characteristic your writing needs to have, no matter the purpose of it… 

 It needs to be ENGAGING. 

 If it’s not engaging, no one will get through it. And if no one gets through it, no one will buy. 

 This leads me to my second point… 

 2 - Reading good copy 

 You’re already subscribed to the best newsletter in the world (mine). 

 Why not add a few more? 

 Seeing different writing styles and the way various arguments are made will help you be more creative in your own writing. 

 Any time you see a good ad, sales page, email, etc. – save it. 

 I have a folder with 200+ funnels on my bookmarks tab. 

 I suggest you start to build one of your own. 

 Last and final point… 

 3 - Thinking & doing other shit 

 Many of my best realizations and ideas have come while doing something that isn’t writing. 

 One time I basically wrote an entire sales page in my head while I was at the gym. 

 I got home, and I just transcribed my brain onto a doc. 

 You need to give your mind quiet time to think. 

 The more you understand yourself and the way you operate – the more you’ll understand the world. 

 And a vast array of experience will give you a wider perspective which translates to you being a better writer. 

 Alrighty, this was a lot easier today. 

 If you actually implement anything I told you to in this email - you’ll become a better writer. 

 Thanks for reading, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here’s a 3-minute info-product marketing masterclass for you ​ 

 ​

subject: never send an email at 12:50am
body:
Every Sunday, I go for a ~2-mile run around this riverwalk close to my apartment. 

 To be clear – I’m not an apple-watch-wearing cardio dork. 

 But I enjoy getting out in the sun, and running provides a great opportunity to fight the voice in my head that wants to be lazy. 

 So today, I threw on my running shoes and went over to the path. 

 It’s almost always crowded, so I’ve made it a competition in my head when I see other runners in front of me. 

 My pace fluctuates a bit when I’m more motivated or going downhill versus uphill. 

 But there are two scenarios where I drastically increase my speed. 

 When I see someone in front of me, I turn on the jets. 

 I try to run by them as fast as I can, so they feel bad about themselves they decide to stop running altogether (this is my attempt to make the riverwalk less crowded). 

 On my way home today, I was coming up on this big intersection. 

 Usually, it takes about 25 seconds to walk across. 

 By the time I got up there, the countdown signal to cross the street was down to 4 seconds. 

 I had two options… 

 One - Stop and wait 2 minutes for the lights to turn red again. 

 Or two - Hit the gas. 

 I put my head down and ran faster than I had all day. 

 If I didn’t, maybe I would've ended up on someone's windshield based on how aggressive drivers can be in Miami. 

 My point – I ran the fastest when I absolutely had to. 

 Faster than when I’m tracking down another runner. 

 And faster than when I feel more motivated. 

 Because nothing can induce speed the way necessity will. 

 If you emptied your bank account and had to make a certain amount of money, or you’d be homeless in 30 days – you’d figure out a way to get it done. 

 At that point, motivation doesn’t matter, it’s just a buzzword. 

 It’s easy to take action when you have no other option, but it gets harder once you’ve had some success. 

 Let’s say you’re making decent money with X business model. 

 You want to pursue Y business model, but right now, X is paying for your lifestyle. 

 What I’ve done, and perhaps the practically “sound” decision, is to start Y on the side while maintaining X. 

 Once you’re making good money with Y, you transition into doing it full-time. 

 Logically it makes sense – but here’s where it gets dangerous. 

 If there's an idea that’s been on your mind for a while and you haven’t acted on it yet, it could be because your current situation offers you too much comfort. 

 And if that idea lingers for long enough without the according action, it’ll drive you crazy. 

 Maybe that’s when you consider burning the boats. 

 ​ You’ll figure out how to swim when you’re in the water. ​ 

 Ben 

 P.S. I’ve made my clients millions of dollars online, and I don’t know the difference between a metaphor and an analogy. I thought this running story was an analogy, but Chat GPT told me it was a metaphor. Maybe AI will replace us.

 P.P.S reply if you liked this email <3

 ​
​

subject: can you help me think of a subject line?
body:
Following your passion is bullshit.

Kinda.

There is a route where your passion intersects with your leverage
and knowledge.

It’s your job to find that intersection.

To think you can make a lot of money “doing what you love”
without complementary skills is a naive approach.

There are times when you won’t be passionate about the vehicle
you’re in.

But those times give you an opportunity to find a key that you’ll
need later on.

I’ve always enjoyed writing.

If I could make millions of dollars sitting at my desk writing
these emails, I’d do it.

But I wouldn’t have anything worthwhile to write about if it’s
all I did.

I need life experience as a reference point.

And progressing in business allows me to share insights and bring
value.

If writing was my sole focus, maybe I’d use bigger words or know
the difference between an analogy and a metaphor.

But it wouldn’t matter because no one would read it.

It’s like trying to build a puzzle by finding the last piece
you’ll need.

No bueno.

Being passionate about what you get paid for is a privilege that
must be earned.

And the way to earn it is through experience.

Which in my opinion is one of the most valuable things you can
optimize your life for when you’re young.

You simply need to taste everything to know what you like.

Work in different industries.

Live in a big city then move somewhere quiet.

Be a degenerate and then go into monk mode.

The best reference points and learnings are found on various ends
of the spectrum.

And with enough experience, the connection between your knowledge
and your passion will be obvious.

But only when you have the necessary toolkit.

When your work starts to feel more like play, it means you’re on
the right path.

At least I think so.

But as always, I could be way off about everything in this entire
email.

May Chat GPT be the judge.

Goodnight,

Ben

P.S. About to watch this Tai Lopez rant if you wanna watch it
with me (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hvgq8d3b6/7qh7h8ho8mn02wtz/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_dj1rVW1LZHJqaHkzTQ==
) (no homo)

P.P.S Banger analogy from Chat GPT:

It's like setting off on a cross-country road trip without a map
or GPS. You have an idea of your destination – it's a city you've
always dreamed of visiting. But without understanding the
terrain, the distances, and the possible roadblocks, you'll
likely end up lost or going in circles. Along the way, you need
to gather information, learn how to navigate, and understand the
characteristics of your vehicle. Similarly, following your
passion without developing relevant skills and acquiring
necessary knowledge can lead to frustration or even failure.
Experience and understanding of the real-world terrain of your
passion is crucial to reach your desired destination.

subject: {{ subscriber.first_name }} i literally wrote this in my sleep
body:
I had a dream last night where I was playing basketball. 

 I can’t recall the exact situation or where I was, but I know this – my team was up 7 points with a few minutes left in the game. 

 We started playing keep-away. 

 Instead of trying to score, we passed the ball around the perimeter to keep it out of the other teams' hands. 

 Then I started dribbling around, weaving through the defenders. 

 Eventually, I lost the ball, and that’s when I woke up (I never lose the ball, so my brain was like yup, this is a stupid dream). 

 In my delirious half-awakened state, I had an idea. 

 Most people are playing keep-away with their lives, and it’s fucking everything up. 

 They just try to get to a baseline level of comfort so they have just enough breathing room to not blow the lead. 

 And then they stop trying to score. 

 They’re no longer playing to win, they’re playing not to lose. 

 If you know anything about sports, this is how big leads get blown. 

 In life, it’s no different. 

 Avoid this at all costs. 

 I literally woke up at 4:44 am and said, “Hey Siri, text Ben Bader “Run out the clock” so I’d remember this idea. 

 ​ You need to constantly be on offense. 

 When you start to feel happy with what you got, and you go into “preserve mode,” that’s when you’re gonna find yourself in trouble. 

 This is especially true as you start to make more money. 

 It gets easy to think you have a big enough “lead” (safety net or nest egg) to where you can coast. 

 I don’t know about you, but I just can’t see that working out well. 

 Stay on offense. 

 Keep attacking. 

 And run up the scoreboard. 

 Happy 4th, 

 Ben

subject: Why you need to be a drug addict
body:
When you were young, you wanted to be extraordinary. 

 Maybe you wanted to be an athlete, singer, painter, gamer, astronaut, etc… 

 Maybe you became obsessed with this idea. 

 You convinced yourself it’s what you were born to do. 

 Most of your days were spent practicing, envisioning, and thinking about this one goal. 

 But after a while, that dream was beaten out of you. 

 Something you’d been obsessed with for so long was now gone. 

 And like energy -- obsession cannot be created or destroyed. Only converted from one form to another. 

 This is where it gets problematic. 

 We’re naturally hardwired to stalk our prey, attack, and kill. 

 But the sad truth for most people is that they become their own prey. 

 Instead of finding a new outlet for that obsession, they try to stuff it down. 

 The world tells them who they should be, obsession is bad, and that they need to find balance. 

 So they listen. 

 Next thing you know, these are the people that are addicted to drugs, alcohol, gambling, porn, etc. 

 And perhaps just as miserable are the ones who bury their obsession to the point where it doesn’t have one of the above outlets. 

 They are the ones who eat themselves from the inside out. 

 They become obsessed with attacking themselves, overthinking, and fantasizing about what life could be like if they were dealt a different hand. 

 Because no matter what, you can’t outrun obsession. 

 It’ll eat you alive. 

 In 1854, Henry David Thoreau wrote, “The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them.” 

 You can’t outrun obsession. 

 Find an outlet for it -- And do it every day. 

 Unless that outlet is black tar heroin. 

 Thx for reading -- Reply and LMK your thoughts on this topic, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Read Kobe Bryants' article on obsession if you haven’t already ​ 

 ​

subject: Only open if you brush your teeth
body:
I haven’t been super consistent with these emails the past few
days.

Once upon a time, not too long ago – I set out to write an email
to my list for 100 days in a row.

I made it about 9 days before I disappeared for a few months, and
my subscribers probably thought I died.

If you remember that, you’re an OG.

Consistency is something we all struggle with at times.

But why?

You brush your teeth every day (hopefully) without any issues.

You scroll through social media every day.

You text your ex every day.

But sometimes, when you try to build a new habit, or you sit down
at your desk to work, or you’re trying to make progress in the
gym…

It just doesn’t happen.

And it’s because you’re trying too hard to be perfect.

When you brush your teeth, you don’t think about the “perfect”
stroke. *pause*

You’re a robot.

You probably have the same brushing pattern every time, whether
you’re conscious of it or not.

Sometimes you’re still drunk from the night before, and you’re a
bit less thorough.

Other times your breath smells, so you’re more intentional.

But it happens no matter what (with some exceptions, of course).

As I felt the looming pressure of going another day without
writing an email, I started racking my brain to get an idea.

I came up with a few things, but they all felt forced and
repetitive – and now generating an idea for something that I
usually enjoy doing started to feel like work.

Then I stopped and said to myself:

“Just do something.”

Use those 3 magic little words the next time you feel like you’re
in a rut.

That something doesn’t have to be great.

It doesn’t even have to be good.

But it’ll protect you against the atrophy that would occur if you
didn’t use your muscles that day.

Just. Do. Something.

Done,

Ben

P.S. In most of my recent emails, I keep coming back to the same
few principles. One that seems to be ever-present is this idea of
having trust in yourself – even in uncertainty. Trust that you’re
on the right path and trust that if you just start, you’ll figure
it out. The painting can only be completed after the last stroke.

P.P.S Just do something (

subject: i'm freezing.
body:
Today marks day one of making the cold plunge my entire
personality.

So here’s a lesson I’ve learned from submerging myself in cold
water:

It only hurts when you resist the pain.

When I first get in, all my brain says is, “This is freezing. Why
are you doing this? Get me out of here. Joe Rogan is a liar. Ok
seriously get out.”

But then I take a deep breath and relax.

I loosen the muscles in my body that are tensing up and tell
myself it’s really not that bad.

And after a minute or so, the pain goes away.

Or maybe it doesn’t dissolve – but I learn to tolerate it.

Either way, it’s an interesting dynamic.

There are a few analogies we can pull from this.

The most obvious one is “run towards fear. Pleasure is on the
other side of pain, blah blah blah.”

It’s a valid point, but I’m not gonna bore you with David
Goggins-themed motivation.

I think there’s a deeper lesson here that may or may not resonate
with you…

We feel pain when we resist our true selves.

It creates an internal conflict where the image that we’re
presenting to the world isn’t congruent with our core belief
system.

Because saying what you want to say and showing others who you
really are, sounds intimidating.

It makes you vulnerable.

So you’d rather hide.

It’s more comfortable to just paint on a fake smile, fake
personality, and fake belief system.

But after a while, you’ll realize that you’re pretending – and
it’ll start to eat you alive.

And then you’re left with a choice.

Do you continue to cover up your authenticity with a bigger
shield so that people can’t see in?

Or do you remove the layers that you’re hiding under and stop
resisting who you really are?

Because maybe there’s a chance that it was all just a figment of
your imagination.

Maybe raw authenticity won’t actually make you vulnerable.

Maybe you’ll unlock the desires that you were chasing and
couldn’t catch.

And maybe you’ll finally find peace with that same voice in your
head that tells you that the water is too cold.

Or maybe, I’m just kind of sleepy, and this made no sense.

Reply and let me know what you think :)

Talk soon,

Ben

P.S. Come to my friend Mason's free copywriting class this Sunday
if you want to learn how to get paid to click letters on a
keyboard like a monkey with an 80 + IQ (

)​

 Maybe raw authenticity won’t actually make you vulnerable. 

 Maybe you’ll unlock the desires that you were chasing and couldn’t catch. 

 And maybe you’ll finally find peace with that same voice in your head that tells you that the water is too cold. 

 Or maybe, I’m just kind of sleepy, and this made no sense. 

 Reply and let me know what you think :) 

 Talk soon, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Come to my friend Mason's free copywriting class this Sunday if you want to learn how to get paid to click letters on a keyboard like a monkey with an 80 + IQ ​

subject: don't let your friend drive your trackhawk
body:
I’m staring at a page of semi-coherent thoughts.

For the past 20 minutes, I’ve been attempting to write to you
about reliance on others.

What I’m trying to say to you is making sense in my brain, but
I’m having difficulties translating it into legible English.

In short, here’s my point:

Odds are there are many things that you situationally rely on
other people for - even though you could do them yourself if you
tried.

Some of these things are as simple as being the one who drives,
leading the conversation with the waiter, or planning the trip
for everyone.

Other examples could be relying on a partner to operate a part of
the business or lead the conversation on a sales call.

If you’re constantly taking the backseat, these little things add
up over time and make you less capable.

Is this making any sense yet?

Feed your brain information that says, “I’m not the one who takes
the initiative in this situation,” and you’ll start to think
you’re incapable.

Let’s try to reel this in some more.

This became apparent to me recently when I noticed I take a
different role socially depending on who I’m around.

When I go out with one group of friends, I’m the one who calls
the shots.

I decide where we go, I walk up first, I order the drinks, and I
go talk to the group of pretty blonde girls.

When I’m with a different group, I do none of the above.

This might sound elementary, but it’s important to take note of
where this concept bleeds through in other areas of your life.

Reliance on other people allows you to limit yourself.

Notice the verbiage there. Other people don’t limit you – they
allow YOU to limit you.

Let’s say your Mom “makes” your pop tart every morning by putting
it in the toaster and clicking a button.

You were never cognizant of how she did it, and now you think you
don’t know how to heat up a pop tart.

Extrapolate this to every part of your life, and I think this
jumbled-up email will make a bit more sense.

What you’re aware of you’re in control of. What you’re unaware of
controls you.

Reply if you liked this one Bo.

It’s been a while since I used the first name field.

I kinda like saying your name Bo.

Ok bye Bo,

Ben

subject: i bought a richard mille for lunch
body:
Here’s a POV as I open my laptop to write this email.

​
I’m at my favorite lunch spot that I go to every day in Brickell.

I spend $40-$50 here every day (sometimes more if I get a sweet
treat).

And honestly, I’d pay double for the hospitality, speed at which
the food comes out, and ambiance in this place.

It’s the Richard Mille of lunch.

When I first started my business, I was closely attached to the
money.

I wasn’t necessarily cheap, but I felt every dollar I spent – and
when I was having a slow week or slow month, it was reflected in
my confidence.

But recently, I’ve never worried less about money.

$400 dinners with the boys, 100 bucks to skip the line at the
club, first-class flights, 100% tips on the bill, a few grand on
new clothes…

I don’t feel any of it.

And I know some of you may be reading this thinking I’m a
bombastic asshole, but that’s not my intention here.

The best part of making money is not thinking about money.

But we all pedestalize it to an extent.

“Making $10k per month will fix all of my problems and make up
for the fact that I’m insecure because my left nipple is slightly
smaller than my right one.”

No, it won’t – but I get it.

It’s a lesson that can only be internalized if you experience it
firsthand, over and over.

You hit the arbitrary money goal in your head and immediately
want more.

Go through a few cycles of this and then realize it’s turning you
into a crazy person.

And eventually, you come to the realization that money is just a
tool.

Solve the money problem, so you have the financial peace of mind
to develop other areas of your life.

The biggest irony is when people say things like, “I don’t care
about money!”

This attitude causes every decision you make to be limited by a
lack of financial resources.

Those who TRULY don’t care about money – focus on it & make it –
So they never have to think about it again.

Ok, enough writing for today.

I’ve been at this restaurant all day and have had a revolving
door of friends walking in and out of here, so this email has
been a highly distracted excursion, but I hope you liked it

Talk later bb,

Ben

P.S. Help me out real quick (

)​
