subject: i'm going through a quarter life crisis bc of my TV
body:
I woke up viscerally angry today that I don’t have more followers
on Twitter.

​So plz go here and follow me real quick if you don’t already (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdnpo8ralh7/g3hnh5h3nw7dw6ar/aHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9iZW5oYmFkZXI=
) (it’s where I actually share more in-depth business advice).

Thx.

Moving on – this morning, I went through a brief quarter-life
crisis on my walk.

You see, a few months ago, my TV randomly broke.

I tried everything to fix it – I turned it off and turned it back
on (twice, actually).

But it didn’t work.

Most of the time, I don’t think about the fact that I lack a
functioning TV until I sit down on the couch, grab the remote,
click the on button, and see a black screen.

In theory, I could order a new TV or go to best buy, but it just
sounds like too much of a hassle – so instead, I opt to grab my
laptop and just watch whatever I want to watch on there.

It’s a tricky spot to be in.

I kinda want a new TV, but that desire isn’t strong enough to
spur me into action.

So let's break this down…

Most of the time, we operate within a range of 2 levels of
desire.

Things that we kinda want.

And things that we can’t not get.

The latter of the two usually eventually unfold - I felt like I
had to drop out of college, start a business, build a personal
brand, etc.

There was no other option, so the action became obvious.

You probably have some things like this in your life – those
things that you can’t not get – you’re obsessed. You’re
constantly thinking about them, and they're going to happen no
matter what.

But you also have a laundry list of the things that you kinda
want.

Maybe you kinda want to get jacked, take surfing lessons, learn
guitar, go on more dates, start a YT channel, etc.

These unclosed loops become death by 1,000 papercuts.

They linger in the back of your head like a gnat that only
bothers you occasionally.

Most of the time, you’re not thinking about it, but when it’s
buzzing in your ear, you want nothing more than to kill it.

And in life, you’ll get occasional reminders about your “kinda
wants” to the point where you’ll eventually need to start
tackling them.

They could be completely unrelated to your main thing (the things
you can’t not do) and feel like a pointless side quest.

But if they continue to linger, it means there’s something there.

It’s an urge you have to quench.

All this said, I likely won’t be getting a new TV until September
10th (first day of the Bengals football season).

Don’t be like me.

Start attacking one thing that you kinda want today.

​And follow me on Twitter plz, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdnpo8ralh7/g3hnh5h3nw7dw6ar/aHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9iZW5oYmFkZXI=
)​

Ben

P.S. Chat GPT graded this an 8/10, which is lower than usual. I
care more about your opinion bc you’re a real person. Let me know
if this one resonated

​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdnpo8ralh7
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdnpo8ralh7
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdnpo8ralh7/9qhzhnhpxrkqr9c9/aHR0cHM6Ly9jb252ZXJ0a2l0LmNvbS9mZWF0dXJlcy9lbWFpbC1tYXJrZXRpbmc_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPXBvd2VyZWRieSZ1dG1fY29udGVudD1lbWFpbCZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPXJlZmVycmFsJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9ZHluYW1pYw==
)

subject: I'm getting a 9-5 (clickbait)
body:
I walk past the 9-5ers in Brickell on a sunny Thursday afternoon.

Most of them are dressed as men's warehouse mannequins. Shirts
tucked in, pants the perfect length, and Apple watches on their
wrists.

It’s 90 degrees outside, and they’ve gotta be burning up.

I can’t help but feel a sliver of guilt as I pass by shirtless –
wearing nothing but kill crew shorts and running shoes.

At the age of 22, I have the freedom and am making the money that
they’re trading 40+ years of their lives for.

I’m not saying this to sound like a pretentious asshole but
rather to point out the inequity of our inputs.

Those of us who are in a similar position to me (where life
effectively feels like a video game) are not inherently smarter
than those trapped at a desk.

I’d be willing to bet some of those people would smoke us as
entrepreneurs.

But the difference is in the way we view the world.

For whatever reason, we were lucky enough to be delusional.

So delusional to the extent that we brainwashed ourselves into
believing a different reality was possible.

And this reality rewarded us for our delusion.

No matter where you’re at in life, you’re going to reach a
multitude of intersections where you have to make a decision.

Do I continue living in my current reality by telling myself the
same thoughts, ideas, and stories?

Or do I change the narrative I tell myself and thus adopt
different beliefs that will let me see a new reality?

This might sound a bit “woo woo,” so to put it simply:

The guy hating everyone in tik tok comments lives in a different
reality than the guy who’s making $10k/month.

The guy making $50k/month lives in a different reality than the
guy making $10k/mo.

And the guy making $1m/month lives in a different reality than
any of the above.

To reiterate – these realities are simply made up of the stories
we tell ourselves. To change your situation in life, you must
change your belief system.

Observe the ever-present thoughts running through your head.

Do they make sense?

Do they serve you?

Do they align with your goals?

OR have you just been identifying with them out of habit? They’ve
been engrained so deep into your psyche that you don’t even
question them.

Continue to audit your beliefs, continue to discard those which
don’t serve you, and continue to watch your dreams unfold.

I must add -- all of this means nothing without taking the
according actions and developing skills.

Love you,

Ben

P.S. My friend Grant helped me connect the dots and understand
this concept - follow him on Twitter if you’re not weird (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5x9vzni7hx/25h2hoh2gz4n74t3/aHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9yZXRpcmVtZW50a2V5cw==
)​

P.P.S. I ordered a new TV this morning. I know – very courageous
of me. If you’re new here and don’t understand why me ordering a
TV is a big deal, check out this email from the other day. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5x9vzni7hx/qvh8h7hrv5oq8nbl/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2IvazB1bWg2aGRucG84cmFsaDc=
)​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5x9vzni7hx
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5x9vzni7hx
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

decisions and actions that you’ve chosen (consciously or
unconsciously).

Whenever you're faced with a tough decision, the answer isn’t
always obvious on the surface – but it’s only once you make a
decision the right answer will reveal itself.

I’m kinda talking in circles right now, so let’s get more
practical…

As I look back at the last few years of my life, every big
decision I made eventually became the “right” decision – but in
the moment, there were always doubts.

From when I decided not to play college basketball to when I
dropped out of college, those felt like big moves at the time.

As I think about them now, it couldn’t be more glaringly obvious
that those decisions served me.

But a lot of people get stuck trying to make a perfect decision,
so they never do anything.

Even the wrong move will illuminate the right move – as long as
you’re MOVING.

The first real business I started was a marketing agency for
local basketball trainers.

I couldn’t have picked a worse niche, but in hindsight, it’s what
led me to the info-product world, where I’ve been able to find
success.

Someone I know reached an impasse in their career a little bit
ago.

They had just shut down their previous business and were ready to
start something new – but trying to figure out what that new
thing was gonna be.

We were on the phone one night, tossing around an idea for what
they could do next.

After some back and forth, they said, “what the hell I’ll try
it."

They’re now in a position to make multiple seven, if not eight
figures with that business and impact thousands of people.

But none of this would’ve happened if they didn’t simply decide
and act.

So if you’re wondering why I’m telling you this and how it
applies to you – I don’t know.

I can’t answer that question for you.

Maybe you’re contemplating a big life move right now, and you’ve
been weighing your options for a bit.

Maybe the weight of the decision is making you anxious and
unhappy.

Maybe it’s time to make the decision so you can finally figure
out if it was the right or the wrong move.

And eventually, you’ll see that all you needed to do was decide
because you’ll end up right where you need to be.

As always, reply and let me know if this one resonated.

)​

Ben

subject: {insert subject line here}
body:
The right answer can only become obvious once a decision has been made. 

 I could end the email here and leave that sentence open to your interpretation. 

 But there's almost nothing I love more in this world than to spew my thoughts across a computer screen, so here we are. 

 Your current situation in life is made up of a series of decisions and actions that you’ve chosen (consciously or unconsciously). 

 Whenever you're faced with a tough decision, the answer isn’t always obvious on the surface – but it’s only once you make a decision the right answer will reveal itself. 

 I’m kinda talking in circles right now, so let’s get more practical… 

 As I look back at the last few years of my life, every big decision I made eventually became the “right” decision – but in the moment, there were always doubts. 

 From when I decided not to play college basketball to when I dropped out of college, those felt like big moves at the time. 

 As I think about them now, it couldn’t be more glaringly obvious that those decisions served me. 

 But a lot of people get stuck trying to make a perfect decision, so they never do anything. 

 Even the wrong move will illuminate the right move – as long as you’re MOVING. 

 The first real business I started was a marketing agency for local basketball trainers. 

 I couldn’t have picked a worse niche, but in hindsight, it’s what led me to the info-product world, where I’ve been able to find success. 

 Someone I know reached an impasse in their career a little bit ago. 

 They had just shut down their previous business and were ready to start something new – but trying to figure out what that new thing was gonna be. 

 We were on the phone one night, tossing around an idea for what they could do next. 

 After some back and forth, they said, “what the hell I’ll try it." 

 They’re now in a position to make multiple seven, if not eight figures with that business and impact thousands of people. 

 But none of this would’ve happened if they didn’t simply decide and act. 

 So if you’re wondering why I’m telling you this and how it applies to you – I don’t know. 

 I can’t answer that question for you. 

 Maybe you’re contemplating a big life move right now, and you’ve been weighing your options for a bit. 

 Maybe the weight of the decision is making you anxious and unhappy. 

 Maybe it’s time to make the decision so you can finally figure out if it was the right or the wrong move. 

 And eventually, you’ll see that all you needed to do was decide because you’ll end up right where you need to be. 

 As always, reply and let me know if this one resonated. 

 ​ And check out this podcast I did recently with my friend Alex. ​

 Ben

subject: don't read this
body:
Start 7/24/23 10:08am

I’m sitting outside Starbucks, sipping on a cold brew.

I just watched this mid-20’s aged mom struggle to open the door
with her stroller.

While I considered getting up to help her, I figured it would
take too long to get up and walk to the door.

Now I feel like an asshole.

There’s a man standing about 20 feet in front of me.

I can’t determine if he’s homeless or not.

He’s wearing a grey wife-beater, champion shorts, and
Birkenstocks while holding his(?) phone and dancing like a maniac
to the music coming out of his wired headphones.

You might be thinking, “Ok Ben, well if he has a phone and
headphones, that means he’s not homeless.”

And to that I say, most homeless people in Brickell actually make
around $10k a month and have base model Rolex’s.

Stop 7/24/23 10:14am

Start 7/26/23 7:43pm

I wrote that two days ago and then got distracted.

Unfortunately, I wasn’t able to figure out if the guy was
homeless or not – but he started aggressively yelling and
laughing shortly after.

That’s when I left.

It’s now been 4 days since you last heard from me.

At the moment I have no idea what I’m gonna share with you, but I
figured if I miss another day it could spiral into a long hiatus.

This is usually the point where I’d transition into how just
showing up every day is better than trying to be perfect blah
blah.

But you’ve heard enough of that.

In fact, you’ve probably heard enough of everything.

Once upon a time, I was addicted to consuming content.

I’d go down a dropshipping rabbit hole, then SMMA, then Amazon,
etc.

For weeks I’d mindlessly watch Youtube videos and take notes so
it felt like I was being productive and doing something that
would help my life.

But I never implemented any of the stuff I learned.

Finally, I realized that I was effectively fantasizing about
success and giving myself a false dopamine hit by watching this
content, so I turned it off and stopped listening to all the
gurus.

Then I made money.

Simple right?

The lesson here is that there’s no lesson here.

If you’re not where you want to be stop endlessly consuming
content without taking action on any of it.

You’re basically getting off to other people's words.

And that’s weird.

Go do something

Ben

​

subject: i lost $28k today
body:
I’m back at the Starbucks I wrote to you about yesterday. 

 6 cops on motorcycles just drove by with their lights on. 

 The man I told you about in yesterday's email is here again, and I’ve concluded that he’s definitely homeless. 

 He’s wearing the same clothing except for a different pair of sandals (which actually look really comfy) and is carrying 6 worn down plastic Target bags – which I imagine hold the entirety of his belongings. 

 He’s still schizophrenic too. 

 The girl sitting behind me just asked me to watch her bag while she goes inside to get a drink, and now I feel morally obligated to defend it with my life. 

 I just fought off 12 large men. 

 The world is so interesting when you stop to observe it. 

 I could write about the Mehgan Fox-looking girl who just walked by or the man that just sat down in front of me, and I think is staring at me because every time I look up, we make eye contact… 

 Do you ever think about how maybe we’re the NPCs and the schizophrenic homeless guy that’s screaming in laughter is actually the awakened one? 

 This guy’s still staring at me. 

 He just nodded, and I pretended not to see it. 

 I’m not mean he just has a crazy look in his eye. 

 I fucked up. 

 He’s walking over here. 

 Ok, he’s gone now. 

 He definitely had a screw loose, but he seemed harmless. 

 He sat down across from me, shook my hand, and told me his name was Cornelius (I promise I’m not making this up). 

 He went on to tell me how his phone is broken and then started asking me if I live around here and if I have a working phone. 

 I said no to both and then pretended to be intensely working on my computer, so he said goodbye and walked away. 

 What an interesting morning. 

 Honestly, if I read this email, I’d think I’m either a pathological liar or that schizophrenia is contagious and that I should stay away from the homeless guy. 

 Anyway, I spent $18k this morning and then gave away another $10k. 

 Long story short, I realized I wasn’t getting billed for a mastermind that I’m in, so I let them know, and they offered me a $6k discount to just pay in full for the year. 

 I couldn’t say no. 

 And the $10k was a “misunderstanding” with a now ex-client where they claimed we agreed to a performance fee of bottom-line revenue (profit), but we actually agreed to topline (total rev). 

 Although I have a document (that they signed) that clearly states I’m entitled to roughly $10k more than they paid, I honestly don’t care enough to go through the headache of pursuing it. 

 Oh well. 

 Feeling like aggressively inflating my lifestyle, so I’m forced to make more money. 

 Stop taking life so seriously, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Good movie about a dog that I watched the other night ​

 ​

subject: How to stop fumbling the bag
body:
Finally.

I’m so back.

This is the first ounce of creativity I’ve had in a week.

For a bit, I thought I was completely out of ideas, and I’d said
every word of value that I could.

But I was wrong.

I have plenty to tell you about, and I just wasn’t giving my
thoughts enough of a vessel to transfer into reality (whatever
the fuck that means).

As I was sitting outside Starbucks this morning, it hit me.

The only reason people don’t find success in life & business is
because they fail to recognize opportunities that are presented
to them.

They wander through life, perpetually messing up every chance
they have at making a lot of money.

All it takes is one good connection or one win to completely
change your life.

They get a well-respected client who could send them hundreds of
referrals…

Buuut they can’t get results, so it falls apart.

Or they meet someone who can open various doors for them…

And they don’t go above and beyond to add value to that person's
life.

It’s like they’re either blind to the opportunity or so nervous
to mess it up that they just crumble.

One of my first big personal brand clients was a guy named DJ
Sakcmann.

He’s got about half a million followers on IG and is one of the
main authorities in the online basketball training space.

I connected with him through a cold DM on Instagram.

We got on a call, and he said needed a new funnel.

I said, “say no more, fam” and spent the next 4 hours writing
some of the best copy I’d ever written.

I built the entire landing page, and by the next morning, he had
a new funnel.

At the time, I was making around 10k per month, so I obviously
could charge for my work – but I didn’t ask him for a dime.

The funnel I built literally converted 5x better than the one he
had previously, and it generated hundreds of thousands of
dollars.

For the next 4 months, I basically worked with him as an unpaid
intern, and it was one of the best decisions I ever made.

Not only did I eventually get paid a lot of money from DJ, but it
opened so many doors for me.

* He sent me a handful of referrals
* It gave me confidence that I could get results in the
info-product space
* And DJ is now a good friend of mine and one of my most notable
case studies

But it would’ve been so easy to fumble this opportunity.

I could’ve let my ego get in the way and asked for a lump sum of
money upfront.

I could’ve stopped following up with him when he didn’t reply.

I could’ve half-assed the funnel and taken much longer to get it
done.

But I recognized the potential upside in this partnership, so I
seized it.

This is just one of many examples of the art of craftiness – the
most overlooked skill in business.

I’m working with a kid right now named Kevin, who edited a recent
podcast I did (without asking for money).

Not only am I gonna pay him, but I’ll send him intro’s to
potential clients and give him advice on scaling his business…

Just because he has enough foresight to go out of his way to
provide value for me and not be greedy by asking for a bunch of
money.

Odds are you’ve had chances in your life to help someone who can
open doors for you.

It’s up to you to recognize when those opportunities present
themselves and go above and beyond to pounce on them.

Hope you enjoyed this email, I’m glad to be back.

​Check out the podcast I did with Cardinal Mason and Grant Lannin
here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvh86n6wnt6h7m77kgg/n2hohvh35x20d5a6/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS81S01TZGFzVjVCYw==
)​

Ben

P.S. Reply if you liked this one :)

​

subject: I'm selling you something
body:
I’m once again sitting outside this Starbucks without any idea
what I’m going to write about today.

I just chugged a cold brew and coconut water, so my bladder feels
like it’s going to explode.

But I refuse to use the bathroom here because it’s one of those
where you have to ask them for the code to unlock the bathroom
door.

And that’s just not something I’m willing to do.

“Hey sir can you give me the code for the bathroom??” Nope.
Couldn’t be me. I dropped out of school for a reason.

Okay, I’m stalling now.

What should I write to you about?

Uhhh.

I’ve been thinking about putting together a course or coaching
offer for a while now.

I keep going back and forth on what I’d offer, how hands-on it’d
be, and what people want to learn from me.

If I built an agency coaching offer, here’s how I’d position it:

I’d start by demonizing the traditional SMMA model.

You may have heard the saying, “An enemy of my enemy is a friend
of mine.”

This common enemy tactic is one of the most powerful tools you
can use as a marketer.

You’re breaking the beliefs of your audience while simultaneously
building a bridge to your solution.

This is how I’d sell you on the “full-stack marketer” business
model.

I’d show you how it’s easier to get a few clients to pay you
$5k-$10k+ per month rather than try to stack a bunch of clients
on cheap retainers and constantly have to do outreach.

I’d tell you how I worked with 50+ clients that paid me $1k per
month and how much of a headache that was.

And I’d show you how I now get paid $10k- $30k per month (per
client) without needing a huge team.

With enough social proof and personal stories, I’d sell you on
the business model, and I’d sell you on me.

Now it’s time to sell you on you.

This offer would be for people that have a client or two as a
freelancer, so I’d speak directly to that archetype.

“Since you already have some results, this is the easiest way to
scale. You’ll simply be selling more services to someone that
already trusts you.”

This is where I’d use language that shows you how I was once in
their shoes and transfer my certainty into their soul (if I can
do it, you can do it).

This is how successful offers are created.

Sell an audience on a mechanism (business model), sell them on
yourself as the authority, and sell them on themselves so they
can actually visualize their own success.

Hope this gave you a better understanding of how to extract money
from strangers on the internet.

Reply if you liked it :)

Ben

P.S. It's a miracle I finished this email without peeing my
pants. You're welcome.

​

 I’ve been thinking about putting together a course or coaching offer for a while now. 

 I keep going back and forth on what I’d offer, how hands-on it’d be, and what people want to learn from me. 

 If I built an agency coaching offer, here’s how I’d position it: 

 I’d start by demonizing the traditional SMMA model. 

 You may have heard the saying, “An enemy of my enemy is a friend of mine.” 

 This common enemy tactic is one of the most powerful tools you can use as a marketer. 

 You’re breaking the beliefs of your audience while simultaneously building a bridge to your solution. 

 This is how I’d sell you on the “full-stack marketer” business model. 

 I’d show you how it’s easier to get a few clients to pay you $5k-$10k+ per month rather than try to stack a bunch of clients on cheap retainers and constantly have to do outreach. 

 I’d tell you how I worked with 50+ clients that paid me $1k per month and how much of a headache that was. 

 And I’d show you how I now get paid $10k- $30k per month (per client) without needing a huge team. 

 With enough social proof and personal stories, I’d sell you on the business model, and I’d sell you on me. 

 Now it’s time to sell you on you. 

 This offer would be for people that have a client or two as a freelancer, so I’d speak directly to that archetype. 

 “Since you already have some results, this is the easiest way to scale. You’ll simply be selling more services to someone that already trusts you.” 

 This is where I’d use language that shows you how I was once in their shoes and transfer my certainty into their soul (if I can do it, you can do it). 

 This is how successful offers are created. 

 Sell an audience on a mechanism (business model), sell them on yourself as the authority, and sell them on themselves so they can actually visualize their own success. 

 Hope this gave you a better understanding of how to extract money from strangers on the internet. 

 Reply if you liked it :) 

 Ben 

 P.S. It's a miracle I finished this email without peeing my pants. You're welcome. 

 ​

 I just chugged a cold brew and coconut water, so my bladder feels like it’s going to explode.

subject: Getting canceled on a podcast
body:
I’m sitting at the crowded coffee shop in my hotel lobby.

It’s kind of cold in here, so I ordered a hot latte with vanilla.

Fun fact – I went through a 3-day phase where I was drinking
black coffee and felt like I was better than everyone else.

Then I missed flavor and switched back to sugary, milky coffee.

My airpods are dead, but I have them in my ears to try to drown
out the noise from all of the other people in here.

There’s a guy sitting over to my right that I swear I’ve seen
many times throughout my life.

Does that happen to you too, where you see people that you think
have been following you from city to city since you were old
enough to remember?

Because same.

I like asking you questions even though I know you can’t actually
answer me because you’re a stranger on the other side of the
screen, probably reading this on the toilet (unless you’re a
female bc girls don’t do that).

Ok, I’m 173 words in now, and I’ve written nothing of value.

This is the part where I try to find some important life lesson
to share with you that makes you go, “Wow, that’s super
interesting,” and then you forget about it 2 minutes and 6
seconds later.

I’m going on a podcast in a few hours, and I’m a bit nervous.

I have no logical reason to be nervous, but I am.

The nerves are coming from feeling like I need to uphold or
project an image of myself to the world.

I know when you’re 100% comfortable with yourself, the nerves go
away...

But I woke up this morning to a (well-meaning) comment on my Tik
Tok that said, “Having a conversation with you must be so
insightful. Your friends are so lucky to be in your circle.”

And now, I feel the need for every word I say to be insightful.

What if I want to talk about Joe Burrow and Cincinnati Bengals?

Or my fear of fat people?

Or how I’m currently seated next to the line to order a coffee,
and some dickhead is standing too close to me?

If you couldn’t tell by now, my newsletter is more for me than it
is for you.

You’re just an innocent bystander getting hit in the crossfire of
the combative thoughts in my head.

Thanks for reading, and as always lmk if you liked this one Bo.

Have a great Saturday (if the day of the week means anything to
you),

Ben

P.S. I wrote to you yesterday about how I’m considering offering
coaching for agency owners that want to make more money with
fewer clients and fewer headaches.

If you fall into that bucket, can you do me a quick favor?

Simply reply and let me know what type of agency you run and what
your biggest challenge is with your business right now.

You can write 6 words or a full novel, thanks in advance :)

​

subject: it's getting late and i miss you
body:
I’m 34,000 feet in the air as I type this on my phone.

If there’s one reason to make multi-8 or 9- figures, it’s to
avoid airports and only fly private.

Smelly fat people.

Idiots standing still in the middle of the aisle.

And NPCs standing up right when the plane lands as if their
stomach rolls are gonna magically propel the plane to the gate.

This is the first time I’ve flown in a bit actually, and I’ve
decided that I’m only sitting in first class from here on out.

Although I still had to deal with the airport people, the power
trip of walking past the line at the gate, and sitting down in 1D
is 100% worth the extra money.

I’ll stop being a judgmental asshole for a sec and share
something that’s been on my mind recently.

Your eyes are a gateway into your soul.

You know when you meet someone that you can just tell us actually
ALIVE?

They’re not just going through the motions of life or suppressing
their true self.

They’re attacking every day with ferocity.

I’ve started to take note of this whenever I’m in public.

Walking around the airport is mostly an energy drain.

Most people look like life’s beaten every ounce of creativity and
passion out of them.

I swear you can see it just by looking people in the eyes.

Here’s my hypothesis:

Every time you suppress a desire, it sacrifices a piece of your
soul.

Working a job, you hate, staying in unhealthy relationships, not
approaching the pretty brunette that you saw at lunch 2 months
ago( miss her man).

These things eat at you.

At the end of last week's podcast, I was asked the following
question…

“If you had to leave the world with one message, what would it
be?”

Immediately I said, “follow your curiosity.”

I was never super religious growing up, but I’ve always noticed
these signals where I’m simply called to follow an inclination.

You’re drawn to ideas, people, and places for a reason.

And you have the choice…

Do you ignore those desires and sacrifice your soul?

Or do you follow your curiosity no matter how intimidating it may
be?

Just touched down in LA.

Hope you’re having a good hump day Bo,

Ben

​

subject: Stealing my rich neighbors Porsche in Beverly Hills
body:
I just got a sugary iced latte from the most liberal coffee shop
I could find in Beverly Hills as I start this email from the
balcony at my Air BnB.

I’m in a nice residential neighborhood, and my across-the-street
neighbor just pulled out in a black Porsche boxter with red rims.

His driveway looks like a luxury car shop.

Along with the boxter, he has a white 911 turbo, a new range
rover, and a vintage beige Mercedes.

He drove the 911 yesterday morning.

I’ve become so accustomed to the sweltering heat in Miami that
I’m wearing a hoodie on this cloudy 72-degree morning.

The energy here is quite different from Brickell.

It’s more laid back, and there seems to be a constant blue
undertone in the sky.

As I think about ways to transition this email to a life lesson,
my mind is drawing a blank.

I’ve been stuck for the last few minutes staring at this blinking
cursor.

Whenever I feel like my well of original thoughts has run dry,
there’s one thing that revitalizes my creativity.

Movement.

I’ll go on a walk, work out, or simply do anything to get myself
away from my computer and back in touch with the thoughts in my
head.

When I sit at my desk and try to force creativity, it usually
eludes me.

The harder you try, the harder it gets.

I’ve realized that much of the progress I’ve made in business has
been in times when I don’t feel like I’m trying that hard.

I’ll get obsessed with something for a period of time, and the
work starts to feel like play.

I don’t have to force myself to sit at my desk – I simply do it
because it’s the obvious thing that I want to do at that moment.

This trait seems to be a blessing and a curse.

It’s made it very difficult for me to do things that I don’t want
to do.

In school, I absolutely hated homework.

I’d do anything and everything that I could to avoid it.

And in business, when there are tasks that I don’t feel like
tackling, I’ll procrastinate until the final deadline.

Even if it’s something that literally takes me 3 minutes to knock
out, it feels like a herculean feat.

Obviously, you can’t always neglect the things you're not excited
about.

But there’s definitely a balance between doing work that allows
you to enter a flow state and swimming upstream for too long and
going in the wrong direction.

Not sure if that makes sense, but I have a handful of things that
I’ve been putting off this morning that I need to go do.

They’ll take me about 3 minutes each.

I decided to write this email first because it’s something I
actually felt motivated to do.

Weird how that works.

Talk soon,

Ben

P.S. Check out my recent podcast with Grant Lanin and Cardinal
Mason if you haven’t already (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukho4vl0vsrh5655onn/wnh2hghwvqv76qu7/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS81S01TZGFzVjVCYw==
)​

P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one (if you feel motivated enough
to do so)

subject: skipping my flight to write this
body:
The doorman told me I should leave now for my 11:59am (PST)
flight.

He said it’s one of the year's busiest travel days, and LAX will
be a madhouse.

I don’t buy it.

I’ll leave in an hour or three.

(if I miss this flight to write this email, it’s 100% your
fault).

I have too many things to write about today.

Instead of writing about one singular idea like a normal person,
I’m gonna go rapid-fire.

You ready?

- I met a kind, early 30’s woman at the bar at Catch.

I told her I liked her bag, and we started chatting for a few.
She’s a famous model/actress (isn’t everyone), and I’m thinking
about asking her to fund my lifestyle.

- Have you ever had New Zealand licorice?

Go to Trader Joe's right now and get some if you haven’t.

- I kind of want to get a place in LA.

Only for a few months out of the year, so I don’t end up dying my
hair purple and cutting off my [redacted].

Do I actually want to spend more time here, or am I idealizing it
because it’s new to me?

- Business is easy once you’re good at making other people money.
I’m gonna repeat that for the people in the back.

Business is easy once you’re good at making other people money.

Everyone tries to play the client acquisition game, but nobody
plays the get results game (for lack of a better term).

I have inbound leads coming to me, following up with me till I
finally reply (because I hate getting on calls), and then they
transfer 5 figures to my bank account after a 20-minute phone
call… Because they know I will make them wayyy more than that.

Keep your client acquisition systems dorks.

- I was originally going to leave yesterday, but I moved my
flight, and first class was full.

I’m in 12C like a peasant.

- You guys kept harassing me, so I’m finally building a course
about funnels.

It’s literally gonna be the bible for understanding types of
funnels and when to use them.

And I’m gonna charge you an arm and a leg for it (lmk if there
are some specific things you want to learn).

Okay, I think I actually have to go now.

The doorman is gonna be mad at me when I walk out of here an hour
after he said I should leave.

I still have to pack up my stuff and go get a coffee.

Let’s see if I make it to Miami.

Deuces,

- Ben

​

subject: waste 3 min of your day with me
body:
I wrote one-fifth of an email to you yesterday.

It was about how I’d been spending too much time on my phone and
how to get out of the “social media vortex.”

Then I got distracted by my phone and stopped writing.

The most honest people are hypocrites.

I’ve realized it’d be a really good idea to start taking more of
my own advice that I write to you about in these emails.

The other day I told you how I’m creating a course about building
funnels.

It’d be wise for me to spend the next couple of weeks talking

subject: waste 3 min of your day with me
body:
I wrote one-fifth of an email to you yesterday. 

 It was about how I’d been spending too much time on my phone and how to get out of the “social media vortex.” 

 Then I got distracted by my phone and stopped writing. 

 The most honest people are hypocrites. 

 I’ve realized it’d be a really good idea to start taking more of my own advice that I write to you about in these emails. 

 The other day I told you how I’m creating a course about building funnels. 

 It’d be wise for me to spend the next couple of weeks talking more about business and priming you for when I drop the offer. 

 But I don’t want to. 

 Instead, I’ll write about how I finally took 47 seconds out of my day to hire a maid to clean my apartment. 

 It was something I’d been contemplating for weeks, and it’s one of the best decisions I’ve ever made. 

 She even got the stains out of my windows from months ago when I decided to launch blueberries at the glass (story for another day). 

 Remember the doorman I told you about at my hotel in LA? ( context if you’re new here ) 

 He told me I was gonna miss my flight if I didn’t leave right away. 

 I waited another hour and then left. 

 Turns out he was a paranoid liar. 

 I got through security in 3 minutes and had to stand there for an hour before my flight boarded. 

 And to make it worse, I had to sit next to a very large woman on the plane who wouldn’t stop trying to teach me bad words in sign language. 

 I was nice to her at first, and that was a mistake because then she attempted to give me her life story throughout the flight. 

 It got to the point where I was basically pretending to be deaf (hence the sign language). 

 I wouldn’t wish that experience on my worst enemy. 

 It’s a cloudy day here in Miami, and my energy is low because of it. 

 This has been a super jumpy email, and if you’re still reading, I applaud you. 

 Maybe you’re waiting for a life lesson or something to take away from this. 

 You’re gonna be waiting for a while because I’ve got nothing for you. 

 Sometimes I just want to brain-dump, and this was one of those times. 

 Maybe I’ll teach you how to solve world hunger and make a gazillion dollars tomorrow. 

 Thanks for wasting your time with me today, 

 Ben 

 ​

subject: Outside bleeding in the rain waiting for you
body:
The back of my left sock is bloody again.

It’s a gloomy morning.

The sky is dark grey, and constant gusts of wind indicate it’s
about to start raining.

I lace up my shoes and look out the window.

“It’s gonna pour. You should just stay inside and work out here
instead,” I think to myself.

I go back and forth for a few minutes before deciding not to
cancel this run.

If I get caught in the rain, I’ll be okay.

Four minutes later, I’m outside running, and the wind is picking
up.

The people around me are hustling to their cars.

It’s not directly raining yet, but somehow, it feels like I’m
getting hit with raindrops from the side.

Considering I’m running by a river, I guess it’s safe to assume
the water is being blown from there.

My left shoe is starting to rub against the back of my ankle.

I already have a blister there from the same thing happening the
other day.

As I continue along, it starts drizzling.

At this point, I’m honestly excited about the torrential
downpour.

But as I get closer to the end of my route, it still hasn’t
started.

I think my blister ripped open, but I can’t feel the pain because
I’m hunting down the man in a blue shirt about 150 feet ahead of
me.

I fly past him, and not too long after, I’m back at my apartment.

That’s actually when I tried to start this email, but I got
distracted by a call from a friend.

I then tried to continue it at the coffee shop, but it was far
too crowded for me to be able to hear my own thoughts.

You might be thinking, “Ben, is there a reason you just described
your morning in vivid detail to me, or are you wasting my time
again?”

Oh yeah, I had a metaphor for you.

Long story short, the “rain” is a future obstacle that’s keeping
you from attacking a goal.

You don’t start a business because you’re worried about paying
taxes (lol).

You don’t ask her out because you’re worried that you’ll look
like an idiot.

You don't step in the ring because you're worried you'll get hit
in the mouth.

It’s a tale as old as time.

But once you start running toward the things that scare you, you
realize that the rain isn’t as bad as you thought it’d be.

Maybe you end up with a bloody ankle, but you don’t care because
you’re finally in the game.

It's a feeling of aliveness that money can’t buy.

Don’t rob yourself of this gift – if you get caught in the rain,
you’ll be okay.

Thx for reading.

As always, reply if you made it down here

Ben

​

subject: Advice for Bo
body:
I need to clean this computer screen.

I’m outside on my balcony, and the combination of the sun and
dust on my laptop is making it difficult to see.

Maybe I’ll just buy a new computer instead.

I have a friend that doesn’t do laundry. He just cycles through a
dozen new shirts every few weeks.

About a year and a half ago, I read Jordan Peterson’s book “12
Rules For Life” – and by “read,” I mean I skimmed about 70% of
it.

One of his first rules was “treat yourself like someone you’re
responsible for helping.”

At the time of reading that, I didn’t think much of it.

But for whatever reason, it’s on my mind as I sit here writing to
you.

You have all the answers, you’re just letting your emotions get
in the way.

You know how to make more money.

You know how to stop overthinking.

You know how to get over your fears.

And if someone in your exact situation came to you and asked for
advice, you’d tell them exactly what they need to hear – even if
they don’t want to hear it.

But when it comes to ourselves, it’s like we have blinders on.

We pretend not to know the answers to our problems because this
state of “uncertainty” becomes comfortable…

Well, at least more comfortable than the real uncertainty that
would occur if we changed what actually needs to be changed.

That make sense?

A lack of clarity isn’t the issue – it's emotion disguised as a
lack of clarity.

I just reread that, and I think my breakdown made this concept
more confusing than it really is.

Long story short, take the advice you’d give to a friend in your
situation.

It’s easy to come up with a solution when it isn’t clouded with
fear or doubt – just pure logic.

This was pretty jumbled, but at the end of the day, it’s really
just advice to myself.

Maybe I should take it.

Good luck,

Ben

​

body:
Hi Bo, sorry I haven’t been emailing you much recently.

I have a good excuse.

Do you notice how traveling, trying a new hobby, or going
somewhere new unlocks thoughts you didn’t previously have access
to?

If you get stuck in the same routine and virtually live the same
day every day, your ideas will usually remain constant.

It’s not a bad thing – but for the sake of creativity, I think
it’s good to switch things up every now and then.

That leads me to the lack of emails as of late.

I’ve been on a mini-bender.

Up until now, my well of creativity had run dry.

I’d sit down to write and type “good morning” or “hey” and then
immediately get stuck.

I literally have 4 emails in the drafts from this week where I
didn’t make it past the first line.

Usually, when I feel a creative lull, I go for a walk, and it
fixes me.

But not this time.

I concluded that more drastic measures were necessary.

Aside from the bender, I started taking boxing lessons, playing
tennis, I’m 5 days off the zyns, and I’m moving to a 2-bed
apartment because I want an office.

I think it worked.

The lesson here?

When you get bored, simply change everything.

Don’t take that too seriously.

That advice probably isn’t the most practically sound, but
understand that your environment will dictate your thoughts

When things feel off, and you don’t know why, maybe you need to
shake the snowglobe.

Ok, I have a lot of work to do today, so this’ll end here.

I’m rusty, and my computer's light is hurting my brain.

Hopefully I’ll write to you tomorrow, but I can’t make any
promises.

Have a good Sunday friend,

Ben

P.S. Here’s a clip of me spewing nonsense to a 6’8 woman (

subject: moon blue coffee black
body:
I’m starting this from my phone outside of Starbucks.

A cold brew sits in front of me, but something looks different.

Instead of the usual sugary vanilla cream that creates a smooth,
lightly brown colored milkshake…. it’s…. black.

…

I started a 48-hour fast last night.

Why?

Something to do with a full blue supermoon.

And so that I could tell you I’m doing it.

I’ve got some thoughts today.

Holy fuck it’s windy I’m gonna walk home - be right back.

Ok, I made it.

Anyway, I was about to tell you about procrastination.

You familiar with that word?

Me too.

I’ve been procrastinating building the course I told you I was
gonna build 2 weeks ago.

I was procrastinating taking boxing lessons for a year.

I procrastinated finding a couch for my new apartment that I’m
moving into on Friday, but luckily, I caught a hail mary and
found what I was looking for yesterday on Instagram.

I’m even procrastinating doing other work by writing this right
now.

All of the reasons you tell yourself why you have to put
something off until later are usually a facade.

They’re a pastiche. A simulacrum. A Potemkin village. They’re not
the real McCoy.

The best example I can think of to illustrate what I’m trying to
tell you is cold approach.

You see a girl. You want to go talk to her (if you’re a woman
reading this, replace the girl with me, and you’re nervous to
come say hi because I’m so famous).

Your brain starts feeding you objections.

“I need to learn how to approach girls first.”

“I don’t know what to say.”

“I actually like men.”

“My shoe is untied.”

Aaaand she walks past you.

The singular action you needed to take to succeed was to walk up
and say hello.

But you found all these scapegoats for why that couldn’t happen.

Odds are this exact situation is happening in multiple areas of
your life.

A big one for me was content.

I told myself for a while that I’d start making more content once
I was making $10k per month.

But I didn’t really put effort into growing on TikTok until I
started making over $50k/mo.

And I’m still not making YouTube videos like I wanted to.

The thing is, I’m getting a dopamine hit by telling you this
right now.

It gives me an illusionary feeling that I’m moving closer to
making YT vids.

The same thing happens when you tell your friends you’re starting
75 hard soon or you’re gonna start training for a marathon.

You get brownie points in your brain but don’t get closer to the
goal.

Tricky territory to be in.

The solution is actually to do the singular action.

The unsexy action that you’ve known all along that you needed to
do.

Like set up a camera and start talking.

Or walk up to her and say, “Hey, I’m Bo.”

That’s when you stop fantasizing success (like a cuck).

Love you, and happy blue full superhuman moon or whatever,

Ben

P.S. reply if you read all 510 words

​

 The best example I can think of to illustrate what I’m trying to tell you is cold approach. 

 You see a girl. You want to go talk to her (if you’re a woman reading this, replace the girl with me, and you’re nervous to come say hi because I’m so famous). 

 Your brain starts feeding you objections. 

 “I need to learn how to approach girls first.” 

 “I don’t know what to say.” 

 “I actually like men.” 

 “My shoe is untied.” 

 Aaaand she walks past you. 

 The singular action you needed to take to succeed was to walk up and say hello. 

 But you found all these scapegoats for why that couldn’t happen. 

 Odds are this exact situation is happening in multiple areas of your life. 

 A big one for me was content. 

 I told myself for a while that I’d start making more content once I was making $10k per month. 

 But I didn’t really put effort into growing on TikTok until I started making over $50k/mo. 

 And I’m still not making YouTube videos like I wanted to. 

 The thing is, I’m getting a dopamine hit by telling you this right now. 

 It gives me an illusionary feeling that I’m moving closer to making YT vids. 

 The same thing happens when you tell your friends you’re starting 75 hard soon or you’re gonna start training for a marathon. 

 You get brownie points in your brain but don’t get closer to the goal. 

 Tricky territory to be in. 

 The solution is actually to do the singular action. 

 The unsexy action that you’ve known all along that you needed to do. 

 Like set up a camera and start talking. 

 Or walk up to her and say, “Hey, I’m {{ subscriber.first_name }}.” 

 That’s when you stop fantasizing success (like a cuck). 

 Love you, and happy blue full superhuman moon or whatever, 

 Ben 

 P.S. reply if you read all 510 words <3 

 ​

subject: i didn't eat for 2 days
body:
Start: 11:32am

I’m 40 hours into this fast and concluded that food is a scam.

This is so easy that I watched a cooking show on netflix last
night to try to make it harder.

I have a call in 30 minutes, so I have to be quick.

I’m sitting outside of Starbucks, casually sipping another black
cold brew.

The dude I see here every day who drives an R8 with “forexxx” on
the license plate is sitting across from me, getting a tarot card
reading from a pretty girl.

Astrology chicks >

You guys seemed to like yesterday’s email, which gave me a lot of
dopamine.

I’m moving tomorrow, and I still haven’t called a mover. Ugh.

There’s a new grey Ford Bronco parked to my left.

The new models seem to get hate, but I really like them.

If I get a place in LA, maybe I’ll get a 911 and a Bronco…

Stop: 11:47am

Start again: 10:52pm

A lot has changed since I left off here.

I broke my fast a few hours ago, found a mover, and even started
thinking about packing up my belongings.

Oh, and I bought a rose gold olive dial Rolex Presidential today.

I didn’t mean to, but I finished my work early for the day and
had nothing else to do other than drive 40 minutes to my boy
Jamie and buy a new watch.

I don’t want you to think I’m flexing (even though I am).

I’m sharing this with you because I noticed this purchase felt
different.

You know all the things that you envision coming with your
“dream” life? The car, the girl, the house, the status, etc…

I remember thinking to myself at one point, “Wow, I’ll be so cool
once I have Rolex – or Audi – or move to Miami.”

And every time I got one of those things, they lost their lust
quickly.

I’d buy them expecting some grand feeling of accomplishment, only
to be let down once the lust wore off.

But today, I didn’t feel that.

I bought the watch because I wanted it – I didn’t expect it to
make me feel any better about myself or change my perception of
who I am.

Dropping those illusionary expectations allowed me to find a
different level of appreciation.

Everything that you own, you’ve earned in one way or another.

You have a right to be proud of that.

But understand that the things are not you. They are not a place
to source for your own self-worth. And they are not much more
than a subtle external trophy for winning internal battles.

Fuck I gotta start packing for tomorrow.

Goodnight,

Ben

P.S. I went on the Stick Talk podcast recently if you wanna check
it out (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukhoz640nirh56e0pnn/dpheh0h0mzoxzwam/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9fQlNrb3dZNFQ2QT9zaT05RlNzSXV6Zzg2RWJhalBr
)​

​

subject: I fought off a pack of wolves for wifi (story)
body:
I’m sitting at the counter at my lunch spot in Brickell.

Yes, I now call it “my” spot because it basically is.

Some chubby dork in a red tank top is standing right over my
shoulder waiting for his food, and I’m seconds away from
backhanding him.

I hope he’s reading this because he’s close enough to see it.

I will hit you buddy.

If you’re not brand new here and you actually read my emails,
you’d know I moved a few floors up to a 2-bed apt the other day.

Moving sucks.

I swear it’s a less strenuous process for me to make $50k+ on an
hour-long webinar with a client than it is to lug around boxes
and disassemble/reassemble furniture.

Mr. Red Tank Top just left.

I’m sitting at this counter because I don’t have wifi in my new
spot until 2pm.

And I had to fight tooth and nail even to get it that soon.

AT&T is the only provider you can use in my building.

I thought setting up new wifi would be as simple as carrying up
the box from my old apartment to the new one, but that wasn’t the
case.

Oscar (support agent) told me over the phone that they had to
transfer and activate the signal to the new unit and then have a
“technician” come out to verify it.

But before that could even happen, they needed the lady who lived
in the unit before me to cancel her account to be able to
transfer the signal.

I thought that was bullshit, but Oscar implored me that it was
the quickest solution and that he’d reach out to the previous
tenant and let me know when she answers.

So I did what any rational human would do and built an army of
Phillipino (I’m guessing) AT&T agents.

Right when I got off the phone with Oscar, I called again, got
placed with a different agent, explained the situation, and asked
them to reach out to the lady.

I did this a handful of times until I had 5 or 6 agents literally
harassing this woman.

For the next 16 hours… nothing.

I called again and told them the lady was dead so there was no
way of contacting her, but still they insisted that it was the
only solution.

About 30 minutes later, John (definitely not his real name), whom
I’d just told that the lady died, called me back.

“Good news Ben, I got a hold of her and canceled her account.
We’ll have a technician come out on Thursday, and you’ll be all
setup.”

First, I told him I loved him for tracking down the lady and
laughed at how she miraculously must’ve been revived from the
dead.

And then I said, “Thursday isn’t gonna happen; what can you do
here.”

Those nine words saved me 4 days of no wifi.

John (who is now my next of kin in my will) put me on hold for 30
seconds, pulled some Vudu magic, and said, “Ok, your signal will
be back tomorrow at 2pm. You’ll just need to plug the router into
the wall.”

I’m telling you this whole story for a reason.

There is always a way to get what you want.

Whether you’re building a business, trying to get into an
exclusive venue, or want to connect with someone important…

If you’re persistent enough, you will find a way.

Even if it means employing half a dozen Phillipino VAs.

Or harassing staff to get an omelet at 3am (inside joke - if you
know, you know).

Go harass an old lady today,

Ben

P.S. Check out my recent podcast if you haven't already (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkok879cohzwvm0kk/n2hohvh3k8z2koh6/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9fQlNrb3dZNFQ2QT9zaT1kSEdSME1TdEJsckFsazJ3
) (It’s a banger – I think. But I could also be spewing nonsense
– what’s the difference?)

​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkok879cohzwvm0kk
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkok879cohzwvm0kk
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(

)

subject: The eyes chico
body:
I was walking around my house like an idiot 3 minutes ago, trying
to find my computer to write this email.

It was hidden in plain sight, but I didn’t know where to look
because it wasn’t in any of the usual spots.

Lesson in there.

On my walk back from soybucks this morning, I was trying to make
a TikTok about how money means everything and nothing at the same
time.

The video sucked because it’s easier for me to work out concepts
like this in writing first, so let’s do it together, shall we?

Money gives you the autonomy to be who you really are.

My friend Mason has said something like this before.

The peace of mind in knowing you’re good financially allows you
time to “side quest.”

And in these side quests, you’re gonna learn more about yourself
and the world than you would if your only pursuit is money.

I neglected this for a while, but it’s how you start to live in a
way that genuinely aligns with your soul.

And when you do that, you become magnetic.

This sounds woo-woo, but it’s true-true. Ok pretend I didn’t say
that.

You can see this in people's eyes – It’s a glimpse into their
soul.

The eyes chico, they never lie.

It’s why you get a weird feeling about someone when you meet
them, but you can’t explain it, so you just say something's “off”
about them.

It’s why you know she’s a good girl at heart even though she’s at
the club every night (miss her).

And it’s why you naturally gravitate towards some people more
than others.

They’re either truly themselves, and it makes you want to be
around them more, or they’re pretending, and you can feel it on a
subconscious level.

Here’s a litmus test for you: How many things do you do just
because you want to?

There’s no real angle or motive; it just feels like something you
were called towards.

That’s why I make content. That’s why I write these emails.
That’s why I’m boxing.

These are just mini-side quests that I feel obligated to tackle.

At some point maybe I’ll make money from the content/emails (if I
ever get around to building a course), but as of right now, I’m
doing it for free.

And I’ll keep doing it even if I never make a dollar from it.

Find the things in your life that you would do every day even if
the only benefit is quenching an urge that’s floating in the back
of your mind.

Because honestly, doing that will make you feel better than money
ever could.

But you need money to allow yourself the luxury.

Thanks for working this out with me.

Have a good Tuesday,

Ben

P.S. Here's me shamelessly plugging a recent podcast I went on
for the 36th email in a row (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hdpl0rmirh503ze99/kkhmh6hl3e20l3bl/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9fQlNrb3dZNFQ2QT9zaT1tcURyWUo0YkFnbXhyT211
)​

P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hdpl0rmirh503ze99
) | Update your profile (

)

 Here’s a litmus test for you: How many things do you do just because you want to? 

 There’s no real angle or motive; it just feels like something you were called towards. 

 That’s why I make content. That’s why I write these emails. That’s why I’m boxing. 

 These are just mini-side quests that I feel obligated to tackle. 

 At some point maybe I’ll make money from the content/emails (if I ever get around to building a course), but as of right now, I’m doing it for free. 

 And I’ll keep doing it even if I never make a dollar from it. 

 Find the things in your life that you would do every day even if the only benefit is quenching an urge that’s floating in the back of your mind. 

 Because honestly, doing that will make you feel better than money ever could. 

 But you need money to allow yourself the luxury. 

 Thanks for working this out with me. 

 Have a good Tuesday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Here's me shamelessly plugging a recent podcast I went on for the 36th email in a row ​ 

 P.P.S. Reply if you liked this one <3 

 ​

subject: Sorry i forgot about you Bo
body:
There’s a new (potentially) homeless guy next to me this time.

He’s somehow acquired a phone, Lululemon bag, and a watermelon
ice puff bar.

I don’t think I’ve ever seen a more accurate representation of
the word “disheveled” until seeing this guy.

He’s not in horrible shape, and honestly I hope my hair looks as
good as his when I’m his age (probably in his 40’s or 50’s)

But he just looks… disheveled.

Other than that, he’s been arguing with someone on the phone for
the last 7 minutes.

Except his phone is sitting face down across the table, and he
definitely doesn’t have air pods or headphones.

So I guess the “someone” on the phone is actually another
person(?) in his head…

The schizophrenics fascinate me.

Do they have access to a different dimension?

Are they enlightened??

Am I the crazy one???

I’ve missed you, by the way.

It’s been a week since we last spoke, and I’m starting to feel
guilty.

Gonna walk home real quick because I don’t know where I want to
take this email yet.

Ok, I’m at my desk in my new office, and my mind is still blank.

Well, blank isn’t the right word – I have infinite half-baked
ideas I want to write about.

Do you ever think about how you would live your life if you were
completely detached from the outcome of your actions?

Not in a mid-evil barbaric way where you have no consequences, so
you run around like it’s GTA and kill people when they cut you
off in traffic.

But in a way where you do the things you want to do without
giving any value to the voice in your head that tells you it’s
scared.

You simply take more shots.

I saw this Theo Von video where he was giving advice to his
20-year-old self, and he said, “Ask her out.”

Whatever “she” is – a business, a new city, a random inclination,
or a real human.

I think that’s where you find fulfillment.

You just live in complete alignment with your soul.

Your doubts, fears, and worries likely don’t go away, but you
don’t give any power to them. You run your life… you’re not on
autopilot.

Do this enough, and maybe you’ll be so enlightened that you end
up disheveled, sitting outside of Starbucks, talking to the voice
in your head…

Or maybe you end up becoming exactly who you were meant to be.

Missed you, Bo.

And if you’re new here, welcome. I know you’re probably wondering
what you subscribed to, and maybe your finger is hovering over
the unsubscribe button.

I was gonna offer an explanation, but honestly this email is long
enough. So if you want to leave, it was nice knowing you.

Yep, schizophrenia is definitely contagious.

Have a good Tuesday and reply if you liked this email

Ben

​

subject: How to cure everything
body:
I’m convinced everyone has anxiety and/or depression.

It’s just a matter of what degree they listen to it.

Keep telling yourself bad things, and you will literally program
yourself to always think that way.

Those constant negative thoughts end up shaping your entire
identity and perception of yourself.

Once a belief is accepted as an unchangeable fact, our
malleability gets diminished.

“I am an anxious person” or “I am a depressed person” gets
repeated until it’s deeply embedded into someone's psyche.

And on a long enough time horizon, that person forgets that there
was ever another option.

An option where they didn't have to give power to their negative
thoughts.

Or where they understood they could decide who they are.

And as long as they don’t suppress their true desires, that evil
voice gets a little bit quieter.

I don’t think it ever goes away – it just takes a backseat.

Even when you’re living your “dream life,” sometimes you’ll wake
up on the wrong side of the bed.

You’ll never be completely immune to occasional highs and lows.

Every now and then, you’ll question everything about your life
just hours after thinking you’re invincible.

That fluctuation is inevitable. It’s natural.

And accepting it is part of the solution.

It can be as simple as shifting from “I feel like shit right now,
and I hate this” to “I feel like shit right now, and that’s
okay.”

Of course, there are times when a negative situation shouldn’t be
accepted and instead used as fuel for change.

But I’m talking about the other times where you just seem to hit
a wall for no rhyme or reason.

That happens to me all the time. The same goes for almost all of
my friends, so I imagine it happens to you.

The secret is discerning when a feeling needs to be accepted and
when it needs to inspire change.

Before dropping out of college a few years ago, sometimes I’d
quietly get anxious.

Although my life looked fun on the surface, I could simply feel
that path wasn’t right for me (emphasis on feel, not think).

There was objectively no fulfillment.

I went out all the time and “celebrated” although I had nothing
to celebrate – it was an escape from a life with a lack of
purpose, ambition, or improvement.

If I didn’t change, it would’ve eaten me alive.

On the contrary, I’m now in a position that I was enamored by for
years.

But that doesn’t stop me from occasionally questioning if I’m an
absolute idiot and if I should move across the country to live on
a farm with Amish people and cows.

Odds are that’s just a natural low – in fact, I know it is
because it feels different.

So when those types of thoughts come up, I try not to give them
power. I accept them as they are – the devil who will always be
there on my shoulder.

And that’s okay.

Hope this all made sense. Let me know if you made it down here.

Have a good day,

Ben

​

subject: I'm going broke
body:
I turn 23 tomorrow.

I’m expecting to receive a bouquet of flowers from each of you.

That’s 8,395 days I’ve been alive, and I still botched the
spelling of the word “bouquet” so hard that even autocorrect
didn’t know what I was trying to say.

I had to type it into Google and play with the spelling until I
got close enough.

Recently I’ve been spending 3-4x my normal expenses.

Between my upgraded apartment, buying clothes, watches, shoes,
going out, and the very expensive short Jewish chiropractor that
I put on a retainer to come to my place once a week…

Life hasn’t been cheap.

It’s been a bit nerve-wracking but also freeing.

I’m becoming detached from money yet realizing that I need more
and more of it.

It’s shown me how easy it would be to spend $50k/mo+ on lifestyle
consistently, which has given me a renewed sense of excitement
for working.

For the last few months, there weren’t many things business-wise
that I actually wanted to do.

Even when I hit new financial milestones, they felt meaningless
because it was just a bigger number on a screen.

But now I can see the true utility of more money.

I know what I’d do if I tripled my income and now have a real
incentive to get there.

I’m not telling you to go spend all your money but rather to pay
attention to the way that you feel.

When life gets dull, it usually means it’s time to shake things
up.

And dull doesn’t just mean boring; it can actually be the
opposite.

After partying all the time for 2 years in college, that
lifestyle eventually lost its luster.

That’s when I dropped out, moved to Mexico, and basically was in
“monk mode” for 3 months.

Anyway, as I sit here on my balcony, I can’t help but think about
how much can change in one year.

Put real effort into anything for 365 days, and you will come out
on the other side with a completely new perspective.

A year ago I’d just moved to Miami – nervous about upgrading my
expenses and in a very different spot mentally.

Above all – the biggest thing I’ve been able to reignite in
myself this past year is trust.

I follow my gut.

I don’t do things I don’t want to.

And I say what’s actually on my mind.

This alone has made me feel like I know myself way better, and
feels good to live in alignment with your soul.

I encourage you to start paying attention when you suppress what
you really want to do or say.

Start with small things, take baby steps, and it’ll create a
ripple effect.

Do that for a year, and who knows where you’ll be.

Thx for the bouquet in advance,

Ben

P.S. Here’s a video of me talking about living in alignment with
your soul (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh2xnpmni2hxkp3n66/8ghqhohlxdlpm5sk/aHR0cHM6Ly94LmNvbS9iZW5oYmFkZXIvc3RhdHVzLzE3MDQ0OTY0NTA1MDYyMzYzODQ=
)​

​

subject: Your wake up call
body:
I’m sitting in the hotel lobby, drinking a coffee that the
liberal barista just made for me.

She’s actually sweet and made a hell of a latte, so I’m gonna
refrain from saying anything hurtful.

I just got an email from the water company telling me I need to
call and update my address. I’ve been putting off making this
4-minute phone call for 3 weeks now.

I’ll probably continue to procrastinate until I wake up one day
and can’t turn on the faucet to brush my teeth.

Today is my first full day being 23 years old.

Birthdays are interesting because they are meaningless unless you
give them meaning.

It’s not like you instantly reach a new level of wisdom or get
your first grey hair the day after you hit a new number.

The only difference is the perception.

If a 29-year-old degenerate wakes up on his 30th birthday and
decides that he’s now too old to smoke weed all day and throw
together 19 leg parlays in hopes that $6 will turn into $800, and
he changes his actions accordingly; then the arbitrary number now
has meaning.

I’m feeling this right now, too.

The perceived gap between 22 and 23 is rather large in my head.

At 22, the bar’s pretty low – simply having my own apartment, a
nice car, and smelling nice seemed to be impressive.

At 23, I feel more pressure.

$500k-$1m annually is cute. Enough to feel rich without being
anywhere close to it.

My audience should be bigger. I should be employing more people.

It’s honestly embarrassing that I don’t have a supercar.

Why don’t I have $10m liquid?

I’m kind of kidding right now, but I’m really not.

I feel like I’m only tapping into 1/100th of my potential, and
having to say a new arbitrary number when someone asks my age is
a reminder of this.

Maybe you’re in the same boat, and you know that deep down.

But you’re waiting until it gets bad enough.

You wake up at 30 and realize your bucket list is full of
unchecked boxes…

Your bank account hits zero…

You put on so much weight that you can’t see your toes when you
look down…

Maybe you’ll change then, maybe you won’t.

Why do we operate this way?

Is an embarrassingly new low the only thing that can inspire
change?

It can’t be.

Maybe the answer is to give ourselves a manufactured wake-up call
instead of waiting for the arbitrary one.

If you're waiting for a slap in the face, here’s your sign to
stop half-assing life while pretending to give maximum effort so
you don’t have to accept the fact that you’re neglecting your
true potential.

I’m gonna call the water company and update my address.

Happy Saturday,

Ben

P.S. First - thx for the bday wishes yesterday

​

 I’m gonna call the water company and update my address. 

 Happy Saturday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. First - thx for the bday wishes yesterday <3. Second - reply if you liked this one

subject: There's a hornets nest in my bedroom
body:
There's a pink a pink box outside of my apartment door.

I can read the text on the side of the box facing me as I get
closer, which reads "cupcakes."

Do I have a secret admirer?

Was one of my wives feeling generous today?

Is it a bomb?

These thoughts run through my head as I pick it up.

Unfortunately, none of the above is true.

I pick up the box and see a girls name on the delivery address.

The mailman must've mistaken the number 7 for a 2 and
accidentally put the package at my door.

I take the stairs up a few floors and drop it off at her door.

What's a good deed if you don't tell people about it on the
internet?

The error that the mailman made is the same error that stops
people from ever being successful in business -- or anything for
that matter.

It's the thing that causes unnecessary headaches at the worst
possible time.

And it's the reason a football team can lose to a much less
talented team on any given Sunday.

Attention to detail.

Today has been hectic.

It's felt like a thousand little problems have popped up, and
it's making my head spin.

These issues would've been avoided with the necessary planning
and organization.

But those two things have never been my strong suit.

So now I'm left with all these mini-fires that need to be
extinguished.

And the pink cupcake box outside of my door was a perfect
representation of what happens when you take your eye off the
ball for a moment.

Don't be like me.

Kill the hornets before they build a nest.

I'm back.

Sorry I forgot about you Bo.

And if you're new here, welcome.

I usually write a few of these types of emails weekly, sharing
little lessons I learn like this one.

Happy to have you onboard,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you missed me

​

subject: It's okay to want more
body:
I often make fun of the dudes who constantly preach gratitude.

It can sound ingenuine as if they’re talking about how grateful
or how “at peace” they are as a way to make themselves feel
better than others, which couldn’t be more hypocritical.

It’s similar to those who use their belief and connection to God
as a way to prop up their ego.

But there comes a time when gratitude stares you back in the face
as the only answer.

You’ll go and get everything you previously dreamt of, and it
won’t feel the way you anticipated.

How many times can you go through this process until you realize
that you’re chasing your own tail?

Considering this is a topic I’ve written about frequently, the
answer to the question above is obvious.

The truth is, you will always want more.

There’s always gonna be another mountain to climb, hoops to jump
through, and levels to ascend to.

And that’s okay – as long as you accept it.

Acceptance is another thing that’s been on my mind recently.

Everything you do is a choice that you make.

Where you are right now, your habits, and your beliefs about
yourself are all decisions that can be traced back to no one but
you.

Unease comes from the lies that you tell yourself about your
desires.

You say you want to change, but your actions do not correlate
with change.

When your actions fail to follow suit with the things you claim
to want, it creates a disconnect between your actual reality and
your desired reality.

And that’s where unhappiness stems from.

Pause for a second and audit your current situation in life.

Consider your goals, routine, and beliefs.

Would the previous version of you from a year, 2 years, or 5
years ago be ecstatic?

Good. You have a lot to be grateful for.

But it’s also likely that you’re currently holding some desires
that are causing you anxiety because your actions do not align
with them.

It’s okay that you want more – just ensure that you’re taking the
necessary action to fulfill those desires.

Enough rambling for today.

Hope this was semi-coherent,

Ben

​

subject: Why you feel uninspired
body:
I’ve spent the last 45 minutes contemplating the best route to
more money and more freedom.

The past couple of weeks have been busy, and I haven’t had a
chance to spend much quality time alone.

I define quality time alone as the uninterrupted moments between
you and the 37 voices in your head.

These are the opportunities that allow you to think critically
and perform a mini audit on your life.

I could write a whole email on the importance of prioritizing
this and how most people are too sTuCk iN tHe MaTriX to ever
figure out what they actually want.

But I’ll spare you today.

I went on a long walk this morning and let my mind wander.

After my walk, I sat down outside Starbucks with a cold brew, and
now I’m here writing to you.

Sometimes, just the act of thinking about your “problems” will
drastically improve your mental state because you realize how
silly they are.

There are people dying, and I’m over here stressing about how I
need multi 8 figures by age 30.

99.9% of the world would trade everything for my “problems.”

I could go on about this, but there are already enough people who
talk about gratitude on the internet.

While I was walking, I was thinking about a friend of mine who
recently ended up in a sticky situation.

His 7 figure business fell apart nearly overnight, and a series
of unfortunate events drastically depleted his bank account.

Scary right?

There’s a level of freedom you reach when everything goes to shit
like this — and it gives rewards the equal (or even greater)
opportunity if you can get through it.

My friend started a new business and has been on an absolute tear
for the last handful of months.

He’s working nonstop but just seems to be electric about the work
and thinks that this new business could make him 8 figures over
the next few years.

I’ve been envious of the excitement he has for this new project
and asked him if he ever has days where he doesn’t want to work.

I’m paraphrasing, but basically he said, “Sure, there are, but I
don’t give much power to it. The work just feels like something
that has to be done.”

His answer makes perfect sense to me.

He’s not passionate about the day-to-day tasks. He’s not immune
to the monotony that comes with building a business.

But the end goal and the vision are big enough that they carry
him through the tediousness (plus the situation with his previous
business adds some urgency).

My main takeaway here is this:

If the work always feels like a herculean task, you’re playing
too small.

When you truly believe that what you’re building has the
potential to be special, that passion puts you on autopilot and
carries you through the boring stuff.

Take a walk today and think about where you want to be in 5
years.

Clearly envision it – money, lifestyle, relationships, impact.

Do your current daily actions align with that goal?

If not, now you know where to start.

Hope you enjoyed this one.

Much love,

Ben

P.S. Start paying more attention to the things that come
naturally to you.

Write down a list of the things you enjoy doing the most, and do
not neglect them.

P.P.S. I am not a self-improvement guru or life coach. My goal is
simply to share my perspective through the lens in which I view
the world. Nearly nothing I tell you is a universal truth.

Let me know if my perspective resonates :)

​
