subject: Step in the ring
body:
I’m gonna keep this one relatively short:

Listen to yourself.

Listen to what you feel called to do.

Pay attention to the things that you are resisting the most.

Run towards them.

You’ll make it out on the other side and laugh about how you were
ever scared or uncertain. The fear was an illusion.

It was a devil on your shoulder – or in your own mind – that
desperately tried to preserve the previous version of yourself.

That version of you is comfortable the way they are.

They like their limiting beliefs.

They like their fears.

They like their perception of self.

That version needs to die.

I know this sounds like an intro to a corny self-help
manifestation book, but bear with me.

A few months ago, I made a list of things that I wanted to do but
was putting off.

I started checking them off the list, and every single time, I’m
left with the same feeling that sounds something like:

“Why was I ever nervous to do that?”

I stepped in the ring, got hit, and it didn’t feel as bad as I
thought it would.

I’ve actually grown to like it.

And Improvement has come much quicker than I anticipated.

This is both an analogy for everything that I’ve tackled over the
last few months and my actual experience from boxing.

I’m telling you that checking these things off your “one-day”
list is what will make you feel alive.

It’s how you end up living the life that you envision in your
head.

It’ll make you look like you have fire in your eyes, and your
aura will become magnetic.

And it’s how you become authentically you.

Reply if this one resonates :)

Let’s have a good week,

Ben

​

subject: Do more
body:
I use the background of the lock screen on my phone as a reminder
to myself.

Up until the other day, it was a white background with the words
“do more.”

I set it as that about a year ago, during a time when I felt like
I was becoming too one-dimensional.

I’d just moved to Miami and honestly was a bit nervous to be
here.

At the time, I was making $15k to $20k per month, which will
quickly make you feel small in a city like Miami.

The social scene here was also intimidating to me. I’m not
usually one to be anxious socially – It was just a lot of “new”
at the same time.

New city.

New friends.

New routine.

Etc.

I immediately had a solid group of friends who I’d met through
social media, but none of us were really “plugged in” here.

And because all of the newness was intimidating to me, I kind of
just latched on to the friend group.

I never took the lead or planned anything – I would just go with
the flow.

Then, after a few month period where I was almost never going
out, I realized that I wasn’t living the fun “Miami lifestyle” I
envisioned.

I also started to really despise working.

A $50k month vs a $100k month virtually had no difference to me,
so I lost almost all motivation to keep pushing for new numbers.

So I took back control and started doing my own thing.

I hired a boxing coach, went out to new clubs and restaurants,
and started meeting new people.

I learned to lean more into my uniqueness and have become more of
myself.

And now, I’ve created the exact lifestyle that would play as a
movie scene in my head when I pictured moving to Miami a year and
a half ago.

I’m sharing all this with you to encourage you to do more.

-- You can grow your business while living the social life you
want, trying new hobbies, and keeping up with all of your 16
wives.

-- You feel most alive when you get rid of the scapegoats you may
blame for why you’re not as happy as you want to be. Take control
of your habits, routines, and decisions.

-- It’s okay to do things for the “sake of it.” You have an
inclination to do those things for a reason.

-- Do not settle when it comes to your true desires. Most get a
tenth of the way there and justify settling for “good enough”
along the way. Fuck that. We want Lambos and Pateks. Not a Model
3’s and Apple Watches.

Alrighty.

Originally, this email was gonna be about my new lock screen on
my phone, but I got caught in the zone and felt like this
deserved the spotlight.

Maybe I’ll write to you about the new one tomorrow.

Hope you liked it – let me know if you made it all the way down
here

Do more,

Ben

​

 Originally, this email was gonna be about my new lock screen on my phone, but I got caught in the zone and felt like this deserved the spotlight. 

 Maybe I’ll write to you about the new one tomorrow. 

 Hope you liked it – let me know if you made it all the way down here <3 

 Do more, 

 Ben 

 ​

subject: Do your best
body:
Oh no.

This is the first time in over a month that I’ve sat down to
write an email two days in a row.

Are we… back??

I’m running on 5 hours of sleep, and I haven’t had any caffeine
yet.

I imagine this is what the baseball players who weren’t taking
PEDs in the Barry Bonds era felt like.

I’m at a disadvantage, but at least I’m honest.

In yesterday's email (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvh8e0l52i6h7n74kgg/9qhzhnhpgqgx00b9/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2IvNHp1dmhlaDVrOHJubHU2b3Z2ZW9sYTNxMzlsNzc=
), I told you about my phone background that formerly read, “Do
more.”

A few days ago, I changed it to “do your best.”

It’s corny, it’s cliche, but actually doing your best is often
the answer to every challenge you face.

When the goal is simply to do your best, you become
outcome-independent.

It shifts your attention back to where it should be – right here,
right now.

There will be days when the work feels like a pain, and you don’t
want to do it. But if you can simply bring yourself to do your
best in that given moment, you’ll keep moving forward.

Doing your best also applies to your interactions with others.

Instead of worrying about what to say to impress someone or the
perfect lines to make a girl fall in love with you – approach
interactions with the goal of simply spreading good energy (corny
again, but true).

This approach takes all of the pressure away, and It gives you
control of any situation.

Switching gears - sometimes, I’ll run into moments like this when
I’m writing, and I feel like I’ve completed the entire argument
for the point I’m trying to make.

How many more times can I tell you to do your best?

I actually got this “do your best” concept from the book The Four
Agreements, and it stuck with me for a few days, so that’s when I
decided to make it my phone background.

I’m not gonna keep hammering this into your head – But just start
to take note of your goals in different situations.

“Am I anxious when talking to this person because I’m trying to
get something out of them or impress them?”

“Am I tired of doing the same monotonous work, so I procrastinate
until the last second and then half-ass it, which makes me
anxious because I know I could’ve done better?”

In those situations, changing the goal is the solution.

If you go into the interaction aiming to do your best to say what
you want to say, or if you approach your work with the goal of
doing what you need to in the most effective manner possible…

The anxiety goes away.

You feel your best when you do your best.

Anyway, thanks for reading

If you reply and tell me you love me, maybe I’ll even write
another email tomorrow.

Much love,

Ben

​

subject: How to get out of prison
body:
The only rules you have to abide by are the ones you’ve created
in your own mind.

A lot of anxiety comes from feeling obligated to do things that
you don’t want to do.

You feel obligated to go get a drink with an old friend because
they kept asking you, and finally, you gave in.

You feel obligated to get a safe job so you have something to
talk about at Thanksgiving dinner.

You feel obligated to stay in a relationship that doesn’t serve
you anymore because you’re comfortable, and deep down, you feel
like you couldn’t do better.

You feel obligated to live where you live, eat what you eat,
think what you think, and go where you go.

But the thing is, all of these obligations are imaginary –
They’re pacts that you’ve made in your own mind that you never
stopped to question.

You are simply imprisoning yourself.

Do you know how much freedom you truly have?

I was thinking about this after my Sunday morning run…

Right now, if I wanted to, I could pack up and fly across the
country.

I could drop all my clients and start a completely new business.

I could stop running businesses altogether.

I could start making a different style of content, start posting
on a different platform, or stop making content.

I could shave my head, start talking with a Russian accent, and
tell people my name is Igor.

Am I going to do all of these things? No.

But recognizing the freedom and the options that we have will
help us understand this:

Everything that is going on in your life right now is a result of
decisions you have made.

You choose the stress you allow into your life; you choose the
people, the goals, and the perception of reality that you make.

You choose whether or not you want to have difficult
conversations with a friend, and you choose whether or not you
tell yourself that you’re too hungover to go on your Sunday
morning run.

You choose how much of yourself you express when you’re around
different types of people, and you choose the way you react when
things don’t go as planned.

You choose to hold yourself to a certain standard and to do or
not do things that you commit to.

Now, I say all this to show you that if you are unhappy, if you
are anxious, or if you feel like you’re not living in alignment
with the life you’re meant to live – it’s on you.

You’re actively deciding to live the exact life that you’re
living right now, and any conflict comes from failing to accept
that decision as your own.

You have more freedom than you’re telling yourself, but you’re
making shitty rules that keep you stuck.

Obviously, without any rules, chaos would ensue – just make sure
the ones you abide by are actually serving you.

Happy Sunday and go Bengals,

Ben

​

subject: 3 lessons 1 email
body:
Happy Monday Bo,

It’s easy to forget that you are in control of your state.

Yes, you will have bad days, you’ll go through ruts, and there
are some circumstances outside of your control.

But half the battle is in just showing up for yourself and doing
what you know needs to be done.

Yet sometimes, even though you know this to be true, you still
manage to neglect the things that will make you feel fulfilled.

For me, I know that when I do the following, I feel better than
when I don’t:

* Long-form writing (this can be tweeting, journaling, these
emails, or all of the 3)
* Knocking out my to-do list and staying on top of everything in
my business
* Making video content
* Walking outside & spending time in the sun
* Going to the gym

I’m sure there are others that I’m missing, but these are the
core 5 that come to mind.

It’s irresponsible to underestimate the power that little habits
like this can have in our lives (speaking from experience, as
you’ve seen some inconsistency in these emails lol).

My friend Miles is one of the most dialed people I know when it
comes to his routine.

And it just so happens that he never seems to be down.

He knows the handful of things that have to be done every day for
him to keep moving the needle forward, and he doesn’t miss a day.

Make a list of your non-negotiables and do them every day.

I kind of sound like the corny self-improvement personal brand
guy that I make fun of.

Maybe they have a point?

Moving on – success is inevitable when you pull the one big
lever.

I turn away most of the prospects that come to us because they
simply don’t have enough traffic.

They’re trying to optimize all the backend systems and their
offer – but even if those two things are the best in the world,
it won’t matter because no one is seeing it.

If you have a ton of traffic, you can do everything wrong and
still make money – that’s when you know you’ve found something.

Similarly, in dating, when a girl truly likes you, you can break
all the red-pill rules of “game,” and it’ll probably make her
like you more.

You can be goofy, and you don’t have to try hard to have “frame
control” because you are the frame – You’ve developed into
someone worthy of respect and admiration, so simply leaning more
into your nature and showing your personality will make that
person like you more.

Last thing that’s been on my mind that I’ll attempt to
articulate:

Playing in the different arenas of life will expose you to the
fact that you need a true mission.

You need to conquer your inclinations to side quest and quench
those thirsts.

These can be new hobbies, traveling, dating, etc.

Only once you pursue them will you know that you cannot find
fulfillment in them – and that’s a good thing.

You’ll be able to enjoy these pleasures as they are and return to
your main goal with more firepower.

Not sure if this last point is making sense for you, but it’s one
of the biggest things I’ve learned recently – let me know if it
resonates at all.

I know this one was long and scattered, but hopefully, you
enjoyed this somewhat rapid-fire style today.

Let’s have a great week,

Ben

​

subject: about to fall asleep
body:
Whatever your expectations are as you open this email, lower
them.

I’m half asleep, but I can’t miss today as I was just starting to
rebuild momentum with these.

A few things I’ve been thinking about recently:

1: Do girls drink water?

I swear any time I’m with a girl, they will not drink unless I
basically force them to. It makes me wonder how they operate on
their own and if they just go throughout their day without water.

2: We are hard-wired to be obsessed.

If you’re smart, you get obsessed with something that brings you
fulfillment and makes you money.

Your purpose is to find the things that are worth obsessing over
for you and carry them out to their fullest potential.

This is where you find the flow state.

3: I’m (probably) not smarter than you.

Sometimes, I see people comment on my videos or reply to my
emails saying things like, “How are you so wise for being this
young?”

The answer is that I trust myself. I’ve developed enough
conviction in my own perception of the human experience that
seems to resonate with others. You, too, have the same wisdom if
you care enough to listen to it.

4: Being intentional and setting goals put your subconscious to
work.

Almost every time I put “make 2 tik toks” or “write 3 tweets” on
my to-do list for the day, my brain starts feeding me ideas.

This applies to any goal or desire in life.

5: When you utilize money to its maximum ability, you reach a new
level of autonomy.

I buy $300 massages a few times per month (no happy ending). I
didn’t realize this was “expensive” for a massage until the way a
friend of mine reacted when I told them.

It made me think about other little things like this that make me
appreciate money – fancy dinners, clothes, sporting events, paid
parking, and subscriptions, are all effectively free.

6: I’m going to bed.

I’m not gonna proofread this, so if it was illegible or I spoke
about my disdain for fat people - I’m sorry.

Hope this was half-decent. If ya liked it, let me know!

Gn,

Ben

​

subject: "Just wait till you're my age"
body:
I’m sitting outside people watching.

One of my biggest fears is becoming one of those people who love
to tell you about how it all goes downhill after 40.

This fear was brought to my attention as I just watched this
woman mock her husband's hand gesture when they crossed the
street with their elderly parents/in-laws.

It was a small interaction that I’m sure the two of them forgot
about in the following 30 seconds.

But is that just what happens when you spend years with someone?

The way they breathe, the way they sit, the way they chew, and
the mannerisms they use while doing certain activities just
become annoying.

Maybe this is why I like speed dating.

I had a series of brief relationships throughout college that
felt like eternities.

Over the course of two weeks, we’d spend nearly every day
together, share phone locations, and I introduced one of them to
my parents on our 3rd date.

Then I’d usually get tired of the girl and all the little things
she’d do would start to bother me.

The way her ponytail bounces when she walks, the brief moment
where both of us would open our eyes at the same time when we
kiss, the way she sleeps, etc.

I’d be silent about these things though and then completely
blindside her when I pull away.

I’ve changed I promise.

And it’s not that I’ve never been in long-term relationships or
haven’t met girls that make it past the 2-week honeymoon.

It’s just that it has to stay really fast-paced and exciting for
me to be able to overlook the inevitable icks.

The finance bros just walked out of Starbucks and are heading
back to the office.

That scares me too.

Fake smiles, the same 5 shirts they rotate through each week,
taco Tuesdays with the wife, beer night and football on Thursdays
with the boys, and a 401k that leaves you with just enough money
for low-budget vacations twice a year.

To me, it just sounds like a slow, silently painful death that
starts the day where you can semi-accurately predict what the
rest of your life will look like.

I guess that’s what I’m scared of.

Too much predictability. Complacency. Living the same day for 50
years. Losing the spark with a girl and staying in the
relationship only because finding someone else would be too hard.
Or when the most exciting part of the day is hitting the green
light at the busy intersection on the way home from work.

Does the spark inevitably fail after a while or is that a lie
that’s been perpetuated by these doom and gloom water cooler
conversation and “wait till you’re 40” types?

Or are they actually the enlightened ones because they’re able to
seem outwardly content with the “simple life” and I just don’t
have enough appreciation for the little things?

Maybe. These are questions I don’t have the answers to.

For now, I’m gonna go get the same tacos I eat every day for

subject: "Just wait till you're my age"
body:
I’m sitting outside people watching. 

 One of my biggest fears is becoming one of those people who love to tell you about how it all goes downhill after 40. 

 This fear was brought to my attention as I just watched this woman mock her husband's hand gesture when they crossed the street with their elderly parents/in-laws. 

 It was a small interaction that I’m sure the two of them forgot about in the following 30 seconds. 

 But is that just what happens when you spend years with someone? 

 The way they breathe, the way they sit, the way they chew, and the mannerisms they use while doing certain activities just become annoying. 

 Maybe this is why I like speed dating. 

 I had a series of brief relationships throughout college that felt like eternities. 

 Over the course of two weeks, we’d spend nearly every day together, share phone locations, and I introduced one of them to my parents on our 3rd date. 

 Then I’d usually get tired of the girl and all the little things she’d do would start to bother me. 

 The way her ponytail bounces when she walks, the brief moment where both of us would open our eyes at the same time when we kiss, the way she sleeps, etc. 

 I’d be silent about these things though and then completely blindside her when I pull away. 

 I’ve changed I promise. 

 And it’s not that I’ve never been in long-term relationships or haven’t met girls that make it past the 2-week honeymoon. 

 It’s just that it has to stay really fast-paced and exciting for me to be able to overlook the inevitable icks. 

 The finance bros just walked out of Starbucks and are heading back to the office. 

 That scares me too. 

 Fake smiles, the same 5 shirts they rotate through each week, taco Tuesdays with the wife, beer night and football on Thursdays with the boys, and a 401k that leaves you with just enough money for low-budget vacations twice a year. 

 To me, it just sounds like a slow, silently painful death that starts the day where you can semi-accurately predict what the rest of your life will look like. 

 I guess that’s what I’m scared of. 

 Too much predictability. Complacency. Living the same day for 50 years. Losing the spark with a girl and staying in the relationship only because finding someone else would be too hard. Or when the most exciting part of the day is hitting the green light at the busy intersection on the way home from work. 

 Does the spark inevitably fail after a while or is that a lie that’s been perpetuated by these doom and gloom water cooler conversation and “wait till you’re 40” types? 

 Or are they actually the enlightened ones because they’re able to seem outwardly content with the “simple life” and I just don’t have enough appreciation for the little things? 

 Maybe. These are questions I don’t have the answers to. 

 For now, I’m gonna go get the same tacos I eat every day for lunch, hop on the usual 3 pm meeting, hit the gym, and call it a day. 

 Ooh, it’s chest day. If it’s not too crowded and I can get a bench that’ll be the highlight of my day! 

 Some good basketball on tonight too. 

 Will circle back tomorrow! 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my most recent podcast if you haven't already ​

subject: $1,000 on black
body:
I see about a dozen “Untitled Documents” as I open my email
folder to write to you.

It’s the early afternoon here in Vegas, but I haven’t fully
adjusted to Pacific time yet, so it feels like it’s later.

The untitled docs are emails that I started and never completed.

Some had a few sentences, some were too incoherent to send, and
some were completely blank.

I was gonna write about how the untitled docs in our lives are
the dreams that we started and never finished.

We tried to be too perfect, we got nervous, or we half-assed it.

But as I often do when contemplating an idea for an email, I
discard it because it sounds too elementary or basic.

The last thing I want is to become a corny platitude, vanilla
advice type of dude.

At the same time, I understand that there are very few things
that I can tell you that would be completely new or unique.

You’ve heard every piece of advice there is, and you intuitively
know what’s right for you.

The only time we go in the wrong direction is when we refuse to
listen to our intuition.

We’re conditioned to silence it over and over until we can’t hear
it at all anymore.

Anyway, Vegas is interesting.

It’s my first time here, and I didn’t really know what to expect.

I think it’d be extremely easy for me to get addicted to
gambling, so I’ve been staying away from the Casino even though
it’s just an elevator ride down from my suite.

Fuck I wanna go play roulette now.

Ok, last time changing the topic and then I gotta run:

No matter your current situation, you truly are 2-3 years away
from your dream life.

I know that might sound like a long time right now, but I’m not
talking about the “realistic” dream life where you get half of
what you want and settle.

I’m talking about the life you envision that sounds a little
far-fetched, and you don’t even know how to make it happen.

Between my (and a friend's) first-class flight here, my suite on
the strip, dinners, shopping, and other activities, this trip
will probably cost at least $15k.

It honestly could be way more, and I wouldn’t even know because
my Amex is set to auto-pay.

I’m here with an amazing group of friends, business is hitting an
all-time high this month, and I can’t even tell you the details
of what I see when I look up from my computer while writing this.

All it took was a consistent effort for an extended period of
time, and boom - nearly exactly what I used to picture in my head
has come true.

And the best part is; money is a complete afterthought.

I don’t have to think about it, I don’t have to stress about it…
I just pull out this magical card and put it on the reader.

I’ll leave you with this:

You owe it to yourself to make your dream life come to fruition.
You will never experience the depth of life if you don’t attack
the things you want and shape your reality to your imagination.

Just don’t forget to stop and enjoy the moment once you get
there.

I guess this did turn into a motivational guru email, but I hope
you liked it.
Let me know if you did – and finish your Untitled Documents.

$1,000 on black,

Ben

​

subject: Don't forget to water the grass
body:
I’m walking on the sidewalk in Beverly Hills, looking up at the
beauty of the trees and surrounding scenery.

It’s 75 degrees and sunny, with no wind and not a cloud in the
sky.

I like the way California license plates look. I like the
ever-present blue tint in the air.

“It would be impossible to be unhappy living here.” I think.

And that’s when I stop and catch myself.

I already live in paradise.

Minus the aesthetic of the hills and homelessness, Miami is
basically the same thing.

And I’m not unhappy in Miami at all – I’ve absolutely loved it
recently.

But that thought of “better” still crept in.

That singular thought has the potential to be cancerous.

Imagine you’re dating your dream girl (or dream man if you're a
girl).

She’s gorgeous in that unique, innocent way that you just don’t
see every day.

You guys get along perfectly. She’s clever, she can banter with
you, and most of the time, you know what she’s thinking before a
word comes out of her mouth.

It’s that kind of chemistry that makes other couples fight after
seeing you out because it makes them question the depth of their
relationship.

But one day, you start to develop eyes for a different girl.

She’s equally beautiful, and you’re intrigued. So you start
fantasizing about girl number 2.

“What would life be like with her? I bet she wouldn’t get mad at
me for leaving the toilet seat up the same way my girl does.”

And here comes the poison.

You start observing your girl in a different light.

The things you loved about her begin losing their luster.

You think more and more about what she does wrong and what you
don’t like about her.

Over time, your relationship is silently in shambles. Neither of
you have acknowledged it yet, but you’ve been fighting way more
about little things.

You’re no longer the person she fell in love with, and you’ve
warped your perception of her to the point where you think she’s
the problem.

Eventually, it all goes up in flames, and you find your way to
girl number 2.

Except she’s not just number 2.

You’ve ben doing this countless times with nearly everything in
your life.

You get what you want, and stop watering your own grass.

You slowly poison it, evade to the next one, and start all over.

This is a vicious cycle – Water your own grass and be careful of
these thoughts that there is always something better.

They will sprout quickly, and soon enough, you’ll live in a
forest full of poison.

Avoid looking for problems where there are none – because you
will find what you seek.

The grass is always (and never) greener when you fail to water
your own,

Ben

P.S. I had fun with this one. My creativity is way better here
than it is in Miami. I think I’d like it here better, for sure.
After all, the constant reggaeton in Miami gets annoying. And
everythings so congested! Hmmm.

P.P.S. ^ that is sarcasm to illustrate my point if you’re slow
and didn’t catch it.

​

subject: Passion is a scam
body:
You cannot “find” your passion. Get to work, and your passion
will find you.

When I first started playing basketball as a kid, I had no idea
that it would consume the following decade of my life.

I figured, “What the hell?” I’ll try this thing out and see if I
like it.

A few years later, I was still lukewarm – I enjoyed the sport and
was decent for my age, but it wasn’t too serious.

Then I started working with a trainer who played in college.

I still remember walking into the gym in my first session with
him and seeing orange cones sprawled across the hardwood.

And the following workout changed the course of my entire life.

It was the most challenging 1.5-hour session I’d ever done – and
in those moments, I fell in love with the pursuit of mastery.

For the next 7+ years, this pursuit of mastery became my life.

I cherished the times when I’d walk into an empty gym.

The sound of the ball hitting the court was like music to me.

I felt completely present, and that’s when I knew I was alive.

The thing about this feeling is it can never leave you.

It’s almost like you can’t unsee it once you see it.

If you’ve ever been obsessed with something and have spent every
waking hour at your disposal consumed by said thing, you can
never go back.

If and when that thing ends, that fire is still in you, and it
must be transmuted into something else, or it will burn you
alive.

But let’s rewind real quick.

I got so distracted by the power of obsession that I forgot why I
started this email.

It’s no secret that life without purpose is a bland life.

Everyone wants to “find their passion,” but few seem to do so.

The problem is people assume that this intensity towards a
calling is just gonna slap them in the face one day.

They’ll just be frolicking through the dairy aisle and get hit
with a carton of milk that says, “Dedicate your life to XYZ.”

Not how it works.

You have to go out there and hunt. And after hunting for a while,
maybe you’ll find your prey.

But if you don’t, that doesn’t mean you’re broken. It simply
means you aren’t opening enough doors.

You’re not giving luck enough of a chance.

So you keep hunting and building until you realize that you’ve
found exactly what you’re looking for.

And when you stop and pause, you’ll see that passion actually did
slap you in the face. It was already inside of you, and you just
had to let it out.

Happy Monday Bo,

Ben

​

subject: Now what?
body:
Perhaps the best thing about buying expensive material items is
that it quenches the thirst of a desire.

Yes, you’ll enjoy the watch, car, shoes, etc. But the hidden
value is the fact that the desire is no longer taking up mental
bandwidth.

Have you ever been out to dinner with someone that just can’t
decide what they want?

They go back and forth between menu items and keep changing their
mind.

Maybe they want the more expensive dish but are hesitating to
spend the extra money.

It’s been a while since I’ve been around such a person, but this
indecision has always disgusted me.

The way they’d stress over such a meaningless decision would, in
turn, stress me out.

And finally, once they decide, it’s like a weight is lifted off
of everyone’s shoulders.

My first big purchase was my Audi RS5.

I’d moved to Miami a couple of months prior, and although I
didn’t buy it with this intent - the car ended up being a symbol
of a new chapter in my life.

The same thing can be said for the Rolex’s I’ve purchased.

Buying each of these things has helped give me clarity and steer
me back to what’s really important.

It’s like when the cat finally catches the mouse. It’s a surreal
feeling. But life goes on.

And all you’re left with is the question:

Now what?

However, there’s been one common theme that hasn’t sat right with
me among my bigger purchases.

I’ve always waited for some arbitrary permission.

I bought my Audi days after a friend bought a new car and the
same goes for my first couple Rolex’s.

I’ve told myself I need to get to a certain revenue milestone
before making other purchases.

That’s one trait I’d like to discard.

An ungovernable man does not need to justify his desires with
made-up rules.

He simply listens to his own voice and follows his intuition at
his own speed.

The other day I woke up with a visceral urge to buy a Porsche
911.

It’s always been my dream car, and I’ve found myself talking
about it a lot recently.

Here’s a pic of my new turbo.

Hope you’re having a good Tuesday :)

Ben

P.S. The game never ends, and you never win.

You simply collect a combination of trophies and battle scars
along the way.

The collection of these memories is the actual "win" because it
means you're living a full life full of a variety of perspectives
and experiences.

Go get everything you want.

But just know that they're trophies to add to your shelf -- not
the end goal.

​

 Maybe they want the more expensive dish but are hesitating to spend the extra money. 

 It’s been a while since I’ve been around such a person, but this indecision has always disgusted me. 

 The way they’d stress over such a meaningless decision would, in turn, stress me out. 

 And finally, once they decide, it’s like a weight is lifted off of everyone’s shoulders. 

 My first big purchase was my Audi RS5. 

 I’d moved to Miami a couple of months prior, and although I didn’t buy it with this intent - the car ended up being a symbol of a new chapter in my life. 

 The same thing can be said for the Rolex’s I’ve purchased. 

 Buying each of these things has helped give me clarity and steer me back to what’s really important. 

 It’s like when the cat finally catches the mouse. It’s a surreal feeling. But life goes on. 

 And all you’re left with is the question: 

 Now what? 

 However, there’s been one common theme that hasn’t sat right with me among my bigger purchases. 

 I’ve always waited for some arbitrary permission. 

 I bought my Audi days after a friend bought a new car and the same goes for my first couple Rolex’s. 

 I’ve told myself I need to get to a certain revenue milestone before making other purchases. 

 That’s one trait I’d like to discard. 

 An ungovernable man does not need to justify his desires with made-up rules. 

 He simply listens to his own voice and follows his intuition at his own speed. 

 The other day I woke up with a visceral urge to buy a Porsche 911. 

 It’s always been my dream car, and I’ve found myself talking about it a lot recently. 

 Here’s a pic of my new turbo. 

 Hope you’re having a good Tuesday :) 

 Ben 

 P.S. The game never ends, and you never win. 

 You simply collect a combination of trophies and battle scars along the way. 

 The collection of these memories is the actual "win" because it means you're living a full life full of a variety of perspectives and experiences. 

 Go get everything you want. 

 But just know that they're trophies to add to your shelf -- not the end goal. 

 ​

subject: this email lacks coherence
body:
People-watching is so fun sometimes

There’s this one dorky, curly-haired kid sitting to my right

I always see him outside of Starbucks, and he makes me grateful
for the type of business I run.

I overheard him on a sales call one day, and it was apparent he
runs the same kind of lead gen agency I used to run in the
basketball space, but he’s in a boring financial niche.

A tall man in work clothes just walked by while holding a book up
to his face and reading.

Could you do that? I certainly couldn’t.

And then this Asian girl walked out of Starbucks really quickly
and really… hard.

I’m not sure how else to explain her strut.

It was like she was exerting all of her force into each step and
swaying aggressively from side to side.

Similar to the way you’d see the nerdy, overly excited, yet timid
girls walk in school.

I didn’t even mention the homeless man to my left, who’s been
murmuring random sentences for the last few minutes, but let’s
move on.

Often times when I don’t have an immediate idea to write about,
I’ll start the email the way I did above.

Just a bunch of random little observations of my surroundings.

Maybe that’s a lesson.

I feel much more present now than I did a few minutes ago.

I also think it helps put me in a different state where I no
longer approach this blank page with the thought of “I need to
think of something to write about.”

But rather, I just start writing, and whatever comes to mind goes
on the page.

Let’s extrapolate these two things to life:

You know how all guided meditations start with presence?

“Focus on your breathing, feel the seat beneath you, place your
attention on your chest, etc.”

It serves as a reminder that you are here — where unless you’re
in some immediate danger or physical pain, nothing is wrong.

And when you’re fully present this way, that’s when you’re at
your best.

Ok, quick detour, the homeless guy to my left is starting to get
into an aggressive argument with someone in his head and growing
increasingly loud.

If he mistakes me for the person in his head, I’m ready to throw
hands with this guy.

He just got up and scurried away.

It’s interesting because I’ve seen this guy in particular a lot
and sometimes he’s been semi-normal.

I heard him having a conversation about the Ohio State and
Michigan football rivalry, and it sounded perfectly sane.

I guess that’s schizophrenia for ya.

I’m sidetracked now and forget what I was gonna say before that
detour. Ironic for an email about presence.

Anyway, the last thing I’ll share with ya...

My agency has consistently been over $100k a month for a few
months now while working with just 6-9 clients at a time.

A few notes:

* Rev shares are how you make real money with an agency
* Getting clients through inbound and referrals is far superior
to cold outreach.
* Do not be afraid to sacrifice some margin and delegate — this
has been a big one for me as I started to feel burnt out with
client work.
* Learning direct response copy is the first fundamental skill
you need. Over time you can add complementary skills that make
you more valuable to businesses.

Alrighty, that’s all for today.

If you have any specific questions - whether it’s about business
or anything else I ramble about here, reply and lmk

Ben

​

​

subject: How I make 6 figures per month
body:
Let’s talk about business.

If you have zero clue what I do and how it works, here’s a brief
TLDR:

I run a marketing agency where I work with many of the big
personal brands that you see online with hundreds of thousands of
followers.

Over the last few months, we’ve consistently been over $100k per
month with minimal expenses.

I have a team of 3 people, and we work with around 7-10 clients
at a time.

The majority of clients we work with are making anywhere from
$100k- $600k per month selling info-products and coaching
programs.

Most of the revenue we bring in as an agency comes from our
10-20% performance fees on the revenue we generate.

Our bread and butter as an agency are webinars and new product
launches.

We provide full-stack services to our clients, meaning we build
their funnels, script VSLs, script and build slides for webinars,
run email marketing, and provide a few other services, including
general consulting.

All of our clients come to us through referrals and my Twitter
account.

Make sense so far?

Here’s how I ended up here:

A few years ago, I started a different agency working with
basketball trainers.

I was able to work with many of the trainers you may see on
social media that had big audiences, and in that process, I got
really good at one thing:

Getting people to take action through the written word, otherwise
known as copywriting.

I also accumulated a handful of other skills that I use with the
clients we work with, including funnel building, backend system
setup, and a deep understanding of info-product businesses as a
whole.

I don’t know how this all may relate to you, but perhaps you’re
an agency owner or freelancer who wants to make more money with
fewer clients.

Here are some of the biggest things I’ve learned in going from
$25k/mo - $100k/mo+ over the past year:

* The real money is in revenue shares. To be able to get rev
shares where clients pay you $20k+ without batting an eye, you
must become irreplaceable in their business. This is where the
multitude of services we offer (and do better than 99% of other
agencies) comes in handy.
* You need a team, but hiring doesn’t have to be difficult. I’m a
horrible operator, and I didn’t want to have to babysit new team
members I brought on. So, my team consists of 2 of my closest who
were already very skilled in the work we do. And although I
sacrifice some margin, it saves me so much time and headache that
I would have if I tried to do everything on my own.
* Client results & personal brand is the best form of outreach.
Two months ago, I closed a new client who found me through
Twitter and knew some of the people we work with. He’s paid us
over $50k, mostly from our performance fees. I have opportunities
like this come up frequently because of the two assets I
mentioned above (client results & personal brand).
* Do not be afraid to cut ties with clients when things are not
going the way you need them to. I am selective with who I bring
on, and I’ve learned that short-term cash is never worth the
headache when I see red flags. I turn away most of the prospects
that book calls with me if they don’t fit the criteria that I
know we need to succeed.

If you’re working in a similar type of business, I hope this
helps. Feel free to reply and fire away with any questions.

Let get richer,

Ben

​

 I run a marketing agency where I work with many of the big personal brands that you see online w

subject: Re: your question
body:
I got many questions from our chat about business the other day.

​Read it here if you missed it. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hdggx32irh5p37999/3ohphkh77ogrprfr/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2IvazB1bWg2aGR6bXF4bmM2bjMzd240YTh3bnE3Nzc=
)​

I’m sorry if I didn’t get back to you, but I promise it’s for
good reason:

I’m lazy.

And actually, the questions I received helped me come to an
important realization that you might benefit from.

Most of you already know exactly what you need to do.

And if you don’t, it’s probably because you haven’t taken the
time to think critically and objectively about the situation at
hand.

I remember being in this exact position.

I’d hit a plateau in business and invest in a coaching program or
mentor.

Just by taking the time to explain my situation to them, what I
needed to do became obvious in my own head.

By the end of my spiel, I’d usually answer my own question, and
if I didn’t, the advice I’d get would be incredibly simple.

And that’s exactly what I needed.

The answer to most of the problems you face right now is the
following:

Think about it and do what you think is best.

You aren’t lost; you just want to be told what to do.

This reminds me of these two younger dudes who I recently started
consulting with because they kept harassing me and offering me
money.

They come to our calls with a world of ideas, fancy diagrams that
track their data, and a bunch of new buzzwords and KPIs.

Most of the calls are filled with one of them rambling about any
of the things I mentioned above and me saying something along the
lines of “That’s cool, so why don’t you just do more of this one
simple thing that’s already working for you to make more money.”

Sometimes, I feel bad because they’ve paid me, and I’m not
necessarily bringing any revolutionary ideas to the table for
them.

But honestly, that’s the secret – the revolutionary ideas don’t
exist.

And by simply providing a vote of confidence that they’re on the
right track, I’m able to help solidify the things they already
know to be true.

Sure, there will always be some nuances and information that you
unlock with more time in the game, but most of the time, the
right answer is the obvious answer.

Avoid pretending not to know what to do in order to procrastinate
doing the thing you know you need to do.

I don’t know why, but that’s a common trap that I’ve fallen
victim to frequently.

Trust yourself my friend.

Happy money Monday,

Ben

​

subject: The safest thing you can do is floor it
body:
It’s 1:37am and I’m on my way home.

I’m driving with the top down as I merge onto the highway.

The car in the left lane (autistically) creeps into my lane, and
there’s a car on my right, so I can’t move over.

I hit the gas and narrowly weave between the 2 cars.

Sorry it’s been almost a week since I last emailed you.

I went out Monday through Friday.

I know everyone talks about how this whole entrepreneur thing is
a grind, you have to sacrifice fun, blah blah blah – but I’ve
legitimately spent more time in the club over the last 5 days
than I have at my desk.

“Life’s about balance, and the balance is in her (the bottle
girl) account now” - Socrates.

Anyway…

The purpose of the driving tidbit I shared above was to
illustrate the cliche lesson of going on the offensive.

If I hadn’t hit the gas when I did or if I tapped the brake, I
might’ve gotten hit.

So, in hindsight, the safest thing I could’ve done was to floor
it.

This reminds me of my thought process when I decided to drop out
of college.

I remember weighing the two options and coming to a realization
that it actually wasn’t as risky as everyone made it out to be.

Spending 4 years of my life to get a sheet of paper that barely
proves a baseline level of competence in hopes of getting a
$60k/year job out of college sounded riskier.

I was gonna go on and on about this topic, but I’m extremely
sleep-deprived, and I keep nodding off.

Lesson in there.

I’ll write something longer and more valuable tomorrow, but for
now goodnight Bo.

Ben

​

subject: Might as well
body:
When I stepped foot on a college campus 4 years ago, I had no
intentions of joining a fraternity.

Rush week started, and I began going to parties and events with
my roommates

If you don’t know how the whole Greek life thing works; basically
rush week is when all the frats throw these parties and events to
recruit new members.

After that week, I figured this whole pledging thing couldn’t be
that bad.

Next thing you know, I got a bid and became a pledge in a
fraternity.

This is not the fun part.

For the next 3 months, my 11 pledge brothers and I were
constantly running errands for the members of the frat, setting
up events, and of course, having our fair share of… “welcome to
the frat” moments.

If you know me, you know I love my time.

There are few things I dislike more than feeling like I’m not in
control of where I go and what I do.

Pledging a fraternity completely ate up all my time.

There was a moment early on when I was thinking about dropping
(quitting).

It was maybe 2 weeks in, and I started to come to the
discouraging realization that this wasn’t going to end any time
soon.

I was going back and forth thinking about it and honestly was
ready to get out of it.

But by that time, I’d made a couple of close friends, and I
didn’t want to bail on them.

I also felt an obligation to myself to finish what I unknowingly
started.

So I did.

I would’ve never pledged had I really known what I signed up for,
but once I was in it, I couldn’t bring myself to back out.

subject: Might as well
body:
When I stepped foot on a college campus 4 years ago, I had no intentions of joining a fraternity. 

 Rush week started, and I began going to parties and events with my roommates 

 If you don’t know how the whole Greek life thing works; basically rush week is when all the frats throw these parties and events to recruit new members. 

 After that week, I figured this whole pledging thing couldn’t be that bad. 

 Next thing you know, I got a bid and became a pledge in a fraternity. 

 This is not the fun part. 

 For the next 3 months, my 11 pledge brothers and I were constantly running errands for the members of the frat, setting up events, and of course, having our fair share of… “welcome to the frat” moments. 

 If you know me, you know I love my time. 

 There are few things I dislike more than feeling like I’m not in control of where I go and what I do. 

 Pledging a fraternity completely ate up all my time. 

 There was a moment early on when I was thinking about dropping (quitting). 

 It was maybe 2 weeks in, and I started to come to the discouraging realization that this wasn’t going to end any time soon. 

 I was going back and forth thinking about it and honestly was ready to get out of it. 

 But by that time, I’d made a couple of close friends, and I didn’t want to bail on them. 

 I also felt an obligation to myself to finish what I unknowingly started. 

 So I did. 

 I would’ve never pledged had I really known what I signed up for, but once I was in it, I couldn’t bring myself to back out. 

 The words that come to mind when I think about this situation are the following: 

 “You’re already this far in; you might as well finish the job.” 

 And if we extrapolate this to life or business, it’s a valuable lesson to pull from. 

 The hardest part of doing anything new is the beginning. 

 You suck at the thing. It sucks. And change is hard. 

 But once you start, inertia starts to build. 

 Even when you keep getting caught with a right hook… 

 Or a prospect cusses you out and hangs up on your cold call… 

 Or you look like an idiot in front of your date because you stumble over your words and accidentally tell the waiter, “you too,” when they say, “have a good meal.” 

 Momentum carries you through the shitty parts like this. Once you’re in, there’s no going back because it’s like you can almost taste what the other side will be like. 

 Yesterday, I was reminded of this very concept. 

 I sat down to record a YouTube video, and 36 tries later, when I was about to quit, I told myself that this was my last try and I was following through with it no matter what. 

 I imagined how I’d feel after finally making and uploading the video. 

 And I told myself, “You’re already this far in; you might as well finish the job.” 

 ​ You can watch that video here. ​

 Hope you’re having a good week, and show some love on the YT vid if you like it :) 

 Ben

subject: Just get an easy bucket
body:
I used to watch basketball religiously.

Whenever I studied the greatest shooters in the NBA, I noticed a
commonality: each of them had their go-to shots that they would
try to get to towards the beginning of the game.

Guys like Steph Curry and Damian Lillard would do this to get
into a rhythm.

And whenever they got a solid look and knocked down an easy
bucket early on, you could just tell they were locked in, and it
was gonna be a long night for the defense.

Similarly, for nearly any task you want to complete consistently,
you need to find ways to get yourself in the right mental state.

My creativity has been at a high the last few days.

It’s like my brain is feeding me tweet after tweet and video idea
after video idea.

And I think it’s because of the exact same reason that Steph is
ready to go off after he gets that first bucket to drop…

I’ve been forcing myself to write a singular tweet early in the
day.

Even if it’s not my best work or if it takes 10 minutes to get
over the initial resistance, I simply get it done.

It’s my version of an “easy bucket,” and after that, it’s like
the pressure is gone.

That very act builds enough goodwill in my brain that it rewards
me by continuing to keep creativity flowing in spurts throughout
the day.

And this concept applies to a lot more than creativity or
basketball.

Have you ever been on a date where your conversations are kind of
dry?

You keep asking each other questions, but you’re unable to make
the vibe more lively and drop the filter that both of you are
upholding.

Then, one of you says something that makes both of you feel more
comfortable, and the mood instantly switches.

You can feel the weight being lifted off your shoulders as you
conversate, and you’re finally in that carefree state in which
you operate best.

That’s the zone.

And if you understand how you operate, you can put a protocol in
place to give yourself the best chance of accessing it in
different scenarios.

For example, sometimes when I have work to do that I’m dreading,
I’ll start by completing a few easier tasks to build some
momentum and get the ball rolling.

Does it work 100% of the time?

No.

But can it occasionally help me do that thing that I didn’t want
to do with more efficiency and focus?

Yes.

Get an easy shot, get your first rep out of the way, go home with
a four (or don’t), write one tweet, etc.

And boom, you now have access to one of the most valuable assets
that can propel you to success: Momentum.

Good chat today.

I’m selling you something soonish btw.

Hope you’re ready,

Ben

​

subject: You were sold a lie
body:
You scroll through the internet and see dozens of people sharing
various opinions.

Perhaps you adopt some of them and begin to abide by them.

“A capable man needs to get rich, fight, shoot guns, and get
jacked.”

You do as you’re told, and not long after, you’ve acquired many
of the traits and skills that others proclaim as necessities.

You’ve accepted the values, opinions, and rules of others.

On paper, you’re exactly what you “should” be.

And these things were supposed to make you happy, to set you
free, to build you into someone worthy of respect.

But there’s an emptiness that comes with these traits as you’ve
“transformed” into the person they told you that you need to be.

Under all these arbitrary obligations, you’ve buried the most
important one.

Who are you?

“You” are no longer there.

You’re a hodgepodge – a mosaic – an amalgamation of a variety of
opinions and features that you didn’t come to on your own regard.

Self-improvement or self-actualization is not the act of blindly
accepting the ideals of others.

It is piercing through their opinions and standards to formulate
those of your own.

Don’t forget who you were before they told you who you should be.

Value your instincts, your inclinations, your personal
experiences, and your unique perception of truth above all else.

This is freedom.

This is what a “man” does.

This is access to the autonomy that likely seduced you into this
game in the first place.

As you become free financially, you must also become free
mentally and spiritually.

Don’t neglect the last two.

Happy Saturday,

Ben

P.S. Check out my recent YouTube video if you haven't already (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h3rpkwetqhmole333/qvh8h7hrrol793ul/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9SRzZfdGJIa25KSQ==
)​

subject: When to "jump-ship" VS stick it out
body:
I’ve been going to a different coffee shop recently.

This one’s a bit more liberal, and I think they pump estrogen
into the air. All the employees are wearing reindeer ears and the
male barista attempts to hold eye contact with me for a few
milliseconds too long.

I evade and tell him to make me an $8 iced latte with vanilla.

Before I got here, I was scouring my apartment. I tore up my
office, dug under the couch, swept through the kitchen, and even
looked in my bathroom although I knew there was little chance I’d
find what I was looking for in there.

It’s not that I even wanted to find the item that bad, it’s that
I knew it was there somewhere which was driving me crazy.

But for now, I’m listening to Christmas music at this cafe
because I had no luck finding my airpods.

I rarely wear headphones. But when I do, it’s because I’m in a
noisy area and I want to write. Listening to my own music helps
me feel like I’m in my own world where I can ignore the
dorky-looking man at the counter to my right wearing a fanny pack
around his shoulder.

I literally remember putting them on my counter yesterday.

Maybe someone broke into my apartment, ignored the expensive
watches, my car keys, and any other more valuable items they
could’ve taken, and decided to run away with my disgustingly
earwax-stained airpods. Hahaha.

I had something I wanted to write to you about, but I’ve gotten
so sidetracked that I completely forget it now. I guess it’s just
that kind of morning.

Something that’s been on my mind however is career paths.

I don’t understand how people can stay in one role in the same
field for more than a few years.

Especially as entrepreneurs. Maybe I’m just immature, but
thinking about doing the same exact thing I’m doing now for the
next 3 years makes me want to chew glass.

Sure you can always make the argument that “feelings don’t
matter. Do it anyway” blah blah.

And I know there will always be some things I don’t want to do in
any business I run. But to me it just makes sense to upgrade or
switch business models every few years (if that’s what feels
right).

I get bored doing the same thing every day after a while.

Again, you can make a sound argument that it doesn’t matter how
you feel and that you should power through the things you don’t
want to do.

But you can also make the counterargument that if you can find
excitement in your work, you’ll be much more effective than when
you’re dreading it. Even if that means your business model has to
change or evolve every so often.

Last point on this and then I gotta run: I’m not saying you
should constantly be jumping from one completely different
business to another.

You likely have innate skills that can be applied in a variety of
different ways, and sometimes being open to the application of
your skill set in a similar or parallel field may make sense.

You with me here?

I could be completely wrong, but thanks for reading anyway. Let
me know if you liked this one.

Happy Christmas and Merry Hanukkah.

Ben

P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h4vzn5xhmhmogp444/n2hohvh33qv55lh6/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9SRzZfdGJIa25KST9zaT1mMTQtd1M3YjdXeUtqRHZs
) Or...Watch my recent Podcast (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h4vzn5xhmhmogp444/48hvhehrrlmqq3ux/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9zWXZQZUVESnYtbz9zaT1lWFVpdzk4clpZTnNfcExt
)​

​

subject: How to dissipate any chance of regret
body:
I found the airpods that I told you I lost in yesterday’s email.
(
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh0z027nakhzn2l999/08hwh9hdde8vkgul/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2IvbXZ1N2g1aGd2a3pleHR2NW9vNDV3aWVvd25xcXE=
)​

Any guess where they were?

If you said “the washing machine” you’d be correct.

I guess that’s one way to get earwax off.

Last night I was thinking about the last organized basketball
game I ever played.

We were losing by double digits, and I fouled out with a couple
of minutes left.

As I ran off the court, I didn’t realize that it would be the
last time until I saw the look on my coach's face.

It was a mix of sorrow and regret.

I had a fine high school basketball career, but it never felt
like I truly played at the level I was capable of - and like I’d
left something out there on the court.

By the look in my coach's eye, we were silently in agreement on
the statement above, and I think he felt some guilt (although I
don’t offer him any of the blame).

Knowing that you could’ve done better and that you squandered an
opportunity to display your gifts to the world is one of the
worst feelings there is.

It can be as simple as an awkward interaction with someone you
respect or as big as dedicating years of your life to a project
and never seeing it come to fruition.

But as I think more about this situation now, I genuinely think
that it’s the best thing that could happen to you.

That feeling will light a fire inside of you.

If you carry that flame into your next project, your
relationships, and your general approach to life, you begin to
become a light.

Your underlying goal is now to express your true, genuine self.

When you do your best to represent that version of yourself,
you’re no longer robbing the world of your unique gifts.

Getting kind of spiritual here but I hope you’re still with me
and can resonate with this a bit.

Don’t run off the court feeling like you could’ve done more.

Don’t walk away from a relationship feeling like you didn’t
adequately represent yourself.

And don’t take your last breath wondering what could’ve been if
you had just approached your life with a true effort to do your
best.

Thanks for sticking with me here and as always, let me know if
this one hit.

subject: How to dissipate any chance of regret
body:
I found the airpods that I told you I lost in yesterday’s email. ​

 Any guess where they were? 

 If you said “the washing machine” you’d be correct. 

 I guess that’s one way to get earwax off. 

 Last night I was thinking about the last organized basketball game I ever played. 

 We were losing by double digits, and I fouled out with a couple of minutes left. 

 As I ran off the court, I didn’t realize that it would be the last time until I saw the look on my coach's face. 

 It was a mix of sorrow and regret. 

 I had a fine high school basketball career, but it never felt like I truly played at the level I was capable of - and like I’d left something out there on the court. 

 By the look in my coach's eye, we were silently in agreement on the statement above, and I think he felt some guilt (although I don’t offer him any of the blame). 

 Knowing that you could’ve done better and that you squandered an opportunity to display your gifts to the world is one of the worst feelings there is. 

 It can be as simple as an awkward interaction with someone you respect or as big as dedicating years of your life to a project and never seeing it come to fruition. 

 But as I think more about this situation now, I genuinely think that it’s the best thing that could happen to you. 

 That feeling will light a fire inside of you. 

 If you carry that flame into your next project, your relationships, and your general approach to life, you begin to become a light. 

 Your underlying goal is now to express your true, genuine self. 

 When you do your best to represent that version of yourself, you’re no longer robbing the world of your unique gifts. 

 Getting kind of spiritual here but I hope you’re still with me and can resonate with this a bit. 

 Don’t run off the court feeling like you could’ve done more. 

 Don’t walk away from a relationship feeling like you didn’t adequately represent yourself. 

 And don’t take your last breath wondering what could’ve been if you had just approached your life with a true effort to do your best. 

 Thanks for sticking with me here and as always, let me know if this one hit. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Watch my recent podcast here ​

subject: Holidays are for women children and wagies
body:
Merry belated Christmas.

Not gonna lie I’m kind of excited for the Holiday season to be
over and to get back into the natural swing of things.

To me, it’s always felt like Holidays are just for people who
hate their normal lives and want to soak up their annual two-week
break from reality.

Maybe I’m just a grumpy asshole, but I like my normal reality.

I went to the dentist for the first time in a while today, and he
was asking about my business.

There’s an art to being able to describe what you do to people
who are not in your world.

I explained how I run marketing for people who sell coaching and
information online.

To help him understand, I told him that if he were to get on
social media and make educational videos about how he started his
practice, he would naturally garner an audience of people who
would pay to learn more from him.

He then understood. And I had no cavities, so that was pretty
cool.

The online education industry still blows my mind sometimes.

Nearly anyone who has acquired any niche skill has the capability
to share their story on social media and find people who are
willing to spend hundreds or thousands of dollars to learn from
them.

With the boom of short-form content, it’s never been easier to
start making minute-long videos from your iPhone, and *boom* now
you have a potential seven-figure business.

This is the situation for every single one of my clients.

We’ve been working with a client who buys small local businesses.

It’s a much more complicated process than I’ll make it sound
here, but basically, he has a system that allows anyone with a
stable income and some money to invest to acquire a “boomer”
business that cashflows around 6-figs per year right off the bat.

The process of finding a type of business that’s a good buy is
the most complicated part, but once an acquisition is complete,
he can operate the business remotely and only spend about an hour
per week on each business, making sure nothing catches on fire.

He started making content on social media, and just months later,
we’re doing multi-six-figure months, and he’s got dozens of
successful students.

There’s no real lesson here today, but I just wanted to make it
clear how simple it can be to launch and scale an online
education company.

I’ve got something coming for you soon if you’re someone who is
building this type of business or something similar, so be on the
lookout for my emails over the next few weeks.

Let’s hit the gas and build a life in 2024 where you don’t have
to “look forward to the Holidays” because your whole life feels
like a Holiday :)

Thanks for reading my words today. Let me know if you liked this
one.

Ben

​

subject: 4 traits that *might* correlate with success
body:
I’ve been in the online marketing space for about three years
now.

Throughout this time, I’ve met a lot of people who were trying to
“make it” as entrepreneurs. Some completely failed, some
stagnated, and others have been on par with the same level of
success I’ve seen or have found financial success quicker than
me.

Obviously, there are unicorns, but for the most part,
intelligence doesn’t seem to play a huge role as long a baseline
level of competence is established.

It’s similar to being a professional athlete – at the highest
levels, everyone is a “freak” athlete. It’s the minimum standard,
and generally, the intangibles are what separates the good from
the great.

Here are a few of the less tangible traits I see in my more
successful friends (which those who stagnate or fail seem to
lack):

1. Ingenuity & craftiness: In the world of entrepreneurship,
rules are meant to be broken, loopholes are meant to be found,
and the lines between what works and what doesn’t are blurred.

There’s a proclaimed “right way” to find success, and then
there's the way that actually works for you.

Creativity and persistence will (sometimes) take you much further
than blindly following a “proven system” that other people tell
you to.

2. Discipline & the ability to create order in chaos: Freedom
causes most people to lose their minds. When you’re accustomed to
being told what to do, what to think, and where to be, having to
tell yourself those things is a big adjustment.

Build a system for yourself that works for you. Again, it doesn’t
have to be what other people are doing as long as it puts you in
an environment and mental space that allows you to do what you
need to do.

3. Comfortable with the unknown: Eventually, you come to the
realization that no matter how much you plan, no matter how hard
you try, and no matter how badly you want something to happen,
you are not in complete control of the outcome.

Certainty makes us feel safe. And if you’re too attached to that
feeling of safety, go get a desk job and a 401k. Or prepare to
always have a voice in the back of your head that thinks
everything is gonna crumble at any given moment.

Bonus trait 4 - The gut feeling paradox: There’s a balance
between listening to signs from the universe that tell you that
you need to make a change versus jumping from one shiny object to
the next.

Sometimes, when things don’t feel right, it’s a sign that you
need to make a change.

Other times, when things don’t feel right, it’s a sign that
you’re on the cusp of something great if you can power through
that feeling.

This is a constant game. I don’t have any advice on how to
navigate it because truthfully, I don’t know if anyone does.

I guess that brings us back to trait #3, huh?

Alrighty, hope you liked this one. Keep pushing these next few
days and build momentum going into 2024.

Happy hump day, let me know if you read this whole thing

Ben

P.S. If you still haven’t watched my recent YouTube video, go
here plz. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvh8mxq0ob6h7nrpggg/dpheh0h009qp6qum/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9SRzZfdGJIa25KSQ==
)​

​

subject: How to fail in 2024
body:
“Here’s how to make your goals come true in 2024!!!”

I hate the sentence above because everyone is using this angle to
sell their stuff right now.

So, this email will be about why you won’t accomplish your 2024
goals.

Most people will probably tell you to write out your goals and
reverse engineer the steps you need to take to get there.

If you want to make $100k/month, figure out how many clients you
need, and then figure out how many outbound messages you need to
send daily to book calls with potential clients, given your close
rate.

And now boom, you have the goal to “send 30 messages per day.”

It’s a sound system and something I’ve used over the years.

But as I think about times when I felt stuck or fell short of my
goals, it wasn’t because I couldn’t devise a simple plan like the
one above.

It was because the execution of those actions was harder than it
looked on paper.

I’d wake up on January 1st and think, “Ah shit, I told myself I
was gonna start this thing today… ok, let me scroll through
TikTok first.”

By the time I’d get around to attempting to complete whatever
task was at hand, my focus was horrible, and I couldn’t muster up
the discipline to actually sit there and do it.

I objectively was in a situation that I didn’t want to be in.

I knew the steps I needed to take to change.

But actually doing them felt like I was attempting to lift up a
Ram TRX with my pinky finger.

Why is this?

Inaction can be caused by a plethora of factors, but here’s one I
used to face:

I was scared to raise my standards because I knew the further I
got from the bottom, the harder it would be to go back.

There’s a lot of comfort in stagnation.

Even though I was telling myself I wanted to change, I could see
that the road to my destination was filled with potholes and dead
ends.

I was gonna have to become somebody that I wasn’t presently – and
that’s a painful experience.

And you know what’s less painful?

Turning on the TV and watching another episode of South Park
because after all, being a normie doesn’t sound THAT bad.

This mental battle was a constant dilemma I faced every time I
tried to start something new.

If this sounds familiar to you, here’s my advice:

Drop everything that you tell yourself you want, and accept the
fact that you weren’t born to do anything special.

Deal?

No…?

Fine - If that advice doesn’t sound like something you want to
do, then stick with me.

All you have to do is dive in.

When the cold water hits your body, you’re gonna want to get out.

You’re gonna think of a thousand different reasons as to why you
should get out, why Ben’s advice is stupid, and why it’s not the
right time.

Don’t listen to the voices for long enough, and you’ll get over
the flinch.

On the other side of the flinch, you’ll find that the things you
were scaring you are actually not that scary.

The monsters under your bed look more like teddy bears and less
like Dracula.

And maybe you’ll learn to love the cold, uncomfortable,
unchartered water.

Just don’t bitch out. Simple.

Hope you enjoyed my anti-self-improvement turned self-improvement
email.

Love ya,

Ben

​

subject: finally back 2 work!
body:
I'm stoked for the new year.

Mainly because all of the tourists will leave Miami today and my
morning coffee walk will be far less crowded.

Back to the natural swing of things we go.

I crawled out of bed at noon today and saw a text asking me if I
wanted to speak at a Mastermind later this month.

Truthfully I don’t like public speaking. Shit makes me nervous.

I immediately started thinking of excuses I could come up with to
get out of it.

Maybe I’ll plan a trip that weekend so that I have a legitimate
reason to say no.

Or perhaps I’ll say my dog ate my computer and I can’t make the
PowerPoint presentation. Or maybe I’ll start licking door handles
and kissing homeless people so I can be sick that day.

Ugh.

As my conscious thoughts run through a variety of excuses, I have
a feeling in my stomach that tells me that I have to say yes.

This is a common occurrence among the things we don't want to do.

It can be as simple as when someone invites you to dinner, and
you initially try to say no, but somehow you get roped into
going.

Then you end up having a good time, and you're glad you went.

But our ego wants to protect us. It wants to talk us out of
putting ourselves in any position where there’s an opportunity to
look like a fool or be challenged in any way.

I could get up there, start my presentation, and forget how to
pronounce my own name and lose my ability to speak english.

Imagine I do the whole thing in Spanish and no one understands
it.

But in reality — detached from the fragile, overbearing ego
that’s inside of all of us, I know that it’s an experience
that’ll be good for character development in the movie that I
star in inside my own head.

And the last email (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh24e7qzu2hxv6ez66/qvh8h7hrr377o8tl/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2IvNjh1ZWg4aGt6dzdubGNrcTg4Z3FtdHo3dnhra2s=
) I wrote to you was literally about how getting over “the
flinch” is all you need to be successful.

So that’d be extremely hypocritical of me to bitch out because
I’m nervous.

If there’s one thing I want you to take away from my rant today,
it’s this:

You have conscious thoughts that your ego feeds you as a
protection mechanism.

And then you have your gut feeling.

Learn to decipher the difference between the two when you’re
making a decision, and it might lead you to experiences that are
necessary for your development.

Or you’ll embarrass yourself and never listen to me again.

Happy New Year,

Ben

​

 Mainly because all of the tourists will leave Miami today and my morning coffee walk will be far less crowded. 

 Back to the natural swing of things we go. 

 I crawled out of bed at noon today and saw a text asking me if I wanted to speak at a Mastermind later this month. 

 Truthfully I don’t like public speaking. Shit makes me nervous. 

 I immediately started thinking of excuses I could come up with to get out of it. 

 Maybe I’ll plan a trip that weekend so that I have a legitimate reason to say no. 

 Or perhaps I’ll say my dog ate my computer and I can’t make the PowerPoint presentation. Or maybe I’ll start licking door handles and kissing homeless people so I can be sick that day. 

 Ugh. 

 As my conscious thoughts run through a variety of excuses, I have a feeling in my stomach that tells me that I have to say yes. 

 This is a common occurrence among the things we don't want to do. 

 It can be as simple as when someone invites you to dinner, and you initially try to say no, but somehow you get roped into going. 

 Then you end up having a good time, and you're glad you went. 

 But our ego wants to protect us. It wants to talk us out of putting ourselves in any position where there’s an opportunity to look like a fool or be challenged in any way. 

 I could get up there, start my presentation, and forget how to pronounce my own name and lose my ability to speak english. 

 Imagine I do the whole thing in Spanish and no one understands it. 

 But in reality — detached from the fragile, overbearing ego that’s inside of all of us, I know that it’s an experience that’ll be good for character development in the movie that I star in inside my own head. 

 And the last email I wrote to you was literally about how getting over “the flinch” is all you need to be successful. 

 So that’d be extremely hypocritical of me to bitch out because I’m nervous. 

 If there’s one thing I want you to take away from my rant today, it’s this: 

 You have conscious thoughts that your ego feeds you as a protection mechanism. 

 And then you have your gut feeling. 

 Learn to decipher the difference between the two when you’re making a decision, and it might lead you to experiences that are necessary for your development. 

 Or you’ll embarrass yourself and never listen to me again. 

 Happy New Year, 

 Ben 

 ​
