subject: How to make $100k per month by doing everything wrong
body:
My agency website is quite horrible.

​You can look at it here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhxldq54sghzxl28ll/08hwh9hdd87p2ztl/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubmluZXR5Zm91cm1hcmtldGluZy5jb20vYXBwbHktaGVyZQ==
)​

It’s almost been a year since I last revised it, and we have
loads of client results that I’ve been too lazy to compile.

I can’t remember the last outbound DM I sent to a prospect, and
just spent 4 minutes looking for one before giving up.

It’s been months since I last tweeted about what we do, and I’ve
never done one of those corny auto-dm tweets in order to get new
prospects.

We communicate with most of our clients through iMessage, I don’t
really have any SOPs (standard operating procedures), and if it
weren’t for the basic Notion doc I use to plan my days, I’d
completely forget what needs to be done each week.

I am the epitome of most things that people tell you what not to
do in order to scale an agency.

Yet we’ve been consistently doing over $100k per month, whereas
most ‘agency experts touch $20k per month one time and jump into
coaching.

This is a result of a few fundamentals that we seem to have
gotten right:

- Client results

Results create happy clients, and happy clients create referrals.
This one’s simple, so I won’t spend too much time here.

- Clear idea client avatar

We’ve become quite strict on the type of business for which we
can provide the best work.

If a prospect comes to us wanting a funnel, webinar, VSL, or
email list management, yet they have little traffic and a minimal
email list, we do not pitch them.

We usually refer them to a friend who can help them with their
organic content or simply give them pointers on how to build
their audience.

They sometimes end up coming back months later after they’ve
taken the steps we gave them on the call.

- Personal brand & network

If you go to my Twitter or TikTok, there is proof that I am a
real human doing real things. It’s also clear that I’m not
another self-proclaimed “expert agency owner” who regurgitates
the same three talking points.

This makes it so people develop a bit of a relationship with me
and my idealogy before we ever get on the phone.

I’m telling you all this in order to show you that many things
you may think you need to find success are often a facade.

Whether you run an agency or a completely different type of
business, your success often boils down to a few key factors.

Once you understand what those factors are, double down on them
rather than wasting time trying to find the next magic pill that
will carry you to the promised land.

Repeat successful actions, and success becomes inevitable.

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

P.S. I’m making another YouTube video this week. Reply and let me
know if there’s anything you’d like me to talk about in my next
video, and click here to watch my most recent video. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhxldq54sghzxl28ll/8ghqhohll457okfk/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9SRzZfdGJIa25KSQ==
)​

​

https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhxldq54sghzxl28ll

subject: No Half Measures
body:
Have you ever thought about what your life would be like if you
gave it your all?

I’m not referring to the lies that you tell yourself about how
hard you’re working, how you just need some more guidance, how
things are good enough as they are, or how one day you’re gonna
do it.

But truly.

What type of person would you become?

How high would your standards be for yourself?

What would your life look like?

If you can read the questions above and picture the exact life
you’re living right now, congrats. You’re doing it right.

But if you’re like me – and like most people, you know in your
core that you’re not even scratching the surface of your
potential.

Even if things are good.

Hell, that’s honestly more dangerous. You get some money, a fun
lifestyle, a girl or 10… it’s easy to throw in the towel and feel
like you’ve won.

And maybe you have won by most people’s standards.

But you know that it’s not complete. It’s not even close.

That doesn’t sit right with you. So even though you’re “living
the dream,” that voice in your head doesn’t go away.

It’s the same voice you heard when you felt compelled to start a
business or make any life-altering change.

It eats you up silently.
You suppress it and tell yourself false narratives and stories in
an attempt to remove its power.

Perhaps it works temporarily.

But on a long enough time horizon, you just can’t seem to shake
it.

Eventually, you’ll be left at a crossroads where you have to
decide whether or not you’re going to quench those urges and step
into the reality that you know is possible for you.

Or continuously attempt to fool yourself and risk sabotaging your
life in the process.

After all, the only way to ensure that you’re rarely disappointed
is to do your best.

As long as you do that, there will never be “what ifs.”

Sure, things won’t always go your way. But you’ll sleep knowing
you did everything in your power with the resources you had on
hand.

You’ll find peace in the fact that you actually fucking tried.

You get one shot at this. Don’t half-ass it.

Alright even motivation, can we stop saying “Happy New Year” now?

It’s the 4th. Nobody was saying Merry Christmas on NYE.

I hope this made you feel some fire in your soul if you made it
all the way down here, and if it did, you’ll probably like this
too. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hdre3w3crh5x9dv99/m2h7h5h83gnkmmam/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS83QkU0UWN3WDRkVT9zaT1sUFdKTjg1ZGdKMUFDVlot
)​

Happy 4th day of the new year,

Ben

​

subject: Keep it simple, stupid
body:
After waiting 8 minutes and 27 seconds for the elevator, I threw
in the towel and took the stairs 30-something floors down from my
apartment.

I’m refraining from telling you the exact floor in case someone
has infiltrated my email list to gather information and rob me.

If that's you, you’re gonna need backup.

I have nothing to write to you about today and was hoping that
sitting down at this cafe would give me a surge of creativity.

I’ve grown to hate the word “value.”

It makes me think of minute-long Instagram reels with yellow
captions and tweets that contain the words “here’s how” and a
ball of yarn emoji.

Everyone is talking about the same shit over and over.

“9-5 is evil, college is a trap, you have to escape before it’s
too late… Become an appointment setter!!!”

It’s no secret that you can go to YouTube or spend some money on
courses to learn just about any way to make money online.

The abundance of information has made it incredibly easy to build
a business while simultaneously making it more difficult.

There are simply too many options.

If you don’t have the discipline to stay locked in on one thing,
you’ll jump from one business to the next for eternity.

Everything is so simple when you just focus on the basics:

1. Learn how to provide a service or build a product that solves
a problem for other people.

2. Find a mechanism to get clients or customers.

That’s it.

Repeat that process a bunch of times, and then you no longer have
to look at price tags.

I’ve grown to believe that you cannot develop into the highest
version of yourself until you’re in complete abundance
financially.

When you have to worry about menial expenses and constantly chase
cash, it distorts your lens of reality.

Your broke “life coach” has two motives. First, they need to keep
you as a client. Second, they want to help you just enough but
not too much so that you’re “fixed” and can leave.

Sorry, I’m rambling here.

Last thing I’ll share today:

I’m opening up a small consulting group exclusively for people on
this email list.

It’ll be fairly expensive and isn’t for complete beginners.

But it should be pretty dope and “VaLuAble” for people who are in
the online coaching space, run agencies, or simply want to chat
with me on a more intimate basis (no homo).

If you’re interested, just reply to this email and let me know so
that I can have Russian hackers send you a phishing link and
steal your credit card info.

I know this one was a bit all over the place, so thanks for
sticking with me Bo.

Happy Monday,

Ben

P.S. I’ve condensed my best tweets into my “highlights” section
if wanna check them out here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkzloz2cohzdklokk/3ohphkh739vq7kir/aHR0cHM6Ly90d2l0dGVyLmNvbS9iZW5oYmFkZXIvaGlnaGxpZ2h0cw==
)​

There’s some gold in there. But also a lot of nonsense and stuff
that I’ll probably cringe at in 3 months. Such is life!

Okay, bye love u.

​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkzloz2cohzdklokk
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkzloz2cohzdklokk
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkzloz2cohzdklokk/n2hohvh3v5en34a6/aHR0cHM6Ly9jb252ZXJ0a2l0LmNvbS9mZWF0dXJlcy9lbWFpbC1tYXJrZXRpbmc_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPXBvd2VyZWRieSZ1dG1fY29udGVudD1lbWFpbCZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPXJlZmVycmFsJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9ZHluYW1pYw==
)

subject: How we accidentally made $3.5M in 9 months
body:
I just knocked out most of the client work I had for the day as I
sit here in a crowded coffee shop in the middle of Brickell.

I’m drowning out the noise in here with a random Spotify playlist
blasting in my headphones.

The song “Sweater Weather” came on a few minutes ago. Absolute
banger.

Anyway, I've got a good one for you today (I think).

I’ve never publicly shared a ton about the ins and outs of how
we’re scaling our clients' info-product businesses because it’s
always felt a bit boring.

Honestly, scaling a coaching program or course business to
$500k/mo+ is shockingly simple.

I know that may sound like a crazy amount of money, but here are
some of the main things I’ve learned about how we got there *by
accident.*

- Traffic solves all. You can have the best offer in the world,
pay me $20k to build out your funnels, and hire Jordan Belfort as
your closer. But none of it will matter if you don’t have
eyeballs.

- If you can’t crack organic content, you should probably get a
9-5. Seriously. If you have something to sell and you’re unable
to get attention on the internet in 2024, you should be an
accountant instead. The entire multi-7-figure business I’m
writing about was built off of short-form content.

- Do not forget to build your plane while you’re flying it.
Because these businesses scale so fast, there’s a lot of added
complexity to the product and fulfillment side. If you neglect
the customer experience, you will crash and burn on a long enough
time horizon.

- Systems only matter at scale. We neglected a lot of the
optimizations and organizational aspects of the business until we
were already making multi-6-figs per month. Until then, we only
focused on more traffic, more webinar registrants, and more
booked calls.

- There is no secret sauce. I can’t emphasize this enough: Build
offer, get attention. Build offer, get attention. Build offer,
get attention. Fix everything else later. The degree to which you
can scale is dependent on your ability to consistently bring more
people into your funnel who know, like, and trust you.

Enough writing for today.

I hope this helped you in some way, and if it didn’t, thanks for
wasting some time with me.

By the way, there were a lot more people than I anticipated who
replied to my email yesterday (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh24w7o5b2hxv6ez66/kkhmh6hln363vgsl/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2IveG11cGg2aHJvZTNvN2hybnBwdm5xYzAzbHBrbGw=
) about the consulting group that I’m opening up.

I’m still mapping out the details in my head, but I’ll have more
info for you soon.

Thanks for chatting with me today.

Talk soon,

Ben

​

) | Update your profile (

subject: Time freedom is a trap
body:
Sometimes I get lazy.

I procrastinate.

Tasks that should take 3 minutes to complete end up taking weeks
because I put them off for so long.

On the contrary, I’ve had periods where I’m super locked in and
productive.

After I dropped out of college, I spent the following 3 months in
Mexico.

I’d wake up early every morning, hit the gym, bike home, take
sales calls, spam more prospects, check in with my clients, write
copy, and make content.

There was no room to be lazy.

If I skipped one thing, everything else would fall apart.

The whole “time freedom” fantasy is a bit of a trap.

Not having any obligations sounds great in theory, but if you
don’t have the discipline to fill your time with productive
activities that help you generate momentum, you’ll fail.

Think about these three instances:

Guy quits his job.

Kid drops out of school.

Girl breaks up with guy.

Each of these usually acts as a catalyst for a big life change –
either positive or negative.

All the time and energy that was spent working, studying, or
reminding your girlfriend to drink water is now freed up.

Some people replace those things with a structured routine, and
others don’t.

Most cannot handle freedom.

But obviously, this is all paradoxical because too much structure
makes you a dork, and too much freedom makes you lazy.

Here’s what reminded me of this concept:

Last night, I ordered a cheesesteak on Uber Eats.

This isn’t just any cheesesteak.

Imagine God himself transmutes into a hard-working (likely
Mexican or Cuban) man who sets up a ghost kitchen on Uber Eats
called “Chef Pepper.”

As I waited for Liana to weave through traffic on her motorbike
to deliver my order, I remembered that the last thing on my long
to-do list for the day was to make a YouTube video.

I’d already had a busy and productive day, so why not see if I
could knock out a video in the 10 minutes that I’m waiting here?

I set up my iPhone camera and started yapping.

7 minutes and 19 seconds later, I had a semi-coherent ramble that
I had enough confidence in to upload on the World Wide Web.

​(you can watch it here btw) (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmh0e6xexc6hdx03600/dpheh0h0e7q9n2sm/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9BeEp0aGM4SU5oNA==
)​

Funny how that works, huh?

I’d procrastinated for 27 days since making my last video, but
once I entered a race against a cheesesteak, I was able to knock
it out in less than 10 minutes.

Pressure spurs you into action. If you’re not competing, you’re
likely stalling.

Even if it means you have to find creative ways to jumpstart your
productivity.

Happy hump day,

Ben

P.S. Don’t forget about my YT video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmh0e6xexc6hdx03600/dpheh0h0e7q9n2sm/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9BeEp0aGM4SU5oNA==
)​

P.P.S. I’ll be opening consulting spots in one of my next few
emails. Keep an eye out if you don’t want to miss it (thanks for
your patience).

​

subject: Stop avoiding punches
body:
I’ve been boxing for the last few months and sparred with a guy
yesterday who was way better than me.

It felt like every time I’d throw a combo at him, he’d counter
with some shit I was completely unprepared for.

Even my jabs would rarely make contact.

By our 4th round, I was mostly just trying not to get hit.

Instead of continuing to attack, I became reactive.

I tried to guess what he would throw next rather than being
focused on my own game.

As I ran around like a chicken with its head cut off, I looked up
at the clock and saw that there were only 32 seconds left in the
round.

“Thank God,” I thought to myself.

But those next 32 seconds were the longest of my life.

It felt like 32 minutes.

That’s a feeling I haven’t experienced in a while.

Remember in school when you’d tap your pencil on the desk,
waiting for the clock to hit 3pm?

Those last 30 minutes before the bell rang felt like an eternity.

Yesterday’s sparring session made me think about the dangers of
trying to play against the clock.

You’re not trying to win.

You’re not improving.

And you’re not present.

You’re simply trying to hang on for dear life until it’s over.

That’s not a winning recipe in the ring, and definitely not a way
to live your life.

You want to anticipate, play offense, and create opportunities
for success to find you.

Instead, most people are constantly in a reactive state:

They hate their job, are obsessed with other people, and just
trying not to mess up too badly or piss anyone off while they’re
here.

It’s the same thing when you’re in a destructive relationship,
and you’re just waiting for your partner to do something bad
enough so you can justify leaving.

Or as an entrepreneur, you don’t give your full effort and push
off problems that need to be dealt with.

Eventually, that comes back to bite you, and you have to react to
a tsunami of issues that you created.

Don’t spend your life scrambling for answers and trying to wait
out the clock.

Make shit happen. Play offense.

If you’re gonna be here, you might as well make the most of it.

TGIF (every day is Friday),

Ben

P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video and leave a comment if you’re
not fake. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h7zq82ptlhnpk9wkk/9qhzhnhpdpxo7qb9/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9BeEp0aGM4SU5oNA==
)​

P.P.S. The Bader Group is opening soon.

If you’re in the info-product space, you’re a freelancer, agency
owner, bad bitch, or simply someone who likes my content and
wants to make a 4 figure donation to me monthly, this might be
for you.

We’ll have fun. And you might learn a thing or two.

Details soon.

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h7zq82ptlhnpk9wkk

)

subject: What would you do if you lost everything?
body:
Before I get into today's message, quick update on the consulting
group I’m putting together:

To be quite honest, I’ve been going back and forth on the idea,
debating whether or not it’s the right time.

But if you’ve been reading my emails for a while, you’ve probably
heard me say the “perfect” time never comes.

I decided to take my own advice.

This week, I’ll be launching “The Bader Group.”

Once launched, the application window will be open for a few
days, and then I’ll close the doors for a bit.

More details on the way in future emails.

That being said, let's get into it…

I often think about what I’d do if I lost everything.

Bank account gets wiped clean, housekeeper steals my watches, and
all my clients drop me.

This thought honestly excites me more than it scares me.

I could throw in the towel, sell the rest of my possessions, and
move back home with my parents.

Or figure out a way to make money fast so I can uphold the
lifestyle I’m living right now.

Let’s pick the latter.

If I still had my personal brand, network, and skillset, I’d be
absolutely fine.

It’d probably light a fire under my ass to go 10x harder than I
am right now.

The three assets I mentioned above are the ultimate safety net.

Once acquired, it’s nearly impossible to go broke.

But one thing I realize as I think about this hypothetical
situation is that my next move becomes rather obvious.

If I needed money fast, I’d start pitching people on Instagram
and Twitter. I’d sell anything I could to my audience. I’d find
ways to help my friends in their businesses.

And because I’d be on a real-life clock against time, I know I’d
be absolutely relentless.

Take a second now to think about what you’d do in this situation.

Who can you go to for help?

What’s the easiest way you can make an extra $10k?

What value can you provide to other people?

When you picture yourself in this predicament, you may realize
that the solutions you come up with could be implemented right
now.

If you feel like you’re stuck or you’ve stalled out at a certain
income threshold, odds are you’re just not being resourceful
enough.

Maybe you’re a bit too comfortable, and although you tell
yourself you want to progress, your desire doesn’t outweigh the
pain of change.

This leaves you with a few options:

1. Do nothing and stay in this constant state of unease where
your actions don’t meet your desired reality.

2. Do nothing and accept that you are comfortable where you are,
even if you’re selling yourself short.

3. Act like you just donated your livelihood to a stripper and
get back to work with a newfound ferocity.

The choice is yours – Just some food for thought.

Talk to you tomorrow Bo,

Ben.

P.S. Watch my recent YouTube video here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5nno9wc7he2x69xx/wnh2hghwqg434qh7/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9BeEp0aGM4SU5oND9zaT1WQ1VhWEcyWUp3cTJsc0hq
)​

​

) | Update your profile (

) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: do not join
body:
My least favorite part of my day is the time spent twiddling my
thumbs, waiting for the elevator.

If that’s the worst part of my day, I’m pretty lucky, huh?

I’m on my 5th coffee shop since moving to Miami 15 months ago.

This means I’ll frequent one place every day for roughly 3
months, randomly get sick of it one day, and start going
somewhere else.

I’ve noticed this desire for periodic change as a trend in many
other areas of my life, including those that bring more
consequences than a slightly different-tasting latte.

Over time, things just seem to get dull if you’re not iterating –
business, relationships, habits, lifestyle, environment, etc.

Oh wait real quick before I continue…

If you subscribed to this list yesterday to apply for my
consulting group, you can go here to do so. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hgv5mg3imhe9qplqq/08hwh9hd2qqww3al/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vZ3JvdXA=
)​

If you applied and I haven’t gotten back to you yet, I will
shortly.

Anyway, back to what I was saying:

I think this habit of switching things up once you get bored can
be both good and bad.

You see people like Hormozi talk about doing one thing over and
over for a very long time.

I know he has like $100m’s or whatever but that sounds boring.

Gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with
Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila.

Actually, do you think she– never mind, I’m being rude.

Variety gives life flavor.

It broadens your perspective.

You learn what you like and what you don’t like.

You try out different lifestyles and business models and voyage
on different side quests.

A man goes and gets what he wants. And then sometimes realizes
that he didn’t actually want it once he has it. But at least he
knows now.

To me, it’s at the point where you’ve tried everything and
quenched the majority of the desires that you actually have the
perspective to say –

“Okay, here’s the way I want to live the rest of my life.”

Adults vaping has to be one of the most cringe things I’ve ever
observed.

Sorry to get sidetracked here, but I just saw a woman who looks
like her name is Susan tilt her head back and blow a fat cloud
into the air as if she’s smoking hookah at a club.

I guess I’m an adult too, and I do occasionally vape, but I don’t
act like I’m Rick Ross in a sea of large women while sitting at
the coffee shop.

And I’m not a 30-something-year-old woman.

I know today's email has been all over the place, but I’m doing
this to ensure you that my list will not become an “escape the
matrix, gain remote freedom” sausage fest now that I’ve opened
consulting.

I frankly do not care if you join, but it’s here if you want it
:) (

subject: do not join
body:
My least favorite part of my day is the time spent twiddling my thumbs, waiting for the elevator. 

 If that’s the worst part of my day, I’m pretty lucky, huh? 

 I’m on my 5th coffee shop since moving to Miami 15 months ago. 

 This means I’ll frequent one place every day for roughly 3 months, randomly get sick of it one day, and start going somewhere else. 

 I’ve noticed this desire for periodic change as a trend in many other areas of my life, including those that bring more consequences than a slightly different-tasting latte. 

 Over time, things just seem to get dull if you’re not iterating – business, relationships, habits, lifestyle, environment, etc. 

 Oh wait real quick before I continue… 

 If you subscribed to this list yesterday to apply for my consulting group, you can go here to do so. ​

 If you applied and I haven’t gotten back to you yet, I will shortly. 

 Anyway, back to what I was saying: 

 I think this habit of switching things up once you get bored can be both good and bad. 

 You see people like Hormozi talk about doing one thing over and over for a very long time. 

 I know he has like $100m’s or whatever but that sounds boring. 

 Gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila, gym, work, missionary with Leila. 

 Actually, do you think she– never mind, I’m being rude. 

 Variety gives life flavor. 

 It broadens your perspective. 

 You learn what you like and what you don’t like. 

 You try out different lifestyles and business models and voyage on different side quests. 

 A man goes and gets what he wants. And then sometimes realizes that he didn’t actually want it once he has it. But at least he knows now. 

 To me, it’s at the point where you’ve tried everything and quenched the majority of the desires that you actually have the perspective to say – 

 “Okay, here’s the way I want to live the rest of my life.” 

 Adults vaping has to be one of the most cringe things I’ve ever observed. 

 Sorry to get sidetracked here, but I just saw a woman who looks like her name is Susan tilt her head back and blow a fat cloud into the air as if she’s smoking hookah at a club. 

 I guess I’m an adult too, and I do occasionally vape, but I don’t act like I’m Rick Ross in a sea of large women while sitting at the coffee shop. 

 And I’m not a 30-something-year-old woman. 

 I know today's email has been all over the place, but I’m doing this to ensure you that my list will not become an “escape the matrix, gain remote freedom” sausage fest now that I’ve opened consulting. 

 I frankly do not care if you join, but it’s here if you want it :) ​

 Gonna go smack this vape out of Susan's hand. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you’re newer here and were hoping for super in-depth information about how I run my agency and how we scale our clients' offers to half a million per month, this might not be for you. 

 Every now and then, I’ll give specific business advice, but most of these emails are little rants and observations I find interesting. 

 Too many people become carbon copies of big gurus when they take the “give value” approach, and I never want to be one of them. 

 Stick around if you’d like, and maybe you’ll enjoy it <3 

 ​

subject: Is selling an info product immoral?
body:
Question for you:

Would you kill 1,000 terminally ill people to save 50 healthy
children?

What about 10,000 to save 100?

What if you knew one of the children would go on to cure cancer?

This is a tough one for me. Sure, the terminally ill people are
likely gonna die soon anyway, but that’s a lot of blood on your
hands.

This is the way I see the majority of the info products on the
market.

Most people will fail.

As an education business scales, a few things happen that start
the degradation of their client success rate.

First, they start selling to beginners and idiots.

Oftentimes, if you want to get to $300k/month+, this is the only
way to do it (although there are anomalies).

And naturally, when the quality of your customer decreases, so
does the effectiveness of your product.

They buy courses and never open them. They ask for a refund or
chargeback after doing 1% of the work.

These are the terminally ill. They were never gonna make it
anyway. And you’re better at spending their money than they are,
right?

The second reason success rates decline is because it’s fucking
difficult to manage hundreds (or thousands) of customers.

Many won’t get the support they need unless they proactively seek
it out.

Plus in some situations, teaching a large batch of people the
same methods to start a business can make those methods less
successful.

Does this make selling info products immoral or evil?

Here’s the flip side:

Let’s say 100 people buy a course that teaches them how to start
a marketing agency.

95 people give up after a few months and lose the few hundred or
few thousand dollars they’d spent on the course.

But 5 people actually commit to building this business.

6 months to a year later, they’ve completely changed their lives.
They’ve quit their 9-5s, dropped out of college, and paid off
their parents' medical bills.

Fast forward a few years, and one of them has amassed millions of
dollars.

That person now employs a dozen people, supports their family,
and inspires thousands of others online.

So, was that worth it?

Sure, a little blood was spilled, but think about all the good
that came out of it.

And after all, who are we to be judges of morality?

If you read this far, hit reply and let me know what you think.

Two last things for you:

1. Enrollment for my 1-on-1 & small group consulting is closing
in a few days.

​Go here to apply before the deadline on Sunday. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hro0lvvh5h03lpkll/p8heh9hz4rxzlkhq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vZ3JvdXA=
)​

2. Internet Kids clothing is back.

​Check it out here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hro0lvvh5h03lpkll/6qheh8h7lxo7d5to/aHR0cHM6Ly9zaG9waW50ZXJuZXRraWRzLmNvbS8=
)​

Good chat today my friend,

Ben

​

subject: I paid $20k for this advice
body:
I’m in a coaching program by a guy named Jeremy Haynes. I pay
about $20k per year to be in the group.

He hosts a quarterly mastermind at his house in Miami, where
he’ll have a handful of speakers talk about a variety of topics
and give a presentation of his own.

If you were reading my emails earlier this month, you may
remember me saying that he invited me to speak.

I gave my presentation this morning.

Here are some things that I found interesting from giving my own
talk and some of the other speakers today:

- Most of the time, you’ll be glad you said “yes” to doing things
you initially felt resistance towards.

Whether it’s a business opportunity, speaking at an event, or
saying yes to the voice in your head that tells you to go up to
the pretty girl.

The more you can overcome that resistance, the more it loses its
power, and you’ll laugh that you were ever nervous.

- You do not need to be back against the wall to find motivation.
You need to manufacture internal dialogue that tells you to make
more money.

It’s easy to be inspired when you have no other options. But as
you find success, you need to move out of “survival mode,” and
your vision needs to get bigger.

Set goals and envision a lifestyle that gives you a reason to
make more money – especially if you have enough money to live
comfortably for the next 3 years sitting in your checking
account.

- Your current reality is a lagging indicator of your previous
actions and habits.

The future version of you 6 months – 1 year – and 10 years down
the line is the result of what you do today.

Figure out what you want that future to look like and reverse
engineer the daily actions you need to take to make it
inevitable.

The three lessons above may sound basic or elementary to you, but
most of the time, we don’t need revolutionary new advice.

We need to be reminded of the fundamental elements that lead to
success and we need to actually practice them.

These masterminds always remind me how small I’m playing and how
much further I have to go.

If you feel an equal need to get substantially richer, the
application for my 1-on-1 and small group consulting is closing
tomorrow.

No pressure and no fake scarcity, but this is one of your last
chances to apply before our calls start on Monday.

​Go here now to learn about The Bader Group. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9hov5rmvclhwe50x55/7qh7h8ho9l3qmraz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vZ3JvdXA=
)​

I’m exhausted so apologies for the lack of personality in this
one, but hope you liked it.

Need moor monies,

Ben

​

subject: Four lokos and the secrets of the universe
body:
I met a homeless man while restocking on zyns a few minutes ago.

He wasn’t all the way there mentally, but enough to tell me his
name was David and make some small talk that didn’t necessarily
confide within the usual “weather and sportsball” chit-chat.

He first told me that God had answered his prayers and that he
was going to see his family in 13 days.

We walked towards the back of the rundown 7/11 together to get
him a “brew.”

He said he was from New York, and that word was a part of their
slang.

In this case, “brew” meant a large gold four loko (which is
utterly insane to be drinking casually).

As we made our way back to the counter, he told me that he’d
spent 15 years in prison for trafficking cocaine, and it’d been
tough ever since.

“I thought I was God, and it was a big mistake,” he exclaimed.

I told him I’d been there (not prison but rather feeling
immortal).

It was a refreshing interaction.

Although the cards may not have fallen in his favor, he was in
good spirits and seemed excited to enjoy the brew and pack of
Newports I’d just bought him.

On my way home, I walked by Myron (fresh and fit guy) and Sneako
filming a video.

They’d set up a table and chairs on the street corner with a sign
that read “Why women deserve less.”

As I walked by, a bus full of large, screaming women drove past
slowly.

It’s one of those 2 story party buses that blasts music through
the street.

My friend Mason has coined them the “brokie buses.”

I think we all appreciated the perfect irony as they panned the
camera from the “Why women deserve less” sign to the brokie bus
full of hippos.

I’m sure that made for good content.

Anyway, I’m excited for the coming week.

Life has a way of reminding you of what you need to hear at the
perfect time – if you’re open to receiving it.

It’ll guide you in the right direction when you’re looking for
answers and shoot you down when you’re flying too close to the
sun.

The more I’ve relied on intuition and divine guidance, the more I
see how everything is connected.

Your relationships, work, habits, and even quick interactions
with homeless people.

It’s all intertwined and likely relaying an important message if
you’re cognizant enough to receive it.

Have a killer week, and don’t participate in drug trafficking,

Ben

P.S. Let me know if you read this one :)

​

subject: Have you been in Vogue?
body:
I forgot my headphones today.

This is one of the many minor inconveniences that come with
living in a box 30-something floors up in the middle of a city.

I realized I’d forgotten my headphones the second I got off the
elevator.

But at that point, I’d already taken the trek down.

Am I really gonna click the button to go back up, stand there
like a wagie, and bobble my head to the non-existent elevator
music back up to my room?

No. I’m a man.

However, the crying baby in the coffee shop is making me
reconsider this decision.

I think when I have kids, I’ll be out of their lives until they
turn 4 or 5.

At that point, I think they’re supposed to be potty trained, and
I can start breeding them to go to the NBA.

This is why I like tall girls. We’ll make a bunch of future
all-stars and live vicariously through them as I grow old and
start taking TRTs so I can keep up with my much younger model
wife.

Hahaha.

Speaking of girls, I’ve been reflecting on some things I’ve
learned about dating recently.

First, women are amazing.

Nearly every girl I meet is pleasant to be around and has their
own unique vibe (if they’re comfortable enough to show that side
of themself to you).

Don’t listen to the losers who tell you Western women are ruined.

Sure, not every girl you meet is gonna be a potential wife, and
that’s okay.

Understanding this allows you to appreciate them for who they are
and simply have fun.

It also gives you a more complete perspective on what qualities
you look for in someone you would take more seriously and
potentially date.

Next, take it slowwwwwww.

If you scroll through TikTok, you’ll see “dating coaches” say
that you need to commit to someone within 1-3 months.

This is absolutely crazy in my opinion. Normalize 6-12 month
talking stages. Sometimes longer.

Seriously.

It takes time to get to know someone. There are many things
you’ll learn about them that will only come out over time.

Rushing into a relationship is a surefire way that it’ll go up in
flames.

And no, this isn’t just a way to keep your freedom and avoid
exclusivity.

It ensures that you guys actually know each other before you put
a label on it. Because that label will only complicate things.

Little fights turn into UFC matches (not physically, I hope) and
if the foundation of the relationship isn’t rock solid, it’ll
collapse.

Last thing and most important one.

If you’re a girl reading this, you should stop here. I’m sorry it
has to be this way, but it does.

The solution to 99% of your “girl problems” is solved by having…

options.

Lots of them. 3 Barbies, 2 Cinderellas, a Tinekerbell, and maybe
a Harley Quinn or 3.

This sounds bad when I say it out loud like this, but I’m doing
so for a reason:

Detachment.

Neediness has to be the #1 turn-off for women. And when she’s
your only option, she can feel it.

Women are intuitive little creatures. They’re actually harder to
deceive than men.

When you’re someone who truly has options, you care less about
losing one of them, and it changes your entire demeanor.

You’re not a dancing monkey trying to impress her. You’re you.

They’ll never admit it, but they like a man with options.

Crucify me. But I’m right.

Ok, enough for today. Lmk if you liked my takes on this topic and
want to hear more.

Take a pretty model on a date tonight,

Ben

P.S. One of my subscribers suggested I take my old emails and
basically turn them into a little blog. Any suggestions or ideas
on how to do this (platforms, organization, etc.)?

​

snippet: Why having 17 model wives will help you in your journey of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

subject: Have you been in Vogue?
body:
I forgot my headphones today. 

 This is one of the many minor inconveniences that come with living in a box 30-something floors up in the middle of a city. 

 I realized I’d forgotten my headphones the second I got off the elevator. 

 But at that point, I’d already taken the trek down. 

 Am I really gonna click the button to go back up, stand there like a wagie, and bobble my head to the non-existent elevator music back up to my room? 

 No. I’m a man. 

 However, the crying baby in the coffee shop is making me reconsider this decision. 

 I think when I have kids, I’ll be out of their lives until they turn 4 or 5. 

 At that point, I think they’re supposed to be potty trained, and I can start breeding them to go to the NBA. 

 This is why I like tall girls. We’ll make a bunch of future all-stars and live vicariously through them as I grow old and start taking TRTs so I can keep up with my much younger model wife. 

 Hahaha. 

 Speaking of girls, I’ve been reflecting on some things I’ve learned about dating recently. 

 First, women are amazing. 

 Nearly every girl I meet is pleasant to be around and has their own unique vibe (if they’re comfortable enough to show that side of themself to you). 

 Don’t listen to the losers who tell you Western women are ruined. 

 Sure, not every girl you meet is gonna be a potential wife, and that’s okay. 

 Understanding this allows you to appreciate them for who they are and simply have fun. 

 It also gives you a more complete perspective on what qualities you look for in someone you would take more seriously and potentially date. 

 Next, take it slowwwwwww. 

 If you scroll through TikTok, you’ll see “dating coaches” say that you need to commit to someone within 1-3 months. 

 This is absolutely crazy in my opinion. Normalize 6-12 month talking stages. Sometimes longer. 

 Seriously. 

 It takes time to get to know someone. There are many things you’ll learn about them that will only come out over time. 

 Rushing into a relationship is a surefire way that it’ll go up in flames. 

 And no, this isn’t just a way to keep your freedom and avoid exclusivity. 

 It ensures that you guys actually know each other before you put a label on it. Because that label will only complicate things. 

 Little fights turn into UFC matches (not physically, I hope) and if the foundation of the relationship isn’t rock solid, it’ll collapse. 

 Last thing and most important one. 

 If you’re a girl reading this, you should stop here. I’m sorry it has to be this way, but it does. 

 The solution to 99% of your “girl problems” is solved by having… 

 options. 

 Lots of them. 3 Barbies, 2 Cinderellas, a Tinekerbell, and maybe a Harley Quinn or 3. 

 This sounds bad when I say it out loud like this, but I’m doing so for a reason: 

 Detachment. 

 Neediness has to be the #1 turn-off for women. And when she’s your only option, she can feel it. 

 Women are intuitive little creatures. They’re actually harder to deceive than men. 

 When you’re someone who truly has options, you care less about losing one of them, and it changes your entire demeanor. 

 You’re not a dancing monkey trying to impress her. You’re you. 

 They’ll never admit it, but they like a man with options. 

 Crucify me. But I’m right. 

 Ok, enough for today. Lmk if you liked my takes on this topic and want to hear more. 

 Take a pretty model on a date tonight, 

 Ben 

 P.S. One of my subscribers suggested I take my old emails and basically turn them into a little blog. Any suggestions or ideas on how to do this (platforms, organization, etc.)? 

 ​

subject: Tend your own garden
body:
It was my 6 month anniversary with my wife yesterday.

We’re not dating, and we break up every three days.

But I was appalled by the absence of “Happy Anniversary” messages
I got from my loyal subscribers.

Extremely rude of you bo, but I guess we can move past it.

I want to make a documentary called “Normies In The Wild.”

It’d be a compilation of people freaking out while trying to
navigate basic human tasks.

Have you ever observed the mid-IQ wagies in airports? Or coffee
shops? Merging onto a highway?

It’s like their systems get overloaded, and they revert to monkey
brains, where they just start making sounds and looking for
bananas.

Anyway, let’s talk about more important things.

Imagine you’re building yourself a car.

You get all the parts you need and spend countless hours
configuring your vehicle.

Finally, you’re ready to hit the road.

You hop in and start driving.

At first, it’s great. You’re excited to finally enjoy the fruits
of your labor.

But after a few hundred miles, the engine starts making a strange
noise.

You pull over and pop the hood.

It’s a minor problem, and you know exactly what you need to do to
fix it.

You close the hood and tell yourself you’ll fix it later.

As you continue driving, you see another car and are immediately
enamored.

“That’s the kind of car I want,” you think to yourself.

When you get home, you order parts and set out to build it.

Over the next few months, you start neglecting car #1, and the
minor problem with the engine has turned into a much bigger
issue.

Instead of fixing it, you spend all your time building a new car.

And finally, once your “perfect” car is ready, you hit the road.
And the cycle continues. You see a new car you like better,
neglect your own, and start all over.

See where I’m going with this?

This is how many of us treat our businesses, relationships, and a
variety of other endeavors.

We spend so much time laying the foundation for what could be
something special.

But once the novelty wears off and we realize the constant
maintenance that’s necessary for continuous progression, we start
looking for the "new thing."

Instead of putting our feet on the gas and maximizing what’s in
front of us, we let what we’ve built deteriorate so that we can
have an excuse to start all over.

It’s a familiar comfort. It allows for the illusion of
productivity. But it keeps you stuck.

And don’t you want to find out how far you can go if you can
resist the urge to turn your head every time you see a new girl
in a red dress?

Water your own plants. Today, tomorrow, and especially in 6
months when it’s no longer as exciting.

Thx for reading,

Ben

​

subject: Don't be dumb, get rich
body:
Fuck it’s only 9:49 am.

I haven’t even been here for 2 hours yet, and I’m already
counting down the time until I can leave… Gonna be a long week.

This is how I remember Mondays sitting in class.

Odds are you can relate, and maybe those thoughts are going on in
your head as you read this if you’re in school or at a job you
don’t like.

Side note: There’s about $600,000 worth of Patek Phillipes on the
wrists of the two men sitting across from me at the coffee shop
right now.

Let’s talk about money.

Odds are, it’s at the forefront of your mind.

It’s the reason why you’re living the life that you are right
now.

Whether that reality aligns with what you want or not is
completely on you.

Before I had money, I hated Mondays.

Today, I woke up at 7:31 am, got dressed, and walked over to the
coffee shop to knock out some work and write this email.

I enjoy this routine.

My life has gotten exceptionally better as I've made more money,
and I’m still relatively poor.

The lesson I have for you today is this:

You owe it to yourself to make money.

You owe it to yourself not to have to think about money.

You owe it to yourself to be able to live wherever you want, with
whoever you want, and actualize the lifestyle you dreamt of while
you were naive enough to think you could do anything.

And you will never be able to experience the full spectrum of
what life has to offer if you’re trapped worrying about expenses.

But I have good news:

Making money is easy.

All you have to do is crack the “money code” once.

Develop a skill set that people are willing to pay you for…

Or learn how to build and sell products…

Or solve some other niche problem for people.

Boom, now you have some kind of value to add to the financial
ecosystem that you can sell repeatedly.

Do that until rich.

You don’t have to be exceptionally smart, creative, or ingenious.

You just have to be stupid enough to not be stupid.

Action. Action. Action.

That’s it. Don’t be stupid.

This email is especially simple to prove to you that I am no
smarter than you.

All of my friends are relatively rich.

And all of my friends are likey no smarter than you either.

Do not be dumb. Get rich. It’s easy.

Enough motivation for today.

Gonna go do things that will make me money!

I recommend you do the same :)

Ben

​

subject: You are that guy (or girl i guess)
body:
Gm.

When was the last time you thought about how lucky you were to be
alive?

I’ve found that I’m usually more grateful in times of stress or
when I feel like things aren’t going my way.

It’s these times that force you to zoom out.

You’ll be beating yourself up, feeling like the walls are caving
in, and then boom - you have a glimpse of consciousness that puts
it all in perspective.

And you realize that your problems are amazing problems to have.

Maybe you don’t want to hear this right now.

Maybe you think I’m turning into a life coach who lives in Bali
and makes $3k/mo selling breathwork classes.

But let's just take a second to appreciate what we have.

…

On to today’s lesson.

Developing magnetism in yourself will change your life.

It’s not something you’re necessarily conscious of but rather a
byproduct of living your life a certain way.

You know people who seem just to have this special aura about
them?

It makes you respect them and want to be around them. They lift
your energy and make you feel better about yourself.

Recently, I’ve noticed that people generally perceive me quite
positively.

I’ll get random invites to things, girls will pursue me to an
extent, service workers love me, and I have absolutely amazing
friends in my life.

I’m not saying this to gloat here.

I’ve had times in my life where it feels like I’ve been perceived
as the exact opposite of what I just described above.

If I had to boil down what’s changed for me into one word, it’d
be this:

Expression.

People like it when they can be themselves. They like it when
they know they’re not gonna be judged or used for some ulterior
motive.

And the easiest way to get people into this state is to be in it
yourself.

When you’re truly you – you say what you want, you’re honest,
you’re observant… it creates this genuine look in your eyes and
your smile.

People can just sense it.

But this is only developed when you cultivate enough respect for
yourself to stop suppressing who you really are.

So let me remind you:

You are uniquely you.

You’ve overcome every hurdle you’ve encountered.

You’ve relied on yourself in times of hardship and uncertainty.

And you got yourself through it.

There's a voice inside you that knows the way.

That trusts you fully.
That accepts you for who you are.

You owe it to that voice to bring it to life.

And when you do – you deserve the world.

Be you, bo.

Love ya,

Ben

​

subject: Life is working
body:
Sorry for the week-long hiatus, but I’m back.

It’s been frigid the last few days in Miami, like mid 50’s- low
60’s cold.

I’m going to New York tomorrow, and I don’t imagine it’ll be any
warmer there.

Such a tough life!

I can’t remember if I’ve told you about one of my friends who
works in my building.

He’s a Hispanic dude in his early 40’s but looks much younger.

We see each other nearly daily, and he talks to me in Spanish as
I nod and smile in confusion.

I don’t know his name so I call him Papi. I genuinely think he’s
the happiest person I know.

Papi always has a smile on his face and just radiates energy that
lets you know he’s grateful to be alive.

Yesterday in the elevator I told him I just went to the gym (fui
al gimnasio) and was about to get work done (voy a trabajo).

In English he said, “Life is working.”

Papi probably knows a total of 100 words in the English
dictionary, but those three together can be quite powerful.

I recently realized that I’d developed a bad habit.

No matter how great things are, I’m constantly pondering every
detail of my life – even the things I already understand and have
no reason to be stressing about.

“How am I gonna make more money?”

“How is this relationship gonna work out?”

“Why don’t I feel the way I anticipated when I envisioned the
lifestyle I’m living now?”

“What do I need to change?”

All I’m doing as I think about these things is reinforcing the
idea that there is some future Utopia that I don’t have access to
right now.

No bueno.

Most of us need to think less and do more.

You can analyze and reflect once you reach the top of the
mountain.

But until then,

Feet on gas.

Head down.

Quiet mind.

Life is working.

Thanks for reading - glad to be back.

Talk soon,

Ben

​

subject: 3 steps to life-maxxing
body:
I saw my ex today.

She’s not really my ex because I never asked her to be my
girlfriend, but nonetheless, we shared a lot of time together and
many amazing memories.

Seeing her from across the restaurant that we used to go to
together was strange.

We waved and briefly said hello as she walked by on her way out.

I got back from a 4-day bender in New York yesterday.

We didn’t do much other than go to dinner and the club with the
20 girls (literally) that we brought, but it was fun for obvious
reasons.

My sincere apologies for neglecting you over the last two weeks.

Over the last 6 months, my lifestyle has taken a complete 180.

I barely went out during the first 10 months I lived in Miami.

While I had a circle of a few close friends, I was never the one
to initiate the plans or make an effort to find exciting things
to do.

After a while, it started feeling like I wasn’t my own person.

I became an extension of my friend group, who lacked his own
interests, hobbies, and network.

And most of my nights were spent sitting at my desk with a lit
candle and some music in the background, clicking buttons on my
computer.

Now, nights like this are rare, and I have an added appreciation
for them.

While the work I did during the time when I lacked a social life
laid the groundwork for us getting to 6 figure months with my
agency, life feels a lot fuller now.

I’m sure there will be a time when I go back to being a bit more
of a hobbit, but this work-hard, play-hard lifestyle is much more
enjoyable for my current stage.

Here are some of the things I did that allowed me to build a fun
social life while continuing to grow my business:

1. Delegation

I sent a $30,000 wire to a team member/friend today.

Bringing him on was one of the best decisions I’ve made.

It’s made it much easier for me, freed up my time, and the
quality of work we’re able to deliver has improved.

After all, money is just a number on a screen until you put it to
use.

If you’re unwilling to sacrifice some margin, have fun being
trapped at your desk all day.

2. Branching out

I went out of my way to make new friends and build a bigger
network in Miami.

Once I met one or two well-connected people, it created a
snowball effect in my social life.

Outside of just my network, I started to “branch out” by taking
up new hobbies, like boxing and tennis.

Finding new interests and hobbies like this helped me reinvent my
perception of myself.

This helped reshape my identity and made me feel like I had more
exciting things going on in my life.

3. Social media

If you go look at my Instagram toward the end of July, you can
see a shift occur.

Even my facial expression and demeanor appear more confident in
more recent photos.

I know it may sound superficial, but putting effort into making a
better-looking Instagram and posting consistently on TikTok has
opened so many doors and brought me a world of connections.

These three things helped me enter a version of myself that I
couldn’t access previously.

My lifestyle is exactly the way I envisioned it when I pictured
living in Miami.

Although this is just a “side quest” to the main mission (getting
disgustingly rich), it’s brought me a lot of clarity and taught
me lessons that I couldn’t have learned at my desk.

Cheers to life-maxxing.

Call your ex today,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you read this whole thing and happy early
Valentines Day baby

​

body:

 We waved and briefly said hello as she walked by on her way out.

subject: You create your problems on purpose
body:
The “make money online” info-product space is starting to give me
a headache.

Everyone is teaching things that they’ve never done to naive
beginners who have a better shot at getting struck by lightning
than they do to succeed with whatever business model they’re
being sold on.

Am I bitter that some of the people selling these courses are
making more money than me?

Yes.

But as you frequently see people do online, I’ll take the moral
high ground in order to opt out of feeling envy.

I just want to print cash by writing words in a cafe for a few
hours daily.

No fulfillment, no calls, no community.

Just cold hard course content.

Recently, I’ve had 692 things on my mind at any given moment.

I’ve found creative ways to stress about things that don’t need
to be stressed about.

You know how sometimes you’ll have days when you’re constantly
anxious and feel like the world is ending?

It’s interesting to observe yourself on these days.

You’ll realize that you’re repeating the same negative thought
pattern repeatedly.

Whatever you’re thinking about likely only requires a few minutes
of consideration, but you let it consume your mind all day.

Next thing you know, you’re super stressed out for no reason.

And it’s almost like you enjoy this stress.

I guess feeling something is better than feeling nothing.

This brings me back to a topic I frequently revisit: Acceptance.

When will you learn to accept what is?

You’re creating problems out of boredom.

It’s like you’re taking out a magnifying lens and analyzing a
painting to see if you can find any tiny flaws.

Once you find them, you obsess over them, even though they only
account for less than 1% of the entire portrait.

Now you’re distracted.

You can’t focus on what really matters.

You start neglecting the things that you know are good for you.

And now that your attention is scattered, you can’t show up as
the full, present version of yourself because a large portion of
who you are is trapped inside your own head.

The solution?

Idk. Maybe write an email about it.

Tends to help me.

I hop this one made sense. I have to get on a call and don’t have
time to proofread or revise it.

I WILL send you an email tomorrow (maybe),

Ben

​

subject: Dumb = Rich
body:
I’ve been grinding all morning and am now trying to switch my
brain back to creative mode to write this email.

This would be a lot easier with a zyn, but I quit (again) 3 days
ago.

One thing I’ve realized recently is that everyone is dumb.

Even smart people.

Actually, especially smart people.

All of the rich young dudes that you see on social media are
likely no more intelligent than you.

They’re unorganized, naive, and negligent.

The key to their success is simplicity.

They have a few personality traits and skills that allow them to
thrive – and they’re dumb enough to double down on those two
things.

Yesterday, I was telling a friend how the majority of advice I
give to people who are trying to scale their agency or coaching
program goes as follows:

Me: “What have you done that’s worked so far?”

Agency guy: “I got 3 clients by sending cold DMs.”

Coaching guy: “I sold 5 people who found me on TikTok.”

Me: “Okay, do more of that.”

Do you see how stupidly simple this is?

But it’s literally the secret.

Find something that works – do it a lot.

The same thing goes for your day-to-day life.

Highs and lows are natural.

I’ll have part of my day where I feel like the world is ending
and other parts where everything seems perfect.

I know that I am in a better mental state when I occupy my mind
with productive tasks.

The more progress I make, the less stressed I become and the
better I feel.

I think the key here is identifying your non-negotiable daily
habits that keep you sane.

For me, some of these are writing, making content, journaling,
walking, and boxing or lifting.

No matter what, you won’t be in a peak mental state every day –
that’s just not realistic.

But if you identify a few things that keep you at least around a
6 or 7 out of 10 each day, and you’re consistent with them, you
can decrease the power of the tide in your emotional state.

This email is kind of a culmination of half-baked ideas, but I
gotta go meet a friend for lunch, so we’re gonna end this here
for today.

Talk tomorrow, thx for reading,

Ben

​

subject: Who are you competing with?
body:
Yesterday, I saw a clip of Johnny Manziel talking about how
depressed he was during his first couple of years playing in the
NFL.

He said Lebron, who was his childhood hero, would call him a few
times a week to hang out, and he’d decline because he didn’t want
to leave the house.

Looking at this from the outside in, here’s what I gather:

Once you begin to get the things you want, you gradually
internalize that they won’t change anything.

By “things you want,” I don't just mean material items or
lifestyle, but also your outward perception.

You can get all the praise, respect, and validation.

You can be the guy other dudes envy and girls want to be with.

This comes with a lot of pressure, which can break you if your
self-image isn’t rock solid.

The expectations of others start to weigh on you, and your
standards rise to a level that takes a lot to maintain.

If you feel undeserving, you manifest that idea into reality.

Your motivation dwindles, you lack discipline, and you start to
let your problems add up.

“You can’t outperform your self-image.”

The weight of the contrast between how others perceive you versus
how you perceive yourself causes you to crumble.

That make sense?

Anyway, a guy in front of me at this coffee shop is reading the
book “7 Habits Of Highly Effective People.”

He’s mouthing the words as he reads, which I find interesting.

When I walked in to order my coffee, the barista told me she
liked my hoodie and replied, “Ben 10” when I told her my name was
Ben.

I found that endearing, so I gave her the Van Cleef bracelet off
my wrist.

One time, I sat next to Johnny Manziel at dinner (I think I told
you about that in an email months ago).

Not long after, he DM’d the girl I was with that night.

Shooters shoot, I guess.

Last thing – Yesterday, I was journaling and asked myself, “What
would make your life better than it is right now?”

It was easy to come up with an answer to that question, and I
found it interesting that my answer had little to do with more
money or anything flashy.

I encourage you to ask yourself the same thing when you have 20
min today.

Thanks for reading, and hope you enjoyed,

Ben

​

subject: Self improvement doesn't work
body:
Spotify and I haven’t been getting along recently.

Sometimes, I’ll hit shuffle and it’ll give me one banger after
another.

Other times, it force-feeds me the same 6 songs until my mind
goes numb from the repetition.

For the last few weeks, it’s been the latter.

Per usual I’m sitting at an ultra-liberal, hipster coffee shop,
hoping that I’ll get a good idea to write about before I bore
you.

There’s a bulletin board of post-it notes in front of me with a
bunch of Pinterest-esque quotes.

“Be happy! Enjoy 2024”

“You are loved!”

“Smile! Today’s a great day”

Outside the quotes, a combination of people likely identify as
“creatives” are promoting their work.

“Need graphics? DM me on Instagram! @arthoe6969”

There are over 100 sticky notes and “business” cards on here.

Plus a lost cat flyer in the top right corner.

In the middle, nearly covered up by the self-love propaganda,
there’s a note that says, “Be here now.”

Probably a lesson in there.

Being present is something that’s a constant battle for me.

Two summers ago, I was on a beach in Greece, watching the sunset
with a bunch of friends.

Instead of admiring the view, I was stuck in my head, stressing
over whatever was happening in my business then.

I remember looking around at my friends and wondering if they
were thinking about something else too, or if I was just broken.

Last night, a client of ours ran a webinar (where we made over
$100k) and was asked the question:

“How do you deal with stress as an entrepreneur?”

He said, “I don’t… Nothing that I do is stressful,” and moved on
to the next question.

As simple as this answer was, I found it interesting.

What you give your attention to grows.

The people who wrote these stupid little quotes on the board in
front of me are probably unhappy.

They’re so obsessed with positive affirmations – and fearful of
anxiety, that they bring their fears to fruition.

The “self-love” reminders attempt to convince themselves that
they don’t hate themselves.

A happy person doesn’t need a reminder to be happy. They just
are.

It’s almost like when you’re overly conscious about improving
your mental health, it has an inverse effect.

Dictating how you feel can be as simple as making a decision.

Simply decide not to stress over something, stop giving it power,
and it goes away.

When my client on the webinar was asked that question, it was
like the idea of stress didn’t even exist in his world… he was
almost confused.

And, after all, worrying and over-analyzing do nothing but
exacerbate the problem.

Maybe the answer is to bE hEre noW!

Corny but true.

I’m gonna start meditating.

Hope you and your Spotify shuffle get along today,

Ben

​

subject: Self improvement doesn't work
body:
Spotify and I haven’t been getting along recently. 

 Sometimes, I’ll hit shuffle and it’ll give me one banger after another. 

 Other times, it force-feeds me the same 6 songs until my mind goes numb from the repetition. 

 For the last few weeks, it’s been the latter. 

 Per usual I’m sitting at an ultra-liberal, hipster coffee shop, hoping that I’ll get a good idea to write about before I bore you. 

 There’s a bulletin board of post-it notes in front of me with a bunch of Pinterest-esque quotes. 

 “Be happy! Enjoy 2024” 

 “You are loved!” 

 “Smile! Today’s a great day” 

 Outside the quotes, a combination of people likely identify as “creatives” are promoting their work. 

 “Need graphics? DM me on Instagram! @arthoe6969” 

 There are over 100 sticky notes and “business” cards on here. 

 Plus a lost cat flyer in the top right corner. 

 In the middle, nearly covered up by the self-love propaganda, there’s a note that says, “Be here now.” 

 Probably a lesson in there. 

 Being present is something that’s a constant battle for me. 

 Two summers ago, I was on a beach in Greece, watching the sunset with a bunch of friends. 

 Instead of admiring the view, I was stuck in my head, stressing over whatever was happening in my business then. 

 I remember looking around at my friends and wondering if they were thinking about something else too, or if I was just broken. 

 Last night, a client of ours ran a webinar (where we made over $100k) and was asked the question: 

 “How do you deal with stress as an entrepreneur?” 

 He said, “I don’t… Nothing that I do is stressful,” and moved on to the next question. 

 As simple as this answer was, I found it interesting. 

 What you give your attention to grows. 

 The people who wrote these stupid little quotes on the board in front of me are probably unhappy. 

 They’re so obsessed with positive affirmations – and fearful of anxiety, that they bring their fears to fruition. 

 The “self-love” reminders attempt to convince themselves that they don’t hate themselves. 

 A happy person doesn’t need a reminder to be happy. They just are. 

 It’s almost like when you’re overly conscious about improving your mental health, it has an inverse effect. 

 Dictating how you feel can be as simple as making a decision. 

 Simply decide not to stress over something, stop giving it power, and it goes away. 

 When my client on the webinar was asked that question, it was like the idea of stress didn’t even exist in his world… he was almost confused. 

 And, after all, worrying and over-analyzing do nothing but exacerbate the problem. 

 Maybe the answer is to bE hEre noW! 

 Corny but true. 

 I’m gonna start meditating. 

 Hope you and your Spotify shuffle get along today, 

 Ben 

 ​

subject: it is what it should be
body:
I got multiple messages today asking when I’d write my next
newsletter.

It made me feel bad for neglecting you, so here we are.

My sleep schedule is out of whack after a few late nights in
Puerto Rico.

Here’s a thought that’s been rattling around in my brain:

We make decisions based on how we feel in the moment.

If you ask a girl to marry you after a long night of fighting
because you told her that her sister is hot, she’ll probably say
no.

On the flip side, your chances are much higher if you propose
during a romantic dinner on the Amalfi Coast while listening to
old Frank Sinatra music.

Similarly, your potential customers must be put into a buying
state when you ask them to purchase your product.

That’s why webinars have worked so well for our clients.

Every slide in the presentation is strategically placed to steer
them into an emotional high.

They need to feel understood, they need to understand, and they
need to believe.

Meaning you’ve demonstrated that you empathize with their pain
points and their exact dilemma.

You’ve broken down how your method works, and they’re confident
in it being the vehicle that will take them from pain to
pleasure.

Lastly, you’ve put them into a state where they’re hopeful they
can overcome their previously held limiting beliefs.

And just like that, they’re ready to pull out their wallet when
presented with the right offer.

When you want someone to do something, it’s your job to
understand how they feel in the current moment.

Even the words on this page are reflective of the current state
I’m in.

Switching gears a bit, life is beautiful.

Do not miss it.

Do not take it for granted.

Do not tell yourself something is missing, as you will always
find something to look for.

The thing you are looking for is you.

You have the power to bend reality to your will.

A few years ago, I was at a frat party, looking around at
everyone happily drinking, and I remember this moment when the
lights turned on in my brain.

I had no purpose and was going down a route that would lead me to
a lifetime of emptiness.

In that instant, I decided I’d change my path.

Fast forward to now; these past few days have felt like a movie.

I celebrated my friend's birthday with amazing people, took a jet
to and from PR, and hopped in my dream car to drive to dinner at
Carbone.

It’s all possible, my friend.

And when you get here, don’t forget to enjoy it.

Goodnight,

Ben

​

subject: The opposite of locked in
body:
* { word-break: break-word; }

Happy Friday bo,

I wrote this one yesterday and forgot to send it once I got to my
hotel, so I am sending it now.

Enjoy

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I’m on a flight to LA right now.

I land in about 30 minutes and have spent the last 4 hours
finding clever ways to procrastinate writing this email.

It started with the usual scroll through social media, but that
can only last so long.

So I got creative. I took a personality quiz, changed my return
flight, got ahead on some work, and did enough research on LA
restaurants that I could write one of those gay “Top 10 MUST TRY
spots in LA” blog posts.

Just so you know, I’m in seat 1A. There’s no reason for me to
tell you this, but I figured I’d tell you anyway.

Let’s talk about money and identity.

When I first started making some money a few years ago, my mental
well-being became entirely reliant on my monthly income.

When I’d hit a new all-time high, I’d be over the moon.

I was more confident, I spoke with conviction, and I generally
felt and acted much more positively.

Conversely, when my monthly income stagnated or regressed, I lost
all confidence and was in a constant state of panic.

When I’d talk to people, I wasn’t really there. I was physically
there, but my mind would drift, drowning out the person who was
talking with my own thoughts.

These times were interesting.

This fight-or-flight mode wasn’t pleasant, but I think it helped
me progress quicker.

All I thought about was business.

Recently, it’s been the opposite. I honestly don’t know if it’s
been a good or bad month for the agency numbers-wise.

We did help a client make $400k in 4 days recently which was
pretty cool.

He paid us our commission in crypto, so I threw all that money
into a meme coin.

Back to the main point - I’ve been the opposite of “locked in”
recently.

Locked out?

Opened in?

Not sure of the correct term.

Everyone loves to act like they’re always working so hard.

This may cause you to feel like you constantly need to be at war,
as it did for me.

It also meant my self-image was tied to my income.

While I think that can be a good thing to an extent, it’s a
hamster wheel that no amount of money can get you off of.

Sure, if you’re not growing, you’re dying — but growth can come
in many forms.

It doesn’t always mean you’re doubling your monthly income or
spending 12 hours a day at your desk.

Maybe it means you’re traveling more, building deeper
relationships, beating your friend Jimmy in 2K, etc.

Simply side questing.

And know there will be a time when you need to lock back in.

You can’t just coast forever — but sometimes, momentary coasting
can help you return to work with an added excitement.

Or at least that’s what I’m telling myself.

I'm about to land and gotta wrap this up, but there is one last
thing I want to add…

*Everything I just said does not apply to you if you don’t have
enough money to fulfill the immediate image that pops into your
head when you think about having money.

For me, that image is the exact life I’m living now.

I imagine for me to find the motivation to push beyond where I’m
at now, that vision must evolve.

Ok, I just landed. Gotta go. Missed you, let me know if this one
made sense to you.

Bye from 1A,

Ben

​

subject: Why you need to get punched in the face
body:
I just got home from sparring with my boxing coach.

We were going pretty light, though he caught me in the head a few
times.

Maybe I’m a weirdo, but it feels really good to get hit in the
face.

We’ll be trading punches, somewhat messing around until boom…

I’ll move the wrong way and position my face perfectly into his
jab.

There’s this feeling of aliveness that comes after that moment.

It’s like a signal goes through my brain that says, “Okay, time
to lock in,” while I simultaneously realize that I’m not going to
die.

Immediately after, I enter a new state where I’m much more
free-flowing, and my energy is revitalized.

I’m ready to attack because once that first punch connects with
my nose, I’m no longer scared of it.

I know I’m gonna be okay no matter what.

There’s an equally powerful lesson in there that we can
extrapolate to life.

Sometimes, you have to let yourself get rocked.

When you’re comfortable at a certain income level or have enough
money in the bank to where you wouldn't have to work for the next
couple of years…

You have to punch yourself.

You’re trying to live comfortably and ignore the possibility that
reality could rock you with a right hook if you’re too slow.

Over the last few months, I completed the vision that I’d been
aiming at for a while.

My business reached six-figure months, I bought my dream car, my
social life was thriving, and I was living in the exact movie
that I used to dream of.

After a few months of fun, my anxiety started to increase.

I’m not growing. I’m not evolving or working towards anything.

And admittedly, I started to take my foot off the gas.

This life I aspired to attain began to feel empty, and I was left
with the feeling of…

“What now?”

Stagnation served as a punch.

Stay in the same place for too long, and you become predictable.

Become predictable, and you get hit.

But the solution is simple.

You gotta keep moving.

Reach a milestone, great. What's the next level you can get to?

Picture it.

Maybe it’s a house in the hills, more supercars, and the ability
to fly private whenever you want.

Or you don’t want to feel an ounce of anxiety on any purchase
under 6 figures.

You want a penthouse, your girl wants a Birkin, and you want to
put a family member on payroll to do nothing.

Sure many of these are materialistic, but it’s your reality – you
can design it however you’d like.

You’ve just begun to taste freedom. You’re not even scratching
the surface of how you could live, and you’re getting
comfortable.

Don’t rob yourself.

True freedom has no bounds, and the only limits come through your
imagination.

Let your imagination run free, and you’ll create a new movie in
your head that you aspire to live in.

That's your new goal.

Start building towards it now unless you want to wait until you
get knocked on your ass.

And by then, it’ll be a hell of a lot harder to get up.

Thanks for reading, and I promise I’m really back for good this
time.

Lmk if you liked this one,

Ben

​
