subject: How to manifest without being weird
body:
There are some elements of spirituality that I find rather
stupid.

Once upon a time, I hired a “life coach.”

After our first call together, I decided I didn’t need him and
would instead take life advice from myself.

He was one of those meditate in Bali, peace and self-love types.

This is loosely related to the topic of this email, but it popped
into my head when I started thinking about spirituality.

If manifestation and the law of attraction sound a bit out there
to you, I’m gonna try to break down what I believe these concepts
to be as simply as I can.

Your subconscious is constantly working either for or against
you.

When you set goals and intentions, you give your subconscious a
direction to follow.

When you fail to do so, your brain finds another way to occupy
itself that likely isn’t conducive to the reality you want to
build.

The most simple example of this that I see is in my habits and
daily routine.

Making content every day has been a priority of mine for a while.

I’ve noticed I’m the most consistent, and content ideas come to
me easily when I’m intentional.

If I write “tweet 3 times” or “make 2 videos” on my to-do list
for the day, my subconscious starts to help me out.

I’ll be walking to the coffee shop to get an iced vanilla latte
from a blue-haired barista with an Adams apple who calls
him(her?)self Megan, and boom – I’ll get a random idea for a
video.

Could it be a coincidence?

Sure. But nearly every time I set intentions like this,
completing the action becomes easier.

Although this is just one basic example, I hope it’s starting to
illustrate the point.

What you focus on and put your attention toward grows, even if
you’re not conscious of it.

If you’re obsessed with reaching a new income level, your brain
is constantly working on that problem in the background.

You’ll get an idea while you’re driving or doing some other
mindless activity, and it’ll be the key to reaching that next
milestone you’re aiming for.

You might feel like the idea came out of nowhere, but it’s likely
because you’ve given your subconscious something to occupy itself
with.

And eventually, it finds the solution.

The same thing goes for anything that you want in life.

If you can create a clear image of the lifestyle, people you’re
surrounded by, what you’re doing for work, how your routine
looks, and the general way of life you want to build…

And you work towards those things…

The combination of the work and setting intentions will
eventually reach a perfect storm and you’ll feel like everything
somehow ended up exactly how you wanted it.

The way that your goals unfold likely won’t be how you imagined,
but that’s a topic for another email.

Hope you enjoyed this one and it made sense to you.

Happy Friday,

Ben

P.S. I finally compiled my old emails and aded them to this site
(

) – you don’t have to opt in over there, just scroll down to view
previous newsletters.

subject: How to manifest without being weird
body:
There are some elements of spirituality that I find rather stupid. 

 Once upon a time, I hired a “life coach.” 

 After our first call together, I decided I didn’t need him and would instead take life advice from myself. 

 He was one of those meditate in Bali, peace and self-love types. 

 This is loosely related to the topic of this email, but it popped into my head when I started thinking about spirituality. 

 If manifestation and the law of attraction sound a bit out there to you, I’m gonna try to break down what I believe these concepts to be as simply as I can. 

 Your subconscious is constantly working either for or against you. 

 When you set goals and intentions, you give your subconscious a direction to follow. 

 When you fail to do so, your brain finds another way to occupy itself that likely isn’t conducive to the reality you want to build. 

 The most simple example of this that I see is in my habits and daily routine. 

 Making content every day has been a priority of mine for a while. 

 I’ve noticed I’m the most consistent, and content ideas come to me easily when I’m intentional. 

 If I write “tweet 3 times” or “make 2 videos” on my to-do list for the day, my subconscious starts to help me out. 

 I’ll be walking to the coffee shop to get an iced vanilla latte from a blue-haired barista with an Adams apple who calls him(her?)self Megan, and boom – I’ll get a random idea for a video. 

 Could it be a coincidence? 

 Sure. But nearly every time I set intentions like this, completing the action becomes easier. 

 Although this is just one basic example, I hope it’s starting to illustrate the point. 

 What you focus on and put your attention toward grows, even if you’re not conscious of it. 

 If you’re obsessed with reaching a new income level, your brain is constantly working on that problem in the background. 

 You’ll get an idea while you’re driving or doing some other mindless activity, and it’ll be the key to reaching that next milestone you’re aiming for. 

 You might feel like the idea came out of nowhere, but it’s likely because you’ve given your subconscious something to occupy itself with. 

 And eventually, it finds the solution. 

 The same thing goes for anything that you want in life. 

 If you can create a clear image of the lifestyle, people you’re surrounded by, what you’re doing for work, how your routine looks, and the general way of life you want to build… 

 And you work towards those things… 

 The combination of the work and setting intentions will eventually reach a perfect storm and you’ll feel like everything somehow ended up exactly how you wanted it. 

 The way that your goals unfold likely won’t be how you imagined, but that’s a topic for another email. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one and it made sense to you. 

 Happy Friday, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I finally compiled my old emails and aded them to this site – you don’t have to opt in over there, just scroll down to view previous newsletters. 

 ​

subject: Angry normies & how dating is like an iceberg
body:
A large corner of the internet is very angry at me right now because of this tweet. ​

 They’re calling me a scammer posting rage bait to sell my course. 

 If you’ve been around for a while, you know I don’t have one – although I probably should. 

 This reaction has been surprising to me as I didn’t think much of the post when I sent it. 

 The thought was formed while I was in a crowded elevator going up to my apartment. 

 There was a guy who looked a few years older than me with airpods in and a bag of Chipotle in hand. 

 He was visibly disgruntled, carrying a black work bag. 

 When we stopped to let others off on the way up, he spammed the “close door” button, almost shutting it on a few people who were too slow for his liking. 

 Considering it was a Friday around 5 pm, I imagined he’d just gotten off work after a long, boring week and was eager to get home and devour his burrito on the couch. 

 I could be completely wrong in my assessment, but I then started thinking about what my life would’ve looked like had I continued on the college, 9-5 route. 

 And that tweet is what I came up with. 

 I didn’t mean to attack this life path but rather paint a vivid picture of what I wanted to avoid – who knows if it would’ve actually been my reality. 

 My Twitter is unusable right now, as every time I refresh, I have dozens of new notifications from wagies who felt attacked by my words. 

 If anything, they’re proving my point to be true; if they didn’t partially identify with the person I described, they wouldn’t be offended, right? 

 To me, it looks like they’re trying to defend the lie they’ve sold themselves that they’re happy with an average existence. 

 I guess every hive needs worker bees. 

 Anyway, I’ll stop being mean and move on to a completely unrelated topic. 

 Something that’s been on my mind recently is the difference between short “flings” and hookups compared to longer-term relationships. 

 Any guy who’s casually dated many girls knows at some point, the game gets a bit too easy. 

 Although it’s fun, it’s kind of like an iceberg. 

 You show someone just enough of your personality for them to start to romanticize you. 

 By nature, you end up saying similar lines, sharing the same stories, and cultivating a particular image of yourself. 

 You can do this endlessly – revealing a glimpse of your character to new people over and over. 

 Once you reach the stage where the entire tip of the iceberg has been revealed (pause, no homo), you bounce to the next situationship to do it all over again. 

 You never give anyone the chance to get to know you past the image you aim to portray. 

 And there’s nothing wrong with that. Maybe it’s just a phase of life that you’re in, or you’re especially selective about who you spend an extended period of time with. 

 But if and when you move past the casual fling stage, you realize there’s no longer a place to hide. 

 Your flaws and insecurities are reflected back to you when you let someone get to know the real you, and that process reveals your self-image. 

 Fake confidence only lasts for so long, and if there are areas in your identity that you’re not comfortable with, you’ll be forced to make amends with them. 

 I hope this makes sense to you. I’d go a bit more in-depth, but I just realized that I have hundreds of new subscribers here. 

 Some of whom are probably ops that were angry at my tweet and will do anything they can to take what I say in this email out of context. 

 So I’ll let them weed themselves out, and then we’ll continue our regularly scheduled programming. 

 Anyway, It’s date night with sweet pea tonight! 

 Can’t wait to try the restaurant and watch our favorite show on the couch!!!! 

 Hah. 

 Happy early Easter, 

 Ben 

 P.S. If you’re new here, watch this to learn more about me and how I built a 7-figure copywriting business. ​

 P.P.S. Check out my previous emails here. ​

 ​

subject: The antidote to resistance
body:
I’ve grown to love the peaceful Sunday night at home.

When I was in school, this day was always dreadful.

Monday morning was around the corner and the looming stockpile of
work I’d been procrastinating was staring me in the face.

I was just debating whether or not I’d write an email to you
today.

There are a million excuses my brain could come up with as to why
I shouldn’t.

But then I thought about the feeling I get after completing one
of these.

It’s like when the endorphins kick in after a tough workout.

Maybe you didn’t want to do it, but you always feel better once
it’s done.

There are many things that we resist even though we know they’re
good for us.

If you’re building a business you can likely think of a few off
the top of your head.

The boring 30 minutes of outreach.

The long meeting with your sales team.

Or the time spent planning your week to stay on track with your
next income goal.

Usually, with tasks like this, the only immediate reward you get
is internal.

Going to the gym once won’t add 15 pounds of muscle.

You won’t close a client right after sending 20 DM’s.

And writing this email does nothing for me financially at the
moment.

But these things give us that type of dopamine that can only be
earned when we know we’re doing something positive for our future
selves.

When a goal is accomplished, it’s a lagging indicator that shows
you consistently completed those sometimes monotonous actions
that yield you next to nothing in the short term.

As I contemplated writing this, I considered how I felt yesterday
after I clicked send.

I knew replicating that same feeling would be worth it (plus, I
actually enjoy writing these).

So I guess that’s my first piece of advice:

Any time you resist something good for you, think back to how you
felt after the last time you did it.

And if it’s something that you’ve never done before, replace that
image with anything else you once felt a sense of accomplishment
after completing.

If you can’t think of anything, you’re cooked.

But if you can, use it as fuel to complete the task in front of
you.

This is how you rewire your brain to crave long-lasting, deserved
dopamine rather than cheap, social media-infused dopamine.

It’s like how you view a relationship with someone who is easy to
get versus someone you have to work for.

You’re always gonna place more value on the person who’s a
challenge because you had to earn it, which shows they value
themself.

When you bring a girl home after buying her two drinks and making
fun of her shoes, that usually means she isn’t wifey material
because if you could do it that easily, so could someone else.

Compared to the more elusive girl, who, although she likes you,
wants to make sure you’re really the person you appear to be
before she fully trusts you.

And that’s the difference between cheap dopamine and deserved
dopamine.

The more you can teach your brain to run toward the hill that’s
harder to climb, the better.

Anyway, hope you’re avoiding the Sunday scaries and ready to
crush the week.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4xx50ptph2k9d500/g3hnh5h3xovvz0fr/aHR0cHM6Ly9iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcG9zdHM=
)​

​

subject: indirectly following your passion
body:
Ok, I know it’s probably past your bedtime, but I wanted to talk
bo.

If you’re reading this in the morning, gm.

I have an important topic for you:

Money.

The way you’re gonna get rich is to find the intersection between
what you’re naturally good at/passionate about and what you can
make money with.

Sure, you can figure out how to make money with a “passion
project” or collect some shekels doing something you hate.

But these two elements are most powerful together.

When I think about the people I know who are crushing
financially, their business fits their personality type.

My friend Mason built a multi-seven-figure business by yapping on
TikTok and being relatable.

My friend Rob (who is worth many millions) is absolutely obsessed
with building brands and actually uses the products he sells.

My Dad has always been a car enthusiast and makes his money
flipping cars at auctions.

I was obsessed with basketball growing up and built my first
business running ads for basketball trainers.

In school, I always enjoyed writing and built my second business
using the skill of copywriting.

In all these examples, we ended up in vehicles that allowed us to
make money using our predisposed interests.

Had we directly followed our passion, we’d be in very different
spots.

I’m a few decisions away from being a journalist making $50k per
year or teaching people how to dribble balls for a living.

If you need some direction, odds are you'll find it in
discovering how to use your innate abilities to add value to
other people's lives.

To get a bit more practical, if you’re a people person, use your
networking skills to connect wealthy people and take a cut of the
business they do together.

If you’re organized and good at managing multiple tasks, you can
use that skill to be an operator in a company.

If you’re a hot girl, use that to swindle old men into giving you
money.

I’d dive deeper into this idea, but I’m getting sleepy, and
Glenda (my cleaner) is coming tomorrow morning, so I have to get
up early.

Let’s talk more tomorrow, and hope you enjoyed this somewhat
inconclusive ramble.

Goodnight,

Ben

)​

subject: Decide, commit, act
body:
I’m 37 minutes into an hour-long Tai Lopez rant on YouTube and
just clicked pause to write this.

Yesterday, I wrote a tweet about shifting your identity and
wanted to expand on it.

It’s long, so it’ll take up the majority of this email, but I
genuinely think this is one of the keys to making continuous
progress in any realm of life.

Here it is:

The speed at which you progress is dependent on your ability and
willingness to shift into a new identity when you complete the
vision you were formerly working toward.

When you actualize financial/lifestyle goals, it’s like you’re
beating a level in a video game. the next level is an entirely
different game, and you’re starting at zero with new obstacles
that you’re unfamiliar with.

Sometimes, you may fail or refuse to move to the next level
because you’re comfortable with the current level you’re
operating at and the problems associated with it.

This is where you get trapped.

Stay in one identity for too long, and your lack of progression
starts to eat away at you.

So, you begin to sabotage your current reality because you want
to feel like you’re moving forward.

The only way to do that while avoiding a complete shift in your
identity is to first move backward and then go back up the ladder
you already climbed.

So you’re now spending your time beating the same level of a
video game only to click the reset button and start over.

This is the trap of stagnation, where you give yourself the
illusion of progress.”

I’ve found that whenever I feel stuck, it’s because I’m simply
refusing to step into a new identity.

Perhaps you’ve heard the saying, “The vehicle that gets you to
point A isn’t the vehicle that gets you to point B.”

Similarly, the person you are right now has a ceiling.

You can reach a certain level financially, emotionally, and
spiritually.

Once you reach the peak of that level, you have the choice to
continue progressing or stay where you are.

And change is hard.

This is especially true when that change requires you to discard
your previous beliefs about yourself and replace them with
beliefs that will suit you in the new arena you are stepping
into.

You can spend eons avoiding this and fool yourself into believing
you’re making progress when you’re actually sputtering.

But this will only create an internal hell.

You know you’re capable of more, and you’re resisting.

The solution here can be summed up into three words:

Decide, commit, act.

Devise a plan to reach your next level, paint a vivid picture of
how this new version of you operates, and execute that plan.

It’s the work you’re avoiding, the habits you’re refusing to
develop, and the beliefs that hurt to change.

It’ll be painful, but so will the feeling of staying the same.

And this is the only way through.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​Read my previous emails here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hr05odmu5h03owzll/wnh2hghw8w68rot7/aHR0cHM6Ly9iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcG9zdHM=
)​

​

subject: Your standards determine your reality
body:
We procrastinate on the things we know we need to do most because
we are afraid of becoming the person who is capable of doing them
consistently.

For the last two weeks, the words “make a YouTube video” have
been at the top of my to-do list.

Every day, I wake up and look at that task only to put it off to
the next day.

Today, I finally got around to it, and it was a struggle.

Over a dozen takes later, I gave up.

I told myself, “At least you tried,” and turned off the camera to
go buy zyns.

As I stood in the hallway waiting for the elevator that was
taking obnoxiously long to arrive, I thought about how I still
wouldn’t be able to cross that off my to-do list.

Then, I considered how I’d feel if I’d accomplished it.

That’s when I turned around, walked back into my apartment, and
made this video. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh0n8z50ukhzp7n399/z2hghnh305k34dfp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS8xZEZGZGU4VWp0ND9zaT1DR21JdFhNckg2eDdMMkRk
)​

And the weight of the unfinished task was finally lifted off my
shoulders.

Recently, I’ve been thinking a lot about standards.

It’s your standards that hold the invisible bar for what you
believe you are capable of.

Whenever you want to transform into someone new, that bar has to
be raised.

We know this, and it’s the reason that we sabotage ourselves.

You’re likely comfortable in the reality that you’re currently
operating in.

Sure, you want to improve, but committing to the actions required
to do so is a whole lot different than fantasizing about progress
and telling yourself you’ll get around to it one day.

So you place a ceiling on yourself and resist anything that
forces you to step out of that box because you’d then show
yourself that the ceiling is imaginary.

give yourself data to solidify that.

Because then you can no longer be naive, and you have to exit the
box of limitations you’re comfortably situated in.

With that new identity comes a reality you’re unfamiliar with.

Challenges you haven’t faced and standards you’re not accustomed
to.

It might be easier to stay where you are for now, but that voice
telling you to do more won’t go away.

It’ll torture you until you either quench it or suppress it
enough to where you’re comfortably numb.

subject: Your standards determine your reality
body:
We procrastinate on the things we know we need to do most because we are afraid of becoming the person who is capable of doing them consistently. 

 For the last two weeks, the words “make a YouTube video” have been at the top of my to-do list. 

 Every day, I wake up and look at that task only to put it off to the next day. 

 Today, I finally got around to it, and it was a struggle. 

 Over a dozen takes later, I gave up. 

 I told myself, “At least you tried,” and turned off the camera to go buy zyns. 

 As I stood in the hallway waiting for the elevator that was taking obnoxiously long to arrive, I thought about how I still wouldn’t be able to cross that off my to-do list. 

 Then, I considered how I’d feel if I’d accomplished it. 

 That’s when I turned around, walked back into my apartment, and made this video. ​

 And the weight of the unfinished task was finally lifted off my shoulders. 

 Recently, I’ve been thinking a lot about standards. 

 It’s your standards that hold the invisible bar for what you believe you are capable of. 

 Whenever you want to transform into someone new, that bar has to be raised. 

 We know this, and it’s the reason that we sabotage ourselves. 

 You’re likely comfortable in the reality that you’re currently operating in. 

 Sure, you want to improve, but committing to the actions required to do so is a whole lot different than fantasizing about progress and telling yourself you’ll get around to it one day. 

 So you place a ceiling on yourself and resist anything that forces you to step out of that box because you’d then show yourself that the ceiling is imaginary. 

 You’re capable of more, and you know it, but you’re refusing to give yourself data to solidify that. 

 Because then you can no longer be naive, and you have to exit the box of limitations you’re comfortably situated in. 

 And you’re forced to step into a new identity. 

 With that new identity comes a reality you’re unfamiliar with. 

 Challenges you haven’t faced and standards you’re not accustomed to. 

 It might be easier to stay where you are for now, but that voice telling you to do more won’t go away. 

 It’ll torture you until you either quench it or suppress it enough to where you’re comfortably numb. 

 And the light that shines with hope behind your eyes will be gone. 

 That’s probably not a recipe for a happy and fulfilled life. 

 Don’t let that light go dim. 

 ​ Watch my new YouTube video here :) ​

 Thanks for reading, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Read my previous emails here ​

 ​

subject: Clarity is earned
body:
I’m sitting on my balcony, watching boats go by.

The buildings are lit up, and the city is buzzing.

I have a 10:45pm dinner reservation at Carbone.

My friend Mason convinced me to go to the club after (against my
will).

Opportunities are a lot like puzzles.

If you try to build a puzzle by mapping out where all the pieces
will be placed, you’ll never start.

You can sit there for hours, thinking about each piece
individually and where it will end up.

But if you don’t combine any of them, you’ll never get closer to
a finished product.

Similarly, if you try to predict every step you will take to
achieve a goal instead of taking step one, you’ll never move
closer to the goal.

Simple right?

Although this is an easy concept to grasp, it’s much more
difficult to put into practice.

When you feel stuck, the problem is likely because there are too
many different directions you could go in.

Obviously, you want to pick the best one, so you sit there
thinking about how everything will work out.

This puts you in a state of inaction.

You tell yourself you’ll start moving toward your goals once you
have clarity on where to go.

But as you wait for some divine sign telling you what to do, the
clarity you’re looking for continues to elude you.

So, you go back to the drawing board and start thinking more.

You can do this for eternity if you let yourself.

But the truth is opportunities are created through action.

You open one door, and the next opens up.

You take the wrong turn, and it reroutes you to the right one.

You must earn clarity.

When you’re lost, it’s because you’re refusing to step on the gas
despite the fact that you don’t know where the road you’re going
down will lead you.

Do the things that feel right, even if they offer no immediate
reward.

Eventually, you’ll end up in a situation where everything aligns,
and you find the last piece of the puzzle.

That’s when the road becomes clear, and you can finally floor it.

It starts with step one.

See you at dinner,

Ben

P.S. Watch my new YouTube video here (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8hk7k68vfzhqgk0o66/z2hghnh30x5nr3cp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS8xZEZGZGU4VWp0ND9zaT1DR21JdFhNckg2eDdMMkRk
)​

​

subject: 5 steps to make more than an investment banker
body:
Happy Monday.

I genuinely think 90% of the people I meet sell info (courses and
coaching).

Literally.

I met a 96-year-old woman named Dorthy on my coffee run this
morning.

We started talking because she complimented my eyes and told me
she hoped her granddaughter would find a guy like me one day.

She then started telling me how she sells a course teaching
elderly women how to keep their husbands happy by learning how to
bake her special apple pie with a secret ingredient.

The ingredient reinvigorates their marriage and helps them find
that spark they felt years ago.

It’s called Viagra.

Dorthy grabbed my arm and asked if I wanted to try it.

That’s when I stole her cane and ran away.

Now, I’m writing this fictitious story to you with Dorthy's
imaginary cane leaning up against my desk.

Jokes and fictional stories aside, EVERYONE SELLS INFO.

If you’re a copywriter, I don’t think finding opportunities
working with coaches has ever been easier.

All you have to do is:

* Become a competent writer and gain a fundamental understanding
of how coaching businesses work.
* Send loom video pitches on Instagram until you get someone on
the phone.
* Talk to the potential client and see what they need. Maybe it’s
email copy, ad copy, video scripts, VSL scripts, funnel copy,
etc. You are a copywriter. That means your skillset is versatile,
and you should be able to fill whatever gap they have in their
business to get your foot in the door.
* Once you close the client, go above and beyond. The bar for
service providers is so low that if you simply put in more effort
than what is asked, you will be rewarded. They’ll send you
referrals, give you a case study, or trust you to operate other
parts of their business (meaning you can now charge more + rev
share).
* Now, you turn a $3k/month client into a $10k/month client.

Complete the process above a few times, and you’ll be making more
than the average investment banker at Goldman Sachs.

Plus, you didn’t have to snort Adderal and cheat off your smart
Asian friend named Kevin for four years while getting your
bachelor's degree.

That’s what I’d do if I had to start all over.

Even if you’re not a copywriter, the process I outlined is
basically all you need to do to accelerate your success in any
service-based business.

Your skillset gets you in the door, and you decide what happens
now that you’re in the room.

If you earn the trust of the right person, one connection could
change your life.

Just be competent and over-deliver.

Now you’re rich.

​Thank me by watching this video and leaving a like and comment
:) (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmh09n0omf6hdxoe400/8ghqhohlkv8q85hk/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS8xZEZGZGU4VWp0ND9zaT02aW1xdmowV1daT2tKTWVx
)​

Peace,

Ben

P.S. If you’re trying to build a copywriting or “growth
operating” business, hit reply and let me know what your biggest
roadblock is right now. Building something cool for you.

​

subject: i was wrong
body:
Yo bo, big news…

I ordered a whiteboard.

It comes with a stand, markers, and erasers.

Cool right?

A problem I sometimes encounter when I sit down to write is that
I start questioning whether the immediate idea that comes to mind
is important enough to warrant an entire email.

As I sit here thinking about where to take this, I’ve probably
discarded five ideas.

All of which could have made for a banger email.

But because I don’t feel they’re worthy, I sit here telling
myself my mind is blank.

I recently wrote about how your standards determine your reality
and that if you want to improve anything, you have to raise the
internal bar for what you perceive as acceptable.

I’m now realizing the opposite is also true.

I believe nerds call this a paradox.

(side note real quick – Grammarly fucking sucks. It’s a tool that
gives you suggestions on your writing, and everything it tells me
to do sounds like it’s attempting to be an off-brand
Shakespeare).

Anyway, back to the standards paradox.

Sometimes, if you don’t lower your standards, you won’t do
anything.

You want to write the perfect message, make the best video
possible, say the right line to the girl, or impress someone you
look up to.

The desire for perfection has an inverse effect.

You don’t start, or you filter your thoughts, and you find any
excuse not to approach the girl.

This is because the measuring stick is in the wrong place.

Instead of setting an incredibly high bar for the quality of the
output, the bar needs to be set for the quantity of the input.

“I need a big idea for this email” becomes “I need to write an
email today, no matter what.”

“I need to say the right line to the girl” becomes “I need to
walk up and say anything.”

“I need to impress this person” becomes “I need to express myself
and say what I’m thinking.”

You’re optimizing for reps instead of trying to protect your ego
by being perfect.

Sure, I want to “wow” you with every email I write.

But if I wait until I have a groundbreaking idea every time, I’d
be writing once a quarter.

If I make sure to get this done even when I don’t feel heavily
inspired, the quality of the output increases in correlation to
the input.

That means do more of the thing, and you will get better at it
way quicker than you would if you tried to do it perfectly.

There's a Harvard study about this.

Long story short, students in a ceramics class were separated
into two groups. One group was told to make the “perfect” clay
pot, and the other was told to make as many as possible.

All of the best-looking pots came from the quantity group rather
than the quality group.

You should get the point by now.

Be wary not to conflate having “high standards” with a defense
mechanism to protect your ego.

Odds are that when you fail to take action, you’re trying to save
yourself the embarrassment of realizing that you have some
improvement to make.

So does everyone else – and those who improve the fastest are the
ones who get the most reps.

Grammarly keeps giving me more dumb suggestions, so I’ll wrap
this up here, but go watch my recent YT video if you haven’t
already. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukhol2ln2crh5d9ronn/wnh2hghw8208kgi7/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS8xZEZGZGU4VWp0ND9zaT1zbzc0NTJRUVByNldjQ2FI
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you liked this one :)​
​

​

subject: My thoughts on "growth operating"
body:
I was having an amazing morning until now…

It’s a beautiful 78-degree day in Miami.

Birds chirping, sun shining, and people genuinely seem happier
here.

I walked to Soybucks to grab my iced shaken espresso. They
greeted me with love and told me to have a great day.

I smiled and tossed the barista the keys to my G Wagon.

Then, everything changed.

I opened my phone and went to Instagram.

Boom, I see another pitch from some little ass kid telling me he
could be my “growth operator.”

He said, “Ben, did you know you could monetize 1% of your
audience??? I can make you $30k per month!”

If you don’t know what “growth operating” is, let me fill you in.

You partner with someone who has a big audience, help them set up
a Skool community, and take 50% of the profits.

It’s basically a simplified version of what we do at my
info-product agency.

Obviously, I think it’s a solid business model to run, and it’s
made me 7 figures.

But I think there’s a bit of a misconception about how it’s been
positioned online.

From firsthand experience, I can promise you that helping someone
scale an info-product is complex.

There are many moving pieces in these types of businesses, and
you need to have a broad skill set along with a general
understanding of the info-product space to succeed as a service
provider.

You write email copy, build funnels, script video sales letters,
build systems, and orchestrate the sales process.

If you’re a complete beginner, it’s damn near impossible to learn
all these skills at once.

Instead, it makes much more sense to start by learning one thing
and one thing only – copywriting.

It’s the foundation of my business and the reason I’ve scaled to
6 figures per month with my info agency.

We’ve scaled offers from zero to $600k/month and orchestrated
over a dozen multi-six-figure launches.

We helped a client go from $30k/mo to $350k/mo in a month and a
half, and our smallest clients are making a minimum of $1m/year.

But I didn’t end up in this position by saying I wanted to be a
“growth operator.” That term didn’t even exist.

I worked as a freelance copywriter/marketer and eventually
accumulated the skills required to run a full-stack agency for
info products.

If I were starting all over again, I’d start by becoming the best
copywriter I could be. I’d study all types of copy – emails, ads,
sales pages, VSLs, direct mail, billboards.

Then I’d start doing outreach to get clients while continuing to
learn supplementary skills like funnel building, the different
types of funnels, when to use which, how to navigate zapier,
sales process management, etc.

Once I had a better understanding of these things, I’d pitch my
copywriting clients on more services.

Get one really good case study, and boom – now you have a real
business.

Let me clarify, though: I’m not saying the growth operator
business model is bad. The guys who teach it are legit.

subject: My thoughts on "growth operating"
body:
I was having an amazing morning until now… 

 It’s a beautiful 78-degree day in Miami. 

 Birds chirping, sun shining, and people genuinely seem happier here. 

 I walked to Soybucks to grab my iced shaken espresso. They greeted me with love and told me to have a great day. 

 I smiled and tossed the barista the keys to my G Wagon. 

 Then, everything changed. 

 I opened my phone and went to Instagram. 

 Boom, I see another pitch from some little ass kid telling me he could be my “growth operator.” 

 He said, “Ben, did you know you could monetize 1% of your audience??? I can make you $30k per month!” 

 If you don’t know what “growth operating” is, let me fill you in. 

 You partner with someone who has a big audience, help them set up a Skool community, and take 50% of the profits. 

 It’s basically a simplified version of what we do at my info-product agency. 

 Obviously, I think it’s a solid business model to run, and it’s made me 7 figures. 

 But I think there’s a bit of a misconception about how it’s been positioned online. 

 From firsthand experience, I can promise you that helping someone scale an info-product is complex. 

 There are many moving pieces in these types of businesses, and you need to have a broad skill set along with a general understanding of the info-product space to succeed as a service provider. 

 You write email copy, build funnels, script video sales letters, build systems, and orchestrate the sales process. 

 If you’re a complete beginner, it’s damn near impossible to learn all these skills at once. 

 Instead, it makes much more sense to start by learning one thing and one thing only – copywriting. 

 It’s the foundation of my business and the reason I’ve scaled to 6 figures per month with my info agency. 

 We’ve scaled offers from zero to $600k/month and orchestrated over a dozen multi-six-figure launches. 

 We helped a client go from $30k/mo to $350k/mo in a month and a half, and our smallest clients are making a minimum of $1m/year. 

 But I didn’t end up in this position by saying I wanted to be a “growth operator.” That term didn’t even exist. 

 I worked as a freelance copywriter/marketer and eventually accumulated the skills required to run a full-stack agency for info products. 

 If I were starting all over again, I’d start by becoming the best copywriter I could be. I’d study all types of copy – emails, ads, sales pages, VSLs, direct mail, billboards. 

 Then I’d start doing outreach to get clients while continuing to learn supplementary skills like funnel building, the different types of funnels, when to use which, how to navigate zapier, sales process management, etc. 

 Once I had a better understanding of these things, I’d pitch my copywriting clients on more services. 

 Get one really good case study, and boom – now you have a real business. 

 Let me clarify, though: I’m not saying the growth operator business model is bad. The guys who teach it are legit. 

 But it’s not a beginner business model, and you won’t get anywhere close to 50% profits from any creator who knows what they’re doing. 

 If you’re starting from scratch, learn copy, and the next door will open for you. 

 Hope you enjoyed this one, 

 Ben 

 ​ Read my previous emails here. ​ 

 ​

subject: why your beliefs will change
body:
Goood morning bo,

Before I start rambling and forget to tell you, I made a new
video explaining how I’ve made $124,255 in a month as a
copywriter. You can watch it here after you read this. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh0vp4lvckhzp7n399b3/dpheh0h0r2g9gesm/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9yNDlweGt0QWZXNA==
)​

I’m sitting on my balcony as I write to you, and the dude who
parades around the streets in Brickell while dancing on his bike
is blasting the song “Dance Monkey.”

If you’ve ever been here, you probably know who I’m talking
about.

He usually annoys me, but I’m in a good mood today, so I’m
refraining from sniping him.

Anyway, whenever I see someone online pushing a narrative really
hard, it makes me think they’re trying to convince themselves
that it’s true.

I’m sure we’ve all been guilty of this at some point.

But I keep seeing Alex Becker pop up on my Twitter timeline,
talking about how “fulfilled” he is by getting up at 3 am and
sitting at his desk all day.

He’s a pioneer in the online money space, so no shade directly at
him – I just think that someone who is truly happy doesn’t have
to tell you how happy they are.

In the same way, someone who’s found the right path for
themselves doesn’t tell you how your path is wrong.

And a person who has a true relationship with God doesn’t judge
you for not following the same rules they follow.

This problem seems to arise when you deeply subscribe to a belief
and discard anything that may contradict that belief. You don’t
understand that most things are temporary and there are few
universal truths.

But because you’ve fully convinced yourself that your way is the
right way, when you encounter a situation where that belief is
challenged, you take it as a threat.

It’s why someone who follows the college, 9-5 route gets angry
when they see a 16-year-old with their annual salary on their
wrist.

And on the contrary, it’s why a struggling entrepreneur feels the
need to criticize 9-5ers so they can solidify that they made the
right choice in their own mind.

There’s a sliver of doubt that they’re attempting to cover up by
denying that any alternative could be true.

But that’s the thing – the alternative can almost always be true.

One thing I know with 100% certainty is that my outlook on life
will change over time. It’s supposed to.

Different seasons in life bring additional perspectives.

I’m not saying you should lack conviction in your current beliefs
if you’ve thoughtfully crafted them.

Just understand that they may change over time.

Don’t marry your beliefs, or you’ll end up bitter when you see
someone succeeding in a different lane than you.

There are a million ways to win. Choose yours.

Alright, I gotta go to boxing, and you gotta watch this video. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh0vp4lvckhzp7n399b3/dpheh0h0r2g9gesm/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9yNDlweGt0QWZXNA==
)​

Happy Friday,

Ben

​

subject: Two habits that will change your life for the better
body:
Hello and happy Sunday, bo.

If you’re in a cold or grey climate right now, I feel bad for you
because Miami is absolutely beautiful.

I’m wearing Birkenstocks without socks, which could be considered
a crime against humanity but is also indicative of the sunny
80-degree day we have here.

First, I want to say thank you for the love of my recent YT
videos. Your validation is giving me the motivation to upload
consistently, so please keep it up.

Recently, I’ve been thinking about how copywriting has impacted
my life.

Not only has it helped me build my business, but it’s served as
an outlet for me to develop more concrete ideas.

For the last couple of years, I’ve been journaling, tweeting, or
writing an email nearly daily.

It feels like a form of art.

In simple terms, I’m taking ideas that are jumbling around in my
head and assembling them into a series of words that form a
complete thought.

This has made me a more articulate speaker as well.

Whether talking to friends, on a date, or making content, I feel
the ripple effect that comes from writing consistently.

Being able to use your words and share your perspective with
someone in a way that may persuade them to agree with your
beliefs feels like a superpower.

Whether or not you want to build a business that involves
copywriting, I genuinely think getting into the habit of writing
consistently is one of the highest ROI activities you can do.

Once you hone this skill, a world of opportunities opens up.

It can lead to a successful business, deeper relationships with
others, and/or a loyal audience of people on the internet that
resonate with your beliefs.

And as I think about the most successful entrepreneurs I know,
this is almost always their unfair advantage.

Switching gears a bit, another thing that’s been on my mind is
the value that comes with continuous learning.

School tricked us into thinking that education is a boring chore.

This causes most people to put little time into gaining new
information once they graduate.

But learning new things should be fun.

I’m sure there are dozens of topics that you are naturally
curious about and would enjoy exploring further.

And who knows – maybe it could lead to more money, a better
social life, or at least give you an interesting topic to discuss
at the dinner table.

When you’re constantly learning new things, you become more
unique and interesting. And being a wealth of knowledge is cool.

I encourage you to take some time each day to learn about
something new. It doesn't have to be about money or anything that
even offers you any tangible benefit.

Simply allow your curiosity to lead you and someway, somehow,
you’ll be glad you did.

This is a part of how you develop into a well-rounded version of
yourself, which I talk more about here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hv8zeela6hrqdz344fn/z2hghnh30gp7mehp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9TdU9fOXRGY185VT9zaT1DazBDcXpNUzRIUEtmUXN3
)​

Anyway, I gotta record some course content (which you’ll have
access to soon), and Grammarly is pissing me off again because it
keeps suggesting retarded edits to my writing.

Go watch my latest YT video if you haven’t already :)

Love you,

Ben

​P.S. Read my previous emails here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hv8zeela6hrqdz344fn/x0hph6hwxg9z43c5/aHR0cHM6Ly9iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcG9zdHM=
)​

​

subject: the only way to get better at anything
body:
I was working out with my boxing coach the other day, practicing
a new combination.

While we train, he frequently pauses to give me an analogy or
anecdote to help cement new concepts in my head.

In this particular session, he said something that gave me no
other choice but to reply with the word “bars” because it applies
to any area of life that you are aiming to improve.

He said, “Confidence comes through competence, which comes
through repetition.”

In other words, the more reps you get, the better you become, and
the better you become, the more confidence you build.

I’m noticing this already on YouTube.

The first time I sat down to make a video, it took me too many
tries to count.

I’d start talking and stumble over my words, lose my train of
thought, or find an issue with the lighting or how the camera was
positioned.

Because of this, making a video felt like I was climbing this big
mountain.

Although I still run into occasional issues, it’s become much
easier to sit down and knock out a video.

While the quality is subjective, I also feel that my ability to
articulate the concept I’m discussing in each video has improved.

The words flow more smoothly, I’m more comfortable being
expressive, and I’m getting closer to losing the filter that
naturally comes with making videos for the internet.

It’s a perfect example of the quote from my boxing coach.

I don’t want to harp on this one point for too long because it’s
so simple yet so difficult to actually practice.

The last thing I’ll say here is that I promise you with full
certainty that when you stop putting off things you want to do,
it’ll be worth it.

You have to get over the immediate flinch that comes with
starting anything new and sometimes have to say, “fuck it if it
sucks, it sucks,” and do it anyway.

Over time and repetition, you will get better.

Anyway, I gotta hop on a coaching call, so I’ll keep this one
short.

Thanks for reading – and go here to check out the video I
uploaded today about why “monk mode” makes you less productive. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hv857q3a6hrqdz344fn/25h2hoh2lvol4wu3/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9Hc002X1BydndvVT9zaT1JUjNaQzVVZ2YxbHdLV1F1
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​

subject: HOW TO NOT BE A BOT
body:
I sneezed on my walk to get coffee and a stranger said, “Bless
you.”

I found that endearing.

Then I saw a grown man wearing a bulky helmet and work clothes
zipping through traffic on a scooter.

Those are for children. Grow up.

A couple things on my mind today:

1. Craftiness is the most underrated skill in business.

It’s the reason some people seem to get lucky.

I know a newer copywriter who’s gotten to multi-five figures a
month way faster than most people.

He’s a smart kid but considering he’s brand new to copywriting,
it’s safe to assume there are many better writers than him.

But it’s the intangibles that have allowed him to scale to
quickly.

I’ve watched him relentlessly follow up with prospects in a
nonaggressive way that doesn’t piss them off.

He’ll confidently say “yes” when someone asks for something he
has little idea how to do and figure it out on the fly.

He’s simply the boy.

I was talking to my friend Mason about this the other day.

When I describe someone as “the boy” it’s one of the biggest
compliments I can give.

It means that they just get it. They’re a good vibe, people like
them, they’re socially calibrated.

It’s the highest rank in the Bader-dialogue hierarchy. A step up
from “the homie” even.

When someone has the traits above, they "make it" — even if
they’re not the most skilled.

My mentor when I was building my basketball trainer SMMA used to
always say that if we can get someone laughing on a sales call,
they will close.

It's a high ROI tip — in a world of cookie-cutter, boring,
lifeless robots, be expressive. Crack the borderline offensive
joke. Tell your prospect they need to hire you so they can afford
better wifi when their connection cuts out on the Zoom call.

Smile. And be handsome.

I got carried away writing this first point and now I forget the
other things that were on my mind.

Hmmm.

I’m sitting outside at Starbucks and another corporate drone just
rode by on a scooter.

Oh, next thing that that I was thinking about:

2. If getting clients is a struggle, you’re being a bot.

This relates to my first point but THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX.

“I can’t get any clients, I’ve been sending the same retarded
pitch to everyone for 3 months and no one replies.”

CHANGE YOUR PITCH.

Test shit. That’s life. You test until something works for you,
even if it goes against the “proven system” that cornballs on the
internet give you.

One of the copywriters I consulted with got his first couple of
clients by digging through Youtubers channels, finding their
email addresses, and pitching them via email.

No one taught him that. But that’s ingenuity.

The first time I heard the word “ingenious,” I had just broken
into my high school gym to play basketball.

There was a hidden key in the storage closet to turn the lights
on and lower the hoops. I’d found it months before, but one day,
I walked in there, and it was gone.

“Goddamnit, Terry,” I thought to myself. She was the athletic
trainer who would always kick me out because it was a liability
for a minor to be in the gym without supervision.

I bent the metal part of an old lanyard I found in my backpack
and made a new key. It worked.

subject: HOW TO NOT BE A BOT
body:
I sneezed on my walk to get coffee and a stranger said, “Bless you.” 

 I found that endearing. 

 Then I saw a grown man wearing a bulky helmet and work clothes zipping through traffic on a scooter. 

 Those are for children. Grow up. 

 A couple things on my mind today: 

 1. Craftiness is the most underrated skill in business. 

 It’s the reason some people seem to get lucky. 

 I know a newer copywriter who’s gotten to multi-five figures a month way faster than most people. 

 He’s a smart kid but considering he’s brand new to copywriting, it’s safe to assume there are many better writers than him. 

 But it’s the intangibles that have allowed him to scale to quickly. 

 I’ve watched him relentlessly follow up with prospects in a nonaggressive way that doesn’t piss them off. 

 He’ll confidently say “yes” when someone asks for something he has little idea how to do and figure it out on the fly. 

 He’s simply the boy. 

 I was talking to my friend Mason about this the other day. 

 When I describe someone as “the boy” it’s one of the biggest compliments I can give. 

 It means that they just get it. They’re a good vibe, people like them, they’re socially calibrated. 

 It’s the highest rank in the Bader-dialogue hierarchy. A step up from “the homie” even. 

 When someone has the traits above, they "make it" — even if they’re not the most skilled. 

 My mentor when I was building my basketball trainer SMMA used to always say that if we can get someone laughing on a sales call, they will close. 

 It's a high ROI tip — in a world of cookie-cutter, boring, lifeless robots, be expressive. Crack the borderline offensive joke. Tell your prospect they need to hire you so they can afford better wifi when their connection cuts out on the Zoom call. 

 Smile. And be handsome. 

 I got carried away writing this first point and now I forget the other things that were on my mind. 

 Hmmm. 

 I’m sitting outside at Starbucks and another corporate drone just rode by on a scooter. 

 Oh, next thing that that I was thinking about: 

 2. If getting clients is a struggle, you’re being a bot. 

 This relates to my first point but THINK OUTSIDE THE BOX. 

 “I can’t get any clients, I’ve been sending the same retarded pitch to everyone for 3 months and no one replies.” 

 CHANGE YOUR PITCH. 

 Test shit. That’s life. You test until something works for you, even if it goes against the “proven system” that cornballs on the internet give you. 

 One of the copywriters I consulted with got his first couple of clients by digging through Youtubers channels, finding their email addresses, and pitching them via email. 

 No one taught him that. But that’s ingenuity. 

 The first time I heard the word “ingenious,” I had just broken into my high school gym to play basketball. 

 There was a hidden key in the storage closet to turn the lights on and lower the hoops. I’d found it months before, but one day, I walked in there, and it was gone. 

 “Goddamnit, Terry,” I thought to myself. She was the athletic trainer who would always kick me out because it was a liability for a minor to be in the gym without supervision. 

 I bent the metal part of an old lanyard I found in my backpack and made a new key. It worked. 

 A few days later, Terry walked in right after I used my makeshift key to get the baskets down. 

 She asked how I did it, and I told her I had made a new key. That’s when she said, “Well, that was ingenious of you.” 

 In my head, I was like “fuck yeah it was Terry.” 

 Anyway, I’m rambling, but if you’re stuck right now, BE CRAFTY. BE INGENIOUS. DONT BE A LUKE BELMAR IMAN GHADZI ANDREW TATE CLONE. STEAL YOUR GRANDMAS COMPUTER. SELL YOUR KIDNEY ON THE BLACK MARKET. SEND THE MAFIA TO A PROSPECTS HOUSE. 

 Ok, thanks for reading all this, now go here to uncover the secrets of the Universe. ​

 Talk tm, sorry for yelling. 

 Bye, 

 Ben

subject: how to overcome the voice in your head
body:
The hardest part of starting anything is the beginning.

When I open this document to a blank page, and a blinking cursor,
a voice in my head tries to convince me that today isn’t the day.

“You’re out of ideas for now. You’re uninspired. Just wait until
it comes to you,” it says.

This is a familiar voice.

I hear it whenever I turn on the camera to make a video.

It screams at me when the cold water touches my body in an ice
bath and tells me to get out.

Maybe you’ve heard it too.

When you listen to it, you’ll be convinced not to go to the gym,
avoid approaching the girl, and wait until the “perfect time” to
start the business.

A few years ago, I listened to an audiobook about this topic
during a plane ride.

It’s called The War Of Art by Steven Pressfield.

He refers to this voice as “resistance” and describes it as “A
universal force that has one mission: to keep things as they
are.”

You’re likely aware of the things you resist – consciously or
unconsciously.

You also probably don’t want to stay the same forever.

And you know that the only way to change is to overcome your
initial desire to flinch when taking the first half step.

You can ask yourself three questions to identify what you’re
resisting right now and make a convincing argument for moving
toward it.

Answer these with me real quick:

1. What’s one thing I want that I’m not getting right now?

2. What’s stopping me from getting this thing?

3. What would happen if I could do this thing?

Got it?

Okay.

By answering question one, you thought of something you want to
do that you’re avoiding.

In question two, you selected the first excuse that came to mind
for why you couldn’t do it.

And in question three, hopefully, you realized how stupid that
excuse is because of the benefits, the person you become, and the
new life you unlock by overcoming your resistance.

It’s literally impossible to make a logical argument for why you
should avoid the things you’re avoiding.

Your excuses are bullshit.

That’s your ego trying to defend against change.

Because with change comes the possibility that things don’t go as
planned.

Maybe your video gets three likes, and they come from your
grandma, mom, and little brother.

Even your cousin gave it a thumbs down.

Or maybe you get rocked in the face the first time you step in
the ring.

If those are big enough reasons to stay where you are, be my
guest.

But by making that decision, you’re also closing the door to the
possibility that it will eventually work out.

Sure, maybe it will start slowly.

Maybe things won’t go as planned even after you beat resistance.

But one day, your efforts will compound.

You’ll hang in there long enough and have the results to show for
it.

That’s when you’ll laugh at the fact that you ever were scared to
pursue the things you want.

You in?

Cool.

​Now, go here and let me tell you about the one trait you need to
make as much money as you possibly want. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkglkzzfohzd87nkkb9/z2hghnh357ddllcp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9heElaRDZ2Nkhwcz9zaT1kUktSYkFLQTBOR0R5WW5Q
)​

Love you,

Ben

​

subject: stop feeling sorry for yourself
body:
Today was a tough one for my speaking ability.

I probably have over 100 clips on my camera that will all be
deleted.

Earlier today I was trying to make a VSL for a new offer I’m
putting together where you can work with me directly.

After dozens of takes, I finally had a video that I thought was
sufficient.

I exported it and was about to call it a day.

Then I watched it a couple more times and decided that I didn’t
like it.

I took a walk to clear my head and was inspired to make a Youtube
video once I got back.

20 takes later, I still didn’t have a complete video. The sun
went down and the lighting in my apartment makes the video look
grainy once it gets dark.

I turned off the camera and am now sitting here writing to you.

It’s funny because yesterday I wrote an email to you about
overcoming the initial resistance you feel when starting
something new.

And today, I couldn’t beat it.

I started to feel bad for myself after the initial VSL failure.

And then during my walk earlier, I opened an email reply from
someone on this list.

They said “Thank you Ben for rekindling this flame inside me with
these emails.”

That’s when I realized that the decision to pity myself after
things didn’t go as planned is incredibly selfish.

I’m making videos and sharing content on the because it feels
like something I have to do.

As a byproduct, I get to inspire other people and impact lives
for the better.

Obviously, I’m not on the front lines here risking my life for
the benefit of humanity, but making

content like this is probably one of the most influential things
I can do with my time at the moment.

When I think about, the possibility that I even impact a few
people for the better vastly makes up for days like today, where
I struggle.

I get messages and comments every day from people telling me that
I’ve helped them in some way.

And to say “woe is me” while sitting and pouting about a couple
of unsuccessful videos is childish, bitch-like behavior. I have a
responsibility here, and it’s my obligation to uphold it. I’m too
blessed to feel sorry for myself. The mission doesn’t allow for
pity.

This is the pep talk I heard in my head. Perhaps it applies to
you as well.

In general, I think the worst thing you can do in any situation
is to feel sorry for yourself. It makes you powerless. It’s a
slap in the face to anyone who supports you or roots for you, as
you’re not even giving the same level of respect to yourself.

No more pity parties. You have responsibilities to tend to and a
divine calling to follow.

Don’t be a bitch.

Ok bye thx for reading Happy Friday.

Ben

P.S. Did you watch my recent YT video yet? (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5pqeqlh7he24rkxxb8/l2hehmh3qvv849b6/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9heElaRDZ2Nkhwcz9zaT11VUpzMmgzeERySmFtbzND
)​

P.P.S Lmk if you liked this one

​

subject: How to build a copywriting business from scratch
body:
I started writing this in my head during my morning run.

The trail was abnormally crowded today.

I had to weave through an abundance of slow walkers, oblivious
dog owners, strollers, and preoccupied middle-aged Hispanic men.

It was windy, to the point that the water from the Miami River to
my left was blowing up onto the walkway.

The trees were rattling, but I pierced through the wind in my
white Nikes, which I’ve been wearing for the past year.

It’s definitely time to buy a new pair, but completing minuscule
tasks like going to the shoe store feels equivalent to climbing
Mt. Everest to me. So I’ll probably wait until the sole starts to
fall off or my toes bust through the mesh.

I was walking back home after my run when I ran into my friend
Bo. Bo is a copywriter that Mason and I have been coaching for
the last six months or so.

She quickly reached $10k per month inside Mason's program, the
Copy MBA Inner Circle, and then started asking me for help
scaling further.

With my help she’s scaled past $50k per month by turning her
copywriting business into a full stack info agency.

A few weeks ago, I was thinking about how we could create more
success stories like hers.

She started by learning the skill of copywriting and then added
many of the other services that I offer to clients.

Things like funnel building, VSLs, webinars, and building all the
systems on the backend.

It seems like this is the common path for those who get the best
results when first starting out as a beginner.

They get good at copy and then expand their skill set to become
more valuable to their clients.

This gave me the idea to partner up with Mason inside of Copy
MBA.

Over the last few weeks, I’ve been building out course content to
add to the program, and I’m nearly ready to launch it.

If you’re just starting out, this is gonna be a cheat code for
you.

Not only will you get access to Mason and his team, along with
all of the existing content inside of there…

But you’ll also begin to learn the skills that you’ll need to
know to eventually be able to charge clients up to $40k in a
single month the way I have.

I’m putting the final touches on everything, and because you’re
on this list, you’ll get first access to it once it goes live.

I can promise you with full certainty that if you’re a complete
beginner who’s looking to build a copywriting business, this is
gonna be the most valuable resource you have at your disposal.

I’ll be giving you more info in the coming emails.

For now, go here and check out this video that’ll help you
develop a magnetic aura and make other people love you. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnhqmz9k6i9h0xvg933bw/qvh8h7hre08nrotl/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS90cXBCM0QzVV8zND9zaT1VVVdfaXNGeXM2amxQV2hj
)​

Happy Sunday, and thanks for reading,

Ben

P.S. If you’re interested in the program I outlined above, hit
‘reply’ real quick and let me know.

subject: The anti-robot approach to getting clients
body:
The other day, I sent you an email titled “HOW TO NOT BE A BOT.”

It’s the most important life hack you can understand.

It’ll get you clients, friends, perceived status, etc. Simply
put, not being a bot makes you a winner.

Today, I want to dive into the psychology behind this.

In college, there was a kid in my pledge class who we called a
robot.

For the sake of the story, I’ll call him Robo-Joe.

Robo-Joe had one goal in life:

Get with sorority girls.

He was decent-looking and our school was literally 70% female, so
the odds were stacked in his favor.

But there was a problem…

He had the charisma of a rock.

Joe was the type of person that likely doesn’t have inner
dialogue, but if he did I imagine it would sound as follows:

“I want gorls. I go to school that 70% gorl. I join frat to seem
normal so I get mor gorl. I go gym to get big and strwong so gorl
like me.”

Because he was a robot, he took a very direct approach to the
above goal.

He thought that all of the things above would make him desirable.

And while he did have some ‘success,’ Joes intentions became
clear to anyone with half a brain.

He didn’t pledge a fraternity because he wanted to make genuine
friends; he did so to make it look like he had friends.

He was obsessed with the gym because, in his mind, it would make
him desirable to women.

Robo-Joe tried to cover up his intentions by becoming your
typical jacked frat bro.

And he wasn’t the sharpest tool in the shed, so it didn’t really
work.

Fun fact: our wardens actually made him play brain games for 20
minutes a day and report back with his progress because he was
quite slow.

Anyway, I’m telling you all about Robo-Joe because this is the
approach most people take when they want something.

subject: The anti-robot approach to getting clients
body:
The other day, I sent you an email titled “HOW TO NOT BE A BOT.”

 It’s the most important life hack you can understand.

 It’ll get you clients, friends, perceived status, etc. Simply put, not being a bot makes you a winner.

 Today, I want to dive into the psychology behind this.

 In college, there was a kid in my pledge class who we called a robot.

 For the sake of the story, I’ll call him Robo-Joe.

 Robo-Joe had one goal in life:

 Get with sorority girls.

 He was decent-looking and our school was literally 70% female, so the odds were stacked in his favor.

 But there was a problem…

 He had the charisma of a rock.

 Joe was the type of person that likely doesn’t have inner dialogue, but if he did I imagine it would sound as follows:

 “I want gorls. I go to school that 70% gorl. I join frat to seem normal so I get mor gorl. I go gym to get big and strwong so gorl like me.”

 Because he was a robot, he took a very direct approach to the above goal.

 He thought that all of the things above would make him desirable.

 And while he did have some ‘success,’ Joes intentions became clear to anyone with half a brain.

 He didn’t pledge a fraternity because he wanted to make genuine friends; he did so to make it look like he had friends.

 He was obsessed with the gym because, in his mind, it would make him desirable to women.

 Robo-Joe tried to cover up his intentions by becoming your typical jacked frat bro.

 And he wasn’t the sharpest tool in the shed, so it didn’t really work.

 Fun fact: our wardens actually made him play brain games for 20 minutes a day and report back with his progress because he was quite slow.

 Anyway, I’m telling you all about Robo-Joe because this is the approach most people take when they want something.

 Let’s say you want to get your first client and decide that you’re just gonna spam DM a bunch of people without doing any research on who they are or what you should offer them.

 You do that for 3 months, and it doesn’t work because you’re retarded so you quit.

 That’s the direct Robo-Joe approach.

 Let’s talk about the better way to get what you want…

 The first five info-product clients I got were all online basketball trainers.

 I went 4/4 on outreach, and one of them (who had half a million followers) reached out to me first.

 So, to make it clear, I sent four messages and got five clients, which is statistically impossible if you’re not named Ben Bader.

 The reason this worked wasn’t because of my script or even any crazy case study.

 It was because of two things:

 I existed on the internet. I was posting content about basketball trainer marketing and running ads. I used my brain to reach out at the right time. If they posted a new offer or something that I thought I could help with on their story, that’s when I’d send a DM. Actually, I guess I lied — the third element was that I was half decent at writing copy and providing the other services I was offering, so I was confident in the way I spoke to them.

 That’s the anti-robot approach. It might sound like it’ll take longer, but it diminishes your need to get lucky by spam DM’ing a bunch of people.

 I don’t know if there was any saving Robo-Joe, but if he had put the time into becoming someone who was desirable to women instead of trying shallow fixes to fake it, maybe he would’ve had a shot.

 ​ Anyway, I figured out the key to happiness and share it with you in this video. ​

 See you over there,

 Ben

 ​
​

subject: Opportunity for you bo
body:
As I walk past the joyful construction workers on my way back
from the coffee shop, I can’t help but feel a sense of guilt.

It’s only 9am but the dirt covering their hands and clothes
indicates they’ve been up working for hours.

They’re blasting an upbeat Hispanic song while smiling and
laughing, probably making fun of stupid gringos clutching their
coffee cups tight to their chests as they walk by.

I’m sure they have a long day ahead of them, but the spirit in
their eyes shows that they’re okay with that.

“These are the people I envy,” I think to myself as I sit here
clicking buttons in my air-conditioned box in the sky.

I’ve spent much of the morning in my head.

Thinking about how I need $100m yesterday, my dead hoop dreams,
and the mountain of things on my to-do list for the day.

But when I walked by the jovial construction workers, it brought
me back to the present.

They were sitting there on the edge of their truck, completely
here.

No moping, no whining, just utter appreciation for life itself.

The lesson that resonated with me the most in The Four Agreements
was “Do your best.”

Those three words make up the background on my phone, and
although it’s a simple message, it truly diminishes the
possibility of disappointment.

It gives you a sense of pride as it ensures that you always show
up as the best version of yourself.

When you do your best, you make the most of every opportunity. It
makes time fly by, even when you’re completing a rather trivial
task.

The construction workers show up every day and do their best.
That's what makes it fun.

Sure, they have other goals, aspirations, and worries.

But for now, they are where they are.

And you are where you are.

Accepting that fact doesn’t mean you’re forgoing your hopes and
dreams, as you don’t need to constantly create an internal Hell
to continue progressing.

You perform best when you find a way to enjoy what you’re doing.

Be here, do your best, and life goes from black and white to
color.

Anyway, this was supposed to be a launch email where I tell you
about my new partnership and offer for you.

As you can tell, I deviated from that plan, so I’ll just plug it
here quickly.

If you’re trying to build a copywriting business, become a
‘growth operator,’ or build an agency, and you want my help…

​Go here and I’ll give you all the details. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hd5xwzkcrh5qor999cm/25h2hoh2l7m4p3t3/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItb3B0LWluP2VsPWJlbi1lbWFpbA==
)​

Have a good day and don’t forget to be where you are,

Ben

​

subject: how i accidentally became a copywriter
body:
I was just writing a separate email to you, but I got stuck
halfway through.

Now I’ve opened up a new blank page, and hopefully this time,
I’ll be able to fill it with enough words to create a coherent
email.

My fingers keep trying to drift to one of the other 30 tabs I
have open on my computer to distract me from writing this.

I guess while we’re here, I’ll tell you about my new partnership
with Copy MBA. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh2rkd85t2hx904666u7/9qhzhnhp4d6pn2c9/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbA==
)​

You may know of my friend Cardinal Mason.

He has a coaching program teaching people how to build a
copywriting business.

A few years ago, we did a podcast together while I was living in
Tulum, Mexico.

He was making around $40k per month as a copywriter, and I was
spinning my wheels trying to scale my basketball trainer
marketing agency.

I remember thinking to myself that I could do what he was doing
and make more money than I was then.

I didn’t realize it then, but the next month, I got my first
copywriting client.

It was an online basketball trainer named Ganon Baker.

He had tens of thousands of social media followers, and I came in
to write ad scripts, run his email marketing, and write a new VSL
script.

He was paying me $2,500 per month for all of this, which I was
stoked about because I’d previously been working with clients who
paid me just $1k per month.

Next thing you know, I was working with 3 of the other big online
basketball trainers.

One of them was a guy named Jordan Lawley, who has over half a
million followers on Instagram.

I remember him telling me on our first call that he wanted to
work with me because he liked the copy in one of the ads I wrote.

This was the foundation of the business I run now which has
allowed me to hit $100k months.

I used my copywriting ability to land clients and then started
offering other services to them.

Things like I mentioned above, like ads, email automations, and
video scripts.

Plus, building funnels, backend systems, and helping manage their
sales teams.

It was the addition of these skills that allowed me to get
clients on rev share deals and charge up to $45k/month.

But it all started with copy.

And that’s why I think it’s the most valuable skill anyone can
learn as a beginner.

The Copy MBA Inner Circle is the best place to start.

Mason will give you everything you need to know to become a
proficient copywriter, and you’ll also get access to my course,
which will teach you the additional skills I’ve used to scale my
business.

I made a video talking about this new partnership, which you can
watch here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh2rkd85t2hx904666u7/9qhzhnhp4d6pn2c9/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbA==
)​

See you over there,

Ben

P.S. Here’s my recent YT video on how I got my first client (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh2rkd85t2hx904666u7/3ohphkh7x327vqur/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9UdmVnX3dQWllXQT9zaT02cTN4VEhhY2ozeWpCNnJx
)​

subject: how to stop drifting through life
body:
I was sitting at lunch today with a couple of friends, and we
talked about what people do after college.

All three of us could think of a handful of people we knew in
school who are now just drifting.

They either moved back in with their parents or they’re working
some dead end job “figuring things out.”

This is absolutely asinine to me.

Wasn’t the point of college to find some direction and career
path?

Many of my friends who graduated about a year ago have reached
out to me, expressing unhappiness about the situation it’s left
them in.

They’d spent the last four years (and hundreds of thousands of
dollars) pretending like this day would never come.

Now, it’s not like they’re doomed for life, but it’s definitely a
hell of a lot harder.

I’m not writing this to shame them but rather to warn you about
what could happen if you try to ignore the inevitable destination
that it will lead you to.

How long will you lie to yourself and say you’ll make a change
“one day?”

That day will never come if you don’t create it.

It starts by making the conscious decision to design your life in
a way that will steer you in a new direction.

Your habits, thoughts, and beliefs must begin to change.

This is how you step into a new identity.

The worst place in life is in the middle, drifting between what
you want and what you have.

If your actions aren’t in alignment with the life you want to
create, you’re in danger.

You can continue ignoring that feeling that tells you that you
want more, or you can decide to actually commit to building this
new reality.

I know this sounds simple, but if you objectively audit what
you’re doing right now, and it isn’t propelling you to where you
want to be, you have a problem.

If you choose to ignore the problem, it will grow like a parasite
in the back of your mind.

Eventually, you’ll be the unhappy 50-year-old with a life full of
“what ifs.”

Stop drifting, my friend.

Life is beautiful when you create it. I’m telling you firsthand
that the hardship that comes with change is worth the experiences
and freedom it grants you access to.

Take control of your life before it’s too late,

Ben

P.S. If you want to build a copywriting business, I have an
opportunity for you.

You may have seen that I recently partnered with my friend
Cardinal Mason inside of Copy MBA.

It’s his birthday tomorrow, and we’re running a $1,000 discount
for the next few days.

​To get access to it, go here and apply now. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h75wlwnalhn5g6kkku4/6qheh8h7x002wvfo/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbC1CZGF5c2FsZQ==
)​

This is limited and won’t be available for long.

P.P.S. I made a new video that’ll show you how to get through the
days when you don’t feel like being productive.

​You can check it out here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h75wlwnalhn5g6kkku4/kkhmh6hlz449edul/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9jaFktellYTllEcz9zaT1MbjA0UmJ3cnE4bWhQTG5m
)​

​
