subject: Preparation is the enemy of success
body:
When I moved to Miami almost two years ago, I was a very
different person.

I was making around $15k-$20k per month, I had less confidence,
and the move here was intimidating to me.

The last ~20 months have been transformational.

My income has increased by more than 5x, and my social circle has
expanded while I’ve developed tighter bonds with the few people
I’d consider brothers.

The entire way I view myself has changed.

I started doing many of the things that were on my “one-day”
list.

My personal brand has grown, I’ve picked up new hobbies, and my
lifestyle is exactly the way I used to dream of.

I’ve taken a series of actions that have created a ripple effect.

When you do one thing that you’re a bit nervous to do, your brain
realizes that the fears you have around that thing are
self-imagined.

The ceiling that you’ve placed on yourself starts to get removed.

This makes it easier to tackle the next thing you’re putting off,
and so on.

But knocking down that first domino is always the hardest.

Right now, you have beliefs that align with the person that you
are in the present.

To do something new, those beliefs have to change – but they
won’t change by standing in the mirror and telling yourself
affirmations, watching self-help YouTube videos, or meditating in
front of a Tony Robbins poster.

You must go out into the world and give yourself real data that
an alternate identity is possible.

Obviously, I can sit here and tell you this over and over, but it
won’t mean shit to you until you actually put it into practice.

Throughout my days as a basketball player, this was something I
struggled with.

I was always in the gym, watching film, writing down goals, and
doing everything I could to make my hoop dreams come true.

But I was never fully able to step into that new reality and play
to what I knew my true ability was in real games.

It’s almost like I was rewarding myself for all the preparation I
was doing rather than actually applying it where it mattered.

This is similar to rehearsing the “perfect” lines to say to a
girl at the bar, but when you get there, you stand in the corner
refreshing the weather app.

Or you could do all the research possible about copywriting, read
all the books, and buy courses, but never send a DM and try to
get a client.

Practice means nothing without action.

Sometimes, it’s better to be less prepared and dive in head first
rather than sharpening your sword to never pull it out.

Do the things that are difficult for you and watch your
limitations evaporate.

I promise it’ll be worth it.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: Preparation is the enemy of success
body:
When I moved to Miami almost two years ago, I was a very different person. 

 I was making around $15k-$20k per month, I had less confidence, and the move here was intimidating to me. 

 The last ~20 months have been transformational. 

 My income has increased by more than 5x, and my social circle has expanded while I’ve developed tighter bonds with the few people I’d consider brothers. 

 The entire way I view myself has changed. 

 I started doing many of the things that were on my “one-day” list. 

 My personal brand has grown, I’ve picked up new hobbies, and my lifestyle is exactly the way I used to dream of. 

 I’ve taken a series of actions that have created a ripple effect. 

 When you do one thing that you’re a bit nervous to do, your brain realizes that the fears you have around that thing are self-imagined. 

 The ceiling that you’ve placed on yourself starts to get removed. 

 This makes it easier to tackle the next thing you’re putting off, and so on. 

 But knocking down that first domino is always the hardest. 

 Right now, you have beliefs that align with the person that you are in the present. 

 To do something new, those beliefs have to change – but they won’t change by standing in the mirror and telling yourself affirmations, watching self-help YouTube videos, or meditating in front of a Tony Robbins poster. 

 You must go out into the world and give yourself real data that an alternate identity is possible. 

 Obviously, I can sit here and tell you this over and over, but it won’t mean shit to you until you actually put it into practice. 

 Throughout my days as a basketball player, this was something I struggled with. 

 I was always in the gym, watching film, writing down goals, and doing everything I could to make my hoop dreams come true. 

 But I was never fully able to step into that new reality and play to what I knew my true ability was in real games. 

 It’s almost like I was rewarding myself for all the preparation I was doing rather than actually applying it where it mattered. 

 This is similar to rehearsing the “perfect” lines to say to a girl at the bar, but when you get there, you stand in the corner refreshing the weather app. 

 Or you could do all the research possible about copywriting, read all the books, and buy courses, but never send a DM and try to get a client. 

 Practice means nothing without action. 

 Sometimes, it’s better to be less prepared and dive in head first rather than sharpening your sword to never pull it out. 

 Do the things that are difficult for you and watch your limitations evaporate. 

 I promise it’ll be worth it. 

 Talk tomorrow, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Our $1,000 discount on the Copy MBA Inner Circle is live – go here to start building your copywriting business. ​

subject: brain dump for bo
body:
Happy Friday! TGIF!!! Any fun weekend plans???

Hahaha.

Grow up.

It’s such a beautiful day here that I feel bad for anyone who
isn’t in the state of Florida.

Besides those who are in Orlando. Or even worse… Tampa. Ew.

Imagine the highlight of your city being a predatory theme park
or a place called “Meat Market.”

At least Tampa has “The Edition” - a 3.5-star hotel in any major
city, but seems to be the main attraction since there’s nothing
else to do there. They also only employ members of the LGBTDJKD
community.

I’m not trying to be homophobic, but members of this community
don’t seem to have the best work ethic, so things tend to take
longer at this hotel. However, they are very good at making
lattes.

Anyway I’m sitting outside Starbucks, sipping on a cold brew with
vanilla cream and sugar, and thinking about how much of a
hypocrite I am.

I just got jealous of a homeless man because he looked happy and
had really good posture.

I can’t help but judge the man a couple tables away from me
wearing a suit on his lunch break.

I started off this email by making fun of those who look forward
to Fridays and weekends, but I’d be lying if I said my mood isn’t
slightly better on days like this.

And if I actually followed the majority of the advice I give on
the internet, I’d be a billionaire by now.

A wise man once said, “The most honest people are hypocrites.”

The wise man who said that is the same one who’s writing this
email.

And if you’re still reading by now you’re probably wondering
where the lesson is or what I’m gonna “teach” you here.

My goal is not to teach but rather entertain.

The richest people are the entertainers. Think about Tate. His
message wasn’t something that others hadn’t said prior.

But he blew up because the guy is just outrageous. The way he
speaks, the stories he tells, and the unapologetic expression of
his thoughts.

It was refreshing to see someone who genuinely seemed not to care
if people didn’t agree with him while simultaneously saying what
everyone else was thinking.

On another note, most of the successful people I know are really
lazy when they’re uninterested.

Myself included — I’ve always had a really hard time doing things
I don’t want to do.

I’ll wait until the final deadline, half-ass the project, cheat
off the Asian kid, and do everything I can to get by while
putting in minimal effort.

But when I’m bought in and find something that I’m interested in,
I turn into an autistic computer engineer.

I can spend hours at my desk without losing focus. It occupies my
mind constantly.

Maybe you’re the same.

One thing I’ve started to understand about this is that obsession
is created, not found.

You don’t “stumble” upon something you’re passionate about.

But rather, you create that passion by diving into a project and
learning to love the mundane tasks that come with it.

Ok, I gotta hop on a call, but before I go, I’m feeling generous
today, so I’m giving $100 to a random subscriber who watches and
comments on my recent YT video.

​Go here and watch this video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4v2mvvbph29lx000h6/7qh7h8hod5vd8waz/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9OWGFNYktTcDdLMA==
) (leave a comment with your favorite thing I said in the video).

Considering my audience is still relatively small, you have like
a 1/10 chance of winning probably.

Bye love you,

Ben

P.S. If you want me to help you build a copywriting or “growth
operator” business, check this out. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4v2mvvbph29lx000h6/owhkhqhrxd3xnoiv/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbC1CZGF5c2FsZQ==
)​

​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4v2mvvbph29lx000h6
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4v2mvvbph29lx000h6
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnh4v2mvvbph29lx000h6/z2hghnh35x9570fp/aHR0cHM6Ly9jb252ZXJ0a2l0LmNvbS9mZWF0dXJlcy9lbWFpbC1tYXJrZXRpbmc_dXRtX2NhbXBhaWduPXBvd2VyZWRieSZ1dG1fY29udGVudD1lbWFpbCZ1dG1fbWVkaXVtPXJlZmVycmFsJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9ZHluYW1pYw==

subject: secret to enjoying your life
body:
Happy Mother’s Day.

I’m mildly hungover and going to lunch in 10 min, so this will be
a quicker one.

I saw a tweet from my friend Grant this morning that goes as
follows:

“If your work doesn’t get finished, you can’t enjoy anything

So if your habit is avoiding work, it is also a habit of living
without enjoyment”

Couldn’t be more true.

Odds are, you know that exact feeling.

You could be out with friends, walking on the beach, or in bed
with the love of your life.

But when there’s something that you’re avoiding, you still hear
that voice in the back of your head.

It mocks you while you try to forget about it by doing literally
anything but confront it.

It doesn’t let you find peace. It doesn’t let you enjoy the
moment. It’s a constant chatter that won’t be shut up by ignoring
it.

Whether it’s work you’re avoiding, a decision, or the direction
of your life entirely — your soul knows when your actions aren’t
in alignment with your desires.

You’ll be in a constant state of anxiety when you’re avoidant.

You can lie to others, but you can’t lie to yourself.

But honestly if this sounds familiar, you’re one of the lucky
ones.

You now know that there’s some fire in your soul.

And you know that there’s a direction it’s pulling you in.

It’s up to you to follow it :)

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. Come with me to get a pup cup (

) (like and comment your favorite quote from the video, and I’ll
send a random subscriber $100)

P.P.S If you commented on my previous video I just replied to the
winner of the last giveaway so check your notifs.

subject: The money you want is right in front of you
body:
The money you want is right in front of you; you’re just looking
in the wrong places.

This is something I think about often.

Every now and then, I’ll hop on calls with people who are clearly
sitting on a goldmine.

Maybe they have an in-demand skill, a large audience that isn’t
properly monetized, or some other form of leverage they are not
accessing.

From the outside looking in, the right move is so clear to me.

But it’s almost like they’re wearing tinted glasses that are
blocking them from making the obvious decision that could
drastically increase their income.

It’s like when you have a friend who gets into a relationship
with someone who clearly isn’t good for them.

They’re “drunk in love” and can’t see the red flags or problems
associated with the relationship.

Once the glasses are removed, their vision becomes clear, and the
problem vanishes.

This works the same way in business.

People continuously look for the next shiny object, the next
move, or the alternative direction they could take.

But they refuse to look at what’s right in front of them.

Let’s say you get a copywriting client who pays you $3k per month
to run their email marketing.

You think to yourself, “Okay, this is great. Now I just need to
get a few more clients, and I’ll be at $10k per month.”

You then spend the majority of your time trying to get more
clients.

It doesn’t go as planned, and the client you had dropped you
after a few months because they weren’t getting the desired
result from email.

Now you’re back at square one.

The problem?

You were looking in the wrong place.

Had you objectively assessed their business, you would’ve noticed
that their funnel needs work, their VSL is shit, and their sales
team isn’t following up with leads.

Because of this, your emails didn’t increase revenue because
there were other holes that needed to be patched.

But you weren’t focused on that.

You were spamming strangers on the internet, trying to get
another client.

What if you had fixed the other gaps in your clients' business?

Let's say you rewrite their VSL, build them a new funnel, and
help the sales team manage their leads.

Between these changes and your email marketing efforts, the
revenue increases by 2 or 3x.

And because you were the person who helped them make more money,
they’re happily giving you a percentage of the revenue.

Boom - you just turned your $3k/month client into a $10k/month
client because you maximized the opportunity in front of you.

Here’s the part where I shamelessly plug the Copy MBA Inner
Circle (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmh09dnlzi6hdow7000sg/3ohphkh7x504w3ur/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbA==
) and show you how Vagner is doing exactly what I described
above.

​
He’s already made an extra $2k because of it.

To get access to the same information he has, a community of
other copywriters, and direct coaching from me and the Copy MBA
team, go here now to learn more. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmh09dnlzi6hdow7000sg/3ohphkh7x504w3ur/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbA==
)​

See you over there,

Ben

​

) | Update your profile (

subject: Winners And Losers
body:
Hey bo.

I don’t know why, but I have this deep disdain and partial
jealousy for people who “sell out” for the info bag.

By “sell out” I mean normify their offer.

All their videos turn into hyper-edited VSLs.

They talk about extremely basic and broad concepts.

And their sole goal is to convince the masses that the business
model they’re selling is the “easiest way to hit $10k/month.”

This works. You dumb down all of your content and sell the dream
to naive beginners.

You know 90% or more of your customers will fail, but this is
usually how to make the most money in coaching.

Is it unethical?

Not necessarily — if your program is good and some people still
get results, you can make the argument that you did your best.

But it’s just not my style.

Even though I’m now partnered with Copy MBA (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8hk7eq2xfzhqk4v666bn/8ghqhohlwrxwdzik/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbA==
) and am financially incentivized to tell you how “easy”
copywriting is, I can’t.

No business model is easy.

I think it’s a better option than dropshipping, trading,
wholesale RE, and many other business models.

But is it any better for a beginner than doing sales or TikTok
shop affiliate?

No.

And will most people who buy any course or coaching program fail,
no matter the business model?

Yes.

I don’t mean to be pessimistic here. I just firmly believe that
the intangibles make or break you.

There are winners and losers.

​The best copywriting program in the world (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8hk7eq2xfzhqk4v666bn/8ghqhohlwrxwdzik/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPUJlbi1FbWFpbA==
) can help you, but at the end of the day, you will never
outperform your self-image.

And if you’re unable to transform yourself into a person
deserving of financial success, it will always elude you.

No matter if you’re a copywriter, dropshipper, TikTok shop
affiliate, or onlyfans thot.

Actually, OF might be the one exception.

Anyway, I’ll always keep it real with you. Even if that costs me
money.

You will succeed at any business if you’re a winner. If you’re a
loser, good luck.

Enough rambling for today — I made a vlog yesterday and will give
a random commenter $100.

subject: Winners And Losers
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 I don’t know why, but I have this deep disdain and partial jealousy for people who “sell out” for the info bag. 

 By “sell out” I mean normify their offer. 

 All their videos turn into hyper-edited VSLs. 

 They talk about extremely basic and broad concepts. 

 And their sole goal is to convince the masses that the business model they’re selling is the “easiest way to hit $10k/month.” 

 This works. You dumb down all of your content and sell the dream to naive beginners. 

 You know 90% or more of your customers will fail, but this is usually how to make the most money in coaching. 

 Is it unethical? 

 Not necessarily — if your program is good and some people still get results, you can make the argument that you did your best. 

 But it’s just not my style. 

 Even though I’m now partnered with Copy MBA and am financially incentivized to tell you how “easy” copywriting is, I can’t. 

 No business model is easy. 

 I think it’s a better option than dropshipping, trading, wholesale RE, and many other business models. 

 But is it any better for a beginner than doing sales or TikTok shop affiliate? 

 No. 

 And will most people who buy any course or coaching program fail, no matter the business model? 

 Yes. 

 I don’t mean to be pessimistic here. I just firmly believe that the intangibles make or break you. 

 There are winners and losers. 

 ​ The best copywriting program in the world can help you, but at the end of the day, you will never outperform your self-image. 

 And if you’re unable to transform yourself into a person deserving of financial success, it will always elude you. 

 No matter if you’re a copywriter, dropshipper, TikTok shop affiliate, or onlyfans thot. 

 Actually, OF might be the one exception. 

 Anyway, I’ll always keep it real with you. Even if that costs me money. 

 You will succeed at any business if you’re a winner. If you’re a loser, good luck. 

 Enough rambling for today — I made a vlog yesterday and will give a random commenter $100. 

 ​ Watch me live a normal day in Miami here. (and comment your fav part of the video to enter the giveaway). 

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Just so you know I'm not capping about the $100 giveaways, here's a screenshot of me sending money to the last two winners: 

 ​

 ​ ​

subject: 3 important reminders
body:
It’s gotten to the point in Miami where the second you step
outside, you start sweating.

I just got back from a 30 min walk, and I’m very wet (pause no
homo).

As you may have seen, I recently started uploading on Youtube.

It’s been my obsession for the last month, and I’ve been reminded
of many lessons, three of which I’ll share with you now:

1. You allow for the possibility of greatness when you stop
trying to be perfect.

The other day, I woke up scrambling for an idea.

I wanted to start my next Youtube video with narration and
b-roll.

As I walked to Starbucks to get some shots and try to think of an
idea, I realized it was right in front of me (watch the video for
context) (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqhkvz065cvhp6eorrrho/z2hghnh35m263dhp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9Kajd1VUVjdXYyZz9zaT1KV01HWjFtNnFmLVQxVnpM
)​

The lesson:

Your best work and most fruitful business ventures usually happen
by accident.

Just get the ball rolling, and things will work out.

As long as you’re aware and conscious of the opportunities that
appear in front of you, you’ll stumble into greatness.

2. Don’t let your fear of heightened standards stop you from
starting.

This is something I talk about often, as I’m frequently reminded
of it.

As you progress in any endeavor, you add more pressure by
revealing to yourself what you are capable of.

You’re probably subconsciously aware of this now, and it could be
the reason that you’re putting off a goal.

I’m reminded of this with each video I post. There's this voice
in the back of my head that says, “What’s next? How are you gonna
top that?”

It’s a constant pressure that comes with a certain standard. But
I can promise it’s far better than the anxiety that comes with
suppressing your desires.

3. The best lessons are pulled from the trenches.

Any time I take on a new endeavor, I’m able to see many
similarities between each pursuit.

I’ve learned more from things like boxing, lifestyle maxxing, and
making content than I have from any coaching program or course.

Side quests are often life's best teachers.

And who knows, maybe you’ll learn a lesson or open a door that’ll
help you financially as well.

Anyway – here’s the link to my new Youtube video. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqhkvz065cvhp6eorrrho/z2hghnh35m263dhp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9Kajd1VUVjdXYyZz9zaT1KV01HWjFtNnFmLVQxVnpM
)​

As always I’ll give $100 to a random subscriber who comments
their favorite part from the vid.

Love you, and lmk if you liked this one :)

Ben

​

subject: ATTENTION
body:
“Attention is the new currency.”

You’ve likely heard this before.

Make content, build an audience, and sell them something.

It’s one of the quickest ways people are getting rich.

Over the last few years, it seems like the floodgates have been
opened.

Everyone and their Grandma are content creators.

I can’t go to lunch without seeing people with hundreds of
thousands of followers.

It literally seems like it’s one in every three people.

This is what has allowed me to build my agency.

As you may know, I work with people who have a big audience and
sell information.

We write their copy, build their funnels, script their videos,
and basically manage the entire backend for them, so all they
have to do is make more videos and get more attention.

The more eyeballs they get, the more money they make, which makes
our services more valuable and they end up paying us more.

This is the simplest way I can explain my business's role in the
“attention economy.”

We’re leveraging a vast skillset, time, and expertise to
capitalize on creators' existing audiences and help them make way
more money than they would without us.

For most of our clients, our work is relatively the same – we
build the similar landing pages, write similar emails, and even
the VSL and webinar scripts are relatively templated.

On our end, there’s minimal difference in the workload between a
client who pays us $5k/month versus one who pays us $30k/month.

The singular variable is attention.

We recently started working with a guy who has a really solid
audience.

He has multiple six-figure followers, good engagement, and his
content is fire.

From one post on Instagram and Tik Tok, he’s gotten the number of
leads that we should be able to generate around a quarter million
dollars from over the next week.

From one post.

Let me reiterate – the one difference between him and someone who
makes little money from info is the audience.

Someone else could have the same story, results, success,
expertise, etc.

But if they don’t have a loyal audience of people who know, like,
and trust them on the internet, it means nothing.

Attention is everything.

Whether you’re trying to build your own coaching business or
you’re doing something similar to me.

Your marketing efforts, systems, and positioning do not matter if
no one is seeing it.

So if you’re a copywriter or “gRoWtH oPeraToR” keep this in mind
when trying to get clients.

To get a killer case study, you need a killer client – a pig with
lipstick on is still a pig. lol.

Anyway, I’ve been having a ton of fun working with the students
inside the Copy MBA Inner Circle, and it’s dope to see them
getting results from it.

​If you wanna make money as a copywriter or growth operator you
should go here and apply so I can make you rich ok? Ok. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukho5o5l7crh59mxnnnc7/z2hghnh3n98ezzup/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPWJlbi1lbWFpbA==
)​

Talk later,

Ben

​

​

) | Update your profile (

subject: The "easy bucket method"
body:
I was crossing the street this morning and there was a red Tesla
quickly approaching me.

Considering it’s an electric vehicle, I figured if it hit me I
would do more damage to the car than it would to me.

Luckily, it stopped, and we didn’t have to find out if that
hypothesis would hold up.

I have a quick tip for you tn…

I’m on the couch scrolling through Youtube and watching Kyrie
Irving dominate against the Timberwolves.

As I begin writing this, he has 26 points. Early in the first
quarter, he hit two open shots in a row, and from that point on,
he’s been lighting it up.

This is something you’ll commonly see amongst the best scorers in
basketball.

If they get an easy shot early on, this will help them get into a
rhythm, and it’s going to be a long night for the defense.

This “easy bucket method” is something I use almost every day
(off the basketball court).

When I sit down to work, most of my tasks each day fall into one
of two categories:

1. Easy to complete, low time commitment

Or…

2. Difficult to complete, higher time commitment

I almost always start with one of the easier, lower-friction
actions, and once I knock a few of those out, I build momentum –
Which makes it much easier to move on to the more time-intensive
stuff.

This is one of my best “productivity hacks,” and I use it
whenever I am trying to achieve a bigger goal.

Very simple concept, but try it out next time you find yourself
procrastinating.

Anyway, check out my recent video if you haven’t already 👇

​ (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnhqv60koc9h0vqr333bw/owhkhqhrpk7kdeuv/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS83a2ZicFdYTUtCOA==
)I have $100 for a random subscriber who leaves a comment about
their favorite part of the vid :)

Night bo,

Ben

​

subject: The best things in life are earned
body:
All of the best things in life are earned.

This is especially true for men and is something that you’ll
constantly be reminded of as you “level up.”

There are no shortcuts.

True genuine friendships, the girl who loves and admires you, and
the impact on other people are all things that you cannot access
by finding a loophole.

You have to become “him.”

Money alone won’t do this for you.

There is one thing that usually has the biggest impact on the
quality of experience you get to access.

And it’s your relationships.

First with yourself and then with others.

Let’s say you get “lucky” financially.

You hit a big crypto rug pull, you run scam eCom brands, or you
start selling Viagra to old men and pimp out your grandmother on
OF.

It works, and you get “access” to all the money you could need,
which, in theory, will buy you the best experiences that life has
to offer.

But there’s this deep-seated belief in your head that feels like
you’re unworthy.

While you earned the money you wanted you didn’t improve your
relationship with yourself along the way.

Maybe your back was never against the wall and you didn’t develop
the grit that comes with digging yourself out of a hole. Or maybe
you don’t fully respect yourself because you’ve found success
through nefarious means.

Because of these factors, you aren’t the type of person that
other amazing, genuine people want to be around.

You end up attracting shallow people into your life – guys who
would slander your name if it’s in their best interest and a girl
who would leave your table at the club to go to Futures table
(rip).

You see a lot of these types in Miami and they’re usually dripped
out in Chrome Hearts.

These are people who “beat the system.”

They found the financial success that others dream of, perhaps
without having to go through the usual hardship or personal
development process.

But they don’t get to fully enjoy the money because they haven’t
become the person who is worthy of incredible relationships, as
you attract what you are.

And even if you “earn” all the money in the world, you still have
to earn your relationships.

Laying on the beach in Barbados means nothing if you aren’t with
people you love.

Driving your dream car through the Hollywood hills doesn’t hit
the same if the girl in your passenger seat only likes you for
your money.

Opening your banking app to a number that would allow you to
retire at any moment feels empty when you don’t like the person
whose face you see in the reflection of your screen.

Your relationships are everything and there are no shortcuts that
will earn you respect.

So if you’re in the trenches right now and you feel like you’re
not reaping the rewards of your efforts…

Congratulations. You’re in the process of developing into the
person who is worthy of the reality that you want.

Sorry for the hiatus. Good to be back,

Ben

P.S. Go here if you want my help in building a copywriting or
"growth operating" business. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hd08mpkulh84pd777i8/reh8hoh04qw0g8c2/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMx
)​

P.P.S. I’m thinking about putting together a program for coaches,
consultants, and course sellers who are under $100k per month. In
there, I will give you the systems that we use to scale clients
up to $600k/month. If this is something you might be interested
in, hit reply and let me know.

​

​

​

subject: One habit that improves every area of life
body:
Yo bo,

Four years ago, I started one habit that's been the single
biggest driving factor of my growth and success.

Not only has it made me seven figures and helped me build an
audience online…

But this one habit has acted as my therapist, improved my mental
clarity, and has made me a more articulate and effective
communicator.

And the fact that you’re reading this right now is proof of all
of this.

Let's rewind to 2020.

I’m a 19 year old sophomore in college and I’ve started to dip my
toes in the water of entrepreneurship.

There’s a lot on my mind on this particular summer day in
Charleston so I decide to open a Google doc and start writing.

I write about what I’m trying to do in my business and what’s
been stressing me out.

After a few paragraphs, I close my laptop and realize I feel a
lot better than I did before I opened it.

I didn’t realize it at the time, but my life had just changed.

This became a habit I’d do almost daily for the following years.

Over time, I started to notice the benefits.

I became a better writer, my brain felt less cluttered, and
holding myself accountable became easier because I was reporting
back to myself on progress I’d made each day.

I began writing on Twitter, I put together this newsletter and
picked up a few copywriting clients.

Writing became a part of me.

My outlet, my income, and my vessel to share my thoughts with
others on the internet.

It led to the lifestyle I’m living now.

It bought me my dream car.

It connected me with my best friends.

And this is why I think it’s one the most valuable skills you can
learn and habits you can develop.

Whether you want to build a copywriting business, grow an
audience online, or have an outlet to close the tabs in your head
at the end of each day…

Start writing.

You won’t regret it.

Have a good weekend,

Ben

P.S. If you want my direct help in building your copywriting or
growth operating business, I'll show you exactly what we do for
our clients with millions of followers (plus how we're able to
charge singular clients up to $40k/month) -- check this out. (

subject: Why you should tell more lies
body:
Last night my girl and I tried to make Carbones spicy rigatoni at
home from scratch.

We left the sauce on the heat for a bit too long so it got kind
of soupy but other than that it was good.

The only problem is my apartment still kind of smells like
onions.

This information is completely irrelevant to you but I thought
I’d share it anyway.

Moving on – the other day I watched a video my friend Rob made
titled “tell a lie 1,000 times and it becomes the truth.”

Many successful people are examples of this.

It’s like they “crown themselves” prematurely and after enough
time, they become what they were pretending to be.

Let’s use your average agency owner turned course guru as an
example.

They get to ~$30k/month with their agency and build an audience
online in the process.

Eventually they start to feel “burnt out” from their agency and
realize they’re sitting on a different goldmine.

They have this big audience of people who knows, likes, and
trusts them as an authority in the agency space.

Now, are they the most “qualified” agency owner in the world?

Definitely not.

There are plenty of agency owners making 5x, 10x, and even 100x
their revenue.

But are there hundreds of people ready to pay to learn from them?

100%.

And now they reach a crossroads…

Do they keep trying to scale the agency as the main focus, or do
they launch a coaching program?

That’s when they “crown themself.”

They become the agency guru, make a bunch of money coaching and
then stop running an agency.

And because info is typically an easier business model to scale,
now they’re making $200k/month.

They simply decided that they were qualified to consult other
people for a price.

Because they gave themself this permission, they became
"qualified" and were heavily rewarded for it.

This is how most coaching programs and info products are born.

The only issue that eventually arises here is when the coach
stops doing what they are teaching.

After a few months or a year, their knowledge becomes obsolete.

This is why it can actually be good to learn from people who
teach you the exact marketing system they used to get you to buy
their product.

Long story short – give yourself permission to become the person
you want to be or start the business you want to start, and that
reality will come to fruition for you.

Make sense?

Cool.

Happy Monday,

Ben

P.S. Get my help in building your copywriting or growth operating
business to $10k/month+ here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnhqvzk9di9h0v46633hw/dpheh0h0v8e02rhm/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPWVtYWls
)​

P.P.S. Watch my new video where I share 10 rules to change your
life in the next 90 days. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnhqvzk9di9h0v46633hw/e0hph7h06q70dmu8/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9ZV1prbmMtQU9hND9zaT1vendaLVRHMDRJRnJiTG1z
)​

​ (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnhqvzk9di9h0v46633hw/e0hph7h06q70dmu8/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9ZV1prbmMtQU9hND9zaT1vendaLVRHMDRJRnJiTG1z
)​

​

subject: no ones thinking about you
body:
I'm sitting at my favorite coffee shop watching an asian man in a
yankees hat have an episode.

He's sitting about 10 feet to my right in a white tank top with
black shorts and his legs crossed.

There are three empty bottles of corona in front of him and he
just knocked one over.

He's now struggling to open his black leather backpack.

Part of me hopes he’s reaching for a weapon because this would be
the perfect time for me to become a hero. I'm seated slightly
behind him so he wouldn’t see me coming.

Plus he can’t be more than 140 pounds and one right hook to the
temple should knock him out.

Damnit. no weapon, just airpods.

From the moment I sat down he’s been talking abnormally loud.

Most of which has been mumble nonsense but at one point he asked
the man in the floral shirt at the table in front of him if he
could come sit with him.

The man politely declined.

He just took a final sip out of each of his three bottles and is
now flailing his arms above his head.

Smoke break. He put a cigarette in his mouth and walked outside.

This is fun. It's usually only homeless people that you get to
see have outbursts like this.

Other than a few staff members, no one else in the restaurant has
even noticed him.

Everyone is just in their own little bubble, dealing with their
own ambitions, obstacles, and problems.

I guess if there’s a lesson here it’s that letting the opinions
of others stop you from doing something you want is so silly.

First of all, you’re gonna die one day.

Second of all, who cares what they think.

And third, they’re probably not even gonna notice you.

Our friend is back from his smoke break.

He asked for another beer and the waiter reluctantly told him
that they aren’t legally allowed to serve more than three
alcoholic beverages.

I wonder if that’s true or if he was just worried that this guy
was gonna start dancing on the table.

Instead the waiter went and got him some water. The manic man got
up and gave him a hug.

He drunkenly said, “Thank you. I’ve had such a rough day,”
grabbed his things and walked out with hope in his stride.

Aw. What a nice happy ending.

I guess everyone’s dealing with their own shit and it's not good
for us to judge.

Anyway – This video is one of my favorites and it’s something
that helped me go from being a normal college kid to building my
dream life over the last 4 years. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h495rx4bmhmxr5544fl/wnh2hghwngzp3xh7/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9QQWRQLW9nWldjOA==
)​

See you over there,

Ben

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h495rx4bmhmxr5544fl
) | Update your profile (

) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(

subject: Lesson from $100m man
body:
Before I get into today’s email, I have a new opportunity that
may be a good fit for you.

If you’re a coach, consultant, or course seller and you want to
scale to 6 figure months, check out the video on this page. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hvdl9w4f6hrdgvv44fn/l2hehmh3ew8v0vu6/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubmluZXR5Zm91cm1hcmtldGluZy5jb20vYXBwbHktaGVyZQ==
)​

Alrighty, pitch out of the way - let’s get into it.

On my walk today I passed by former NBA player Amar'e Stoudamire.

He was sitting on a bench with his dog’s leash tied around the
leg of it, while reading a torah with a cigar in his mouth.

According to Google, he made $165,683,566 over the course of his
career.

But there he was, enjoying his day while doing something that
costs zero dollars.

I saw a quote the other day that said:

“A rich man works all is his life to live like a poor man in a
village by the sea”

That’s a bar.

Another wise man once tweeted “The best things in life are free
but you can only appreciate them once you buy everything else.”

That wise man was me.

And this is the truth. The best thing money does for you is it
offers peace of mind and freedom.

You earn yourself the freedom to take a long walks or enjoy a
cigar on a bench on a random Thursday afternoon.

Without having to worry about bills, drama at a job you hate, or
any of the other things that normies have to worry about.

You can say what you want. You can think how you want. You can
side quest. You can try new things and embark on “meaningless”
pursuits.

Money is freedom.

And it 100% makes your life 100x better because it lets you live
like you don’t have it, while giving you the peace of mind of
someone who does have it.

Getting rich is the most selfless thing you can do.

Because then you have the clarity to go figure out what you're
supposed to do here.

Make sense?

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

P.S. Go here if you want my help in building your copywriting or
growth operating business (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hvdl9w4f6hrdgvv44fn/m2h7h5h8vwd0g7im/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPWJlbi1lbWFpbA==
)​

subject: How to buy a bugatti asap
body:
Happy Sunday.

I just posted a banger video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h49dlnvsmhmxr5544fl/kkhmh6hlrr00klbl/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9hZUxhZjhoNnAxZw==
) about how I’d make $100k asap if I had to start all over.

Go watch that after you read this, or be poor and sad forever.

A man named Luis is currently on his way to my apartment on a
motorbike, carrying the cheesesteak I just ordered.

The NBA finals are playing on the TV behind my computer screen.

What a life.

They just showed a stat about Luca Doncic, who is averaging 34
points per game in the playoffs, which is the most since MJ in
the 90’s.

The interesting thing about Luca is he simply does the basics.

He’s not incredibly fast or athletic and he isn’t super fancy
with the ball.

But he’s incredible at the basics and makes everything look
simple.

Every movement is precise, from his footwork to the way he uses
his body (no homo).

He makes the right read coming off of screens and just plays at
his own speed.

Because he is so exceptional at the simple “big levers” he’s
better than 99% of players in the league.

Business works the same way.

Many of the richest people I know aren’t the most… meticulous.

They stay away from complex systems and focus on the one to
handful of actions that produce the most results.

If you’ve seen this jacked dude named Wes Watson on social media,
he’s the perfect example of this.

Go watch his content right now and he’s regurgitating some Bruce
Lee quote with motivational music and a workout compilation over
it.

He’s yelling at the camera with veins popping out of his eyelids.

Clearly he isn’t the most intelligent or articulate person in the
world.

But he’s posting multiple times per day and if you opt-in to his
funnel, you’ll get a text and a dial from his sales team within
minutes.

And based on his social media and the fact that I constantly see
him on Brickell avenue in an orange Bugatti, the guy is fucking
rich.

He has one job – get attention.

The more eyeballs he gets, the more the sales team can harass new
leads and quite literally sell them air.

That part is unimportant.

He does the basics better than everyone else.

He knows what the big levers are in his business.

He yells. A lot.

And it bought him a Bugatti.

Fuck. I want a Bugatti.

Let’s do more of the basics and have a great week,

Ben

P.S. Go here if you sell info and you want to scale to
$100k/month. (

)​

business. (

subject: How to buy a bugatti asap
body:
Happy Sunday. 

 I just posted a banger video about how I’d make $100k asap if I had to start all over. 

 Go watch that after you read this, or be poor and sad forever. 

 A man named Luis is currently on his way to my apartment on a motorbike, carrying the cheesesteak I just ordered. 

 The NBA finals are playing on the TV behind my computer screen. 

 What a life. 

 They just showed a stat about Luca Doncic, who is averaging 34 points per game in the playoffs, which is the most since MJ in the 90’s. 

 The interesting thing about Luca is he simply does the basics. 

 He’s not incredibly fast or athletic and he isn’t super fancy with the ball. 

 But he’s incredible at the basics and makes everything look simple. 

 Every movement is precise, from his footwork to the way he uses his body (no homo). 

 He makes the right read coming off of screens and just plays at his own speed. 

 Because he is so exceptional at the simple “big levers” he’s better than 99% of players in the league. 

 Business works the same way. 

 Many of the richest people I know aren’t the most… meticulous. 

 They stay away from complex systems and focus on the one to handful of actions that produce the most results. 

 If you’ve seen this jacked dude named Wes Watson on social media, he’s the perfect example of this. 

 Go watch his content right now and he’s regurgitating some Bruce Lee quote with motivational music and a workout compilation over it. 

 He’s yelling at the camera with veins popping out of his eyelids. 

 Clearly he isn’t the most intelligent or articulate person in the world. 

 But he’s posting multiple times per day and if you opt-in to his funnel, you’ll get a text and a dial from his sales team within minutes. 

 And based on his social media and the fact that I constantly see him on Brickell avenue in an orange Bugatti, the guy is fucking rich. 

 He has one job – get attention. 

 The more eyeballs he gets, the more the sales team can harass new leads and quite literally sell them air. 

 That part is unimportant. 

 He does the basics better than everyone else. 

 He knows what the big levers are in his business. 

 He yells. A lot. 

 And it bought him a Bugatti. 

 Fuck. I want a Bugatti. 

 Let’s do more of the basics and have a great week, 

 Ben 

 P.S. Go here if you sell info and you want to scale to $100k/month. ​

 P.P.S. Go here if you want my help in building your copywriting business. ​

subject: Got a haircut and figured out how be rich forever
body:
Very important update for you bo…

Guess what?

I got a haircut.

It’s my first one in three months because I had PTSD from the
last one, but my boy Roger actually hooked it up this time.

You can hold the applause for now, thank you though.

Today, I’m thinking about an idea that can help you.

Recently I came to the realization that I’ll likely be making
money through my personal brand for a long time.

Whether it’s by getting agency clients, coaching clients, or even
something else that I’m not currently doing.

Unless something changes, my personal brand will likely be the
vehicle that buys me a rose gold Patek and a different supercar
for each day of the week.

But I don’t know exactly how the micro will look.

I don’t know what offer will be the one that I scale long term.

I don’t know what platform will bring me the most clients.

And I don’t know all of the little details that’ll have an impact
on my success.

That’s a lot of don’t knows.

But I do know one thing:

More attention can only help.

The more people that find me on the internet, resonate with my
content and offensive jokes, the better.

That will only make me money.

Plus it’s really fucking cool reading comments from people who
tell me I inspired them because just four years ago I was that
person on the other side of the screen.

So right now, I’m focusing on the macro.

Content the big, obvious lever I can pull and I’d be an idiot not
to do everything I can to maximize it, even though I don’t know
exactly what doors it’ll open.

I’ll figure out the details as I go.

I sound like Gary Vee talking about content and “macro” but let
me ask you –

What’s the one thing you can do consistently that’ll ensure
you’re successful over a longer time horizon?

Maybe it’s content, maybe it’s honing your craft, maybe it’s
outreach, maybe it’s something entirely unrelated.

But figure that one thing out.

And do it consistently.

Congrats, now you can never go broke.

Hope you enjoyed this one, let me know if you made it down here
:)

Ben

subject: NGMI or FITFO
body:
There are two types of people in this world.

The first type of person is the one who hesitates to start a
business because they’re worried about how they’d pay taxes if
they were to make money.

They sit there and think about every possible problem that they
could possibly run into.

“What happens if I get a client and then they ask me to do
something that I don’t know how to do?”

These are the types that want a “full step-by-step playbook” to
start a business.

It’s like they’re taking the 9-5er approach to business and need
to be told what to do every step of the way.

There’s an acronym that accurately describes this type:

NGMI (not gonna make it).

They’re effectively toddlers.

The second type of person is the one who adopts a different
mindset.

Sure, they still have hesitations, fears and doubts.

And they don’t know what every step of the staircase will look
like.

But they take action despite these factors.

There’s a different acronym that they follow:

FITFO (figure it the fuck out).

Yesterday I found a perfect example of these two people in the
comment section of one of my Youtube videos.

One person commented “This video is ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY
POINTLESS” and right underneath him was a comment that read:

“Exactly what I’m going through rn. Your YouTube was really put
in my life for a reason. The timing of this video is impeccable”

Can you guess who’s who in this example?

Sure I’m biased because it’s my own video but this was
interesting to me.

How can two people watch the same exact video and have completely
opposite reactions?

Perception.

Your reality is colored by the lens in which you view the world.

If you think someone is coming to save you, or you think there’s
a step by step system that everyone who “makes it” follows, you
will find information that lacks training wheels useless.

Instead you’ll watch hyper edited videos that follow a script and
have gay animations over them.

You’ll get a dopamine rush and think you’re doing something
useful.

But you’ll never actually find success because you’re type one.

You need everything to be predictable – which is the opposite of
entrepreneurship.

On the contrary, if you understand that anything worth having
takes time and that your reality lies on your shoulders alone,
you will eventually achieve your desired result.

And when you consume information that reminds you of this,
instead of getting angry that you weren’t handed an “A-Z
blueprint” you’ll feel inspired that others see the world the
same way you do.

Every day you have the power to choose which of these two people
you want to be.

One will serve you and push you towards your goals.

And the other will keep you stuck in the same mindset that has
gotten you nowhere.

Choose wisely.

Ben

P.S. Join Copy MBA if you're a FITFO person. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmh0m208ws6hdom6600fg/8ghqhohlzn0o9gak/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuY29weW1iYS5jb20vYmItaWMxP2VsPWJlbi1lbWFpbA==
)​

​

subject: How to easily be a better writer
body:
Happy Saturday bo,

It’s been rainy and gloomy here in Miami for the past few days.

The sky is white right now but there’s no rain coming down so I’m
sitting on my balcony as I write this to you.

Over the last few days I’ve really noticed how the weather
impacts my mood.

I’m a firm believer that 99% of problems can be fixed with a long
walk in the sun.

When it was constantly raining and I was unable to do so, I
started to go crazy.

Anyway it’s unusually quiet for a Saturday in the middle of
Brickell.

Usually there's this dude who bikes around carrying a beat box.

He’ll stop on random street corners and start break dancing.

Imagine you’re hungover at 8am on a Saturday and you’re woken up
by a Bad Bunny song.

You get up, walk out onto your balcony and see some guy with pink
hair and the shape of a heart on the back of his head.

He's blasting music and dancing like a freak.

You’d probably try to snipe him right?

I tried once but hit an old lady by accident.

Maybe someone finally got him because it’s quiet today.

Anyway, the other day I hosted a group call inside of Copy MBA.

Someone asked a question about “writers block” when first
starting out.

Whether you want to build a copywriting business and you’re
trying to practice, or you just want to start writing in general,
this is inevitable.

This student was trying to write a sample email for this
supplement brand, but whenever he opens a google doc, he stares
at a blinking cursor and eventually closes his laptop.

Happens.

I asked him what sport he played growing up.

He told me he does mixed martial arts so I recommended that he
find someone who is selling MMA courses or pick a clothing brand
in that space and write for that instead.

The reason this is effective is because it’s much easier to write
about things you’d be in the market for.

Especially when you’re first starting out.

When I started, I was writing copy for basketball trainers.

In every email, every ad, and every funnel I built – I was
writing to my previous self.

I understood the pain points and desires of the market because I
was the market.

And this made practicing 100x easier.

Between this and building the habit of writing every day, I got
better quickly.

If you want to get better at copy, you need to write for fun.

Start journaling.

Start tweeting.

Write a love letter to your ex.

Go sit down in a coffee shop and write about the barista that
held eye contact for too long when taking your order.

Write about the idiot who’s standing in the middle of the
doorway.

Write about the poor bastard who passes by on a scooter in work
clothes with a backpack on.

Describe what you see in detail.

Make it entertaining and don’t hold back

Just write.

It will make your life better. And eventually, you’ll be half
decent at it.

Alrighty I’m going to the gym.

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

P.S. I posted a free 30 minute live call on Youtube where I map
out the launch of a coaching program.

​Check it out here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9ho653mxhlhw9rxx55fn/25h2hoh26k8455s3/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9HZkM5OVFmcW5lYw==
)​

​

​

subject: Please stop pitching me
body:
Every day I wake up to two things:

1. The ear-itating (Dad joke – happy belated fathers day) sound
of construction workers drilling.

And…

2. Pitches in every digital inbox I own.

Instagram, Twitter, TikTok, Gmail, even Venmo…

People on the internet are constantly trying to get me to buy
their services through cold outreach.

And my audience isn’t even that big.

99% of the outbound messages I read are absolute trash.

With every word they are showing more incompetence and only
proving to be someone who I don’t want to work with.

They barely do any research on me or what I could potentially
need, their messages are too long, they sound retarded, etc.

But honestly, it’s not their fault.

Outreach USED to be a numbers game.

If you blindly send enough cold DM’s, eventually you’ll get a
client.

It doesn’t work like that anymore (especially if you want to get
GOOD clients that will pay you a decent retainer).

Your success is now correlated to the quality of your message and
the way you are perceived online.

Yes, volume still matters.

But failing to put yourself in a more credible position before
doing outreach is like DMing Instagram models when you have 29
followers and one picture of yourself holding a fish.

Not gonna work.

There are three things you can do that will improve your online
perception, thus increasing the likelihood you get replies to
your cold pitches.

1. Post content

2. Lead with material that proves competence

3. Network

The first point (content) is self explanatory.

If you’re a beginner I understand that it may be difficult to
know where to start in that regard.

But I’m not just talking about video content or even posting
information related to what you’re pitching.

If you look like a normal, cool person on Instagram, you will get
more responses.

Simple.

This second element (material that proves competence) is
absolutely crucial as well.

I get pitches with shitty sample emails and clips from my videos.

The time put into these assets is meaningless if they suck.

If they don’t suck, they get a reply.

Last element – network (without being a dork).

Everyone is more likely to respond to someone they have mutuals
with.

Strangers don’t get replies. They stay poor for eternity.

Friends do business together.

Got it?

Stop spraying and praying.

Use the three principles of online credibility above, and your
chances of landing clients will greatly increase (and now it
becomes a numbers game).

Hope this helps – go show some love on this new video if it did
:) (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403seh5ddxdehxh30rvv77t5/dpheh0h0vpe3qzfm/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9SUndzSU9LMkpIQT9zaT1ydEZfXzhoVnB2RjlFY2t3
)​

Please stop pitching me,

Ben

​

​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403seh5ddxdehxh30rvv77t5
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403seh5ddxdehxh30rvv77t5

)

 There are three things you can do that will improve your online perception, thus increasing the likelihood you get replies to your cold pitches. 

 1. Post content 

 2. Lead with material that proves competence 

 3. Network 

 The first point (content) is self explanatory. 

 If you’re a beginner I understand that it may be difficult to know where to start in that regard. 

 But I’m not just talking about video content or even posting information related to what you’re pitching. 

 If you look like a normal, cool person on Instagram, you will get more responses. 

 Simple. 

 This second element (material that proves competence) is absolutely crucial as well. 

 I get pitches with shitty sample emails and clips from my videos. 

 The time put into these assets is meaningless if they suck. 

 If they don’t suck, they get a reply. 

 Last element – network (without being a dork). 

 Everyone is more likely to respond to someone they have mutuals with. 

 Strangers don’t get replies. They stay poor for eternity. 

 Friends do business together. 

 Got it? 

 Stop spraying and praying. 

 Use the three principles of online credibility above, and your chances of landing clients will greatly increase (and now it becomes a numbers game). 

 Hope this helps – go show some love on this new video if it did :) ​ 

 Please stop pitching me, 

 Ben 

 ​ 

 ​

subject: One question you need to ask yourself
body:
I think I just called a they/them “bro”

It was an accident.

I walked into the coffee shop to get my latte and it (they?)
greeted me.

At a glance it was 100% a man.

But as I got closer I realized it had feminine features and no
Adam’s apple.

Oops.

Anyway I heard someone say a really interesting quote the other
day.

“The only stupid questions are those that we fail to ask
ourselves first.”

In other words, use your own brain and critical thinking ability
before asking for help from others.

When you build the habit of constantly seeking advice, you start
to lose trust in your own word.

You reach an impasse or situation you haven’t encountered prior,
and feel helpless.

So you turn to others and want to be told what to do.

This basically turns you into a female uber driver:

Absolutely useless.

(Sorry I couldn’t resist — I know there are some women who are
not horrible drivers).

I actually had a female uber driver for a 30 minute ride this
past weekend and I’m still alive so W’s in chat for her.

Back to the point - you have the answer to probably 90% of your
problems.

When someone gives you advice, generally they’re just flexing the
same critical thinking muscle that you have.

And your guess is as good as theirs.

Over time, the more you rely on others your self-reliance muscle
will atrophy.

You’ll lose all the trust that you had in your own judgement and
seek approval, validation, and direction constantly.

This is even true when you have solid mentors and people that are
giving you “good” advice.

Someone may tell you the right move to make on paper but that
doesn’t mean it’s actually right for you.

It’s often the inclinations, or the trails that you recklessly
and delusionally follow that end up leading to the biggest
opportunities.

Now I'm not saying that gathering perspective from those who know
more than you is always a bad thing.

Obviously there are times where direction from others can really
help.

Just remember to listen to your own voice from time to time.

And before you go looking for help,

Ask yourself first.

Bye bro,

Ben

P.S. I’m launching something cool next week. You’ll get one on
one access to me, a private network, and content I don’t share
elsewhere.

Since you’re on this list you’ll have the opportunity to get in
before I launch it publicly.

Hit reply and say “Yes” if you’re interested and I’ll add you to
the waitlist.

​
​

​

subject: True freedom can't be bought
body:
The other day I talked to two different business owners.

One of them was making $1m a month.

The other was making about a 20th of that.

After the two calls, I noticed something interesting.

I had much more respect for the guy who was making less money.

On that call, we talked a bit about business but the conversation
quickly turned more philosophical.

He shared some of his goals with me and explained why he's doing
what he's doing.

I could tell he was really thoughtful and intentional.

He put effort into considering what he actually wanted -- Not
what would appear "cool" to strangers on the internet.

The other guy was far less interesting to talk to.

Sure, he'd reached a higher number in his business, but he was a
dork.

He had an Amazon automation offer (which are typically a scam).

And was stressed because a few things had gone wrong in his
business recently causing revenue to decline.

I wrote a tweet yesterday expanding on this which I'll share with
you now:

"After a few years in business I’ve stopped “looking up” to
people simply because they’re making a lot of money.

Most guys end up losing the traits that make them interesting.

They get so bought in to adopting a worldview that others tell
them to have.

With that, goes their autonomy.

They’re no longer thinking for themselves and what they want but
rather for what other men will perceive as higher status.

I have more respect for the broke guy who figures out a way to
live a dope life.

Or the entrepreneur who follows a more creative path, even if it
costs him money.

Freedom of the mind can’t be bought.

And $1m a month is meaningless if you never stopped to figure out
why you’re doing it.

Money can be an outlet to live how YOU want. It’s not an
identity."

I'll never be someone who tells you not to make as much money as
possible.

But just remember to continuously audit the path you're on and
ensure it aligns with what you want.

And whatever path you choose -- follow it with conviction. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hk833ekcohz8qookkb9/n2hohvh3md25g6u6/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9rMDgwMWVxcmhpbw==
)​

Talk later,

Ben

​

​

subject: Do this to guarantee you never go broke
body:
It’s 11:02am on a Monday morning as I start writing to you
shirtless from my balcony.

I’m thinking about what I would do if everything got wiped to
zero tomorrow.

Bank accounts drained, car stolen, watches donated to the
homeless, all of my clients fire me, etc.

And I realize that I’d be fine.

There are three things I’ve done over the past few years that
have made me “recession proof.”

Meaning if some event occurred where I had to basically start all
over, I have full conviction that I’d get back to where I am
quickly.

And that’s good news for you, because the three things that give
me that confidence are resources that anyone can access.

If you want to ensure that you can never go broke, do this:

1. Learn high income skills

2. Use social media to build a network

3. Build a personal brand

Those three assets turn you into a weapon.

The first step (learning skills) is simple.

Simply learn copywriting and sales and you’re in better shape
than 99% of people.

Watch Youtube videos, pitch strangers on the internet, learn more
on the fly.

Step two (building a network by being a normal cool person) opens
doors and gives you a safety net.

If you can just start to connect with more people who are on a
similar path as you (or ahead of you) opportunities flow your
way.

The best way I’ve found to do this has been through Twitter and
by joining mastermind and coaching programs.

And lastly, step three (personal brand) is perhaps the most
valuable resource you can build in 2024.

Now, not everyone is meant to have tens or hundreds of thousands
of followers.

But that doesn’t mean that you can’t share some insights on
social media and utilize the platform.

This goes hand and hand with networking in step two.

Even if you don’t end up building a huge personal brand, posting
content online can only help you.

All three of these things will give you security and the best
safety net possible if things ever go south.

It’s the peace of mind that a college degree is supposed to give
you.

Let me know if you liked this one :)

Btw I have something really cool for you launching this week and
I’m excited to share it with you.

Talk soon,

Ben

​
​

​

subject: How to go from good to great
body:
I cracked the code.

It’s summer 2015.

An hour in to a grueling basketball workout, my trainer makes a
new rule.

“If the ball hits the rim it counts as a miss and you have to run
sprints. Swishes only.”

I think to myself “this mf crazy, I need a new trainer.”

But I keep shooting, now aiming only for nylon.

The ball hits the back of the rim and goes in. Doesn’t count.

Front rim. Side rim. Rattles in off the glass.

Doesn’t matter, I’m running.

“This is ridiculous. I’m literally making these shots and still
being forced to run,” I complain to myself.

But then something cool happens.

I find the sweet spot and the ball stops hitting the rim.

The way I’m shooting feels different now.

I’m no longer just aiming for the basket.

I’m aiming for a very specific part of the back of the net.

I’m conscious of exactly how the ball has to leave my fingertips.

Everything is incredibly precise.

I’ve reached a level of attention to detail and focus that I
wasn’t accessing previously.

This is the difference between good and great.

It’s what keeps some business owners stuck at $10k, $50k, or
$100k per month.

It’s what causes tens of thousands of dollars worth of leads to
fall through the cracks in a sales process.

And it’s what created the opportunity for me to make 7 figures as
a marketer for info-product businesses.

I get paid to fill in the gaps.

To improve the copy, or the sales process, or the video script.

I bring a new level of attention to minor details and make an
extra 6 figures a month for my clients.

They pay me a percentage of it.

This is how you win as a service provider for coaching business.

Find the broken piece(s) of their business.

Identify a solution using your critical thinking ability.

Get paid.

For example if an usually low amount of leads end up on sales
calls, my job is to find the crack in the system.

Maybe the email sequence sucks or there’s none at all.

Maybe the leads aren’t getting dialed.

Maybe the video sales letter is horrible.

Maybe there’s a lack of congruence between the content and the
messaging on the funnel.

Whatever the problem is, the way to make money is to identify and
fix it.

Boom, now you’re a valuable piece to any coaching business.

You’re turning good, into great.

​Congrats, that’s how the money is made. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhxz2x36ughz7p88llb9/7qh7h8hol66pooiz/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9EVnRvZUdmZHFabz9zaT1yeGJHWnBGTDRKNGduTU52
)​

Ben

P.S. I'm in the process of building a course and community called
The Artisan Lab.

Because you're on this list, you'll have access to it before I
promote it publicly (and at the lowest price).

It's made up of the 3 pillars:

Self, skillset, and social.

Anyone who wants to increase their income and build their dream
lifestyle needs to master those 3 things.

If you're building a similar business to mine or if you want to
direct access to me and my network, this will be a game changer
for you.

Excited to share it with you in the coming days.

​

​

subject: Re: your $30M payout is on the way
body:
I just uploaded one of my favorite videos to date.

I interviewed my friend Rob, who sold a company to a private
equity firm a few years ago.

This made him a rather rich man.

But a lot of “rich guys” are still dorks.

They’re either complete nerds or they use their money to make up
for the fact that they never got laid in high school.

As you’ll see in the video (

subject: Re: your $30M payout is on the way
body:
I just uploaded one of my favorite videos to date. 

 I interviewed my friend Rob, who sold a company to a private equity firm a few years ago. 

 This made him a rather rich man. 

 But a lot of “rich guys” are still dorks. 

 They’re either complete nerds or they use their money to make up for the fact that they never got laid in high school. 

 As you’ll see in the video , Rob is not your typical rich guy. 

 Originally I’d booked a podcast studio where we were just gonna sit down and chop it up. 

 That’s cool and all, but to me it felt bland. 

 I wanted to make a video that had more flare. 

 So, we did just that. 

 This is the best video you’ll watch today. 

 Warning: Watching this video will make you handsomer, richer, fitter and potentially serve as a spiritual awakening. 

 ​ Consume this content at your own risk. ​ 

 See you over there, 

 Ben 

 P.S. I’m pushing back the launch of my community, The Artisan Lab, by a couple weeks. 

 I just realized the 4th of July is coming up and that threw a bit of a wrench in the timing of the launch. 

 However I can promise you, this will be well worth the wait. 

 Will keep you updated in the coming emails. 

 ​
​ 

 ​

subject: Why successful people are lazy
body:
July 1st.

Before I was doing anything with my life, it was usually around
this time of year where I’d start to panic.

In the beginning of the year, I’d set a bunch of lofty goals.

I’d promise myself that this year is gonna be different.

But my New Year’s resolutions would remain as unchecked boxes on
my computer screen.

By March, I’d start feeling the pressure.

“Ok, you gotta lock in bro.”

I’d change my routine for a few days or maybe a week.

Then something would throw me off and I’d revert back to old
habits.

I’d continue on autopilot for the next few months and then this
time of year would hit.

That’s when I’d reach panic mode.

We’d be more than halfway through the year and I hadn’t made
nearly any progress on my goals.

If this sounds familiar and you woke up in a frenzy this morning,
good.

You’re just a few actions and a few months away from a very
different life.

I’m writing to you from the lobby of one of the nicest hotels in
LA where they filmed the movie Pretty Woman.

In a couple hours, I’ll order a $200 uber black lux to take me to
the airport even though I could get a normal one for $50.

On my flight back to Miami I’m in seat 1A and my girl is in 1B
(as long as they don’t rug pull me again).

My life looks a lot different than it did when I’d procrastinate
taking action on my goals for the better half of a year.

But I’m that same lazy kid.

I hate doing things I don’t wanna do.

I hate not knowing exactly how things are gonna work out.

I hate change.

But more than all of these, I hate the idea of living a life that
I don’t want to live.

And that fear was powerful enough to help me overcome my lazy
nature and habit of procrastinating.

So if you want to spur yourself into action, picture in vivid
detail what your life will look like if you keep stalling.

And if that doesn’t do the trick you’re probably cooked. Sorry.

Talk to you when I’m back in Miami,

Ben

P.S. I uploaded a new narration style video yesterday — let me
now your thoughts ⬇️

​ (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvh8z5g9qu6h7ooxwgghl/6qheh8h7r2006rfo/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS91SjRVZk9jTXFQTT9zaT0zUkRybkFrcVhuSzZqYlJo
)​
​

​

subject: my subconscious wrote this email
body:
Quick one for you today.

You need to make your subconscious your friend.

Once you activate your RAS (reticular activation system) to work
in your favor, opportunities and ideas fall into your lap.

It’s like when you start thinking about a certain car and begin
seeing more of it on the street.

Similarly, when you become intentional and get a general idea for
the direction you want to head in…

Your subconscious starts to conspire in your favor.

You get a random idea that turns into a breakthrough.

You get a weird inclination to start a new habit, or connect with
a certain person.

That inclination create an opportunity.

This starts by doing the following:

When yo u want something, write it down. Think about it. Start
taking actions that will move you towards said thing.

I’m frequently reminded of this when I make content.

Since I’ve developed the Tuesday, Thursday, Sunday, Youtube video
schedule, I start getting ideas on these days.

It begins when I consciously decide, “Okay, I need to make a
video today.”

As I continue thinking about what I want to talk about, sometimes
my subconscious will throw me a random thought.

I’ll be on a walk or in the shower and boom.

I figure out what I want to talk about.

I could keep going on about this but I have to leave for dinner
so maybe we can revisit another day.

​Here was today’s thought by the way. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8hkmdvk2bohz8850kku9/58hvh7hmx5knkef6/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9QSWpYQXgtSG04ST9zaT10TjUxSFJuRjNPRGhLVEdP
)​

Okay love you bye,

Ben

​

subject: $10 and spaghetti can create your dream life
body:
“I would much rather fail gloriously than not try. I’m not
interested in telling stories with competence. I’m looking to
tell them with some style, originality, and creativity.” -
Anthony Bourdain

Happy Saturday bo.

The other day I was on a 90-foot yacht for the 4th of July,
having a brief conversation with a friend about YouTube.

A few years ago, he had 27k subscribers but wasn’t making any
money from his channel.

Then he got a piece of advice that changed his life forever.

In passing, one of the biggest YouTubers in the world told him to
change the thumbnail on a video he’d posted 6 months prior.

So, he paid someone $10 to take a new thumbnail photo and
uploaded it.

Over the following 24 hours he went from 27k subs to over 100k
and quit his job at Subway.

He eventually reached over 1m subscribers before his channel was
banned by the platform (you might know who I’m talking about here
lol).

What’s crazy to me is that all happened because of one small
adjustment.

Here’s how this pertains to you:

A single decision can completely change your life.

It could be a seemingly miniscule decision that you don’t give
much thought to.

It could be a risk or hail mary attempt that leads to a big
break.

Or it could be the decision to power through a tough time and
change a behavior.

Genuinely, sit there and think about this for a second.

You are one decision away from everything you could ever dream
of.

Right now, you don’t know what that decision is.

Odds are, you won’t know the ripple effect that it’ll create even
when you make it.

But if you keep throwing spaghetti at the wall hoping that it
sticks, eventually it will.

Maybe you’ll have to get creative and change from spaghetti to
penne, or marinara to alfredo.

Maybe Anthony Bourdain will descend from heaven and casually tell
you to add a single ingredient that makes it stick.

Or maybe you just have to keep throwing it over and over, past
the point that you would usually quit.

One day, it will stick.

The culmination of all of your formerly unrewarded effort will be
paid back 10 fold in an instant.

To others, you’ll appear to be an overnight success.

But you’ll know that’s not the case.

It was a result of tens, hundreds, or thousands of decisions and
repetitions…

Plus a disdain for the run of the mill, competent effort.

Eventually, it works.

Keep firing, and test the occasional aberrant idea.

Ben

P.S. Let me know if you liked this one.

Someone recently left a comment on a video of mine saying
“Anthony Bourdain energy.”

I was somehow unfamiliar with Anthony until then and just watched
this video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhxznd90hghz77e0llu9/reh8hoh0dw9ne0c2/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_dj12VUVGZFdBS3BmMA==
) where I got that quote in the beginning of the email.

​

​
