subject: The superpower you don’t know you have
body:
I have a superpower.

It's a singular strength I’ve really developed over the last few
years.

It’s helped me in my personal life, business, and social media.

It seems to have made me more likable and has played a role in
client acquisition and results.

Meaning it’s the reason people buy things.

And it’s probably the same reason you like my content (unless you
hate it and you’re just here to talk shit in my replies).

The cool thing about this superpower, is it’s something you have
too.

Maybe you’re accessing it right now, maybe you’re not.

But I think it’s one of the key factors in finding success in all
the above domains.

“Ok Ben, I get it, this thing is important. Now would you tell me
what it is???”

No.

Don’t you understand?

Right now, you’re either using your superpower or you’re not.

You’re either hearing me, or you’re not.

And that’s the secret.

My superpower is I listen.

I listen to others when they talk. Not just what they say, but
what they mean.

When my girl says “it’s fine” I know that’s code for “you fucked
up but I’m not telling you what you did, so you have to figure it
out.”

When a prospect tells me about their business, I put myself in
their shoes.

I think about their motives, desires and roadblocks.

And I assess their situation as objectively as I can.

This is obviously a huge part of copywriting and sales. It’s
having the empathy to prescribe the right solution to a certain
problem.

And if you don’t listen, you won’t be in tune with the problem.

Furthermore I listen to myself.

What do I actually want?

Why am I doing or not doing a certain thing?

Are my actions in alignment with what I say I want? And if not,
am I willing to change?

I honestly think my habit to intellectualize my life is a
blessing and curse.

It keeps me quite in touch with the underlying narratives going
through my head.

Which helps me create content that feels really personal.

If it’s ever felt like I’m articulating an exact problem you
have, and the way you think about it, this is why.

But sometimes it also stops me from taking action as quickly as I
should.

Two sides to every coin I guess.

Anyway - listen more.

Stop jumping to conclusions.

Get off your high horse.

And do your best to be empathetic. Both with others and with
yourself.

Remember - you’re one decision away from turning everything
around. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhxzpogwighz77e0llu9/owhkhqhr9ogrrocv/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS94cEkzNWZPNGtNQT9zaT1iazhFc1lNM09UbGdNenc3
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. My community, the Artisan Lab is in the works and launching
soon.

If you want to learn from me in any capacity this is gonna be for
you.

Plus it should be a really dope “networking” opportunity if you
want to meet more people in the online money space who aren’t
dorks.

Excited to let you in :)

​
​

subject: Don't forget about data
body:
Yo bo,

Let’s talk about data.

Personally, I hate numbers.

I cheated in every math class I ever took.

But sometimes only data can reveal a clear answer when things are
stagnant or you’re not getting a result you want.

This can be quite obvious when looking at quantifiable data.

If you’re spending $10k on ads and only making $5k back, clearly
there's an issue.

Any reasonable person who doesn’t want to lose money would then
try to figure out the problem.

To do this, they’d look at the more granular data.

The click through rate, cost per click, cost per impressions,
conversion rate, etc.

Using this data, they’d attempt to identify the problem and test
a solution.

Rinse and repeat.

This is a pragmatic, data-driven approach that will result in
objective truths.

And if you’re not progressing in a certain area of your life the
way you want to, this is what you need to apply.

Let’s say you’ve been trying to put on muscle for 6 months.

Your approach hasn’t been very meticulous and you stepped on the
scale today and saw that you’ve only gained 2 pounds.

As a sensible person, capable of critical thought, what would you
do in this scenario?

Answer in your head real quick.

If you said something along the lines of “I’d audit what I’m
eating and how I’m working out, and see what needs to be
changed,” you’ve come up with a solid answer.

Now for whatever reason, this ability to analyze data gets
forgotten when the data is less quantifiable.

Meaning if you’ve been in a situation you don’t like for an
extended period of time.

Whether it’s:

Trying to start a business and not making much progress

Stagnating in your business

Lack of growth on social media

Or even in your personal life:

Maybe you’ve been wanting to improve a relationship, you’ve had a
list of hobbies that you wanted to try but haven’t, or you want
to build better habits…

Whatever that thing is, you eventually need to take an objective
look under the hood.

“Why am I not solving this problem I have? What are the variables
that go into the problem? If I were to solve this problem, what
would need to change?”

And just like that, you’ve given yourself action steps to execute
on.

Don’t forget to look at the data in your life and perform
mini-audits.

Be pragmatic, and find the objective truth.

Ben

subject: Don't forget about data
body:
Yo {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 Let’s talk about data. 

 Personally, I hate numbers. 

 I cheated in every math class I ever took. 

 But sometimes only data can reveal a clear answer when things are stagnant or you’re not getting a result you want. 

 This can be quite obvious when looking at quantifiable data. 

 If you’re spending $10k on ads and only making $5k back, clearly there's an issue. 

 Any reasonable person who doesn’t want to lose money would then try to figure out the problem. 

 To do this, they’d look at the more granular data. 

 The click through rate, cost per click, cost per impressions, conversion rate, etc. 

 Using this data, they’d attempt to identify the problem and test a solution. 

 Rinse and repeat. 

 This is a pragmatic, data-driven approach that will result in objective truths. 

 And if you’re not progressing in a certain area of your life the way you want to, this is what you need to apply. 

 Let’s say you’ve been trying to put on muscle for 6 months. 

 Your approach hasn’t been very meticulous and you stepped on the scale today and saw that you’ve only gained 2 pounds. 

 As a sensible person, capable of critical thought, what would you do in this scenario? 

 Answer in your head real quick. 

 If you said something along the lines of “I’d audit what I’m eating and how I’m working out, and see what needs to be changed,” you’ve come up with a solid answer. 

 Now for whatever reason, this ability to analyze data gets forgotten when the data is less quantifiable. 

 Meaning if you’ve been in a situation you don’t like for an extended period of time. 

 Whether it’s: 

 Trying to start a business and not making much progress 

 Stagnating in your business 

 Lack of growth on social media 

 Or even in your personal life: 

 Maybe you’ve been wanting to improve a relationship, you’ve had a list of hobbies that you wanted to try but haven’t, or you want to build better habits… 

 Whatever that thing is, you eventually need to take an objective look under the hood. 

 “Why am I not solving this problem I have? What are the variables that go into the problem? If I were to solve this problem, what would need to change?” 

 And just like that, you’ve given yourself action steps to execute on. 

 Don’t forget to look at the data in your life and perform mini-audits. 

 Be pragmatic, and find the objective truth. 

 Ben 

 P.S. I finished recording the last few modules of the Artisan Lab today. 

 It has basically become a digital version of my brain. 

 Here’s some of the info inside: 

 How I’ve built my agency to 6 figures/month How we’ve scaled info businesses to $500k/month+ My full copywriting guide I’ve used to generate millions The daily habits & routine that took me from being an average college kid to successful entrepreneur Plus a lot more. 

 Thinking about launching it in the next couple days. Do you want more info? 

 ​ 

 ​

subject: The three pillars of success
body:
bo,

Tomorrow I'm launching my new mastermind, The Artisan Lab.

It will be centered around the 3 pillars that play the biggest
role in your success in online business.

Whether you're just starting out, or you're a copywriter, growth
operator, course seller, or you're building a different business
entirely...

These three pillars dictate your success:

1: Self

Simply put, change starts in the mind.

To do something you haven't done before, you need to step into a
new identity.

This requires you to build new habits and discard old beliefs
that don't serve you.

2: Skillset

Skills give you the security that a college degree was supposed
to.

This is what makes you valuable -- if you can write copy and you
can sell, it's nearly impossible for you to lose.

3: Social

Connections are everything and social media has made it easier
than ever to build a network.

Use the internet to connect with likeminded people and
opportunities will fall into your lap.

If you neglect any of the three pillars above, it's gonna take
you a lot longer to reach goals and increase your income.

That's why the Artisan Lab will focus on all three of these.

Obviously, you'll learn all about how I've scaled my agency to
$100k/month...

You'll see inside our service delivery process and what we do to
scale info products to $500k/month+.

You'll get my processes for creating content and growing your
personal brand on social media.

And yes, you'll get my full systems for building webinars,
writing copy, VSLs, etc.

But none of that will matter if your mindset is flawed or you

The Artisan Lab will equip you with all of the necessary tools
and attributes.

subject: Hack to an easier life and effortless success
body:
I’m on my balcony watching a boat go by in the river in front of
me.

It’s early in the morning so there's a really cool
blue/white-ish/yellowish tone in the sky.

I’d take a picture and show you bo, but my phone's inside and I
don’t feel like getting up to go get it.

Anyway, I have an important topic for you today.

If you understand this one thing, you gain complete control of
your life.

It creates a reality where everything becomes a choice.

From making more money, to improving your relationships, to
feeling good about your daily routine.

You simply decide to make something happen and reality follows
suit.

And luckily, the key to all of this is incredibly
straightforward.

Ownership.

Taking ownership is how you make things happen with the push of a
button.

I’m not referring to the “everything is your fault” type of
narrative that you might hear online.

But rather understand that everything is your choice.

When you make a concerted effort to accomplish something, the
outcome is largely dependent on you.

Sure, there are variables that you don’t control and you need to
accept that.

But obsessing over, or placing blame on those variables will make
you powerless.

So when you hear yourself start to blame external factors for why
things aren’t working out in your favor, simply cut that
narrative.

Even if it’s partially true, it doesn’t serve you.

It’s like if you’re playing a sport and you have a bad head coach
who doesn’t let you play the way you want to.

You can complain about it, underperform and be miserable.

Or you can keep doing your best regardless of the situation.

Taking this approach to life makes you unfuckwithable.

If there’s a situation in your business that isn’t going
according to plan, you fix it.

Even if that means a client is slacking on their
responsibilities.

Or a team member isn’t performing the way you need them to.

Or there was a change in the algorithm and your old system isn’t
working the same.

You take the problem into your own hands.

And you don’t do so with bitterness for other people in the
equation, for they aren’t on my email list and didn’t get
equipped with this superpower.

You are the master of your reality and no one and no thing can
throw you off your shit.

That’s the mindset that serves you best and makes success
effortless.

Take ownership of your shit and you’ll be a hell of a lot
happier.

​And join the Artisan Lab if you want to accelerate your growth.
(

)​
Ben

subject: Benjamin is a loser
body:
Yo bo,

I'm sitting here with my friend Mason, who you probably know as
the baby faced assassin copywriter.

We're about to go to dinner with our friend Tyler (TJR Trades)
who you may also know as the day-trader who looks like a rapper.

There's a guy on Tik Tok named Benjamin Graham.

He must not have been loved as a child or he hasn't seen naked
woman since the day he came out of his mothers womb.

This guy has taken it upon himself to become "the internets
white-knight."

Basically he's the fat chick in a group of girls who tells you
the pretty one isn't interested.

In every video he "calls out" someone new.

He'll cherry pick information and find a way to make the guy out
to be a scammer.

His audience loves him.

Everyone in his comments will be like "Yeah! you exposed that
guy! rEnteD LamBo course seller ScaMmEr!!!"

And then they probably continue putting the groceries in the bag
during their shift at Publix.

THIS is the exact mindset that will keep you poor and miserable
forever.

You'll be the guy who complains that the "bad guy" gets the girl.

You'll be the skeptic who hopes for crypto to crash, or the
historically great sports team to lose.

You'll be the divorced single Mother who yells at the T.V. while
watching Leonardo DiCaprio talk about his new 20-year-old super
model girlfriend.

You'll be the unhappy, pessimistic, smug 50 year old who tells
hopeful kids to "wait till you're my age because it all goes
downhill."

But one time you'll be right.

You'll hang your hat on the fact that once upon a time, your
skepticism was accurate.

Even though you get pissed off watching young guys on social
media drive what was once your dream car.

While living where you once dreamt of and dating the girls you
salivate over on social media...

You'll justify it all because every now and then, you do find a
scammer.

So you elect to believe that it's all a scam and nothing more was
ever possible.

Does that result in a fruitful, beautiful life?

No.

If you're reading this right now, it's in your best interest to
believe that it's all possible.

You can be the guy in the supercar.

The business CAN work if you put the work in.

And making money online is possible for you because you're
watching other people who are just like you do it.

Don't be a depressed, miserable dork.

Adopt the mindset that it can all be real, put in the according

subject: How I land the best clients in the info space
body:
Gm. 

 I forgot to write to you yesterday. 

 Not because I don’t love you (I do). 

 But because I was quite busy. 

 I had a few one-on-ones with new members of my mastermind, I boxed with my trainer, and I brought in a special guest to do a group call with my community. 

 Then I was scrolling through Tik Tok and saw a creator with a huge audience and a really ugly funnel. 

 He probably had some 18 year old kid who calls himself a “growth operator” set it up for him. 

 It was a $27/month Skool community. 

 Now listen, I haven't sent an outbound dm since you were in diapers. 

 You’re probably around the same age as me, so that was a really long time ago. 

 But this guy was sitting on such an opportunity and I was so disgusted to see it being squandered. 

 So, I ran into my office and made him a loom video pitch. 

 It took me 2 seconds to find his email, I wrote a few lines of copy and sent the loom. 

 Using my little spy tool, I saw he opened it instantly. 

 Then I got a notification that “someone” watched my video. 

 He didn’t reply yet, but he went over to my instagram and followed me. 

 We’ll see. I honestly don’t care if he closes or not. 

 But it’d be really cool if I could flex on all of you who’ve been doing outreach for a while. 

 Imagine you’re working your ass off sending 30 pitches a day. 

 And then you see me, scrolling through tik tok in my pajamas when I find your ideal client. 

 I open my laptop, click the loom button and start rambling about how we’ve made a lot of clients a lot of moneys. 

 Next thing you know I’m on a call with your ideal client and he loves me. 

 We talk about the weather and he tells me about his favorite spots in Miami when he was my age. 

 I show him the keys to my Porsche 911 turbo and then tell him I can help him make the equivalent of 3 of them in a month. 

 He’s wowed. 

 I pitch a price 100x the average growth operator or copywriters net worth. 

 He says “YES!!!” and asks if he can add a tip. 

 I receive the wire on the call, my team builds him a new funnel, and we make him $1m next month. 

 Hahahaha. 

 That would be cool. 

 I shared this whole outbound process (including the loom and email I sent) inside the Artisan Lab btw. ​

 I didn’t expect to write a rather arrogant email to you today, but here we are. 

 It would also be funny if this whole thing blew up in my face. 

 I’ll keep you updated. 

 This inspired me to start doing outbound again. It’s kind of fun. 

 Anyway, you can apply to join my mastermind here if you want to get a behind the scenes look at it all. ​

 Talk to you tomorrow, 

 Ben
​ 

 ​ 

 ​

subject: want to talk 1-on-1?
body:
In yesterdays email I told you how I sent my first outbound pitch
since the Vietnam war.

A lot of people replied, so I figured I'd give you a quick
update.

I had an hour long sales call yesterday afternoon with the
prospect and his assistant.

He had actually replied to my email 30 minutes after I sent it
but it went to my requests on instagram so I didn't see it
immediately.

Regardless, we ended up on a zoom.

I was sitting at the desk you see me at in my Youtube videos and
he noticed the keyboard behind me.

So I played a verse of Beethovens' Fur Elise.

Not joking.

Then we chatted for a while and I broke down how I'd help him
make a lot more money.

The guy has grown to over a quarter million followers on both
TikTok and Instagram from scratch after starting in April.

Which is absolutely crazy growth and a perfect opportunity for
someone like me to come into.

We hopped off the call, I sent a proposal over and we'll touch
base Monday.

This cold outreach thing is kind of fun(?)

Idk why I've been hating on it for the last two years lol.

Anyway I've been documenting this whole process inside my
mastermind.

From what I said in the loom video pitch, to the email I sent
which got almost an instant reply.

I even shared the 4 page proposal that I wrote with everything
I'd do to help him get to multi-six figures per month.

The Artisan Lab members have been able to see the whole process.

That should give you FOMO.

Actually, I have an idea.

I'm chilling here on the couch on this beautiful Friday evening
and don't have much to do.

subject: Moooooooooove
body:
A lot has changed since the last email I sent to you.

First, I moved.

Here’s my new POV as I begin writing to you:

​
I’m now 80 something floors up with the water view you see above.

It’s much more peaceful than being in the middle of the city (and
better than being on a poverty floor under the clouds).

I was reminded of a very valuable lesson during this move.

You see, I’m the type of guy that does everything last minute.

ESPECIALLY if it’s something trivial or a task I don’t want to
do.

So I waited until 6pm on the day before I was supposed to move to
start clicking around on the internet to find a moving company.

I filled out a few forms to get quotes and assumed they’d reach
out within a day or two.

Next thing you know, I get a call from a local number.

Keep in mind, it’s Sunday at 7:24pm EST, less than an hour after
I filled out the form.

Some kind woman is on the other end with the moving company and
she tells me she can send movers as early as tomorrow.

I’m sold.

I don’t care about the price.

I don’t care to get quotes from other companies.

I had a problem and this woman Kathy (not her real name but she
sounded like a Kathy) extinguished that problem quickly.

That’s the lesson.

If you’re selling agency services or coaching, or literally
anything…

MOVE FASTER.

I’ve personally lost deals because I was too slow or wasn’t
“available” until a few days later.

By then the urgency is gone.

And the pain that comes with a fresh problem is diminished,
meaning getting the sale is gonna be harder.

This is why it’s a good rule of thumb to have a sales team that
dials every lead immediately (if you run a coaching business and
you’re not doing this, that means you enjoy poverty).

One of the first lessons I was taught when I started running ads
for local basketball trainers 4 years ago, was “speed = lead.”

I was in this coaching program and my coach told me to drill this
message into the heads of my clients.

My job was to get them leads, but if they don’t contact those
leads ASAP, then they’re throwing money down a furnace.

As you know, business is just a game of solving problems.

The bigger problems you solve and the faster you can do so, the
more money you make.

The first moving company that called me late on a Sunday got my
business and charged me $1,200 to move me 5 minutes down the
street.

Maybe there was a cheaper option.

But the problem was resolved and I’m happy to pay a premium for
the efficiency.

​Don’t be slow or you’ll get left behind. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h4lggzdhmhmxx7244fl/wnh2hghw7lz4wps7/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0h4lggzdhmhmxx7244fl
) | Update your profile (

subject: Spend more money
body:
Hey bo,

I have a quick money lesson for you today.

Once upon a time I was extremely attached to money.

When it was a good month in my business, I was happy.

When it wasn't a good month, I wanted to go play in traffic.

This obviously made my internal state a bit of a rollercoaster.

I'd get hung up on a number in my bank account and if it wasn't
growing -- or even worse, if it was declining, it'd make me
anxious.

In my opinion, frugality and neuroticism are not traits that
result in fruitful life.

So one day, I started spending money a lot more freely.

I stopped thinking about paying for food, hotels, flights, or any
investment that would help my business.

Over time, the number that felt like a lot of money to me
drastically increased.

This is what broke my attachment to the number in my bank
account.

I've watched that number go up by $50k-$100k in a day.

But I've also cringed while tipping the bottle girl the
equivalent of a decent email marketing retainer on a $15k night
out.

My current lifestyle is expensive.

And it's part of what helped me expand my mindset around money.

The less I've hesitated to send a $20k wire to grow my business,
buy first class seats, doordash every meal, etc...

The more money I have made.

If you view a number as small and achievable, it becomes exactly

subject: Spend more money
body:
Hey {{ subscriber.first_name }}, 

 I have a quick money lesson for you today. 

 Once upon a time I was extremely attached to money. 

 When it was a good month in my business, I was happy. 

 When it wasn't a good month, I wanted to go play in traffic. 

 This obviously made my internal state a bit of a rollercoaster. 

 I'd get hung up on a number in my bank account and if it wasn't growing -- or even worse, if it was declining, it'd make me anxious. 

 In my opinion, frugality and neuroticism are not traits that result in fruitful life. 

 So one day, I started spending money a lot more freely. 

 I stopped thinking about paying for food, hotels, flights, or any investment that would help my business. 

 Over time, the number that felt like a lot of money to me drastically increased. 

 This is what broke my attachment to the number in my bank account. 

 I've watched that number go up by $50k-$100k in a day. 

 But I've also cringed while tipping the bottle girl the equivalent of a decent email marketing retainer on a $15k night out. 

 My current lifestyle is expensive. 

 And it's part of what helped me expand my mindset around money. 

 The less I've hesitated to send a $20k wire to grow my business, buy first class seats, doordash every meal, etc... 

 The more money I have made. 

 If you view a number as small and achievable, it becomes exactly that. 

 If you're scared to spend money on yourself, then why would anyone spend money on you? 

 Lesson in there. 

 Anyway I gotta get on a call for Artisan Lab -- which you should totally join here if you want to spend money on yourself :) ​ 

 Ben 

 ​

body:
Inside my new mastermind, The Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403seh544nzxhxh300zm77s5/p8heh9hz6v87z9cq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
), I bring in a new guest speaker each week.

This keeps it fresh and it’s interesting to hear various
perspectives from people who have found success in their domain.

Last night my friend Miles was kind enough to host a call.

He’s one of the most reputable personal brands in the Amazon
seller space (@flips4miles on all platforms).

Miles has been creating content since the day I met him 3 or 4
years ago.

He documented his entire journey from zero to selling 7 figures
worth of products on Amazon.

The guy is autistically consistent – and I mean that in the best
way possible.

If you want to see, go look at his socials right now.

He’s constantly posting.

In fact, he’s written a Twitter thread every day for nearly 2
years now.

As a result, he’s grown multiple successful businesses off the
back of his personal brand.

2 software companies and a coaching business that you will only
see positive reviews from.

But on last night's call, he said that he made basically no money
from his first 3 years of posting online.

He actually wasn’t even trying to monetize his brand, he was
posting content as a way to build good will and connect with
other people in the Amazon space.

I’m telling you all of this because I want you to understand one
thing:

If you plan on being in the online business world for a while and
you’re not posting any content, you likely have a room
temperature IQ.

There are a few exceptions to this but let’s disregard that for
now.

More people knowing and trusting you can only make you more
money.

Period.

Even if you’re towards the beginning of your journey, get the
ball rolling and then start documenting the process.

You don’t have to build a Hormozi type brand.

You don’t even have to grow a large audience.

But simply existing as a normal human on the internet will only
open doors for you (as long as you don’t say anything that will
get you canceled).

Even if you never want to sell coaching, you can make money
without your personal brand, and you think your teeth are too
crooked to show your face on camera…

It will only serve you, I promise.

It’s how I met all of my best friends you see me hanging out
with.

And it’s the only reason you’re reading this right now.

Now before you say “I dOn’T kNoW whAt tO poSt AbOut.”

It doesn’t matter.

Just start. Talk about what you find interesting. Talk about why
you’re poor. Talk about your dog, or your girl, or your obsession
with sports betting.

Just don’t say the N word or call fat people disgusting hippos.

You’ll be glad you started.

​Get access to the next guest speaker call by going here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403seh544nzxhxh300zm77s5/p8heh9hz6v87z9cq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Bye,

Ben

​

subject: Some discouraging words of encouragement
body:
I’m sorry for the week-long hiatus.

But now, I’m what one may define as ‘so fucking back.’

I’ve been busy closing deals.

If you were on this list a week and a half ago, you might
remember me talking about an outbound pitch I sent.

I just wanted to let you know that it closed.

Yes, that’s correct:

I sent one outbound DM for the first time in years.

And it resulted in a 5 figure set up fee in my pocket 10 days
later.

Plus a rev share that will likely be very fruitful, as this is a
‘dream client’ by most standards.

Imagine you’re grinding outreach, sending dozens of messages per
day, and I waltz in and steal your best prospect because I got
bored.

I’d be pissed.

I know I’m bragging here but I’m on a caffeine/endorphin high so
you’ll have to forgive me.

The point I am getting at is this –

You’re one (quality) pitch away.

It probably won’t be your first pitch because you’re not Ben
Bader.

But it might be your 10th pitch.

Or your hundredth.

Or your thousandth.

Eventually it will work.

Whether you’re trying to get a client, making content hoping
something goes viral, or cold approaching models on the street…

All it takes is one yes.

I'll leave you with a quote from one of the greatest philosophers
of our generation, Future:

“I just want to see my dogs ball, seven figures.”

Go make some money today,

Ben

P.S. I documented this whole process inside my mastermind.

From what I said in the pitch, to the sales call, to the
proposal, follow ups, and the contract that got the deal done.

I’ll also be showing exactly what we do to scale this client to
multi six figures a month inside the Artisan Lab.

If you want to see that, plus get direct access to me, learn from
new guest speakers weekly, and be in a community of winners…

subject: how to practice your writing ability
body:
Hey.

I’m starting this email completely blind.

Meaning I have zero idea what’s gonna come out onto this page.

Hopefully it’s kind of coherent.

I went for a walk this morning.

My new apartment is right by the water so it’s nice being able to
go outside, cross the street, and start moving.

It seems like everyone else who walks during this early morning
shift is one of two things:

1.Old

2.Dog

I’m neither of the two.

Although I did find a gray hair on my head the other day and I
accidentally barked when I saw a pretty girl in the elevator.

Hmm.

Ok, this leads me to a lesson for you.

If you want to become a better writer, you need to enjoy it.

So far in this email, I’ve said nothing of value.

But I’m having fun. And you’re still here, so that means maybe
you’re having fun with me.

I’ve never deliberately “practiced” my copywriting ability, I
just wrote.

I started sending emails to this list in September 2021.

There were probably 6 people who’d subscribed, including my 4
burner emails, my mother, and grandma.

On top of that, I was effectively an autistic Chinese child who
didn’t speak a word of English (if that offended you, grow up).

I had no idea what I was talking about, nothing to sell, and very
few people who cared to listen to what I was saying.

But I started anyway.

I developed my own style, my writing became more clear, and I
began articulating the ideas that were rattling around in my
head.

Along with the newsletter, I was consistently tweeting and
journaling.

This was the “training camp” that prepared me to work with
clients.

I’d read a few copywriting books, I practiced every day (even
though it didn’t feel like practice), and I became half-decent at
this writing thing.

It’d be impossible not to.

One of my favorite copywriting books is The Boron Letters by Gary
Halbert.

The reason I like it is because it feels personal (he wrote it to
his son while he was in jail).

Instead of writing in a super authoritative tone, it reads as if
it’s a journal with insights and tips sprinkled throughout.

You can tell he clearly enjoys writing and isn’t putting any
pressure on himself to be grammatically correct or follow any
rules.

This is how you have to practice.

Write about your day.

Write about something you enjoy.

Write about how you overcame a difficult time in your life.

Write about the weird crush you have on your cleaning lady
(creep).

It doesn’t matter what you write about, as long as you find a way
to enjoy it, and it doesn’t feel like work.

Ok?

Ok.

Enough for today.

​Join me in the Artisan Lab if you want to get rich. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h3q2w20iqhp3ql333hr/wnh2hghw6w3v9mu7/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

If you don’t want to join me in there, that’s fine. But at least
reply and tell me you made it all the way down here to make me
feel good.

Thanks,

Ben

​

​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h3q2w20iqhp3ql333hr
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h3q2w20iqhp3ql333hr
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(

subject: nice try diddy
body:
I’ve been a bit stressed out lately that my content hasn’t been
doing super well.

YouTube views are down, Tik Tok only pushes my videos when I say
something controversial, and half the retards in the comments
tell me to “put the fries in the bag.”

This is the new normie army insult and it’s pretty funny.

They’ve also started leaving “Nice try Diddy” in the comments on
ads.

If only they put that energy into something that would actually
improve their lives.

Anyway, whenever I’m stressed, I do one of three things.

The first thing is bad.

If I do this, I lose.

It temporarily numbs the stress but doesn’t revolve anything.

And it’s scrolling through social media.

Now the other two mechanisms I use to combat stress seem to work
like magic for me.

The first is doing what I’m doing right now, writing.

I wrote a whole email to you yesterday and made a Youtube video
about how writing will change your life, so no need to repeat
myself.

Just trust me. Start today if you haven't.

The second thing is walking.

What better way to clear your head?

It’s literally impossible to be sad when the sun is shining and
birds are chirping.

I could watch my best friend get eaten by a lizard but if it’s a
nice day I’ll get over it.

Every wave eventually crashes.

But the ocean never stops moving.

of it.

metrics.

down?

more.

I’ll stop taking you for granted.

subject: how to stop the Chinese from infiltrating your mind
body:
Cdhsuifhinfkfbedbfqbef!

Hey.

Ignore the gibberish in the first line. I’m just excited to talk
to you.

Hope you’re having an amazing Thursday morning.

What do you want to talk about today?

Oh, I got something.

Decisions.

Isn’t it crazy how our entire reality is shaped by countless
micro decisions we’re making on a daily basis?

Like you could just wake up one day and start speaking with a
British accent.

Or you could simply decide to stop being poor and take the
actions necessary to make money.

Orrr you could decide to stop pulling out and build an NFL team
of babies.

Everyday you choose to either take actions that will further
align you with the person you want to be, or do the opposite.

When you open your laptop and the voice in your head tells you
that you need to scroll through TikTok for a minute before
starting work – can you shut it out or do you give in?

Because you know ‘one minute’ usually turns into three hours.

You simply cannot compete with the Chinese artificial
intelligence algorithm.

They figured out, “Oh, all we have to do is show men titties and
show women travel videos and Hermes bags and they just keep
scrolling forever. Stupid little lizards.”

Can you resist the double D’s and birkins?

Or will you give in to the Chinese?

Hahahah.

Sorry I got carried away on that one.

Recently I had to make a big decision.

It was not easy but I knew that it would be better for me in the
long run.

My brain tried to do everything in its power to stop me.

Because with this decision, much change would come.

And that’s painful.

Even days after I’d made up my mind, I’d still find myself trying
to revert back to old habits.

I quite literally had to view the voice in my head like a
toddler.

“No, you don’t actually want that. It’s just a narrative you’re
telling yourself because it’s easier than the alternative.”

I used logic to constantly remind myself that I was making the
right call.

And there was this underlying feeling in my gut that knew that
was true.

I’m telling you all this because I want you to make the right
choices.

You know what you need to do.

You know what needs to change.

And you know that further contemplation is just a way to occupy
your brain so that you feel like you’re being productive.

Don’t let the Chinese control you.

Resist!

​Lmao, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukhop9n4xtrh4nmennnh7/g3hnh5h3wm8g73br/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben
​

​

subject: everything is bad and that's really good
body:
Three days ago I sent you an email about how my content hadn’t
been getting many views.

Yesterday, I had three videos go semi-viral on Tik Tok.

Whenever this happens, it fries my dopamine receptors for a few
days.

Every time I refresh the app, I have more comments, follows, and
dm’s.

And since I’m addicted to dopamine, I end up spending the whole
day staring at my phone.

It’s funny how this works.

In my email the other day, I talked about how success comes in
waves.

It felt like I’d been paddling, trying to catch a wave for a
while and I was getting restless.

But I knew I just had to keep trying.

Two days later, I caught three waves in a row.

The obvious lesson there is that you never know when your time
will come but if you keep shooting, you can’t go wrong.

The less obvious lesson is that “good and “bad” do not exist in
reality, they are constructs of the mind.

I know it might sound like I’m reaching in an attempt to sound
insightful right now and you’re like, “Ok buddy whatever the fuck
that means.”

Allow me to explain.

When I was frustrated about my content not performing, it was a
lot easier to sit and work on real business tasks.

It was the source of the lesson in my email the other day.

And it forced me to not let my desire for external validation
control and discourage me.

You could make the argument that my content flopping was actually
a “good” thing.

On the contrary, because I’ve had these few videos go viral, it’s
been really difficult to do anything else.

Sitting at my desk to do real work feels like a herculean feat.

I’m constantly checking my phone and I now feel an added pressure
to make my videos continually perform.

Again, we could make a solid argument here for why virality is a
“bad” thing.

But in reality, neither of those conclusions would be completely
true.

It simply is as it is.

There are countless pro’s when a situation isn’t going as you’d
hoped.

There are countless con’s when a situation is going exactly how
you wanted it.

It’s your perception that makes it good or bad.

Don’t get caught up in that perception.

And remember, every hurdle is part of a bigger plan.

Alright I gotta get back to scrolling.

But before I do, quick plug – I went on this podcast recently and
discussed some things I haven’t talked much about publicly. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hpr26rms8h825v222cl/n2hohvh30rnogzu6/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_dj0wQnVNMzlSdlRYTQ==
)​

Go watch that and happy Saturday,

Ben

​
​

subject: bo, we're going to Vietnam
body:
Good morning bo.

I went for a run and then tried to meditate but it didn’t really
work.

Now I’m here, typing to you.

I’m actually sitting at the desk in my “office,” which is really
just a den.

Since I moved about three weeks ago, this has been the last area
of my new apartment that still needs work.

The lighting in here is kind of depressing and I have a bunch of
random belongings on the floor.

Because of this, I’ve avoided this room.

My phone is in the kitchen because I’ve been really addicted to
it recently.

It’s cool that you can get rich and all from your fingertips but
wow can that device be destructive.

On my run earlier, I thought about what it must’ve been like to
be a young man who was shipped off to fight in the Vietnam war.

Imagine you’re a 19 year old kid, fresh out of high school.

You’re awakened in the middle of the night by Forrest Gump.

He grabs you by the ear and takes you with him.

Next thing you know you have an AK-47 in your hands and you’re
shooting at anyone who has squinty eyes.

What a turn of events, huh?

All of the problems you had prior to being drafted have now
vanished.

You’re no longer worried about what career you’re gonna go into.

You stopped thinking about what to say to the girl you have a
crush on.

And you couldn’t give a singular shit about the decor in home or
clothes on your back.

You now have one goal;

Survive.

If you’re reading this, I assume that the Vietnamese are not
currently trying to blow your head off.

What a lucky guy (or girl) you are.

I’m in the same boat.

And although this is obviously a privilege, it comes with
consequences.

Naturally, you want a war.

You want a mountain to climb, and a communist to shoot at.

But because life is relatively easy, you have to avoid the trap
of getting caught up in bullshit problems so that you feel like
you’re progressing.

In other words, don’t stress about inconsequential things because
you don’t have a life or death thing.

You need to find your Vietnam war.

Actually, let me rephrase that.

You need to make your life the Vietnam war.

Build businesses, go hard in the gym, nurture beautiful
relationships, get famous, fight a homeless man (lol), travel the
globe…

Just do something.

Preferably something that’s actually productive instead of
worrying about things that have little impact on your life.

That’s how you avoid becoming a Karen who gets mad at kids for
skateboarding on the sidewalk.

Or becoming a fat incel whose only joy is yelling racial slurs at
the TV.

Or even a manic 46 year old housewife who yells at the gardener
because he missed a blade of grass.

You need real(er) problems.

Stuff that’s actually worth stressing about.

And you’re likely not gonna get sent to Vietnam any time soon so
you have to bring Nam’ to you.

You’re lucky. Don’t waste your luck.

Ben

P.S. Join me in the Artisan lab here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukhop7e9mfrh4nmennnh7/z2hghnh3xnm2vrap/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

P.P.S. Lmk if you made it all the way down here, soldier.

​
​

​

 You’re awakened in the middle of the night by Forrest Gump. 

 He grabs you by the ear and takes you with him. 

 Next thing you know you have an AK-47 in your hands and you’re shooting at anyone who has squinty eyes. 

 What a turn of events, huh? 

 All of the problems you had prior to being drafted have now vanished. 

 You’re no longer worried about what career you’re gonna go into. 

 You stopped thinking about what to say to the girl you have a crush on. 

 And you couldn’t give a singular shit about the decor in home or clothes on your back. 

 You now have one goal; 

 Survive. 

 If you’re reading this, I assume that the Vietnamese are not currently trying to blow your head off. 

 What a lucky guy (or girl) you are. 

 I’m in the same boat. 

 And although this is obviously a privilege, it comes with consequences. 

 Naturally, you want a war. 

 You want a mountain to climb, and a communist to shoot at. 

 But because life is relatively easy, you have to avoid the trap of getting caught up in bullshit problems so that you feel like you’re progressing. 

 In other words, don’t stress about inconsequential things because you don’t have a life or death thing. 

 You need to find your Vietnam war. 

 Actually, let me rephrase that. 

 You need to make your life the Vietnam war. 

 Build businesses, go hard in the gym, nurture beautiful relationships, get famous, fight a homeless man (lol), travel the globe… 

 Just do something. 

 Preferably something that’s actually productive instead of worrying about things that have little impact on your life. 

 That’s how you avoid becoming a Karen who gets mad at kids for skateboarding on the sidewalk. 

 Or becoming a fat incel whose only joy is yelling racial slurs at the TV. 

 Or even a manic 46 year old housewife who yells at the gardener because he missed a blade of grass. 

 You need real(er) problems. 

 Stuff that’s actually worth stressing about. 

 And you’re likely not gonna get sent to Vietnam any time soon so you have to bring Nam’ to you. 

 You’re lucky. Don’t waste your luck. 

 Ben 

 P.S. Join me in the Artisan lab here. ​ 

 P.P.S. Lmk if you made it all the way down here, soldier. 

 ​
​ 

 ​

subject: this is the opportunity of the decade
body:
Happy Monday.

On my walk this morning I overheard a guy talking about the
hospitality industry.

It sounds like times are tough right now.

A friend of mine who works in nightlife told me the same thing
recently.

Allegedly, a lot of the bigger clubs and restaurants are losing
money.

Like, lots of money.

I began thinking about how complex it must be to run a
hospitality group.

Between staffing, opening new locations, logistics, operations
and a myriad of other factors I’m probably overlooking.

And then finally on top of all that, the most important piece;
marketing.

You have to deal with all of these annoying logistical issues and
even once you solve all of them, you will still fail if you don’t
get people in the doors.

That does not sound like a fun time.

Let’s compare this to an online service based business or
coaching business.

There are two main objectives in each of these.

1. Create an attractive, in-demand offer.

2. Generate demand.

It’s actually the same process of building a club or restaurant,
without the world of complexity attached to it.

With an internet business, all you have to do is learn some
skills and build the offer.

That can take a week.

And basically costs nothing.

Once the offer is built, you can dedicate the majority of your
focus to acquisition.

If your content gets attention, or you build a lucrative outbound
system, or you can profitably put a dollar into Facebook and get
$2 back, scaling becomes easy.

You double down on the acquisition system and you make sure
nothing breaks on the backend.

Next thing you know, you have a $5m/year business that was built
off a couple TikTok videos, loom pitches, or cringy ads.

Obviously I’m oversimplifying this a bit, but it really is this
simple.

You lose when you try to make it more complicated.

If you’re struggling to grow as a service provider or a coach,
one of two things are happening.

1. You’re focusing on the wrong things and distracting yourself
from the actual needle movers.

2. You’re just really dumb. No offense, but you are cooked. I
think McDonalds is hiring though.

You might not realize it, but opportunity in the info-product
space right now is similar to the way paid ads were 10-15 years
ago.

I was in diapers back then, but a friend of mine told me he was
getting 1 cent cost per click on his ads.

1 cent.

Meaning, holy fuck, you’re gonna get rich.

But over time, that opportunity diminishes and it gets more
expensive.

Right now, in 2024 you can whip out your phone and make a 48
second selfie video that millions of people could see.

If the content in the video is somewhat useful and you have an
offer that correlates with it, you now have a seven figure
business.

I’m not exaggerating.

Idiots are getting rich.

​Do you want to join them? (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h3qx3n8hqhp3ql333hr/p8heh9hzo0660diq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: Does success come down to luck?
body:
Gooooood morning!

I’m sitting on my balcony and the sun is beaming in my eyes so
I’m squinting at the screen.

My neighbors just let out their dogs to take their morning piss
on this mat of grass that they’ve been trained to urinate on.

They have these two little beige pugs named Ricco and Rocco.

Those aren’t actually their real names but it’s what I would have
named them.

I’m going to steal them one day.

Anyway, let’s talk about how to get lucky.

Some people say luck doesn’t exist.

Others believe everyone who’s successful gets lucky.

In my opinion, both of the above statements are true, even though
they’re contradictory.

This is called a paradox, in case you slept through that part of
English class.

I watched a movie last night that had Miles Teller in it and
began thinking about how you end up as a world famous actor.

Sure, he’s great at what he does.

But so are the tens of thousands of broke actors.

There are plenty of people with the same look, talent, and work
ethic.

Why is he one of few who makes it?

Is it luck?

No.

Well, yes.

Well, kind of.

If you run a quick Google search on Miles Teller, you’ll see that
he made his first feature film in 2010.

Three years later, he starred in “The Spectacular Now” which put
him on the map.

And then the film, “Whiplash” a year later was his big
breakthrough.

Now he’s one of the more popular actors and was recently in Top
Gun with Tom Cruise.

But you don’t hear about all the projects that flopped.

From 2004-2010 he was in a bunch of movies neither of us have
ever heard of.

Then he had a few “big breaks” and his life changed forever.

This is how success works.

The majority of the time that you put in, especially in the
beginning, will feel like it’s all for nothing.

You’ll think to yourself, “why am I even working this hard?
Nobody’s gonna notice me anyway.”

It’s an uphill battle and you have no idea where the top of the
hill is.

You just keep climbing and hope that eventually you find it,
which isn’t guaranteed.

You could climb for decades and still end up as one of the
unknown actors who never found a good role.

It’s a gamble.

Maybe you’ll get lucky, maybe you won’t.

However, there are ways that you can increase your chances.

Consistency plus iteration creates luck.

I think that's the smartest thing I’ve said all year.

If you don’t quit and you continually strive to get better at the
craft, you have a chance.

Worst case scenario, it’s likely that your effort will result in
an opportunity, even if it’s not the one you were anticipating.

And best case scenario…

​Well, the sky's the limit. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8hkn3d9wfzhw642666tn/p8heh9hzonl44dcq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Happy hunting,

Ben

P.S. Reply if you made it all the way down here :)

​

 Happy hunting, 

 Ben

subject: pain
body:
Up until my junior year of high school, I was dead set on playing
college basketball.

Being a “hooper” was my entire identity.

But over the previous year, some doubt had started to creep in.

“Maybe this isn’t right for me anymore,” a voice in my head would
tell me.

I tried to ignore it, but it wouldn’t go away.

When I’d consider what life would be like if I decided not to
play collegiately, it was daunting.

All of my friends and family knew me as this basketball guy.

It’s how I viewed myself.

How embarrassing would it be to change that?

I’d look like a crazy person.

And I had no idea what’s on the other side.

But I couldn’t shake that feeling in my gut that knew it was time
for a different route.

In a single moment, I made the decision.

I was no longer going to play in college.

It was time to let that story go and when I did, I became free.

“Walking away from anything you love because it’s not working for
you is the only character building exercise there is. People
can't comprehend how much you have to screw yourself over to get
self respect.” - Brute

It’s no secret that change is difficult.

Changing your habits is painful.

Changing your career path is painful.

Changing your negative thought patterns is painful.

Because of this, most people elect to endure situations that
aren’t right for them in order to avoid the pain that comes with
change.

Sure, working a job you hate sucks, but quitting that job to bet
on yourself would be temporarily more painful than staying in it.

Your willingness to exchange this low level, long term pain for
high level, short term pain is what makes you grow.

You choose to dig the hole a little deeper.

You choose to put yourself in a tough situation.

You choose to sacrifice your (illusionary) peace for struggle.

And then you’re free.

It’ll be difficult and even after making the decision your ego
will try to pull you back into comfort.

But if you can withstand that tide, you’ll make it to the other
side as a new person.

Comfort kills you slowly. Pain kills you instantly.

And maybe that’s what you need.

Happy Monday,

Ben

P.S. Join me inside my mastermind if you’re ready to grow. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8hknlrm0szhw642666tn/n2hohvh304l4npc6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

P.P.S. Watch my new video with 8 figure info-product seller, Tim
Luong (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8hknlrm0szhw642666tn/48hvhehr83730dsx/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9kRGwyRzhRQnBDRT9zaT1lZTBDNkFxS1pMYklJV0Ff
)​

subject: when it rains, it pours
body:
Around this time last year, I hit my first $100k month as a
growth partner.

If you’re completely new here, here’s how my business works in a
nutshell:

I partner with “influencers" who sell courses (think trading
influencer or eCom guru).

I help them build a program from scratch or improve their current
offer

My team and I run all of their operations.

From their sales funnels, to email marketing, automations,
scripting videos, sales team, etc.

My client's job is to make content.

My job is to help them get the people who watch their content to
buy their course.

Make sense?

I hope so, because I just explained that to you as if you’re an
autistic monkey.

Anyway, about 2 years ago, I was stuck between $10-20k per month.

It was frustrating seeing people who I deemed incompetent make
way more money than me.

I was working really hard but just couldn’t get through that
ceiling.

And then, something changed.

I hit $25k.

Then $30k the next month.

Then $35k.

$50k.

I hovered around $60k-80k for a bit.

And then, I finally hit $100k.

It was all because of one thing:

Positioning.

When I was stuck under $20k/month, I had no leverage.

I would take any opportunity I could get.

I was writing a ton of copy, building funnels, managing CRMs, and
it all felt discombobulated.

Every client I got basically felt like I had a boss telling me
what to do.

But then, I got one really good win.

I helped a client go from $30k/month to $350k per month in 2
months.

A couple months later we were past $500k/month.

Not only did that result in a multiple 5 figure rev share for me,

subject: when it rains, it pours
body:
Around this time last year, I hit my first $100k month as a growth partner. 

 If you’re completely new here, here’s how my business works in a nutshell: 

 I partner with “influencers" who sell courses (think trading influencer or eCom guru). 

 I help them build a program from scratch or improve their current offer 

 My team and I run all of their operations. 

 From their sales funnels, to email marketing, automations, scripting videos, sales team, etc. 

 My client's job is to make content. 

 My job is to help them get the people who watch their content to buy their course. 

 Make sense? 

 I hope so, because I just explained that to you as if you’re an autistic monkey. 

 Anyway, about 2 years ago, I was stuck between $10-20k per month. 

 It was frustrating seeing people who I deemed incompetent make way more money than me. 

 I was working really hard but just couldn’t get through that ceiling. 

 And then, something changed. 

 I hit $25k. 

 Then $30k the next month. 

 Then $35k. 

 $50k. 

 I hovered around $60k-80k for a bit. 

 And then, I finally hit $100k. 

 It was all because of one thing: 

 Positioning. 

 When I was stuck under $20k/month, I had no leverage. 

 I would take any opportunity I could get. 

 I was writing a ton of copy, building funnels, managing CRMs, and it all felt discombobulated. 

 Every client I got basically felt like I had a boss telling me what to do. 

 But then, I got one really good win. 

 I helped a client go from $30k/month to $350k per month in 2 months. 

 A couple months later we were past $500k/month. 

 Not only did that result in a multiple 5 figure rev share for me, but it put me on the map. 

 It changed the way I was perceived by others because I could flex that case study. 

 And it changed the way I perceived myself because I saw my actions result in such a drastic impact. 

 That singular win is all it took to give me endless opportunities, and the conviction I needed to be able to handle them. 

 If you’re trying to build a copywriting or growth partner business right now, keep this in mind. 

 Just get one fat W, and the floodgates will open my friend. 

 Extrapolate this to any life pursuit you’re stagnating in. 

 When it rains, it pours. 

 ​ Come check out Artisan Lab if you want to learn from me directly. ​ 

 Later, 

 Ben 

 ​
​

subject: famous and broke
body:
I officially know what it would feel like to be a broke
influencer.

You may have seen some of the skits I’ve been posting on Tik Tok
as they’ve gotten over 15m views in the last 30 days.

It’s wild.

As cool as it is, it offers me almost no monetary benefit (at
least for now).

I always wondered how ‘micro-influencers’ made their money and I
now understand that most don’t.

Sure I’ve gained some followers, gotten a bunch of DM’s and have
been recognized in public a bit more.

But I’ve made $0.00 from it.

Obviously, it’s a different story once you reach real fame and
can make solid money from brand deals.

However, if you want to monetize your personal brand, you’re
better off making niche educational content and building an
audience of a few thousand people.

Then you can sell coaching and happily make millions without
having to rely on brand deals.

On a similar topic, I’ve been thinking a lot about the
intersection between comedy and philosophy.

The funniest people are often the most observant.

They can turn a niche observation into a joke.

They can articulate the thing everyone is thinking, but can’t
express.

They can use analogies to connect two seemingly unconnected
ideas.

Similarly, the most profound insights are often gained from
uniquely personal experiences.

The lesson is articulated in a way that is so personal, that it
becomes universal.

Again, it’s the thing that everyone thinks but no one says.

Ironically, I don’t really have a lesson for this email.

These are just some insights I’ve gained as of late and figured
I’d share because what else is there to do other than attempt to
entertain and educate strangers on the internet?

Anyway, let’s have a good week.

Focus on the needle movers and stop stressing over nothing, okay?

Progress is simple, you just have to get out of your own way
sometimes.

Happy Monday, join me in my mastermind if you want to get rich
selling info. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403seh5xx494uxh67rxv77u5/n2hohvh3p5o3wwh6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​
​

subject: No business model will make you rich
body:
Let’s talk about money.

When you’re a beginner, you typically think you need to find the
right business model.

In reality, it’s not the label that’s important.

Whether you’re a copywriter, IPGA, IPO, growth operator, growth
partner, etc.

All of these terms are different ways to say the same thing.

You offer ‘done for you’ services to online businesses.

This is important to understand because a business model doesn’t
make you money, your skillset does.

People like me, Pierre Khoury, and others who’ve had success in
this space have been able to do so because we can offer a
multitude of services and truly increase revenue.

It’s definitely NOT because of a fancy label we placed on our
services.

This brings me to my second point, which is that the market
decides your niche.

In my business, our biggest wins have come through webinars.

It’s the main reason I’ve gotten to 6 figure months.

But that happened on accident.

We tested a webinar for a client and it worked.

We figured we’d try it out for other clients and it kept working.

That doesn’t mean that your business has to work the same way as
mine.

Your big wins could come through VSLs.

Or you could figure out that you’re really good at scripting YT
videos or short form content.

Or maybe you end up specializing in email automations.

My point here is that you’re a marketer, not a robot.

If you label yourself as a growth operator and you’ll only work
with creators who have an audience but don’t have an offer yet,
your TAM (total addressable market) is limited.

But if you drop the label and think of yourself as a marketer,
you can fit into different roles.

That’s how you get your foot in the door with a client (solve one
niche problem they’re facing) and then you start to take over
other pieces of their business.

Get one big win, and you have a solidified offer.

This doesn’t happen overnight, but it’s the best way to do it if
you wanna work with coaches and course creators.

Learn some skills, pitch a bunch of shit, see what works, double
down.

Now you’re rich. You’re welcome.

​Go here if you want my help in growing your info-product agency
or coaching business. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hv6w74pa6h94g7v44tn/08hwh9hd57o2xgul/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

subject: An email about nothing
body:
Good morning.

I’m sitting on my balcony with an iced latte and a dream.

I don’t know what the dream is, but I thought that sounded cool.

It’s September 5, 2024 which means I turn 24 in 17 days.

Does that mean I’m… old? Do I need to start taking viagra? Am I
developing cataracts?

Oh no.

I’m going to New York with my friends Jimmy and Mason today.

We have quite the weekend planned, but if I told you about it,
I’d have to kill you.

I don’t think I could ever live in NY.

I have one major flaw and it’s that I’m geographically
challenged.

I don’t know what body of water I’m looking at off my balcony
right now.

I don’t know if I’m facing east, west, north, south, or upside
down.

I don’t know how to get nearly anywhere without a GPS.

Miami is relatively small and I have a hard enough time
navigating it.

I can’t imagine how lost I’d be in New York.

Plus I’d have a bunch of angry neurotic people yelling at me.

Speaking of, the other day I watched a clip of Jerry Seinfeld and
Larry David.

They were talking about Seinfeld, and how it was “a show about
nothing.”

This is an email about nothing.

Well actually, I guess I do have something to tell you:

Sorry.

I’ve been slacking on Youtube.

I was growing really quickly at first, then I hit a plateau, and
got too caught up in the numbers.

My focus went from “how can I make content that I enjoy?”

To “how can I hook these stupid little lizard brained monkeys
into watching more of my video so the algorithm pushes it?”

And that took the fun out of it.

I’m gonna get back on there and stop worrying about the metrics,
I promise.

But it might be a few days because there’s a solid chance I get
lost in New York.

Anyway, here’s my last thought for you today:

You can always find a reason to stress when you tie your sense of
self to your accomplishments.

In that sense, you’ll never be complete.

Sure, this can be a way to motivate yourself but it also stains
every experience with jaded glasses.

You’ll be in the club in New York with a dozen models around you
and your favorite song playing as you dance with your best
friends.

But you won’t be all the way there.

There will be a part of you that’s anxious, worrying about how
you don’t have $100m yet.

Instead, learn to accept what is.

You’re on your journey and that’s that.

Stressing doesn’t fix anything, so you might as well be where you
are.

Congrats. You’ve completed this email about nothing.

Let me know if you made it all the way down here.

See you in NY,

Ben

P.S. Join my mastermind here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdx7e3dalho7ed277f8/3ohphkh7ldl850sr/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

​

​

​
​

Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdx7e3dalho7ed277f8
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6hdx7e3dalho7ed277f8
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

)

subject: How to write an email
body:
I’m on the run.

I just let housekeeping into my hotel room and am now homeless
for the next 30 minutes.

Should I join the crackheads that roam the streets of NYC?

Actually, I have a better idea.

The other day, someone asked me about my process for writing
copy.

So this is an email about how to write an email.

If you’ve been on this list for a while, you know that my style
is a bit more casual than your average newsletter.

Sometimes I ramble about random thoughts, other times I hash out
an idea or concept, and every now and then I’ll send you a harder
pitch for Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5l94d6a7hnx859xxs8/6qheh8h7gpg4l6uo/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

No matter what, I have one goal in every line of copy I write.

And it’s to get you to read the next line.

Typically I start this by bringing you into my world.

This is where I set the scene.

I’ll tell you where I am, what kind of state I’m in, and try to
make you feel like you’re right here with me.

It’s personal and casual style.

My best emails seem to be when I describe an idea in a way that’s
so detailed to where you feel like I’m articulating your own
thoughts.

It creates this feeling where we’re solving a problem together.

Me and you against the world, baby.

This is where I think I have a bit of an edge on your average
copywriter.

Most end up talking down to their audience.

They put themselves on this authoritative pedestal, and are so
obsessed with “giving value” that it eradicates the value.

Because people hate being told what to do for no reason.

If you tell someone why they should live a certain way or think a
certain way, without giving them context as to how you arrived at
that conclusion, you’re just preaching.

It’s the personal aspect and storytelling that makes the lessons
hit.

If I tell you a story about how I overcame a fear and then
connect the dots for you as to how you can do the same in your
own life, that’s when it resonates.

Versus if I were to impose my own beliefs on you without
providing any personal anecdotes, you’d have stopped reading by
now.

You read my emails because I talk directly to you.

I don’t think about “providing value” because I know that if my
email is personal enough, it becomes valuable.

Is this making sense?

I hope so.

I’m dying for a bacon egg and cheese here so I have to run, but
the last thing I’ll leave you with is this:

You just have to trust yourself.

I often start these emails without any idea of what I’m going to
say.

But I know that if I just begin writing, my subconscious brain
starts to work for me.

It feeds me an analogy or story that I can use to articulate my
point.

And by the time I get to the end, it ends up being pretty
coherent (most of the time).

Ok I’m starving.

Hope you enjoyed my email about emails, join me in the Artisan
Lab if you wanna learn more from me. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5l94d6a7hnx859xxs8/6qheh8h7gpg4l6uo/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Love you,

Ben

​
​
​

) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhgh5l94d6a7hnx859xxs8
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

(

 It creates this feeling where we’re solving a problem together. 

 Me and you against the world, baby. 

 This is where I think I have a bit of an edge on your average copywriter. 

 Most end up talking down to their audience. 

 They put themselves on this authoritative pedestal, and are so obsessed with “giving value” that it eradicates the value. 

 Because people hate being told what to do for no reason. 

 If you tell someone why they should live a certain way or think a certain way, without giving them context as to how you arrived at that conclusion, you’re just preaching. 

 It’s the personal aspect and storytelling that makes the lessons hit. 

 If I tell you a story about how I overcame a fear and then connect the dots for you as to how you can do the same in your own life, that’s when it resonates. 

 Versus if I were to impose my own beliefs on you without providing any personal anecdotes, you’d have stopped reading by now. 

 You read my emails because I talk directly to you. 

 I don’t think about “providing value” because I know that if my email is personal enough, it becomes valuable. 

 Is this making sense? 

 I hope so. 

 I’m dying for a bacon egg and cheese here so I have to run, but the last thing I’ll leave you with is this: 

 You just have to trust yourself. 

 I often start these emails without any idea of what I’m going to say. 

 But I know that if I just begin writing, my subconscious brain starts to work for me. 

 It feeds me an analogy or story that I can use to articulate my point. 

 And by the time I get to the end, it ends up being pretty coherent (most of the time). 

 Ok I’m starving. 

 Hope you enjoyed my email about emails, join me in the Artisan Lab if you wanna learn more from me. ​

 Love you, 

 Ben 

 ​
​
​

subject: F*** the audience
body:
Gooooood morning, bo.

I got back from New York last night, ready to lock back in and
make some money.

Hope you’re doing the same.

As I sit here pondering what to write to you about, I found
myself thinking, “what will my audience get value from?”

This is a really stupid question.

I could sit here and try to guess what you would find valuable.

I could think of an angle or analogy to drive my point home.

And then I could pitch you my mastermind and a handful of you
would apply.

It works, but it lacks some personality.

You want to know the lessons that seem to hit the hardest?

They’re the ones where I don’t give a fuck about you.

I don’t try to think of what you need to hear.

I don’t tailor my message to hook you in or get you to click a
link.

And the word “value” doesn’t cross my mind.

Instead, I write about what I want to write about.

Typically it’ll be a problem I’m overcoming, a recent
observation, or something else that’s very personal to me.

I can articulate the idea with so much detail, because I don’t
have to imagine what it would be like.

I’m in my own shoes.

Couple that with the fact that I’m not trying to appease the
audience (you), and that’s what makes you feel like I understand
you.

It’s like when you’re trying to win over a girl.

When you’re an idiot, you think “oh, if I just agree with
everything she says and try to say all the right things back to
her, she’ll like me.”

Then you learn that’s not a recipe for success.

You’re not expressing yourself freely.

You’re uncomfortable.

You’re trying to gain something from her, and you both
subconsciously know that.

Plus it's exhausting.

But what happens when you let go?

When you stop caring about winning someone’s approval, you take
back the wheel.

You make the jokes you want to make.

You say the thing that everyone else is thinking but too nervous
to say.

You’re comfortably, freely, you.

And that’s the most attractive state you can be in.

Pure indifference because you are who you are.

Whether you’re speaking to an audience or courting your future ex
baby mama.

Think less about what they want and more about what you want.

It sounds counterintuitive, but it’s actually a much more
selfless act than the alternative.

Hope you enjoyed this one.

​Hop in here if you wanna get rich selling info. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hohvqv99zi3hg48vw44hg/p8heh9hz04okeehq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

subject: Become a Swiss army knife marketer
body:
Once upon a time, you could get away with being a one trick pony.

You could go to a business, pitch them a singular service, and
close them.

When I started out, that’s what I did.

I’d pitch course sellers on building them a new funnel.

This worked to get my first few clients.

But I quickly learned that when you solve one problem, it exposes
three more.

I could build the best funnel in the world but if traffic was low
or if their emails sucked, it wouldn’t make a difference.

So, I started to take over more pieces of my clients' businesses.

Because I understood copywriting, it was easy.

I began writing their emails, scripting their VSLs, scripting
ads, etc.

And then on the operations side, I built automations, managed
their systems, and set up CRMs.

I know this sounds like a lot, but it’s actually quite simple.

Once you learn the fundamentals of direct response marketing, you
can add new skills to your toolbox in a couple hours.

It’s exactly what I did and next thing you know, I had clients
paying me anywhere from $10k-$40k per month each.

The reason this model works is because it turns you into a Swiss
army knife.

You can work with just about anyone, because you have a multitude
of skills.

If they already have an email copywriter, you can build them a
new funnel.

If they already have a funnel builder, you can write them a new
VSL or script short form content.

If they’re just starting out, you can help them build from
scratch.

This is actually how one of my biggest wins happened.

I helped an offer go from zero to $600k per month and that was
all the social proof I ever needed.

The opportunities in the info-product space are endless.

You just have to know where to look and be equipped to handle it.

And that's what you'll learn inside of my small group coaching
program, The Artisan Lab. (

subject: 3 steps to hit $30k months
body:
Gm {{ subscriber.first_name }}. 

 The other day I figured out that 15 minute walks in the morning are the perfect distance. 

 If the walk is too long, it makes me feel like I’m wasting time. 

 If it’s too short, I’m too restless to sit at my desk. 

 Anyway, today I want to tell you how to get rich. 

 About two years ago, I hit my first $30k month. 

 I had no team members so it was pure profit. 

 For the following six months, my income fluctuated between $30-50k per month. 

 This was one of my favorite times in running my info-product agency. 

 The work was pretty simple because I was mostly just building funnels and managing email marketing. 

 And on my perfect 15 minute walk this morning, I realized this is the perfect way for anyone to start. 

 So if you’re towards the beginning of your journey, here’s my braindead simple process for you to get to $10k-30k/month ASAP: 

 1. Learn copywriting 

 Read books, watch Youtube videos, and start writing sample copy. 

 You can improve quickly, you just have to get reps. 

 Writing on Twitter or pretending you have your own email list can also be helpful. 

 Study good copy and your subconscious will recognize patterns. 

 But DO NOT overthink this. 

 You don’t have to be the best writer in the world, you just have to be competent. 

 2. Start outreach 

 Start before you feel 100% ready, as most learning is done on the fly. 

 Go through social media, find people that are selling coaching and pitch them. 

 Just don’t be an idiot and copy what everyone else tells you to do. 

 This part is a grind but the bar is low because everyone else is dumb. 

 If you send a good pitch, you have a chance. 

 I’ve literally sent one outbound pitch this entire year and it landed me a 5 figure deal. 

 3. Just say yes 

 If you understand copywriting, learning other skills is easy. 

 I could teach you how to write a VSL in 10 minutes. 

 Same with managing CRMs, automations, and literally any other relevant skill. 

 Just because you haven’t done something before doesn’t mean you’re not one Google search away. 

 If you get an opportunity, take it. 

 That’s literally how I learned everything. 

 A client would come to me with a need, I’d say “yes I can do that” and boom, I figured it out. 

 It’s really that simple. 

 Just don’t get distracted along the way. 

 ​ If you want my personal coaching in your own journey to wealth, go here. ​

 Deuces, 

 Ben 

 ​
​ 

 ​
