subject: If you don't know where to start, do this
body:
“I don’t know where to start.”

Sound familiar?

I was combing through Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl99lrzt8h89ex022cl/08hwh9hdl850v4ul/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) applications this morning and found a theme.

There’s a question that asks applicants to share any roadblocks
they’re facing.

Around 90% of the answers are long-winded variations of “I don’t
know where to start.”

Whether it’s picking a business model, starting outreach, or
creating content…

Everyone finds a scapegoat as to why they aren’t taking action.

Perhaps a better way of putting this dilemma is “I want to be
told where to start.”

You feel stuck because you have an abundance of options and
you're not doing anything about it.

Any business model can work.

Any style of content can garner attention.

Any outreach method can get you a client.

But instead of trying something and seeing if it works, you
convince yourself that you need more information.

You’re left in a perpetual cycle of looking for more information
rather than actively creating data that steers you in the right
direction.

One thing I know for sure is that everything that’s ever been
created was done so from scratch.

Someone, like you, didn’t know where to start.

They tried something and it probably didn’t work the first time.

So they tried a different method, now with more data.

They do this over and over until they’ve crossed off many of the
“wrong” answers.

In doing so, they came closer to the answer…

And then it clicks.

Action creates clarity.

The route to success is found after knifing through tens,
hundreds, or even thousands of routes that don’t directly lead
you to where you want to go.

But they continuously reroute you until you arrive at your
destination.

And the once “directionless” version of you ceases to exist.

I can’t tell you with full certainty what will work for you.
Neither can anyone else.

We’re all different people with various natural advantages and
inclinations.

That’s life.

The ones who are rewarded are those who act despite the fact that
there is no universal rulebook.

You just gotta start moving and trust that you’ll find the
answers while you’re running the race.

There’s no way around this truth.

​Trust yourself, and you’ll be rewarded. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl99lrzt8h89ex022cl/08hwh9hdl850v4ul/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

subject: This is a privilege
body:
About 3 years ago, I got recognized from social media in person
for the first time.

I was walking on 5th avenue in Playa Del Carmen, Mexico.

This is the main strip in the city, filled with restaurants,
clubs, and a lot of people discreetly trying to offer you drugs.

If you made eye contact with one of these vendors they’d go
directly into their pitch.

“Amigo! cocaine, ecstasy, molly, women…. tengo todo. What you
want?”

Solid offer, but I refrained from ever taking them up on it.

As I walked through the chaos, I could feel someone staring at
me.

I looked over and saw this guy who appeared to be around my same
age.

He came running up to me and asked, “is your name Ben??”

I answered “yes” and he told me knew me from Twitter.

We chatted for a bit and got a picture together.

That was a surreal feeling.

You mean to tell me that by simply making content through the
little device I’m typing this on right now, people from all over
the world could see it?

And it could have enough of an impact on their life that they
feel impelled to come up to me and say something?

In Mexico of all places?

That’s pretty cool.

Now, as I sit here writing this from a Starbucks in Brickell, two
people have come up to me saying they’ve seen my content.

This typically happens multiple times a day now.

But like anything, over time that surrealistic feeling from the
beginning starts to wear off.

It feels normal. I find myself taking it for granted.

This isn’t an attempt to brag, sound like an asshole and tell you
how famous I am. Although it may read that way.

Rather it’s a reminder to myself and to you reading this — don’t
take special for granted.

It’s a privilege to wake up in the morning.

It’s a privilege to work on something you care about.

It’s a privilege to make your own schedule, travel, and take care
of those around you.

And it’s a privilege to be born in an era where you can use the
device you’re reading this on as an all-powerful tool.

You can make money. You can meet your best friends. You can
create content that inspires, entertains, and helps others.
Whether it’s one person, or thousands.

That’s really fucking cool. And we’re lucky to be a part of it.

No matter how big you get, how much money you have, or how many
people want your time and attention…

You’re never too important to appreciate the little things.

​Don’t take special for granted, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0hozzp30cmhzwrkq44al/9qhzhnhpekw35rb9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0hozzp30cmhzwrkq44al
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0hozzp30cmhzwrkq44al
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: This is really, REALLY bad
body:
I’m going to fear monger you today.

Last night I listened to a podcast about the economic and social
state of young men in America.

Long story short, the average guy between 18-30 is down
horrendous.

I used to hear guru’s talk about this and I’d write it off as a
marketing angle.

But when you look at the data, it’s entirely true (and absolutely
fucked).

Here’s some stats for you:

* Over 41% of men ages 25 to 34 make less than $30k per year,
compared to just 25% in 1975 (adjusted for inflation).
* Young men are 4x more likely to commit suicide compared to
women and 3x more likely to overdose on drugs.
* 20% of men (24-35) still live with their parents compared to
just 12% of women.
* 1 out of every 3 men (18-24) hasn’t had sex in the last year.
* Marriage rates have gone down from 70% in 1970 to just 30%
today.
* The average man doesn’t buy their first home until age 38, up
from age 29 in 1981.
* The median income of young men has dropped from $73k in 1975 to
just $40k today (adjusted for inflation).

I’m not much of a numbers guy but this is completely insane.

Young guys are poorer and more isolated than ever.

The days where you could follow the beaten path and live
comfortably are gone.

If you don’t have high value skills that you can use to either
build your own business of get a high paying job, you’re fucked.

Unless you have an ivy league degree, you’re gonna be a doctor,
or you have a clear path to making 6 figures in a 9-5, you’re
left with two options…

* Be poor, unattractive to women, and live a miserable exist
where you’re more likely to kill yourself or overdose on drugs
than you are to become a millionaire.
* Bet on yourself. Start learning skills. Start a business and
fail. Fail again and again. Want to quit. Push through the
turmoil. Find success. Become a millionaire. Buy your dream
car(s). Build an amazing circle of friends. Be desirable to
women. And live the life you’ve always wanted to live.

Which of the two options sounds better to you?

The answer is obvious.

But you gotta get through the hard part in the beginning where
you want to flinch.

And when you consider the alternative, that should make it a bit
easier.

I believe in you.

​Go here to adopt the mindset that saved me from a life of
mediocrity. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h5gdxw2ulhomel577f8/z2hghnh3m4lvnrap/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9sRGpDTy1QN0I2OD9zaT1lai1uVHBCbTJ2WWI0SlJ3
)​

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h5gdxw2ulhomel577f8
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h5gdxw2ulhomel577f8

subject: Why, bo?
body:
The other day, a member in Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h909e98ilhv6rpk55hn/9qhzhnhpe6eqp5h9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) told me that he was having trouble staying motivated.

He asked me, “What's your why?” (meaning the deeper motivating
purpose that drives me to succeed).

Here’s my answer:

When I first started in online business, I just wanted to make
money.

Not having to work a 9-5 sounded cool.

Traveling sounded cool.

Having the freedom to create my own schedule sounded cool.

My “why” was mostly made up of self-serving factors.

I didn’t have to rescue my family from poverty and I didn’t have
a grand vision to save endangered turtles.

I wanted money because it looked fucking sick.

And the idea of clocking in and out for the better half of my
life sounded wayyyy less sick.

Sickening, if you will.

Furthermore, I had this feeling in my gut that you’re likely
familiar with.

It’s the feeling that told me that I couldn’t live a dull life.

I’d try to suppress it sometimes, but it never worked.

I simply knew that if I didn’t take a chance and at least attempt
to gain full agency over my life, I’d be absolutely miserable.

I’d rather end up homeless.

So when I looked at it that way, there was one glaringly obvious
option…

Build the life that I actually wanted to live.

Not for anyone else. Not for a greater purpose. But for me.

I wanted to escape the inevitable future pain of mediocrity.

Is that selfish? Sure.

But had I deluded myself into believing that I needed a stronger
“why,” perhaps I never would’ve started.

I could’ve rationalized, “I’m not motivated and I can’t work
because my life is decent as it is.”

Don’t let Simon Sinek (author of It Starts With Why) fool you.

Your “why” can be ripping an SVJ through the Hollywood hills.

Your “why” can be having the autonomy to wake up at noon every
day.

Your “why” can be club-hopping in Ibiza with a bunch of
ungrateful models.

My point is stop worrying about your fucking “why” and make
money.

Do you want to be miserable?

Do you want to be poor?

Do you want to be an incel?

No?

Okay! Then what the fuck else are you gonna do with your time?
Lol.

Eventually, your motivating factors will naturally evolve.

Once you check off the superficial desires, perhaps your focus
will shift to retiring your parents, setting up future
generations, or saving the Goddamn turtles.

But right now, you probably don’t care much about any of that.

If you’re honest with yourself, you just don’t want to worry
about spending money.

And that’s completely fine.

You don’t need to find some moral justification to stay
motivated.

It’s okay to want something, simply because you want to prove to
yourself that you can get it.

​Ready to get rich now? (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h909e98ilhv6rpk55hn/9qhzhnhpe6eqp5h9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

See you at the top,

Ben

​
​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h909e98ilhv6rpk55hn
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h909e98ilhv6rpk55hn

subject: Indecision will kill you
body:
If there’s one core message from my recent content, it’s this…

Indecision will kill you.

You’ll pass up the open shot and throw the ball to the other
team.

Your foot will hover between both pedals as you slam into the car
that merged in front of you.

The girl who could’ve been your wife will get up and walk away
while you sit there contemplating the perfect line.

Indecision will kill you.

You’ll stand there, idle on the sidelines, watching what could be
pass you by.

Frame by frame, day by day. Missed opportunities stack up. You’re
just waiting for the next one though…right?

At least that’s the story you’re telling yourself.

But even you don’t truly believe that anymore.

You can live your entire life half in, half out, as most do.

Indecision will kill you.

It’s a slow, painful death.

You’ll learn to numb the pain, but with it will go your spark.

Your exuberance, your hopefulness, your natural childlike spirit
will be beaten down to a flicker.

Fake laughs. Forced smiles. An artificial version of you,
stripped of any charm or charisma.

Floating from one day to the next.

Not living, but existing.

Indecision will kill you.

subject: Why you're not motivated
body:
Good morning bo,

I started this beautiful Monday with a 30 minute walk and now I’m
back at my desk.

Important topic today – motivation.

A subscriber left a comment on my recent video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/38umv9xlk7ukh26ndz6irh4kz0onns7/e0hph7h0dngo50i8/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9sRGpDTy1QN0I2OD9zaT1ZaTZ2X1JvNldzWkNkb2dK
) saying he doesn’t feel like he has enough drive to be
successful.

He wants the things that come with success but just can’t get
himself to do the work.

This makes me think of a quote from a super rich guy you may have
heard of named Jim Rohn.

He said, “We generally change ourselves for one of two reasons:
inspiration or desperation.”

This theory generally holds up when you listen to the stories of
successful people.

They were either in a horrible situation and had no choice but to
claw their way out.

Or they created the internal willpower required to take
consistent action.

I’m in boat number two.

I was lucky enough to grow up in an affluent environment in a
first world country with access to abundant resources including
the internet.

To end up in a position of desperation, I would’ve had to make
some seriously poor choices.

And if you’re reading this right now from your phone or laptop in
2024, odds are you’re in a fairly similar spot.

Even if you don’t come from any money, there are guardrails in
place that will likely keep you from ending up as a homeless man
under a bridge.

Because of this, you have the “luxury” of choice.

You can follow the rules and live a semi-decent life.

It won’t be extraordinary and you won’t exceed expectations, but
you’ll survive.

To me, the idea of simply getting by and forgoing my natural
desire to create an extraordinary life sounded like misery.

I knew that if I allowed myself to choose comfort and familiarity
over the slight possibility that everything in my dreams could
come true, I’d hate myself.

That’s where my inspiration came from.

Although I wasn’t truly desperate, it felt like I had no other
choice but to go after everything I wanted.

If it didn’t work out, the guardrails I referenced earlier would
still be there.

So why not attack life with ferocity?

Why not try to build myself into someone I am proud to be?

Why not trade a dull life for one with ups, downs, and everything
in between?

Where I’m entirely in control of my own destiny and I have the
power to make my reality as beautiful as I’d always dreamed.

That was my inspiration and desperation in one.

Inspired because I knew it could all be possible.

Desperate because I knew I wasn’t put on this earth to be another
brick in the wall.

You’re capable of becoming everything you want to be.

If you feel like you’re too comfortable to change, it’s because
you’re not genuinely considering just how uncomfortable life
would be if you let others make your decisions for you.

That’s enough motivation for me.

Reply and let me know if you liked this one.

Happy Monday :)

Ben

​

​

subject: This makes growth effortless
body:
I walked home from the coffee shop with my left shoe untied.

And when I say untied, I mean it.

Laces dragging on the ground. Everyone looking at me like I’m
some sort of neanderthal with no regard for safety.

Did I trip? Of course not.

Imagine tripping due to a little string wrapped around your foot.
Are you 12?

Couldn’t be me.

Although, my formerly white laces are now black from stepping on
them into the pavement.

Anyway, isn't it crazy that 2024 is almost over?

The end of the year is always a good time to reflect.

Odds are, you set some goals about 12 months ago.

Let’s check in on them.

Where are you settling?

What are the things you told yourself that you’d do that you’re
not doing?

What areas of your life require more focus and attention?

Personally, 2024 was a solid year but I feel like I didn’t
squeeze as much juice out of it as I could have.

I’m ready to step into a new reality.

I feel like I have a real opportunity to grow my personal brand
and I’ve been settling a bit too much.

If you’re in a similar spot when it comes to your business or any
other area of life, here’s my advice to you:

You must be the agent of change in your own life.

Nothing happens unless you make it happen.

If you don’t create order, it will be created for you.

With new habits comes an increased level of pressure and
responsibility.

This will make you want to flinch.

That voice in your head will attempt to pull you back down to
where you were previously.

The actualization of your goals and the new version of yourself
that you’re aiming to become relies on your ability to shut out
that voice.

So make it easier on yourself.

Implement small habits that allow you to stay on track with your
goals.

That could be jotting down some action items each night before
bed or making a list of prospects you’re going to reach out to.

It’s small changes like this that create a ripple effect over
time.

Momentum will start to carry you once you get the ball rolling.

But you have to commit.

Set a new standard for yourself and abide by it.

Come this time next year, you’ll be a completely different
person. Likely with a much bigger number in your bank account.

And you’ll be incredibly grateful that you didn’t let your
previous self stop you.

You’re just a few small changes away from a completely different
life.

Get after it,

Ben

PS Use this to kickstart your journey and make 2025 the best year
of your life. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh638lkqivhq3gx8rrao/58hvh7hm45449xf6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

subject: It's simple, but it makes you magnetic
body:
It’s impossible to be unhappy when you’re loved by everyone
around you.

A few months ago, I started working out with a personal trainer
named Earl

From the very first session I could tell we’d get along.

You know when you meet someone and instantly click?

That was Earl (no diddy).

But it’s not just me.

Everyone loves this guy.

At the gym people constantly stop to greet him with warm smiles
and choreographed handshakes.

Last weekend, he had a birthday party with over 100 people in
attendance.

There’s just something magnetic about him.

It sounds like I’m writing a love letter, but there’s an
important lesson here.

Everyone craves connection.

Yet most of the interactions that people have in their day to day
lives are dull.

They’re just going through the motions – no smiles, no small
talk, no genuine compliments.

It creates this energetic lull where life just doesn’t have any
spark to it.

But here’s the good news – one small interaction can break this
cycle.

A simple smile.

A quick compliment.

A lighthearted conversation with a stranger.

When you choose to be a bright spot in someone's day, your life
gets brighter too.

Why?

Because your actions influence your emotions.

When you act like someone who radiates joy and confidence, your
brain begins to believe it – and you become that person.

If you’re low energy, angry, or sad remember:

You have the power to snap out of it right now.

Stop spending too much time alone.

Stop being afraid of real human connection.

Stop replaying negative thoughts.

Instead, focus on making others smile, and that energy will find
its way back to you.

You’ll become the kind of person who’s magnetic, confident, and
happy – like Earl.

And when that happens, life gets a lot brighter.

Be the light,

Ben

P.S. I made a banger Youtube video with my friend Phillip who
turned $1 into millions of dollars. You can check it out here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hqkox97tmhrzm30qqf3/08hwh9hdpgxg27ul/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9sYmgwbzdzR2FyYw==

subject: Here's your answer
body:
Happy Friday,

I just put up a Q&A on my second Instagram (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h90d56xhlhv6rpk55hn/vqh3hrhpqg3xllcg/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuaW5zdGFncmFtLmNvbS9iZW5vbmJ1c2luZXNzLw==
) and will be answering some questions in this email.

Here we go:

“What's the piece of advice for the college kid grinding building
a biz while others coast?”

You will look back at this time period in a few years and be
grateful that you made the decision to start now.

A wake up call is coming on graduation day.

Most of your peers will get slapped in the face with the harsh
reality that their actions over the last 4 years have put them in
a tough spot.

A degree (in most cases) no longer equals security – Building a
valuable skillset and network does.

If you can block out the noise and the FOMO, your life can be
everything you want it to be plus more in the near future.

“How do you know when you should change things up?”

Simple.

Ask yourself “Do my actions align with the reality I want to
create?”

If not, adjust accordingly.

You likely have this pit in your stomach that knows the truth.

As every waking hour goes by it reminds you that you’re wasting
your life.

If you don’t change, that pit won’t go away on its own.

It’ll drain you every single day until you become a dull,
lifeless version of the infinite being with limitless potential
that you once were.

That sounds fucking horrible.

Don’t let that be you.

“How did you network at the beginning of your journey?”

The first element of building an amazing circle of friends who
are all winners, is being on the path to become a winner
yourself.

You need to be building – create better habits, start the
business, audit and remove the broken pieces of your mindset that
are holding you down.

Begin documenting your journey on the internet.

Naturally people who align with you will find you and vice versa.

Hop on calls with those who you want to connect with. Plan a trip
together. Become homies.

Easy as.

“How can I get like you?”

By not trying to be like me or anyone else.

By listening to your internal compass that knows the way.

By following your natural curiosity with a childlike spirit.

By creating your own standards and upholding them.

This is how you become the fullest version, most authentic
version of yourself.

It takes life from black and white to color.

It allows you to figure out who you really are and bring your
uniqueness to the surface.

Hope you enjoyed this one :)

If you're not following my business Instagram account, you can do
so here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h90d56xhlhv6rpk55hn/vqh3hrhpqg3xllcg/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuaW5zdGFncmFtLmNvbS9iZW5vbmJ1c2luZXNzLw==
)​

Will be much more active on there in the near future.

Have a good weekend,

Ben

subject: Do this NOW (Or 2025 will suck)
body:
I’m 40,000 feet in the air, writing this from seat 4A.

Heading home to Cincinnati over the Holidays.

It’ll be my first time back since last Christmas.

This year has absolutely flown by, hasn’t it?

I’m using this last week and a half of the year to prepare for
2025 and go into the new year with momentum.

This is something I didn’t do a great job of going into 2024.

I had a rough idea of what I wanted to accomplish and some goals
written down, but I wasn’t very precise on the key levers that
would make success inevitable.

Because of this, it felt like I was playing catch up for the
first few months of the year.

This reminds me of something one of my high school basketball
coaches used to always say…

“If you’re not 15 minutes early, you’re late.”

It takes time to stretch out, tie your shoes, and get some shots
up before practice.

If you show up “on time” you’ll miss your chance to get ready and
be underprepared.

This is how I’m thinking of this period until January 1st.

It’s the 15 minutes before “game-time” that will dictate whether
or not I go into the new year ready to make it the best one yet.

I’m ready to make more money than ever, explode on social media,
build a bigger team, and simply turn up the dial in all facets of
my life.

So if you want to go into 2025 like a rocket shot out of a cannon
while others kick their feet up till the new year…

Here are some things you should get clear on:

What's the one thing that would make 2025 a success?

This can be an income goal, fitness goal, social media growth,
etc.

Set your standards high and arrow it down to one thing that will
make you feel accomplished.

Be as specific as possible.

How will you measure your progress towards that goal?

If you don’t track it, you don’t improve it.

Create a system where you can continually measure your progress
and make sure you’re staying on par.

This can be as simple as using a google doc or notion sheet.

Again, be specific and write down exactly how you’ll keep track
of growth.

What processes can you put in place that will make the
achievement of your goal inevitable?

These are the big levers.

If you set an income goal, this could look like “send 10 quality
outbound pitches per day.”

You can write down a few things here that have a direct impact on
the achievement of your main goal.

There we have it…

I highly encourage you to not overlook these three questions.

I know it might look corny or basic – I tend to have an aversion
to doing things like this too.

But this simple exercise can be the difference between a
reality-changing 2025, versus yet another year where you feel
like you didn’t make the strides you could’ve.

Be different. Put both feet on the gas. And lap all the dorks
sipping eggnog in pajamas for the next 10 days.

And if you REALLY want to get ahead –go here now (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hp8eq6wu5h29rvzllfn/25h2hoh2qlg8ogi3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) (only if you’re a psycho who’s ready to run through a fucking
wall in order to make this your best year ever).

Cheers,

Ben

subject: Do this NOW (Or 2025 will suck)
body:
I’m 40,000 feet in the air, writing this from seat 4A.

 Heading home to Cincinnati over the Holidays.

 It’ll be my first time back since last Christmas.

 This year has absolutely flown by, hasn’t it?

 I’m using this last week and a half of the year to prepare for 2025 and go into the new year with momentum.

 This is something I didn’t do a great job of going into 2024.

 I had a rough idea of what I wanted to accomplish and some goals written down, but I wasn’t very precise on the key levers that would make success inevitable.

 Because of this, it felt like I was playing catch up for the first few months of the year.

 This reminds me of something one of my high school basketball coaches used to always say…

 “If you’re not 15 minutes early, you’re late.”

 It takes time to stretch out, tie your shoes, and get some shots up before practice.

 If you show up “on time” you’ll miss your chance to get ready and be underprepared.

 This is how I’m thinking of this period until January 1st.

 It’s the 15 minutes before “game-time” that will dictate whether or not I go into the new year ready to make it the best one yet.

 I’m ready to make more money than ever, explode on social media, build a bigger team, and simply turn up the dial in all facets of my life.

 So if you want to go into 2025 like a rocket shot out of a cannon while others kick their feet up till the new year…

 Here are some things you should get clear on:

 What's the one thing that would make 2025 a success? 

 This can be an income goal, fitness goal, social media growth, etc.

 Set your standards high and arrow it down to one thing that will make you feel accomplished.

 Be as specific as possible.

 How will you measure your progress towards that goal? 

 If you don’t track it, you don’t improve it.

 Create a system where you can continually measure your progress and make sure you’re staying on par.

 This can be as simple as using a google doc or notion sheet.

 Again, be specific and write down exactly how you’ll keep track of growth.

 What processes can you put in place that will make the achievement of your goal inevitable? 

 These are the big levers.

 If you set an income goal, this could look like “send 10 quality outbound pitches per day.”

 You can write down a few things here that have a direct impact on the achievement of your main goal.

 There we have it…

 I highly encourage you to not overlook these three questions.

 I know it might look corny or basic – I tend to have an aversion to doing things like this too.

 But this simple exercise can be the difference between a reality-changing 2025, versus yet another year where you feel like you didn’t make the strides you could’ve.

 Be different. Put both feet on the gas. And lap all the dorks sipping eggnog in pajamas for the next 10 days.

 And if you REALLY want to get ahead – go here now (only if you’re a psycho who’s ready to run through a fucking wall in order to make this your best year ever).

 Cheers,

 Ben

 P.S. If you noticed a new font in this email, congrats on being observant. I was re-reading some of my old emails and found the last font a bit hard to read. Do you like this one better?
​

subject: Is goal setting corny?
body:
In yesterday’s email I implored you to set clear goals going into
2025.

There was a time where I thought doing this was a rather silly
act.

This was because when I started my business journey, I was sort
of autistic about goal setting.

Every few months I’d map out new 3, 6, and 12 month goals.

I had clear targets to hit and planned exactly how I’d do so.

After following this protocol for a while, I noticed that things
almost never happened the way I planned.

Although I’d make progress and typically come close to hitting my
goals, I’d get rerouted a dozen times in the process and felt
like an idiot for ever trying to map out the “perfect” route.

So I came to the conclusion that goal setting was corny.

It’s for the Instagram coaches who’ve never built a real
business.

The room temperature IQ neanderthals who get an erection when
talking about their morning routine.

I’m not naive enough to think that things will happen the exact
way I plan them, so I don’t need to set goals.

Or at least that’s what I thought…

Looking back, when I set clear targets I progressed quicker.

Sure the path comes with twists, turns, and hurdles that I
could’ve never anticipated, but that’s not important.

What IS important is the fact that goal setting gives you a
starting point.

You have a target you want to hit.

A method to track your progress.

And daily actions to make it happen.

That’s all that matters.

Obviously unexpected events will occur – you might find an
alternative vehicle that proves to be a better fit.

You’re not a genie with a crystal ball.

But don’t let that stop you from giving yourself that clear
mission and starting point.

Objectively, you will operate better when doing so.

Don’t fool yourself into thinking you’re smarter than other
people because you don’t “need” to set goals.

Accept that your plans will likely change and adapt to future
circumstances.

That’s okay.

Alright?

This might’ve been more of a message to myself than it was for
you, but it’s an important thing to note nonetheless.

Let me know if you liked this one bo :)

- Ben

​
​

subject: is the American dream dead?
body:
I remember being around the age of 12 or 13 when I first started
to conceptualize money.

Many of the houses in the area I grew up in were $1m plus.

At the time I was told that $100k per year is a really good
salary.

After doing some math in my head, it didn’t make sense.

If a nice house costs one million dollars…

And a good salary was $100k…

I’m supposed to work for 10 years and somehow miraculously save
every penny before I can buy a house?

Obviously I was oversimplifying it but this broke my adolescent
brain at the time.

It just didn’t make sense.

Not long after I realized that if I want to live a good life, I
have to get rich.

Not a couple million dollars net worth by 65, rich – But real
rich. Fast.

Millions in my 20’s, tens of millions in my 30’s and so on.

After coming to this realization (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h90g86kblhv6rpk55hn/e0hph7h0d65z9vh8/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_dj1oU1ZXQVRZR1VWWQ==
) about the world, my life changed forever.

I began to see reality through a new lens.

And in this one, I was in control.

​Is the American dream dead? (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h90g86kblhv6rpk55hn/e0hph7h0d65z9vh8/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cueW91dHViZS5jb20vd2F0Y2g_dj1oU1ZXQVRZR1VWWQ==
)​

Ben

subject: How to use "loss aversion" in your favor
body:
Merry Christmas bo.

Hope you’re enjoying the day with your fam.

I bought myself a fancy new camera today.

I was long overdue for an upgrade so I got the Canon R5 with the
15-35mm lens.

All in, it cost me a little over $5k.

But I didn’t buy it because of the quality upgrade (that’s a
bonus).

Personally, I think equipment is somewhat overrated.

If your content is good enough, it will perform if you film on a
potato.

The main reason I upgraded is because it’s a commitment to
myself.

Since I spent the money on a new camera I’ll have more pressure
to put it to good use.

I’m using this concept in psychology called loss aversion to
motivate myself.

Basically it means that people value keeping what they have even
more than they value acquiring things they don’t have.

I spent enough money to where it stings a bit and I don’t want to
feel like I wasted it.

So with this additional motivation, I have a lot of content
coming for you in the new year.

I feel like I left some gas in the tank in this area in 2024.

Sure my audience grew, but I didn’t put in nearly as much effort
as I could’ve.

There was one 3 month streak where I was consistent on Youtube,
posting 3x per week.

Over that time, I went from basically zero to 10k subscribers.

Even then, there was minimal planning or strategy behind my
videos.

I can’t help but wonder what I could do with more intentionality
and consistency.

Time will tell.

Since we’re on this topic – that’s a good way to find new
opportunities that can offer you asymmetric returns.

Audit your efforts right now and see if there’s anything where
you’re getting more out than what you’re putting in.

Maybe there’s a part of your business that comes easy to you and
whenever you focus on it, you make more money.

And maybe it would be wise to double down on that thing.

However I must add a disclaimer – this advice is dangerous in the
wrong hands.

If you’re in the beginning stages of your journey, odds are
nothing is easy right now.

You’re fighting an uphill battle.

Don’t look for the easy way out because there isn’t one.

You have to keep climbing until you break through a lot of the
natural barriers that come with change.

Only once you do that, can you position yourself to go “downhill”
where you have gravity working in your favor.

I know this email has been a bit jumpy, so thanks for sticking
with me here.

I encourage you to do something in these next few days that will
force you to commit.

Risk something that you have to get something you don’t.

You’ll likely end up with more than you could’ve imagined.

Merry Christmas,

Ben

P.S. Go watch this if you haven't already (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hl7p304arh8nlz699cm/p8heh9hzp698r2uq/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9oU1ZXQVRZR1VWWT9zaT16ZlI4QVIzSVFyX21vVUR2
)​

​
​

subject: Business is like hot wheels
body:
Business success is like a battery powered toy car.

Imagine you’re an 8 year old with snot on your face.

For Christmas, you got a miniature brown Bugatti with a bald
action figure sitting in the passenger seat.

You rip it out of the box and put it on the ground.

Excitedly, you click the “on” button and…

Nothing happens.

You turn it off and on again…

Nothing.

And then it clicks inside your little pea brain.

Batteries!

Your Bugatti needs 2 double A batteries.

You run upstairs and say “Mom! Get me some fucking double A
batteries ASAP no rocky!”

To your disappointment, your Mom is hammered.

She caught your Dad cheating on her with your Uncle so she’s
numbing the pain with two bottles of Rosé.

“Dammit! She won’t be able to drive to the store,” you think to
yourself.

Time to take matters into your own hands.

You scour the house for batteries, opening the back of every TV
remote.

None of them fit into your toy car.

You’d ask your Dad for help but he’s upstairs with Uncle Timmy.

So you decide to hop in his Ford F-150.

You can barely see over the steering wheel so you grab a pipe
from the garage as an extension to your foot.

Next thing you know you’re pulling out of the driveway.

Luckily you’ve played a lot of GTA.

By some miracle, you make it to the store, find the batteries,
check out, and make it back home.

Finally you put the batteries in the bottom of the car and you’re
off to the races.

Congrats kid.

Now bo you’re probably thinking...

“Are you going anywhere with this or are you just telling me a
fabricated, alarming story about an unsupervised child with an
alcoholic mother and gay father?”

Here’s how this relates to you and your business success:

Right now, you’re that toy Bugatti.

If you’re a complete beginner, you have to get batteries before
you can start moving.

That means you go down Youtube rabbit holes, read books, watch
courses, and start practicing your skills.

The car won’t start moving yet (you won’t make any money).

But you’re installing the necessary batteries that will allow you
to go fast.

Welcome to the trenches :)

It’s impossible to say how much time you’ll spend here, but I can
promise you that on the other side is everything you’ve ever
wanted.

Once you get through, you’ll hit the gas.

And if you're someone who's already been through the trenches...

Maybe you've been trying to build an agency for a while or you've
been grinding in a sales gig.

All you need now, are the right batteries -- A higher leveraged
opportunity.

Finally, you’ll be rewarded for all of your previously unrewarded
effort.

Just don’t quit before you even get the right batteries
installed.

Let me know if you liked this one,

Ben

​
​

subject: If you're ready to lock in, do this
body:
Happy final Monday of the year, bo.

I’ve been so focused on building momentum going into 2025, that
it feels like it started 2 weeks ago.

Typically I would have plans for New Years Eve, but I’m leaning
towards staying in.

This year I learned an important lesson…

Over the past 12 months, I’ve had a lot of fun.

I’ve traveled a bit, gone out frequently, have met a lot of new
people, and taken on some side quests.

There was a period before that where I was barely doing anything.

Work, gym, eat, sleep. The business was growing, but life felt a
bit dull.

So throughout 2024, I sort of fucked off.

I realized that I could still make solid money without being at
my desk all day.

My income fluctuated from $60K-$140k/mo throughout the year.

I’ve been maintaining – but not growing.

Now I’ve reached a point where I feel the same way I did towards
the end of my “grind phase,” except it’s reversed.

I want to work more.

Sure, I can maintain my current income level with minimal effort,
but what happens if I push?

I want another supercar. I want a penthouse. I want to invest
$50k/mo.

In that order, lol.

This speaks to the seasons in life. I’m glad I turned on “cruise
control” for a while because it reignited my visceral urge to get
richer.

So now, we’re here.

If you’re in the same boat and you want to put all 3 of your feet
on the gas heading into the new year, this video will give you a
blueprint. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh6k4orns9hzn4k933aw/8ghqhohl7menk2bk/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9LZzVOaGx3OU5nZz9zaT1vNUlFM0VfZ29SZjQ2cnI2
)​

I’ve never been more bullish on the opportunities inside of the
online education space.

And I’ll show you how you can get a sliver of this $180 billion
market…

To locking in,

Ben

P.S. This industry will make you a millionaire in 2025 (

subject: The world is yours
body:
It’s a beautiful 75 degree, sunny day in Miami.

And it also happens to be January 1st.

4 years ago, this month was a pivotal one in my online business
career.

I drained my bank account and bought a $5,000 coaching program.

I began journaling every day, describing the new version of
myself that I was becoming in vivid detail.

I got my first few free trial clients for my agency.

Here’s an excerpt from my journal entry on January 15, 2021:

“I am building my business that generates $10,000 per month with
little of my time. I am able to go where I want, buy what I want,
and meet who I want. Reality bends itself to my desires. I am in
the driver’s seat, steering the ship on how my life goes. I am in
full control. Money loves me. I attract more and more of it
daily. I find new ways to make money with ease. I live a life
that has no bounds. My friends look up to me. My parents are
proud of me. I am able to help my brothers. I am the person I
have always wanted to be.”

None of this was true at the time.

But 2 months later I closed my first 3 paying clients at $1k per
month each.

By August, I hit $10k months and dropped out of college.

I moved to Mexico and reached $15k months.

Now as I sit here writing to you 4 years later, my life looks
even better than the way I used to dream of it.

I’ve built a 7 figure agency, grown my personal brand, and
started helping others replicate my success. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghk97o09t7hn34kzxxc8/08hwh9hdpl5qnrtl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

I’m telling you all to show you that I’m not special.

I was once lost, undisciplined, and unfocused.

But a series of decisions led me here.

I began taking life seriously and I understood that nothing would
change unless I made it change.

New year's resolutions are corny and perhaps this is just some
arbitrary date on the calendar…

But your words are powerful.

Today, you can decide that you’ll no longer accept mediocrity for
yourself.

You can begin keeping the promises you’ve made internally.

You can take full control of your life and commit to your goals.

And I promise you…

In a few months you’ll start to see your dreams come to fruition.

In a year you won’t recognize the old you.

In a few years, your life will be better than you ever imagined.

And you’ll be glad you started today.

The world is yours… if you’re ready for it. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghk97o09t7hn34kzxxc8/08hwh9hdpl5qnrtl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Happy New Year,

Ben

​
​

body:
Before I get into today's email, let me show you some recent W’s
from Artisan Lab:

​Briar quit his 9-5 and went from 0-$20k/month in 6 months. (

)​

​Kabrin scaled to $35k/month in 5 months building simple VSL
funnels for clients. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh39z9gnh2hd79mn66s7/z2hghnh3mm6900fp/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS91RlFLNzF1UzlYSQ==
)​

​Dean went from being a burnt out closer to making $27k/mo in 3
months. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh39z9gnh2hd79mn66s7/p8heh9hzpp6k8riq/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS9IbVhNbUhLbzgzQQ==
)​

If you’re in the info-product agency space or thinking about
getting into it, the student interviews above should be
incredibly valuable for you.

Alrighty.

I hope you’ve taken time to give yourself clarity on your goals
and you’re ready to crush 2025.

If so, congrats.

You’ve completed phase one.

Just as important is phase two, which you’ll be entering soon.

As you execute on your plan over the following weeks and months,
you will inevitably hit a wall.

One day you will wake up and think to yourself, “Fuck this. I’ve
been putting in all of this work and I’ve gotten nothing in
return.”

Maybe that voice will temporarily win and you’ll go back to your
old ways for a few days.

That’s normal.

But what you do at this point will determine how the rest of the
year goes for you.

You can right the ship and get back on track.

Or you can continue to spiral and discard the goals you set.

This is a decision you’ll likely have to make within the next
month or so.

Once the motivation and excitement fades a bit, resistance will
rear its head.

When it does, remember this:

You set those goals for a reason.

There is a version of you who is living the exact life you
outlined.

You’re driving your dream car, you’ve become friends with
incredible people, you live where you want, etc.

You’re proud of the person you’ve become.

That doesn’t happen overnight and it doesn’t come easily.

When you feel resistance, you’re being tested.

Is bo actually committed this time?

Can your spirit be deflated?

Are you worthy of having the things you want?

If you pass these tests consistently, eventually you will become
that 2.0 version of yourself.

Because you are actively creating data to prove this.

You’ve held yourself accountable, raised your standards, and thus
become a person who has reached a higher level of consciousness.

And then, you attract everything you’ve ever wanted.

Not trying to get too spiritual on you here, but this is the
basic premise of the law of attraction.

Or I guess you could just throw crystals under your pillow and
hope for the best.

Either way, good things are coming if you remain steadfast in
your commitment to yourself.

Let’s get rich,

Ben

subject: The 3 phases to reach $100k/month
body:
Okay, I have a less philosophical email for you today…

You could be the most profound thinker of the 21st century.

But no one will listen if you’re poor.

Everything you say will have an asterisk next to it.

*Take any advice or opinion with a grain of salt. This person
lacks the basic competence necessary to provide for themself and
their family.*

“OMG Ben, that's so insensitive”– shut up.

Let’s talk about how to get fucking rich… Specifically working
with people who sell info.

I’m gonna break this down into phases for you (if you already
have a client or two you can skip to phase 3):

Phase 1: Exit the clueless monkey

You’re lost.

You hear about all these people making money online and the
different ways of doing so.

You don’t know what’s legit and what isn’t.

You feel like a monkey who was taken out of the wild and placed
at a dinner party.

Here’s how to change this – Immerse yourself into the online
business space.

Tailor your social media feed to show you less baddies and more
money.

Build a swipe file of funnels, email copy, VSLs, etc.

Phase 2: Enter the arena

Once you understand the basics, you need to start getting real
practice.

Write samples. Ask Chat GPT or Claude AI to grade them.

Keep improving and start doing outreach.

Don’t listen to the voice that tells you that you’re not ready.

Send as many high quality outreach messages as you can daily (I
will teach you how to do this). (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghk966voc7hn34kzxxc8/8ghqhohl78q33gtk/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Don’t stop until you get a client.

Phase 3: Squeeze the lemon

Congrats. You got a client or two.

What you do now, can change your life.

Imagine a billionaire hires you as a personal assistant.

He tasks you with getting his coffee in the morning and that’s
it.

So, you spend the rest of your day finding ways to make his life
easier.

He sees your hard work and makes you his next of kin.

This is *basically* what can happen if you maximize the
opportunity with one solid client.

Go above and beyond to improve any area of their business, even
if you’re not directly responsible for it.

This can snowball into a 5 figure rev share from that client.
Plus a case study you can use to get more clients.

There’s your 0-$100k/month blueprint.

I know it sounds simple.

The only part that’s more complicated is the identification of
bottlenecks.

Once you get a client, you have to be able to correctly assess
the levers which need to be pulled to scale them.

And before that, you have to determine if they’re even in a
position that will allow them to scale.

In Artisan Lab, you’ll learn how to do all of this.

You’ll know who to reach out to, what a high quality pitch looks
like, what to offer, how to close the deal, and how to make your
clients a boatload of money.

​Go here now and apply to join the winning team :) (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghk966voc7hn34kzxxc8/8ghqhohl78q33gtk/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk soon,

Ben

​
​

subject: A new way to view risk
body:
Before I get into it, I just made a new video that’ll show you
how to make $20k/mo partnering with online coaches.

​You can watch it here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hp86n2dt5h29ozdlltn/e0hph7h0dxk0kwu8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

It’s an incredible day here in Miami.

Did you know I live on the 80-somethingth floor?

I can basically see the end of the Earth from up here. It’s
definitely flat.

I’m on my balcony watching the boats go by.

The water is this beautiful blueish-greenish color and the sun is
beaming, so it looks even more vibrant than usual.

Switching gears to a much more somber note – I truly think some
people are just NGMI (not gonna make it).

It’s not that they can’t “make it” but rather that they won’t
allow themselves.

They’re too comfortable in their current self-image.

Things aren’t bad enough because their perception of risk to
reward is flawed.

Going after what they want seems like this big leap of faith
where if they fail their life is over.

Obviously that’s almost never the case. If you put your all into
anything, you will naturally unlock an abundance of additional
opportunities.

But they don’t understand this.

So even though they may be unhappy, the desire to change doesn’t
outweigh the perceived pain of it.

From the outside looking in it’s easy to see that the “pain”
really isn’t that bad.

Sure, upgrading any area of your life comes with challenges –
whether it’s financial pursuit or a different quest.

And sure, there may be some level of risk involved but when you
truly weigh your options, you see reality clearly.

You can stay the same forever, merely flirting with the idea of
success.

Or you can think, “Why not? I’ll put my all into this endeavor
and worst case scenario I end up back where I was beforehand.”

Does that sound incredibly risky?

To me, it doesn’t.

And that’s why I think I was able to muster up the courage to
attack my dream life despite the fact that I never had it that
bad.

As Socrates once said, “fuck it, we ball.”

So as I sit here, writing this from my castle in the sky, I’m
grateful that I’ve been able to view risk through this lens.

It will work out for you too.

But you actually have to allow yourself to try.

I’ll leave you with a tweet I wrote over two years ago – “You're
hesitant to hit the gas because you know it raises the bar. The
further you get from the bottom the harder it’ll be to go back.
You know what you're capable of but you're afraid to hold
yourself to that standard. Then it's no longer an option to show
up every day.”

Go after everything you desire.

​It will be worth it, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hp86n2dt5h29ozdlltn/e0hph7h0dxk0kwu8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hp86n2dt5h29ozdlltn

subject: A new way to view risk
body:
Before I get into it, I just made a new video that’ll show you how to make $20k/mo partnering with online coaches.

 ​ You can watch it here. ​

 It’s an incredible day here in Miami.

 Did you know I live on the 80-somethingth floor?

 I can basically see the end of the Earth from up here. It’s definitely flat.

 I’m on my balcony watching the boats go by.

 The water is this beautiful blueish-greenish color and the sun is beaming, so it looks even more vibrant than usual.

 Switching gears to a much more somber note – I truly think some people are just NGMI (not gonna make it).

 It’s not that they can’t “make it” but rather that they won’t allow themselves.

 They’re too comfortable in their current self-image.

 Things aren’t bad enough because their perception of risk to reward is flawed.

 Going after what they want seems like this big leap of faith where if they fail their life is over.

 Obviously that’s almost never the case. If you put your all into anything, you will naturally unlock an abundance of additional opportunities.

 But they don’t understand this.

 So even though they may be unhappy, the desire to change doesn’t outweigh the perceived pain of it.

 From the outside looking in it’s easy to see that the “pain” really isn’t that bad.

 Sure, upgrading any area of your life comes with challenges – whether it’s financial pursuit or a different quest.

 And sure, there may be some level of risk involved but when you truly weigh your options, you see reality clearly.

 You can stay the same forever, merely flirting with the idea of success.

 Or you can think, “Why not? I’ll put my all into this endeavor and worst case scenario I end up back where I was beforehand.”

 Does that sound incredibly risky?

 To me, it doesn’t.

 And that’s why I think I was able to muster up the courage to attack my dream life despite the fact that I never had it that bad.

 As Socrates once said, “fuck it, we ball.”

 So as I sit here, writing this from my castle in the sky, I’m grateful that I’ve been able to view risk through this lens.

 It will work out for you too.

 But you actually have to allow yourself to try.

 I’ll leave you with a tweet I wrote over two years ago – “You're hesitant to hit the gas because you know it raises the bar. The further you get from the bottom the harder it’ll be to go back. You know what you're capable of but you're afraid to hold yourself to that standard. Then it's no longer an option to show up every day.”

 Go after everything you desire.

 ​ It will be worth it, ​

 Ben

subject: AI is going to take your job
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}. This is important.

 There’s a popular meme amongst NBA fans.

 When a player can’t compete in the league, they often go play in China or another country.

 “Get ready to learn Chinese buddy” has become a popular phrase because of this.

 When a player is struggling, you’ll find that sentence in the comment section.

 There is a similar phenomenon going on in the copywriting world…

 AI is going to take your job.

 I’m 100% serious. This is not a drill.

 If you’ve been neglecting it, I’d highly advise you to stop.

 You will be demoted to putting fries in the bag for a living quite soon.

 Get ready to learn minimum wage buddy.

 Up until recently, this was me.

 Although I’ve been using AI for some time, I felt like I was just scratching the surface.

 I’d have it write or critique email copy, VSL’s, content ideas and more.

 It was a useful tool, but I wasn’t amazed.

 And when I’d try to have it write copy for me, it’d do so a 4 or 5 out of 10.

 It wasn’t horrible, but it read like a non-native english speaker who just discovered a dictionary.

 Bland and robotic. When I’d try to get it to spice things up it’d sound too try-hardy.

 Nonetheless, it was somewhat useful.

 That was until I got better at prompting and training it.

 This took it from a 4/10 to an 8/10.

 And I STILL think I’m just scratching the surface.

 When you input enough data with the right prompt(s) it’s capable of writing a sufficient email that’s indistinguishable from human copy.

 I’d be willing to bet it’s better than 99% of beginner to intermediate level writers.

 Here’s what this means for you:

 It’s a tool that you NEED to utilize.

 Go down the rabbit hole and become familiar with popular AI softwares (not just Chat GPT).

 Once you do so, it will make you better, more efficient, and nearly do your job for you.

 It’s not something to fear, IF you learn it.

 If you don’t… well Nǐ hǎo, my friend.

 Extra large fries please.

 If you want to see how I’m using it inside of my business…

 ​ I’ll be sharing everything I learn about AI in the coming months here. ​

 Don’t get left behind,

 Ben

subject: One DM changed my entire business model
body:
Let me take you back to November, 2021.

I’m living in Merida, Mexico after spending the last couple
months in Playa Del Carmen and Tulum.

My days are simple.

Wake up at 8am, bike 15 minutes to the gym, and try to get agency
clients.

It’s working… sort of.

I hit a new high score, of $16,037 profit for the month.

The only issue?

It took SIXTEEN clients to get here.

Most of them are local basketball trainers paying me $1k/month
for lead gen and automation.

Many of which have broken sales processes, so getting results is
difficult.

They’re constantly churning, I’m constantly replacing, and it's
leaving me constantly stressed.

Then, one small pivot changed everything.

I’m scrolling through Instagram and decide to pitch a slightly
different type of prospect.

Instead of selling in person training, he’s selling online
training.

He has a big personal brand and I actually used to watch his
content.

His business partner replied the next day.

3 months later, he became a paying client.

5 months after that, I’m still making $16k/month.

But this time, only with 6 clients.

All of which are selling online coaching, not just basketball
anymore.

A Youtube coach, Amazon FBA offer, and sales trainer.

Your typical make money online gurus.

Fast forward one year…

I hit my first $100k month with just 7 clients.

The difference maker?

I applied my existing skill set to higher leverage opportunities.

While I was running the basketball trainer agency, I got really
good at one thing:

Copywriting.

subject: RE: your resolutions
body:
This is the breaking point.

 Remember the goals you set 8 days ago?

 It’s this time of the year where most people revert back to old habits.

 The motivation and excitement fades.

 And the excuses are creeping back in.

 This is the emotional cycle of change at work.

 Stage 1: Pure excitement "This is it. I’m finally committed."

 Stage 2: Reality check "Damn, this is actually a lot of work..."

 Stage 3: The dip "Maybe I'm not ready for this..."

 Stage 4: The breakthrough "Wait... I think I'm figuring this out..."

 Stage 5: Momentum "Can't believe I almost quit."

 Right now, you're probably somewhere between stages 2 and 3.

 The initial excitement has worn off.

 The path feels harder than expected.

 Your old comfort zone is looking enticing.

 This is exactly where most people quit.

 They think because it got hard, something's wrong.

 But difficulty isn't a sign to stop.

 It's a sign you're finally playing the game.

 Welcome, my friend.

 What you do right now will make or break the rest of your year.

 You can decide to step into the 2.0 version of yourself and actualize the goals you’ve set…

 Or you can let the natural desire to resist change, win.

 Just remember this:

 Goals aren't achieved through motivation.

 They're achieved through showing up when motivation dies.

 Through pushing forward when everyone else quits.

 Through accepting that it's supposed to feel hard.

 Show up for yourself today.

 Lambos, champagne, and models feeding you grapes on a Yacht in the South France await.

 But you have to push through this part.

 By the end of the year, you’ll be unrecognizable.

 ​ Ready to make this the best year of your life? I’ll help you here. ​

 To overcoming resistance,

 Ben

 P.S. AI wrote 80% of this email. In the future I’ll keep it 100% real me, but I just wanted to show you what AI is capable of when you feed it the correct prompts. More on this in here :) ​

 ​
​

subject: Stop resisting your dream life
body:
The secret is that you already know the secret.

You’re looking for solutions to problems that you have the key to
unlock.

The anxiety ridden cloud in the back of your mind can be gone in
an instant.

But you keep searching.

“Maybe if I move across the country.”

“Maybe if I watch another Youtube video.”

“Maybe if I try a different business model.”

You’ll do anything to avoid taking the obvious action.

In Steven Pressfield’s book, The War Of Art, he calls this
“resistance.”

It’s the internal force stopping you from pursuing creative
endeavors and personal growth.

Most succumb to it and live dull lives void of any self
expression.

Every day, you have the option to overcome this.

Only once you start acting despite this resistance, will it lose
power over you.

Although it’ll never disappear entirely, you’ll learn that it’s
okay to not know exactly how things will work out.

You never will.

This morning, someone commented on my recent Youtube video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmhn5d480h6h8lo4v00bg/3ohphkh789d4mlir/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS8tTWFxX3ppUVNPUQ==
) asking, “Can I do this as a complete beginner?”

Here’s my answer:

No… at least, not with that mindset.

No one will ever grant you permission to begin going after what
you want in life.

You will never feel ready, especially if you think that some
external opinion or event will make you ready.

I am not the guard at the gate of your desires holding a magic
wand.

Neither is anyone else.

You hold the wand.

You are making the conscious decision to either let your fear
control you or accept that it’ll never go away.

You decide when you are going to overcome resistance.

Win that battle. Your dream life awaits.

Ben

P.S. I just created what’s likely the most informative Youtube
video I’ve ever posted.

It’ll show you step by step how to land a great client that you
can actually get results for.

Then how to scale with them and leverage that case study to get
more clients and scale past $20k/month.

And in the process, you’ll beat the resistance that’s holding you
back.

​Go here to watch the video now. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmhn5d480h6h8lo4v00bg/3ohphkh789d4mlir/aHR0cHM6Ly95b3V0dS5iZS8tTWFxX3ppUVNPUQ==
)​

​
​

subject: The plague that no one is talking about
body:
There’s a plague happening right now.

It’s incredibly common but people rarely talk about it online.

I’ve gotten it, as well as my friends, and nearly every
successful entrepreneur I know.

And you’re bound to get it too, if you haven’t already.

But when you scroll through social media, you’d think everyones
immune…

It’s Monday morning.

Your favorite guru is up before the sun.

He just went through his 7 step morning routine.

Now he’s sitting at his desk making moves that’ll result in
generational wealth.

Or at least, that’s what he wants you to think.

Unseen is the plague – the constant battle against complacency.

It affects some more than others, but anyone who tells you
they’ve never experienced it is smoking crack.

And it’s not exclusive to those who are already successful.

Before I made any money online, there was a period where I just
couldn’t get myself to do the work.

I’d sit there at my computer, knowing that all I needed to do was
send outbound messages.

My finger would hover over the keyboard for a bit and next thing
you know I’m watching Derrick Rose basketball highlights from
2010.

Objectively, I was nowhere near the point where I should be
complacent.

But somehow, complacency would win.

Though I eventually beat it, it never went away entirely.

I’d feel the constant battle against this plague at every level
of income I reached.

And last year I reached a point where my life was pretty damn
good.

I bought my dream car. $100k months were easy. My lifestyle was
incredibly fun.

And complacency reared its ugly head again.

For a while, it won.

Until one day I woke up and thought to myself…

“Brother, you’re putting in a fraction of the effort you could
be, and things are still working. What would happen if you go all
in?”

Perhaps this sounds familiar.

Whether you’re just starting out, or you’ve gotten comfortable at
your current level of income.

I’ll offer you some advice a mentor of mine gave me recently…

If life’s already good at this level, imagine how much better it
is at levels above this.

We’re playing a never ending game here.

The higher you go, the better life gets.

Not because you can buy another supercar, move to a better place,
and take care of those around you (although that’s a nice plus).

But because you’re actualizing the potential you know you have
inside of you.

With each level you progress, you unlock an upgraded version of
yourself.

And after all, what else is there to do?

​Resist the plague and life will keep getting better. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h2kve5qtqhpz49033hr/reh8hoh0pqrw5xb2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

To overcoming complacency,

Ben

​
​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h2kve5qtqhpz49033hr
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h2kve5qtqhpz49033hr
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: The Tik Tok Ban
body:
Tik Tok is NOT getting banned.

Although I can’t make a logical argument to support that claim,
I’ve been through enough breakups and make-ups to know this is a
smokescreen.

You know when your girlfriend says “Ok, this is it I’m actually
done this time!”

And then she “forgets” her bag at your place and has to come get
it the next day…

What happens?

Exactly.

This is one of those.

At least I think.

If it does get banned, it’ll be interesting to see what happens
next.

More traffic to Instagram reels?

YT shorts?

A new platform?

Who knows. But honestly I think the Chinese algorithm is better
than all of them.

It just knows me so well.

My fyp consists of Johnny Walker, NBA highlights, and random
comedy I didn’t know I was even interested in beforehand.

This whole situation is like the normie super bowl.

“Woohoo course seller! Now you have to go get a real job like the
rest of us!!”

Little do they know… If the ban strikes, we will stand here,
unfazed.

Ready to pounce on whatever opportunity this creates.

Plus many personal brands have built an email list, Instagram,
and Youtube. So one platform getting shut down isn’t the end of
the world.

This reminds me of the common skepticism that unaware people have
when you tell them you’re starting a business.

They’ll say some shit like, “Well what happens when that gets too
saturated! What if AI takes your job? Can’t a business owner just
do that on their own?”

Lol.

Yes, unforeseen events can occur.

Yes, there will be times where you are forced to adapt.

Yes, AI is advancing at a rapid rate.

Good thing you’re a business owner who’s built a plethora of
skills, a network, and developed a mental fortitude that allows
you to thrive in any environment.

Hold that L skeptic.

Fries. Bag. Now. Extra large coke. Keep the change. You filthy
animal.

I am an infinite being with limitless potential. My unmatched
perspicacity coupled with sheer indefatigability makes me a
feared opponent in any realm of human endeavour.

Damn that really is a bar.

Anyway this email has gone off the rails a bit but I assure you:

No matter what happens with Tik Tok, AI, and any other unforeseen
events…

If you focus on mastering your craft, innovating, and creating
leverage – there will always be endless opportunities at your
fingertips.

​Your success is inevitable. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghk5902ka7hn34kzxxc8/e0hph7h0z08993f8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

P.S. Reply and lmk if you liked this one

​
​

body:
It’s an early one today.

I’m starting this at 8:17am from my phone, sitting outside of
Starbucks.

They’re playing “Nice N Easy” by Frank Sinatra.

It’s 60 degrees and sunny-ish, which is cold for Miami but it
feels good.

I took the scenic route here - a 25 minute walk along the water,
circle around and walk back towards my apartment to get to the
coffee shop.

They didn’t put the lid on all the way but luckily I spotted it
before dumping the cup on myself shirt.

You know, most copywriters will tell you that the way I’m writing
right now is flawed.

1 topic per email.

Don’t get sidetracked.

Don’t use more than 14 words per sentence.

Blah blah blah.

Rules like that are made for people who aren’t good enough to
break them.

This applies to any realm of human endeavor (lol).

If you lean in to your authentic edge — and you’re good, you can
do most things “wrong” and still win.

Everyone advises you to follow some content system…

You do the opposite. It works. They copy you.

The Golden State Warriors shoot too many threes. They win four
NBA championships. Now everyone’s chucking threes.

See my point?

Lean into your own unique edge.

This is not school. You won’t get expelled for carving your own
path.

Walk through life with that spark in your eye that only ignites
when you’re authentically you.

Most never get to access it past childhood.

And sure, there are times where the common system is best to
follow.

Remain aware of the norm and let it serve as a starting point,
not an unbreakable rule book.

Got it?

Good.

When you’re authentically you, you leave an indelible mark on
everything around you.

And your success is undeniably, inevitably, certain.

Break more rules,

Ben

subject: How I landed a 9 figure client
body:
A client of mine ran his first webinar last night.

 He’s a Miami resident, so my partner and I pulled up to his studio to help him get set up.

 It was my first time meeting him in person and let me tell you – this guy is a savage.

 For the sake of the email let’s call him Tony.

 Tony’s made 9 figures in Real Estate and recently hopped on social media, sharing his story.

 His audience has grown to the hundreds of thousands fast.

 He’s got 4 decades of experience in RE. Billions of dollars in transactions.

 When someone is this successful for this long, obviously there’s a lot to be learned.

 My first observation was how energetic he is.

 Although he's in his 60’s, he’s sharp as a tac.

 The guy goes through a pack of Neurogum a day (lol) and is always on the move.

 He was telling me about this new office they’re moving into…

 Then how he’s shooting content 3 days a week…

 Then about the new properties he’s developing.

 He just doesn’t stop.

 Working like this definitely keeps him young.

 I pitched Tony about 6 months ago and we started working together.

 He told me “I went with you because I liked your confidence. It was almost arrogance but that’s what you need in a team. I didn’t want someone who was timid.”

 Since then we’ve scaled from zero to multiple six figure months with him.

 As I’ve met more older, wealthy people over the past couple years, I’m always astounded by how normal they are.

 I used to think deca-millionaires and centimillionaires must be so unrelatable and serious.

 But as we sat at this burger restaurant after the webby, Tony was cracking jokes and telling stories.

 He’s a normal guy – just with decades of hard work and calculated decisions under his belt.

 And that's the thing about success...

 The people who achieve it aren't superhuman.

 They're just normal people who make different decisions consistently.

 Tony's not successful because he's special.

 He's successful because he shows up with energy every day, takes massive action, and makes calculated moves.

 But here's what really struck me...

 At 60+ years old, he's still pushing. Still learning. Still adapting.

 While most people his age are slowing down, he's speeding up.

 This is what separates the elite from everyone else.

 Want to see exactly how I landed Tony as a client and scaled him to multiple six figures per month?

 ​ Get access to the full breakdown inside of here. ​

 To calculated confidence,

 Ben

 P.S. Using the exact same pitch that landed Tony, my students are now closing their dream clients every week. You can be next. ​

 ​

subject: I'm buying a Penthouse
body:
Hello and happy Friday, bo.

Good news…

I got my business Instagram account (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9oxekralhv69k855sn/z2hghnh3zwm90ncp/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuaW5zdGFncmFtLmNvbS9iZW55amV0ei8=
) back.

If you’re not following yet, you should – the movement has
commenced and I want you to be a part of it.

Yesterday, I was browsing condos for rent in Miami.

My current place is nice, the view is incredible, and it’s in a
great location.

But I want to hear echoes.

High ceilings. Wrap around floor to ceiling windows. And more
space than I know what to do with.

During my search, I found this penthouse for $19k/mo.

It’s 2,500 square feet, marble floors, huge living area, big
balcony etc.

Basically everything I want.

To move there, I’d pay at least $10k to break my current ($5k/mo)
lease.

Then another $30k+ furnishing the new place.

And then obviously my rent would quadruple.

It’s not that I couldn’t do it, but it would sting.

And that pissed me off.

There’s something I want.

And I can’t get it.

Because it’s too… expensive?

My fingers hurt just typing the word expensi– I can’t do it
again.

Am I a child?

Should I start asking permission to go to the bathroom too?

This lit a fire under me.

My lease is up in July and by then, I want to be in a position
where I can spend $15k+ on rent without batting an eye.

If I can’t, I’ve dishonored my entire bloodline.

People often tell you to find a strong “why” – some altruistic
motive that drives you.

And while I’m motivated by actualizing my potential and being
able to take care of the people around me, sometimes that’s not
enough.

My family isn’t in poverty.

Mom’s already retired and my Dad has more money in cars than most
do in savings.

I don’t need to rescue anyone.

So sometimes, I’ll lean on superficial things as a source of
motivation.

I’ll picture myself hopping out of a new supercar and walking
into my penthouse.

And guess what?

In case no one’s ever told you this, allow me — it’s okay to want
what you want.

If you’re not motivated, maybe you’re just not being honest with
yourself.

You listened to dorks online tell you that you can’t want the
flashy lifestyle.

Now you’re mad at your parents for raising you in a good home
because you don’t have a strong enough “why.”

Be real with yourself. If you want to make money so you can
hangout with baddies on the beach all day, then work really hard
so you can do exactly that. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9oxekralhv69k855sn/p8heh9hzexpk86hq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Sure, at some point you’ll probably need a deeper reason to keep
pushing.

But that’s not a worry right now.

​Get to the bag. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9oxekralhv69k855sn/p8heh9hzexpk86hq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) You’ll find your purpose along the way.

I’ll see you in the Penthouse,

Ben

​
​

) | Update your profile (
