subject: The Kobe and Shaq of webinars
body:
Good morning, bo.

It’s a sunny one today.

I’m out on the balcony squinting at my screen.

I was talking to Chat GPT before bed last night and he told me
something crazy.

Did you know the average 24 year old in America makes $40,768 a
year?

This made me realize how the info-product world has warped my
perception of money.

My biggest client wins in this space have come through live
webinars.

You get as many people as possible on a stream, go through a
calculated, 45 min presentation, and pitch.

They’ve been money printers.

Imagine you’re watching the stripe dashboard as your client
pitches.

Sales start rolling in…

Refresh and you’re at $20k…

Three minutes later you’re at $35k…

Then $53k…

And 20 minutes later you just made six figures in about an hour.

It’s insane.

Throughout the majority of 2023, I had one client who was the
Shaq to my Kobe.

For nearly a 10 month span, we were printing $50k+ on each weekly
webinar.

My client would drive a bunch of sign ups through short form
content.

I had the backend dialed in with email, SMS, and a bunch of
automations.

And like clockwork, we'd clear our age group’s yearly salary
every Thursday night."

But it didn’t stop there…

After selling a mid-ticket offer on the webby, my next job was to
get purchasers on calls for the high ticket offer.

That made up the other half of our revenue and we scaled this
model past $500k/month.

It was electric.

This worked so well for a few reasons:

First, my client was a wizard at content and pulling in
consistent views.

That said, most people struggle to convert viewers from short
form content.

That’s why the webinar played such a crucial role.

No one's gonna spend a meaningful amount of money after watching
a single minute long video.

But they will sign up for a “free live class” if you get them
curious.

Every piece of content was like an ad (that we didn’t have to pay
for).

subject: bo, meet Phillip
body:
If I could give you a phrase to live by it’d be:

“Eh, fuck it.”

I have a friend named Phillip.

I originally met him because he stalked me, sent me a dollar on
Venmo, and I sent him $1,000 back.

He was a stranger at the time.

Fast forward a couple years and he lives a dozen floors below me
in Miami.

For the past year or so, he’s been closing and managing the sales
team for a former client of mine.

He’s made great money doing it and has helped the business scale.

But he ran into an issue…

Over half of his income came from him personally closing deals.

Meaning if he wanted to continue making the same amount of money,
he had to be on Zoom for the majority of each day.

Nearly anyone would get exhausted after spending the better half
of the past year on calls.

So, he decided to take a step back.

His goal?

Get off sales calls and acquire new clients as a marketer/ops
manager – not a closer.

That meant he’d take a pay cut.

And if he wanted to even cover living expenses for the next month
he’d have to go get clients.

But as Plato said, “Eh, fuck it.”

Or maybe it was “Necessity is the mother of invention.”

Regardless, Phillip's info-product agency was born and here’s
what happened next:

​
If you’re looking for an excuse to bet on yourself, now is the
time.

You’ll learn everything from outreach, to fulfillment, to scaling

This is the cheapest it’ll ever be.

)​

Alternatively, if you’re ready to go and want to skip the whole

I’ll personally reply and get you onboarded ASAP.

On Monday, the price goes up.

Don’t hesitate,

Ben

subject: Don't buy courses
body:
You don’t need to invest in coaching.

This isn't a very smart thing for me to say the day that I
increase the price of Artisan Lab.

But it’s true.

If you’re a winner, you’re gonna win with or without my help.

If you’re not a winner, no mentor will save you.

Hormozi could dedicate the rest of his life to getting you rich
and you’d find a way to fuck it up.

So, this email is for you if you just know you’re going to win.

I don’t know how else to describe that feeling.

It’s a hint of delusion coupled with enough rationality to make
it work.

You know it won’t be easy.

But you also know you’re smart enough to figure it out.

And at the end of the day, you operate from a position of “fuck
it, we ball,” knowing that no matter what happens, you’ll be
alright.

Sound familiar?

Alright, I’m talking to you, bo.

You’re just crazy enough to keep going and just smart enough to
make it work.

Your success is inevitable but there are two routes you can take:

1. The slow lane

Try to figure everything out on your own.

Spend hours combing through YouTube.

Feel lost, almost quit, but finally begin to figure it out after
a year or two.

This works, but it’s more difficult. Plus you’ll be in the far
right lane with all the civics and minivans.

2. The fast lane

This is where you find the shortcuts.

Where one piece of advice can save you six months of uncertainty.

And one connection can lead to a world of opportunity.

You have a clear path to follow and mentors who’ve been where you
aim to go.

Your investment serves as a contract with yourself – you’re fully
committed this time.

This lane is for the Porsches, Lambos, and Ferraris.

No bullshit. No filler. Just a direct path to results.

My students are closing 5-figure clients within weeks, not years.

They're scaling to $30k, $40k, and $50k months while others are
still watching YouTube videos.

But here's the thing…

Tonight, at midnight the price increases.

You're going to win either way.

But why take the scenic route when you could be in the fast lane?

​Lock in the current price before midnight tonight. (

subject: The most powerful psychological force
body:
When I first got into online business, I got a role as an
appointment setter.

2 days later I realized what that entailed, so I quit.

But during that 48 hour excursion, I made one core memory.

On the phone with the sales manager, I told him my goal was to
get to $10k/mo.

He said, “just wait until your first $10k day.”

That was an amount of money I couldn’t even conceptualize.

At the time, I thought a $10k day was impossible.

But I was wrong.

It wasn’t about luck or talent—it was about following the right
path.

That’s exactly why I created Artisan Lab: to show others how to
get there faster.

And the recent price increase proved something powerful…

Urgency works, even for people who knew they already wanted in.

I was surprised how many people were on the fence, waiting for an
excuse to pull the trigger.

Obviously the extra $800 is irrelevant to someone who is serious…

They’ll make 1000x that if they’re committed to doing what we
teach inside.

So, the right student is going to buy either way.

But even so, urgency nudges buyers off the fence faster than any
other psychological force.

It’s that extra push that takes them from “thinking about it” to
“Ok, let’s do it”.

Furthermore, the value must exponentially exceed the price.

Artisan Lab was already cheap compared to the value inside and
results students are getting.

I’ve now added full sales management and paid ads courses.

These alone could be sold for thousands of dollars.

But that's not the point.

The point is that what I'm teaching works.

It's responsible for my $10k+ days (and $100k days for clients).

It's responsible for Michael (15 years old) making more than his
teachers.

It's responsible for Briar going from $3k/mo to over $30k/mo.

And for Phillip closing three clients in two weeks.

All of whom had less material and resources when they joined
compared to what we’ve just added.

They simply committed, implemented, and won.

Could you get these results on your own?

Absolutely.

But why take the scenic route when the highway is right there?

Artisan Lab is now at its new price point, but here's the truth -
it's still underpriced for what's inside.

And it's definitely underpriced for what it'll help you build.

)​

Your first $10k day awaits,

Ben

P.S. Even at the new price, it's a fraction of what one client
could pay you.

subject: Underwhelming advice from a $500M man
body:
I’ve been reading How To Get Rich by Felix Dennis.

He was a goofy looking British guy who made multiple 9 figures
through his publishing company in the 90s.

There are plenty of great quotes in the book but here’s one
that’s stood out to me:

“The key to successful business is self-belief and application.”

It’s underwhelmingly simple.

On the surface, you might pass it off as generic, bland advice.

But as I consider my own success, these two elements are at the
core of it.

I believed I could do something cool with my life.

I took the necessary actions required to do so.

And eventually things clicked.

I had no idea how everything would work out, although I naively
thought I did.

Countless reroutes, poor decisions, and overly ambitious
timelines later, I’m where I wanted to be.

The elements of luck, chance, leverage, and opportunity have
played roles as well.

But they’re outputs of the first two elements (self-belief and
application).

Without these, you have nothing.

You are basically a Miami wannabe scammer who swipes up on
Instagram stories saying “put me on fam 💯.”

Felix Dennis rolls in his grave.

If you’re not making the progress you’d like right now, consider
this:

Do you actually believe you can be successful?

If no, fix that first.

If yes, what are the most obvious daily actions you need to take
to move the needle?

Even if these actions aren’t particularly clear, that’s okay.

You just need to use your best judgment and move.

The path is only illuminated once you begin walking.

​This can be your flashlight. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h22o2rkaqhpn5o333hr/08hwh9h20zv3kgbl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

subject: The art of figuring it out
body:
You learn the most while flying the plane.

I’ve always been fairly confident in my figure-it-out-ability.

When I was growing up, I’d hold ‘A’ to skip through the
directions when playing a new video game.

After a brief period of being completely lost, I’d get the hang
of it.

This attitude carried into school as well.

I regularly wouldn’t study for tests, breeze through
instructions, and complete homework assignments while walking in
the door.

Surprisingly, it’d work out more often than not.

I’d end up sitting next to the smart kid who wrote big enough for
me to see his answers or I’d find another creative way to cheat.

This is how I began to learn the art of figuring it out.

There’s one arena where this figure-it-out-ability has been
rewarded tremendously.

It’s almost like the less you try to contemplate and prepare, the
more you win.

Not in a chaotic, irresponsible way, but rather in a way that
relies on internal trust.

It’s an approach that sounds like this:

“I”m gonna try this…

I’ll prepare enough to put myself in a position for success.

But I understand that most of my learning will be done on the
fly.

And I trust my ability to overcome future obstacles.”

This is the world of entrepreneurship.

Where critical thought is your double edged sword.

Too little, and you’ll scramble like an ant on a bathroom sink—

Aimless, frantic, and one wrong move from getting washed away.

Too much, and you’ll hesitate, overanalyzing until opportunity
slips through your fingers.

Success is found in the middle ground between YOLO and over
preparedness.

But when in doubt, err on the side of YOLO.

Seriously – when I got into the online business world, I studied
a lot.

I was constantly reading books, watching YouTube videos, taking
notes, etc.

That helped, but NOTHING compares to getting real, in game reps.

At first you stare at your computer screen like a dyslexic monkey
trying to read Chinese backwards.

But after some trial and error…

Next thing you know, nǐ zhèngzài zuò (you’re doing it).

To learning on the fly,

Ben

P.S. If you're ready to start flying instead of reading manuals,
I’ll give you the exact blueprint to build and scale an
Info-Product Agency.

You'll still learn on the fly, but with me as your co-pilot.

​Go here to apply now. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hllgellc8h8rgp222cl/7qh7h8h9v37gxvhz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vYXBwbGljYXRpb24tcGFnZTE3MjA1NDg3OTI1Mjc=
)​

​

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hllgellc8h8rgp222cl
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hllgellc8h8rgp222cl
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: From $10k to $90k/month in 7 months
body:
Good morning, happy Friday.

Let me tell you a story…

Meet Jace:

​
He used to run an SMMA working with real estate agents.

He found some success, then it all came crashing down when he had
to refund a bunch of clients.

But he didn’t quit – that’d be a rather depressing story and I
definitely wouldn’t be writing about him right now.

Instead, he pivoted.

Why work with obnoxious, entitled realtors when you can work with
personal brands and make more money, with less headache?

Realizing this, Jace decided to dip his toe into the info-product
agency world.

Not long after, he got two clients and was making around $10k/mo,
but it was inconsistent and he wanted to scale.

That’s when he joined Artisan Lab.

From there, it took him six months to get to $50k/mo.

And just one month later, he made over $90k.

Now this isn’t like dropshipping or Amazon FBA where you take
home 10% of that.

This is a high-margin, cash flow business where you're keeping
60-80% of what you bring in.

Here’s a beautiful picture of Jace getting a multi 5 figure
payment from ONE client:

​
He now has over 8 clients, is getting insane results for them,
and has built a team around himself to scale.

Jace got here by mastering a few key things:

1. Finding the right clients (info-product businesses with
existing traffic)

2. Structuring profitable rev share deals

3. Building a predictable system that scales

And obviously – working really fucking hard.

He went from making roughly $120k per year to over a MILLION
DOLLARS per year in 7 months.

Now – I can’t promise you the same type of results as Jace.

Because frankly, his results are insane and he’s a maniac (in a
good way lol).

It’d be audacious to claim you’re gonna 10x your income in less
than a year like he did.

But if you put in the effort…

And if you follow the same principles… (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9930kdblhvlgq555fn/dpheh0hezvpwkqam/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

It’d be reasonable to assume you can achieve a fraction of the
success he’s had.

Some students reach $10k months. Others hit $20-30k. And a
handful, like Jace, go even further.

The beauty is that even the "modest" results would completely
transform most people's lives.

If you want to learn the exact system Jace used, I've documented
everything inside Artisan Lab. From outreach, to client
onboarding, to scaling strategies, and much more.

​Apply here to see if it's right for you. (

subject: I sent $1,000 to a stranger (again)
body:
I’m back in Miami, writing to you from my balcony.

I’ve spent the last few days in Dorado, Puerto Rico and I’m
heading to LA tomorrow.

Four years ago when I started a business, this is pretty much all
I wanted.

A nice apartment with a Porsche 911 in the garage, time and
location freedom, plus a cool friend group to share experiences
with.

Done.

My motivation has been mostly selfish and superficial.

I don’t have an impoverished family to rescue and I don’t care
about saving the turtles or whatever other driving forces people
come up with.

I wanted to get rich because it sounded way cooler than the
alternative – sitting in a cubicle and listening to some blue
haired woman they/them or skinny-fat balding man tell me when to
use the bathroom.

No thank you ma'am… or sir I mean.

Although my initial motivation wasn't altruistic, this selfish
pursuit has seemed to end up as the most selfless thing I can do…

Sunday night, we’re heading home from dinner in Puerto Rico.

I’m on the back of the golf cart as my friend Jimmy drives as if
we’re in a stolen hellcat.

I check my phone and see a DM from a server at my local lunch
spot in Miami.

He doesn’t speak much English, but we’ve become friends purely
through vibes and Google translate.

Let’s call him Juan for the sake of the story (sorry if that’s

subject: I sent $1,000 to a stranger (again)
body:
I’m back in Miami, writing to you from my balcony.

 I’ve spent the last few days in Dorado, Puerto Rico and I’m heading to LA tomorrow.

 Four years ago when I started a business, this is pretty much all I wanted.

 A nice apartment with a Porsche 911 in the garage, time and location freedom, plus a cool friend group to share experiences with.

 Done.

 My motivation has been mostly selfish and superficial.

 I don’t have an impoverished family to rescue and I don’t care about saving the turtles or whatever other driving forces people come up with.

 I wanted to get rich because it sounded way cooler than the alternative – sitting in a cubicle and listening to some blue haired woman they/them or skinny-fat balding man tell me when to use the bathroom.

 No thank you ma'am… or sir I mean.

 Although my initial motivation wasn't altruistic, this selfish pursuit has seemed to end up as the most selfless thing I can do…

 Sunday night, we’re heading home from dinner in Puerto Rico.

 I’m on the back of the golf cart as my friend Jimmy drives as if we’re in a stolen hellcat.

 I check my phone and see a DM from a server at my local lunch spot in Miami.

 He doesn’t speak much English, but we’ve become friends purely through vibes and Google translate.

 Let’s call him Juan for the sake of the story (sorry if that’s racist but I can’t call him John, because why would someone named John not know English lol).

 Juan tells me he had a family emergency and asks if I could loan him $1,000.

 I get his number, go to Zelle, and send it before we get home.

 I’m not telling you this to brag about how virtuous I am.

 But rather to tell you not to be ashamed of your “why.”

 Many people say you need a strong, unselfish reason to pursue wealth.

 And for those that have one, that’s great.

 I didn’t.

 But along the way, nothing has compared to the feeling I get when I can impact the lives of others.

 Seeing people win inside Artisan Lab feels incredible.

 A server thanking me after I tip 100% on a $200 bill feels incredible.

 Being able to send money to people I care about without expecting anything in return feels incredible.

 Just start with whatever motivation gets you moving.

 Even if it's a Lambo with a baddie in the passenger seat.

 Your deeper purpose will often reveal itself later.

 And when it does, it'll fuel you to go further than you imagined.

 Whether you're trying to help your family, escape the cubicle, or just want nice things - you need money to make it happen.

 If you want to learn how to build an info-product agency that could give you the income and freedom to live life on your terms, go here. ​

 I'm not promising you a Porsche or balcony views.

 But I am showing you a path that worked for me and many of my students.

 Where it takes you is up to you.

 To finding your why along the way,

 Ben

 ​

 ​

subject: It's irresponsible not to try to get rich
body:
I’m writing to you from 1B.

I flew private to LA a few months ago, but times are tough now.

Or maybe my brain is just closer to being fully developed.

I’ve got two more years of using an underdeveloped brain as an
excuse.

“Sorry I ran over your Grandma, I’m only 24!”

Lol.

On to more important matters…

It’s quite honestly irresponsible for any young semi-competent
man to not at least *try* to get rich.

I grew up in a very affluent area in Ohio.

Ranked 17th nationally with an average household income of
$318,319.

Many kids from my high school go on to Ivy Leagues.

Some end up at their parents' companies.

Others bounce from real estate to random finance jobs.

It’s reasonable to assume growing up in an area like this offers
great advantages and breeds excellence.

But many of my high school peers are just not… doing much.

It’s not like they’re entirely miserable or crash outs.

They’re just idle.

Basically watching the clock until they get whatever’s in their
trust or inheritance.

They’ll go their entire lives never truly feeling risk.

They’ll never be in sole control of their path.

I know these are privileged problems and this may sound like an
ideal scenario but I can promise you it typically doesn’t lead to
a full life.

Even with all their advantages, these people often end up with
less fulfillment than someone who built something from nothing.

Privilege without purpose is just comfortable emptiness.

It’s like watching an 80 year long movie where you already know
the ending.

And in search of meaning, you grow bitter, finding silly problems
to stress about.

Yes, it’s an incredible privilege to never have to worry about
money.

But it doesn’t guarantee you live a life you enjoy.

And to me - that’s what winning is.

So no matter your situation…

Whether you’re born in the 17th wealthiest place in America or
the 17,000th.

Why wouldn’t you go after what you want?

You either get it all, or end up somewhere in between.

But at least you have a much better story to tell.

If you’re ready to take the risk and bet on yourself…

​I can help you here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh66em2xavhqlmnrrrao/6qheh8hlvmol2vho/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​
​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh66em2xavhqlmnrrrao
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh66em2xavhqlmnrrrao
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: The missing piece I've been lying about
body:
Good morning.

Apologies for the short hiatus, we’re back in full swing now.

After a bunch of delays, I finally returned from LA last night.

While I was there, I met up with James, one of my members inside
Artisan Lab.

We drove around in the hills in my rented 911 Targa.

As we talked about business, I realized I’ve been lying to you.

I frequently discuss the hard skills required – copywriting,
sales, marketing, etc.

I also talk about the mindset shifts that helped me find success.

But I’ve been leaving out the last (and potentially most
important) piece of the puzzle.

It’s the piece that opens doors that are impossible to see.

Opportunities fall into your lap and you wonder how you got so
lucky.

This is the infinity stone that puts your hard skills on
steroids.

And truthfully, it even makes up for a mediocre skillset.

This missing piece?

People skills.

You can network your way to wealth.

You’re one connection away from a lifetime of referrals.

You’re one connection away from hitting a 1,000x on a meme coin.

You’re one connection away from landing your dream client.

Who you know (or who you don’t know) is actively working for or
against you right now.

If you’re a normal, socially adept person who makes an effort to
meet others in your industry without coming off as a needy
cornball, you’ll win.

I was reminded of this as I was driving through the hills with
James.

He told me about one of his clients who was a referral from
another member in Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpzpo89b5h28xwlllin/m2h7h5h3gkroldum/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

And another client I’d given him directly from my network.

Not because he’s an incredibly exceptional marketer who’s way
better than everyone else I know.

But because he’s chill and I knew he wouldn’t sound like a
desperate socially inept Apple store employee.

Now, I’m not saying you have to be the most charismatic person in
the world…

If you’re genuine, you offer value, and don't reek of
desperation, you’re in good shape.

One of my older members inside Artisan Lab networked her way to
$70k/mo purely by being normal and asking for referrals.

Want access to both the skills and network that will drastically
expedite your success?

​Join me here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpzpo89b5h28xwlllin/m2h7h5h3gkroldum/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

subject: Being a great copywriter is overrated
body:
Being a great copywriter is overrated.

I know this might sound like backwards advice coming from me, but
allow me to explain.

The info-product space has changed a lot.

Organic content is more of a necessity now than ever.

You used to be able to spin up an offer, build a landing page,
run ads, and print.

This has become increasingly difficult as consumers have gotten
more skeptical.

Why would they buy from a stranger in an ad when they’ve consumed
hours of free content from someone else?

They’ll go with the person they trust more.

And unless you’re a world-class copywriter, you don't have much
of a shot.

So wouldn’t that mean that being incredibly skilled at
copywriting isn’t overrated?

Yes and no.

For organic audiences you need to be good enough, not great.

An okay copywriter on a great offer with the right funnel and
sales process will outperform a great copywriter without the
above.

The organic content does the heavy lifting.

As long as you know who you’re talking to and what their pain
points are, simple copy is just fine.

Additionally your clients don't care about literary brilliance.

They care about ROI.

A "good enough" copywriter who understands marketing fundamentals
beats the wordsmith who obsesses over minuscule details.

The gap between "good" to "amazing" rarely justifies the time
investment.

And honestly, with AI tools today, achieving "good enough" copy
has never been easier.

The real skill is knowing which questions to ask and what
problems to solve.

My most successful students aren't the grammar perfectionists or
the ones who can recite Breakthrough Advertising by heart.

They're the ones who:

* Understand their audience deeply
* Build systems that convert reliably
* Move quickly and iterate often
* Prioritize relationships over word choice

Don't get me wrong – you still need a baseline of competence.

But if you're obsessing over becoming the next Gary Halbert
instead of building connections and refining your offer, you're
optimizing the wrong variables.

​Inside Artisan Lab, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn00l25u6h958z444in/g3hnh5hmdll50wir/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) we focus on the complete picture – the copywriting fundamentals
that actually matter, plus the systems and relationships that
truly scale an info product agency.

If you want to learn the full blueprint instead of just one skill
with decreasing value -- go here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn00l25u6h958z444in/g3hnh5hmdll50wir/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​
​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn00l25u6h958z444in
) | Update your profile (

subject: Do not buy Artisan Lab
body:
I have a boring topic for you today.

It’s the thing that makes most info sellers roll their eyes.

They ignore it until there are dozens of reddit threads
rightfully slandering them.

Many info businesses crash and burn quickly because of it.

This topic?

It’s called ‘product.’

Yes, product, meaning the thing you actually give to the people
who pay you.

I know it’s rare to hear someone talk about such a foreign
concept.

But this weird little term ends up making or breaking you.

And most people overlook it until it’s too late.

Let’s say you sell a high ticket coaching program.

You have a bunch of course content, a couple weekly group calls,
and a community.

At first, it’s easy to answer questions and make sure people are
staying on track.

It’s a smaller, tight knit community and students get results.

However as time goes on and you start scaling, this once small
community has turned into a big one.

There are too many students and not enough of you.

It’s effectively become a daycare and you’re a babysitter trying
to stop the kids from revolting.

Eventually it becomes this big mess where everyones lost, no one
gets results, and you hate your own business.

But here’s the thing:

Hiring more coaches doesn't fix this.

A better course doesn’t fix this.

Even more support and clearer roadmap doesn’t fix this.

The root of the problem is who you begin selling to.

Oftentimes to scale, you start selling anyone and everyone who
wants to buy your offer.

And now you have loser idiots who expect to get rich in 24 hours
acting as parasites inside your community.

(What a surprise! The person with a 520 credit score who’ll be
paying off your course for the next 76 years isn’t a competent,
responsible human being lol).

They’re unrealistic, lazy, and don’t take accountability.

This turns off serious prospects because no one wants to be
surrounded by a bunch of room temperature IQ smooth brains.

You’ve created a little idiot army. Congrats.

Here’s how to avoid this:

Do not overpromise.

Do not take customers' last dollar.

Do not claim they won’t have to work hard

When you’re realistic in your marketing, people get results like
this:

​
Dom got a new client 3 days in (this is rare but not impossible).

​
Marcus got a new client less than 4 weeks in (also rare, not
impossible).

​
And Vander, struggled for a couple months (perhaps the most
realistic timeline) but is now breaking through, signing two
clients in the past week.

I will not promise you get rich.

I will simply give you the resources, information, and network
that has made me (and many students) rich.

What you do that this is up to you...

Do not click here and apply for Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpzde9nt5h28xwlllin/g3hnh5hmdnodppur/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) if you’re stupid.

Do not click here and apply for Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpzde9nt5h28xwlllin/g3hnh5hmdnodppur/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) if you think it’ll be easy.

But if you’re a winner…

There’s no better place to be.

Ben

​
​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpzde9nt5h28xwlllin
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpzde9nt5h28xwlllin
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: Hard work won't make you rich
body:
Hard work matters, but not as much as you think.

I consider it a prerequisite.

Everyone who finds success goes through a phase where they’re in
the trenches.

This part sucks, but if you’re consistent and actually try for
two years, you basically guarantee that you’ll make it.

It doesn’t mean that you’ll be abnormally successful.

But enough to where you can make a solid living on your own.

After that, hard work seems to have diminishing returns.

Two other factors become increasingly important in your pursuit
of wealth:

* Your ability to create leverage.
* Your speed of execution.

I used to never understand what people meant when they discussed
leverage.

It sounded like a buzzword that guru #138 would throw around
while wearing dorky blue light blockers.

And then, I started to actually understand leverage (in this
context).

Leverage is when you can write one email or make one video and
generate six figures.

Leverage is when one hire frees up a month’s worth of time and
energy.

Leverage is when you can build something once and create systems
that allow for exponential growth.

The more connections, influence, and manpower you have, the more
leverage you have, and the richer you get.

Secondly, your speed of execution dictates everything.

Life and entrepreneurship are just games of data.

You have to experience things to know what you like, what you
don’t like, what works, and what doesn’t.

The quicker you implement ideas, the quicker you get more data.

More data creates better decisions.

Better decisions create more wealth.

I don’t want to be the hardest worker in the room.

I want to be the one with the most leverage and the quickest to
execute.

Then I’ll be doing donuts on a Jetski in the Atlantic ocean while
the hardest worker is at a desk in a dark room trying to figure
out something I did months ago.

To working smarter,

Ben

subject: Hard work won't make you rich
body:

 I consider it a prerequisite.

 Everyone who finds success goes through a phase where they’re in the trenches.

 This part sucks, but if you’re consistent and actually try for two years, you basically guarantee that you’ll make it.

 It doesn’t mean that you’ll be abnormally successful.

 But enough to where you can make a solid living on your own.

subject: 5 traits of people who will never succeed
body:
Some people just aren’t gonna make it.

No matter what they do, they’ll find a way to sabotage
themselves.

You could tell them that all they have to do to get rich is tie
their shoes daily.

They’d come back to you a week later and tell you they’re not
passionate enough or they didn’t know what kind of knot to tie.

They are the kamikaze pilots of entrepreneurship.

They’re true masters at one thing and one thing only:

Self-destruction.

This has little to do with intelligence and it’s independent of
the business model they choose.

So what’s the problem?

They have unwavering loyalty to a broken mindset.

While almost no one starts out with the “right” mindset, the game
is to discard the beliefs and habits that don’t serve you.

Successful people become successful after doing the wrong thing
and then correcting it.

“Kamikaze entrepreneurs” find creative ways to keep doing the
wrong thing while convincing themselves they’re doing the right
thing.

It’s honestly impressive.

Here are some traits of those who are not gonna make it:

- They’re too distracted, jumping from one thing to the next.

- They always have an excuse as to why their lack of success
isn’t their fault.

- They’re incredibly skilled at deluding themselves into
believing they know best.

- They're unlikable and not smart enough to make up for it.

- They always feel like they’re “missing something,” like there’s
a secret success formula they don’t have.

If you identify with any of the above and refuse to change, your
failure is inevitable.

I didn’t include laziness because typically these types aren’t
lazy.

The mental gymnastics they're doing to avoid taking action
requires an incredible amount of energy.

But the good news is everyone starts with some of these traits.

Successful people are self-aware enough to recognize and discard
them.

If these patterns sound familiar, it's your job to begin
adapting.

Only then can everything I'd teach you in here (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmhn43467a6h8r5e000cg/9qhzhnhdqpq496t9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) actually help you.

Choose evolution over self-sabotage.

Your future is depends on it.

Ben
​
​

​

​

subject: "it’s only cringe until it works"
body:
I was just sitting outside Starbucks trying to start this email.

There was this jacked dude to my left in a full salmon-colored
workout set.

Didn’t catch his face, but he had a disheveled videographer
taking pictures of him sipping coffee.

Between the outfit and the coffee photoshoot, I couldn’t help but
start mentally clowning him.

It felt like a live-action version of the morning routine guy who
just went viral on Twitter.

Then he turned slightly and I got a better look.

He sort of looked like this popular fitness influencer/podcaster
you’ve probably seen on YouTube.

And when I got up to throw out my coffee, I realized it was Mike
Thurston.

So I stopped clowning him and walked home to write this to you.

There’s probably a lesson in there somewhere —

“Don’t judge a book by its cover” or “It’s only cringe until it
works.”

Whatever. A lol — that story was a detour.

Here’s what I actually wanted to share:

Do you remember what you were doing at 15?

I’d just gotten my driver’s permit and was riding around
listening to “Hotline Bling” by Drake.

Like any normal teenage kid my top priorities were sports,
keeping my Snapchat streaks alive, and cheating on my homework.

That was 2015.

Now it’s 2025 — and meanwhile, Michael, the youngest member
inside Artisan Lab, is out here pulling in $10k/month with his
Info-Product Agency.

He’s 15.

I sat down with him for a short interview where he breaks down
how he went from $3k/month a few months ago to 5-figure months.

​Watch the full interview here (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhv4o4deaghv4erlllf9/l2hehmhl0lnxgqa6/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vWVVYTUFX
) -- it’ll probably make you rethink how you spent your freshman
year of high school.

Ben

​

​

​

subject: Boredom is a superpower
body:
The best decisions I’ve made have almost never been extremely
calculated.

Typically, they’re a result of boredom and curiosity.

There’s no 10 step foolproof roadmap.

There’s a desire and an idea.

After some procrastination, one day I’d wake up too fed up with
myself to not act.

Next thing you know I’m finally doing it – I swatted the gnat
buzzing in the back of my mind.

One day, I was bored so I searched up “how to make money online.”

One day, I was bored so I sent my first outreach message.

One day, I was bored so I began posting videos online.

The first of those three led me into this space.

The second got me my first client.

And the third has made me a couple million dollars.

All because there was a split second where I decided:

“I’m gonna do it now. Not in one hour, not tomorrow and
definitely not on the arbitrary date I told myself I’d start.
Right. Now.”

About a year ago, that’s exactly how I started posting on
Youtube.

I remember sitting in the office of my last apartment and
thinking, “damn, I’ve really been putting off this Youtube thing
for a while.”

Two minutes later, the camera was out and an hour later, I
clicked upload.

That exact decision has made me lots of money, led to many
connections, and might be the reason you’re reading this right
now.

So bo, what's the gnat buzzing in the back of your mind?

What idea keeps popping up that you've been putting off?

Maybe it's time to get "too fed up" with yourself.

Maybe today is your "right now" moment.

Or maybe you should keep watching thirst traps on TikTok and
forget you ever read this.

I’m not judging you and I’m not your therapist.

Hell, I’d probably keep scrolling too.

But I will say – doing the things you’ve been putting off makes
you feel good.

And being (relatively) rich is fun – Definitely more fun than
sitting in a cubicle taking orders from some overweight, soy milk
drinking, mouth breathing buffoon.

So why not try?

Stop being a [redacted].

That's it.

​Go here if you want my help along the way. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhk7ez68uphwrpd000i6/25h2hoh3v3x503s3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhk7ez68uphwrpd000i6
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: Abraham Lincoln taught me how to use AI
body:
I got coffee with Chat GPT this morning.

We were trying to generate an image of Abraham Lincoln and me in
the back of a carriage shaking hands.

At first I gave him two images of me to work off.

The first response was decent but it made me look like I’d been
born in Brooklyn and was raised on lox and bagels.

My eyes were too far apart and other features were just a bit
off.

I asked Mr. GPT how we can get it closer to looking like the real
me.

He instructed me to upload more photos of myself, from various
angles, so I did.

We generated the image again and it improved, but I still looked
like a close relative of mine, not me exactly.

I asked him how we could get it to be exact.

He told me the best route is to train a custom model.

Now, I know there are softwares that make it easy to generate
more realistic images of yourself, but this got me thinking about
the learning curve with AI.

Some people are telling you to be afraid of it, others are saying
it’ll do your whole job for you, even if you suck.

In the info-product/copywriting world, the true answer seems to
be somewhere in the middle.

Here are both sides of the coin:

AI is incredible and it’s only getting better but as of now, it
can’t do everything for you.

You should only be afraid of it if you’re unwilling to learn how
to utilize it.

A marketer or copywriter empowered by AI is vastly more efficient
and accurate than one who isn’t.

On the contrary, AI will not save you.

The notion that you don’t have to be a good marketer anymore is a
complete lie.

If you don’t have a solid understanding of what you’re doing and
haven’t found success pre-AI, it’s basically useless until you
reach a baseline level of competence.

It won’t effectively do your outreach, take your sales calls,
demonstrate competence, or do your work for you.

Think of AI as power tools for a carpenter.

They make a skilled craftsman more efficient, but give a table
saw to someone who's never built anything and you'll end up with
a missing limb.

​Inside Artisan Lab, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh6ngzlgavhqlmnrrrao/7qh7h8h9kwe3m7cz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) you’ll learn both the foundational skills and how to leverage
AI as a multiplier.

Not as a replacement, but as an accelerator.

Ready to build the skills AI can't replace while learning to use
it as your secret weapon?

​Join me inside here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh6ngzlgavhqlmnrrrao/7qh7h8h9kwe3m7cz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

To augmentation, not replacement,

Ben

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh6ngzlgavhqlmnrrrao
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh6ngzlgavhqlmnrrrao
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

body:

I won’t offer you any word of advice and in no way will this help
you make more money.

Actually, I’ll probably say something that offends you.

Here we go:

Austin and Tampa are my two least favorite cities.

I have a deep disgust for both of them (aside from Terry Black's
BBQ in Austin) and I’d pick a vacation to Gary, Indiana over
these two places.

Austin is just weird.

Their literal slogan is “keep Austin weird.”

When I think of this city, images of the following starter pack
come to mind:

A bag of granola, muddy hiking shoes, a cold plunge, and sweaty
shirtless men that eat raw meat.

Tampa is a different story.

It looks sort of dystopian to me.

The main thing I dislike is that everyone tries to convince you
it’s like Miami, but smaller.

Tampa is not a mini Miami.

There is a meat market, an Edition hotel that smells like
garbage, and a cigar lounge.

That’s it.

It’d be a fine city if everyone stopped trying to push the
narrative that it’s Miami’s younger brother.

If anything, it’s Miami’s adopted cousin from China with a speech
impediment.

You just feel obligated to be nice.

Anyway, this thought sparked because there’s been a lot of Miami
slander on social media recently.

I get it.

I’m tired of the scammers, excess of huracans, and OF girls too.

It’s a party city and easy to get caught up spending money that
you don’t actually have.

But here's the cool thing about Miami – and life in general…

You have the power to choose.

If you’re disciplined, the above is a non issue.

Lol nvm – I’m not gonna try to turn this rant into a lesson.

​Here’s something you might find valuable though. (

)​

Have a good weekend,

Ben

P.S. I was initially trying tell you about what's happening
inside of Artisan Lab but it wasn't working, so this is what we
ended up with.

Here's what I should've shown you:

The craziest win of the week -- Jace is casually ripping 6 figure
days with clients and may quadruple his personal monthly income
(TO $200k) in just a few months.

​

​
And some new clients being signed...

​

​
​Join us here. (

) (As long as you're not gonna tell me that Tampa is a mini
Miami).

subject: How to break out of a slump (w/o excess stimulants)
body:
A fly was just buzzing around my laptop.

I swung twice and missed both times.

This is a rare occurrence.

If there's a worldwide fly swatting accuracy leaderboard
anywhere, I’d be near the top.

It’s a sunny morning in Miami, although it rained all day
yesterday so the ground is still wet.

I have an iced espresso next to me and I’m ready to work.

The past couple weeks have been a bit unfocused.

I got out of my normal routine from traveling and am now getting
back into the swing of things.

You know that feeling when you want to be productive but you’re
being a lazy, unmotivated piece of shit?

Me too.

Slumps like this are inevitable and they happen to everyone.

Even the greatest athletes on the planet go through periods where
they can’t make a shot or get on base.

Let’s consider how they get through this…

A struggling athlete has to become aware of components that are
typically subconscious.

Perhaps they started rushing their follow-through or rotating too
much on their swing.

To correct themselves, they have to be more intentional and
disciplined than usual.

If they can typically get away with lacing up their shoes right
before practice, that’s not gonna fly for now.

They have to put more time in, identify the error they’re making
and consciously decide to fix it.

Eventually things go back to normal and it becomes subconscious
or easy again.

Productivity works the same way.

When you’re in a slump, the bitch voice in your head is the
loudest.

To shut it out, you’ll likely have to be more disciplined than
usual.

Get up earlier.

Stop yourself from scrolling on social media.

Write down a detailed schedule to follow each day.

Put your phone on DND and stick to the plan.

Next thing you know, you’ll knock off the rust and feel good
about working again.

This doesn’t take long unless you let it.

A member of Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhk75qwmhphwrpd000i6/9qhzhnhdq0o34la9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) recently came to me with this exact problem and I told him the
following:

“Momentum and habits outweigh motivation. Small wins will create
bigger ones. You're one productive morning away from a productive
day, and one productive day away from a productive week. Just
have to get the ball rolling with the small things.”

Soon enough you’ll get back in rhythm.

The ball will hit your hands and you’ll effortlessly rise up and
let it fly.

Slump over, Lambo coming soon. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhk75qwmhphwrpd000i6/9qhzhnhdq0o34la9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhk75qwmhphwrpd000i6
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhk75qwmhphwrpd000i6
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: I wrote a VSL in 30 seconds (here's how)
body:
I ran an interesting experiment yesterday.

On my call with the Artisan Lab members, I tested how quickly I
could write a VSL for a new offer using AI.

I scrolled through Youtube until I found a creator who makes
content about high ticket sales.

She has under 1k subscribers but gets solid engagement on her
videos and only began uploading a few months ago.

This potentially would be a great client for a
copywriter/info-agency owner for a few reasons:

- High ticket sales is a validated niche and she innately has a
unique mechanism in selling to women.

- She’s newer to info and doesn’t have a full funnel built out
yet.

- She’s posting consistent content and her personal brand is
growing.

So here’s where the experiment began:

I copied the links of her existing YT videos and put them into an
AI software I’m gatekeeping for now (sorry).

Then I uploaded a VSL framework for AI to reference.

And I prompted it to write the VSL using the information in her
videos based on the winning framework I gave it.

30 seconds later, the script was done.

After a few minor edits, my job would be completely finished.

This is something that used to require hours of research and
another hour or so to write.

Now it can be effectively completed in under 5 minutes with the
right AI tools and prompts.

But here’s the catch…

If you don’t know how to find good clients, what to say in your
outreach, and you can’t articulate your value on a sales call, AI
doesn’t help you.

Sure you could use the same process I laid out and get a similar
result.

But you also need to be able to demonstrate a solid understanding
of the info-product space.

For me and the members inside Artisan Lab, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn0qen4u6h95qqv44in/25h2hoh3v9569ku3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) this is game-changing because we already have the fundamentals
down.

AI is multiplying our effectiveness, not replacing us.

The gap between those who understand both the info-product space
AND how to leverage AI effectively is widening every day.

If you want to be on the right side of that gap, you need both
skill sets.

Only then will you be able to get results like this…

​

​

​
​Inside Artisan Lab, (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn0qen4u6h95qqv44in/25h2hoh3v9569ku3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) you'll learn both the foundational knowledge and AI
implementations that'll fast-track your success.

To not getting replaced,

Ben

​
​
​

​

subject: bo, let's compromise...
body:
Fair and noble people make compromises.

Life is not like Burger King. You can’t always have it your way…

Fuck. That.

This way of thinking is for the mentally enslaved.

But you bo, as a reader of the best newsletter on the internet,
deserve better…

You owe yourself better.

When you’re quick to make compromises, here’s what happens:

Your Ferrari dreams turn into a Corolla (or perhaps you buy a
corvette C8 when you’re 68 and try to convince yourself it’s a
real supercar).

Your supermodel wife turns into a plus sized hand model. Or your
“rich husband” turns into a guy that makes $105k/yr and loves to
say he makes six figures.

Your dream of waking up to the sound of the waves crashing on the
shore only happens 3 days a year. And you’re on vacation in
Myrtle Beach, not Honolulu.

I know this sounds a bit dramatic, but making compromises when it
comes to your desires is a slippery slope.

You need to be militant.

You need to be stubborn.

You need to aim for what you actually want.

When others tell you to be reasonable, or when you begin to hear
a voice in your head negotiating with you, shut it out.

I’d rather be an insane, unreasonable, stubborn asshole than a
chubby balding middle aged man… in a COROLLA!

Do not tolerate behavior that doesn’t align with your goals.

When you make a plan, stick to it as if you are following orders
from God.

There is no negotiating, there is no settling, and when you find
yourself exchanging “great” for “good enough,” stop yourself.

If you compromise, I guess I’ll send you a postcard from
Honolulu.

That’s basically the real thing isn’t it! LOL!

No. Stop. It’s not the real thing. And a C8 isn’t a supercar. And
fuck Mrytle Beach.

Their rules and standards are meant to be broken. Yours aren’t.

See you in a Ferrari with a supermodel in your passenger seat.

To the stubborn and unreasonable – I will help you win. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxg009xb6h6dqq5ggsl/e0hph7h7p3v5rvt8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

P.S. I’d feel slightly irresponsible by not clarifying some
nuance here.

Not compromising doesn’t mean you refuse to turn up the
temperature when you set it at 67 and your girl wants it at 72.

It also doesn’t mean that there is only one way to accomplish a
goal and the route can’t be adjusted.

But when it comes to the real shit you want…

Don’t let anyone talk you out of it (including yourself).

​This is for those who refuse to compromise. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxg009xb6h6dqq5ggsl/e0hph7h7p3v5rvt8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

​
​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxg009xb6h6dqq5ggsl
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxg009xb6h6dqq5ggsl
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: The info-product bull run is here
body:
Big things are happening.

This reminds me of the 2021 crypto bull run.

Bitcoin surpassed $60k and people were buying million-dollar
pictures of cartoon monkeys (NFTs).

What a time.

Many of my friends became millionaires that year.

They’d get in on a big NFT project or they’d buy the right coin
at the right time.

But not me.

I was in the beginning stages of building my agency so that’s
where my energy was directed.

And looking back, I feel like an idiot for sitting on the
sidelines.

Money was falling from the sky and all I had to do was put my
hand out and grab some.

Right now, a new bull run is happening outside of the crypto
world.

And it’s creating some of the craziest success stories I’ve ever
seen…

This is Jace.

​
You may recognize him from some of my previous emails or the
interview we did on Youtube.

When we recorded that video just 3 months ago, he was at $50k/mo.

Now, he made $204k…

In a week…

Actually just 6 days:

​
It feels like the equivalent of hitting a 100x on a random meme
coin.

Except luck doesn’t play nearly as much of a role here.

He followed a blueprint, worked incredibly hard, got the right
clients, and made it happen.

This is a result of capitalizing on the info-product bull run.

leading digital product platform).

subject: You can’t unsee this
body:
“Curiosity killed the cat.”

Have you ever heard that phrase?

I never understood it because my curiosity has never led me
astray.

I just asked Chat GPT about it and guess what he told me?

The full quote is “curiosity killed the cat, but satisfaction
brought it back.”

This flips the meaning and suggests that curiosity is worth the
risk if it leads to the truth.

What a scam!

Imagine going through life thinking that being a curious person
is a bad thing...

Till one day you find out you were abiding by an incomplete
phrase.

This makes me wonder what other quotes we might be
misinterpreting.

Perhaps it’s “Thou shall not kill… unless someone is going 55 mph
in the fast lane.”

Or “All men are created equal… except for those who drive
Corvette C8’s.”

Lol.

I’m glad we cleared this curiosity thing up.

It’s a trait I observe amongst nearly all successful people I
meet.

They’re always asking questions and trying to solve problems.

They don’t blindly accept the popular opinion, they pause, think
and form their own conclusions.

If you ended up on my email list, you’re likely more curious than
most people.

Only stubbornness and blind naivety would lead someone into the
world of entrepreneurship.

Most are too ignorant.

But you’re curious enough to at least go down the rabbit hole.

Congrats…

This was a dangerous, irresponsible thing for you to do.

Because now, you can’t unsee it.

You know this route is possible.

You know you could build the life of your dreams.

And you also know it’s not easy.

So now, if you return to safety and try to blend in with the dull
and ignorant, you’d go insane.

You’d become bitter and angry, both at yourself and at the world.

Because you’d know that there’s a deeper purpose to fulfill and
you’re not doing it.

Maybe curiosity did kill the cat.

But at least you know now…

Everything you dream of exists.

It’s real.

And it’s on the other side of curiosity, courage, and consistent
action.

So keep asking questions…

But be careful, because you’ll get the answer.

​If you're ready to turn curiosity into real results, here’s your
next step. (

Ben

subject: The most productive thing you can do today
body:
You don’t need a different business model.

You don’t need another “high-converting funnel template.”

You definitely don’t need another podcast episode on “morning
routines of billionaires.”

You need silence.

For five minutes.

No scrolling. No input.

No attempt to feel productive by watching someone else do what
you're too scared to try.

Just you. And the truth.

Because in that silence, you'll be forced to admit something:

You already know what you should be doing.

But doing it means letting go of the identity you've built -- the
one that's “learning, researching, and getting ready.”

So you keep hiding behind consumption.

Here’s the truth:

Action is terrifying because it kills the version of you that
talks but doesn’t do.

And that version of you?

It wants to survive.

But if you want your life to change, that version has to die.

I made a video (

It’s not loud.

It’s not aggressive.

It’s just the boring truth.

Or don’t.

Either way, just stop looking for answers you already have.

subject: Claude stole my laptop
body:
Good morning.

There is a 2% chance this is the first email of mine you’ve ever
read.

I did one of those corny lead magnet’s on my Instagram and now
there are an additional 200 of you.

If you’re new, welcome.

This is not your typical guru-list.

Unlike most newsletters, each email is not an engineered pitch
written by a copywriter pretending to be me.

Although, I’ve been the copywriter pretending to be someone else
many times.

But this is me, physically sitting at my desk typing to you.

My second coffee of the morning is to my right.

My first coffee got thrown out after two sips because the barista
at Starbucks must’ve woken up on the wrong side of the bed.

I was playing with AI all night last night.

Claude now has every email I’ve ever written and knows me better
than my mother.

Together we are gonna take over the world.

Watch this:

It mimics my tone, sentence structure, and even my tendency to go
on weird tangents about Corvette C8’s and normies.

The possibilities are endless.

Imagine having a digital twin that can handle the mundane writing
tasks while you focus on the creative work that actually moves
the needle.

But here's where it gets interesting…

Wait –

Did you catch that?

Those last few lines weren't me.

Claude took over after I said “watch this.”

It’s real me again, typing with my actual fingers.

Now that AI has hundreds of my previous emails, it’s pretty good.

Still not 100%, but close.

Does this mean that copywriters are cooked? Are you destined to
put fries in a bag until AI comes and replaces you again?

Maybe.

Here’s what I think:

The edge isn’t voice anymore.

It’s perspective.

AI can mimic cadence. It can’t manufacture conviction.

It can remix a thought. It can’t live one (for now).

If you’re an idiot without AI, you’re still an idiot with it.

If you’re skilled without it, you’re 10x better with it.

Adapt or die,

Ben

P.S. If you want to see how I'm using AI to scale my agency and
help my clients make more

money with less effort, check out Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh37ok73i2hdrvvz66f7/vqh3hrhov2gdg6ug/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

You’ll learn the exact systems (plus everything else that's
working right now in the info-business space).

Or if you just want to tell me your thoughts on AI, hit reply. I
miss talking to you.

​
​

​

subject: Your $204,000 payout is NOT on the way...
body:
I hate it when people come up to me and say “I know you from
TikTok!”

This is a pretentious thing to complain about.

But allow me:

They’ll say these words as if I’m gonna break into character and
start performing for them after.

Like “I know you from TikTok!” is code for me to begin singing
and dancing like a circus clown.

But that doesn’t happen.

We blankly stare at each other for a sec, then I usually say
“yeah?”

Then they say “yeah.”

And after another 2.2 seconds of awkward silence I’ll ask their
name, tell them it was nice to meet them (it wasn’t) and move
along.

As I write this I’m considering the possibility that I’m the
awkward one….

Eh no. I’m normal.

It’s the TikTok brained people.

They’re the type that would approach a girl and expect her to
carry the conversation.

When others approach me and mention they’ve seen me on YT or
Twitter, we have a solid conversation.

This probably reads as if I’m trying to indirectly brag about how
cool and famous I am.

I’m not (ok, maybe a little).

These awkward interactions are sort of a microcosm of the whole
short form content/internet culture.

It’s why the “this is so easy, AI will do all the work for you!”
Angle works for marketers.

It’s a lie, but it’s sexy enough that people want to believe it
anyway.

The people that fall for it are the same ones that will send an
outbound message and follow up “???” after they don’t get a
reply.

There is a special place in Clownland for them.

No one owes you anything.

Successful people understand this and earn everything they get.

Like Jace – a member in Artisan Lab who recently hit six figure
months with his info-product agency.

​In this interview (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn0wlqwf6h95qqv44in/x0hph6hepr962xt5/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vUHNzdUd3
) he talks about how he drove 25 hours from Minnesota to
Scottsdale to close his first client.

25 HOURS. To get a coffee with someone.

That decision led to his first solid case study.

And it’s a big reason why a single client just paid him $204,000
in commission for 10 days of work.

Do the things others won’t and you will win.

That’s how Jace did it. That’s how you can, too.

​Watch the full breakdown here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn0wlqwf6h95qqv44in/x0hph6hepr962xt5/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vUHNzdUd3
)​

Then go do something ridiculous.

Ben

​
​

​

) | Update your profile (

subject: I'm struggling...
body:
I opened a Google doc to write this 19 minutes ago.

Since then, I’ve written and deleted the first line 4 times.

I asked AI to give me ideas to write about but didn’t like any of
them.

Then I got distracted and started scrolling through Instagram.

Many times, I’d lose this battle.

I’d convince myself that I just don’t have it in me to write an
email today and close my laptop.

The 2 espresso martinis and 3 tequila sodas I drank last night
might have something to do with that.

But if I lose this battle, I’ll feel like a loser.

The rest of my day will be clouded by the fact that I didn’t do
this.

So selfishly, I’m writing this to avoid feeling like shit.

And unselfishly, I owe it to you.

I recently watched a Youtube video where this guy said it’s your
duty as a personal brand to show up for your audience.

It’s easy to forget that every “view” on a piece of content is a
living, breathing soul.

Not sending an email on a day you’re supposed to, is the
equivalent of no-showing a date.

I guess this is our date. I like your tits dress.

Consistency is a moral duty.

Every time you leave a task unfinished because you don’t feel
good, you’re letting down everyone who believes in you.

That means your family, friends, staff, future children,
bloodline, baby mama, followers, and GOD himself.

You can’t click buttons on a laptop in an air conditioned box in
the sky because you… have a headache?

Grow up.

You are (probably) a man.

You were lucky enough to be alive in the greatest era in human
history.

Your ancestors had to hunt wild animals.

You click a few buttons and Pedro shows up 15 minutes later with
your burrito.

Show up for yourself, so you don’t hate yourself.

And show up for others, so you don’t let them down.

You’ll be glad you did (just like I am right now).

Ben

P.S. Neither rain, nor snow, nor sleet, nor hail shall keep the
postmen from their appointed rounds. Nor shall a hangover keep
you from clicking this... (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmhn4gwx4b6h8rxx600bg/6qheh8hl55nzpoco/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) and allowing me to assist you in your pursuit of generational
wealth.

​
​

​

subject: How to become a billionaire (easy & simple)
body:
Did you know there are only 902 billionaires in the US?

And somehow they all drive Huracans, sell courses, take high
doses of TRT, and live in Miami (lol).

I have one friend who I think could become a billionaire.

Not because he’s close to it or has any kind of head start.

Right now, he’s actually the most cash-poor in my immediate
circle, as a lot of his money is tied up in a software company.

Obviously he’s intelligent, works hard, all of that.

Those two traits alone aren’t gonna make you billions — the
janitor works hard and the economics professor is intelligent…

Never seen them in a baby blue Huracan.

But there’s one trait that makes me bet on him:

It’s relentless. Inconvenient. Borderline annoying.

And it’s…

Curiosity.

(Coupled with the ability to spot opportunities and execute —I
know I said one trait but there’s always some nuance).

One day, my potential billionaire friend and I are driving home
from the gym.

I’m in the passenger seat as Lebron (probably not his real name,
obviously) speeds past the cars in the left turn lane, cuts in
front of them, and makes a left.

As I hold on to the roof handle, he begins telling me about
quantum physics.

Most of it goes over my head as he discusses his predictions and
what he wants to build in the quantum realm.

Let me pause here.

You might be thinking, “Ben, your potential billionaire friend is
probably just a pothead who goes down weird rabbit holes
sometimes.”

Maybe.

subject: How to become a billionaire (easy & simple)
body:
Did you know there are only 902 billionaires in the US?

 And somehow they all drive Huracans, sell courses, take high doses of TRT, and live in Miami (lol).

 I have one friend who I think could become a billionaire.

 Not because he’s close to it or has any kind of head start.

 Right now, he’s actually the most cash-poor in my immediate circle, as a lot of his money is tied up in a software company.

 Obviously he’s intelligent, works hard, all of that.

 Those two traits alone aren’t gonna make you billions — the janitor works hard and the economics professor is intelligent…

 Never seen them in a baby blue Huracan.

 But there’s one trait that makes me bet on him:

 It’s relentless. Inconvenient. Borderline annoying.

 And it’s…

 Curiosity . 

 (Coupled with the ability to spot opportunities and execute —I know I said one trait but there’s always some nuance).

 One day, my potential billionaire friend and I are driving home from the gym.

 I’m in the passenger seat as Lebron (probably not his real name, obviously) speeds past the cars in the left turn lane, cuts in front of them, and makes a left.

 As I hold on to the roof handle, he begins telling me about quantum physics.

 Most of it goes over my head as he discusses his predictions and what he wants to build in the quantum realm.

 Let me pause here.

 You might be thinking, “Ben, your potential billionaire friend is probably just a pothead who goes down weird rabbit holes sometimes.”

 Maybe.

 But for the right type of person, a weird rabbit hole could be the gateway to extreme wealth.

 You trip and fall and next thing you know you invented the door handle equivalent in the quantum realm.

 If necessity is the mother of invention, curiosity is its grandmother.

 Necessity forces you to be curious.

 Curiosity leads you to find new problems.

 And if you find a reeaaally big problem - and solve it?

 Time to start picking the type of leather you want on the seats of your Gulfstream G700.

 So yeah…

 Maybe “Lebron” ends up broke in five years, yelling about dark matter on the corner of Brickell Ave.

 Or maybe he builds something so impactful it forces us to redefine the word "genius."

 Either way, I’ll keep showing up to hear the next quantum rabbit hole – because curiosity pays.

 Stay curious.

 It just might make you billions.

 Ben

 P.S. Inside Artisan Lab, we’ve got a bunch of curious weirdos turning ideas into income. If you wanna get rich without becoming a soulless automaton, you’d probably like it here. ​

 ​

 ​

 ​

subject: Did AI just replace me?
body:
I don’t want to do this.

But I have to show you something…

I’ve been training Claude and ChatGPT on my writing style for
about a week.

It’s gotten to the point where I could go live in a cabin in
Alaska, spend all day with Alpacas, and if AI-me kept emailing
you…

You’d probably never notice.

So let’s run an experiment:

I’ll come up with an idea for an email.

Give AI a lazy one-line prompt.

We’ll read it together.

Then I’ll meet you at the end and we’ll talk.

Sound good?

Cool. (Not like you had a choice anyway.)

Prompt:

Write and email about why most people fail when trying to start a
business in the info/agency world.

BenGPT:

"Hey bo,

Here’s the part they don’t tell you in those “how I made
$100K/month” YouTube videos:

Most people don’t fail because of strategy.

They fail because they’re fucking soft.

They read Russell Brunson, buy a cold email course, slap together
an offer, and post 3 times on Twitter.

Then wonder why clients aren’t lining up to wire them $5K.

Meanwhile, the guy who is getting clients?

He’s not smarter than you. Or more talented. Or even better
looking (unless it’s me, in which case, sorry bro).

He just didn’t stop.

The truth is, most people enter the info/agency game with all the
wrong expectations.

They think:

* It’s gonna be passive.
* It’s gonna be fast.
* It’s gonna feel good.

Wrong, wrong, and LOL.

What it’s gonna feel like is:

Rewriting your VSL script 7 times and still hating it.

Getting ghosted by 33 different leads in a row.

Having a panic attack after realizing you owe Stripe $1,200 in
fees.

This is not a business for people who crave comfort.

This is a business for psychos.

The type who’ll build a landing page at 2am just because he had a
weird idea in the shower.

If that’s not you – cool.

Go get a job. Live a peaceful life. Watch Netflix and pay rent
forever.

But if it is you?

Then you need to stop acting like a confused beginner and start
behaving like someone who’s already successful.

Because here’s the truth:

There are only 3 things that actually matter when starting your
agency/info-biz:

* A skill that solves a painful problem
* A system that gets that skill in front of people
* The brain damage tolerance to repeat that until rich

That’s it.

Everything else is masturbation.

You don’t need another course.

You don’t need a better logo.

You don’t need to ask your group chat for feedback on your offer
doc.

You just need to move.

Fast. Messy. Relentless. Like your future depends on it – because
it does.

Ben"

[End]

Pretty solid, yeah?

And that was with a half-baked, one-sentence prompt.

Obviously there’s still some magic that comes from real-life
experiences, fresh insights, and having a pulse.

But voice-wise?

I’d say it’s 90% of the way there.

Here’s the coolest part:

I now have a repeatable framework I can use with every client.

Import their data. Feed it the right examples.

And 30 minutes later? Boom -- I have a writing clone that sounds
just like them.

If you want to learn how to do the same — I’ll teach you inside
Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hnon99mc6h95qqv44in/08hwh9h29kr9kval/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

I’ll be in the cabin.

You bring the alpacas.

See you in Alaska,

Ben

​
​

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hnon99mc6h95qqv44in
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hnon99mc6h95qqv44in
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: The three levels of leverage
body:
Money, money, money.

That’s all I care about right now.

Unless you’re already sitting on 8 figures, or you’re a
hippie-meditator-eat-bugs-and-practice-acceptance type…

I’d recommend making money your top priority.

If there’s a sliver of “Capitalist pig” in your mind after
reading that, skip the rest of this email and hit unsubscribe at
the bottom.

Goodbye.

Now that all of the purple haired people are gone, let’s talk
money, bo!

On a recent 1-1 call with a new Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh63xlnzu9hzexx633fw/qvh8h7hd46zp8zbl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) member, I broke down the three elements of success in the
digital economy.

When you first start, you have none of the three.

As you progress, you earn your badges and things get a whole lot
easier.

Here’s the breakdown:

1. Skill set

This one’s the most obvious.

Learn a skill that other people find valuable, trade that skill
for money.

This is the prerequisite.

It’s the equivalent of a college degree in the entrepreneur world
(except it actually means something).

As you increase competency, you grow capable of solving bigger
problems that pay better.

Once this foundation is laid, the other two elements unlock…

2. Opportunity vehicle

This is what you’re selling and who you’re selling to.

The best marketer in the world will make no money if their
clients are broke.

On the contrary, apply your skill set the right way (in a growing
industry where people are making lots of money) you’ll be paid in
proportion.

Nail these two, and money starts to rain.

And then, there’s the third which makes everything click…

3. Influence

This is who you know and who knows you.

It could mean attention on social media or even just a network of
the right people.

That’s it.

Skill, vehicle, influence.

Master all three and business becomes unfairly easy.

Ignore even one… and you’ll feel like you’re a stripper without
rhythm. Or an ass.

So here’s the move:

Audit yourself.

What’s missing?

What’s the next smallest move to fix it?

For me, working with course sellers was the unlock.

Skillset? Check — copywriting and funnel building were finally
being put to good use.

Vehicle? Check — these creators had leverage, audience, and cash
flow.

Influence? Check — proximity to high-level operators opened more
doors than I could count.

It was the rare overlap of all 3 elements.

And once I leaned in, everything changed.

If you’re still trying to force something that doesn’t check all
three boxes…

​Maybe it’s time to pivot. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh63xlnzu9hzexx633fw/qvh8h7hd46zp8zbl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh63xlnzu9hzexx633fw
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh63xlnzu9hzexx633fw
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205
