subject: Still interested in the 911 Turbo S?
body:
What’s the difference between a Porsche 911 Carrera and a Turbo
S?

From the outside, they look almost identical.

Only car nerds can tell the difference.

But the Turbo S will cost you over $100k more than the Carrera.

Why would someone pay six figures more for a model that only
impresses car nerds?

They give you a handjob at the dealership when you get the Turbo
S.

The engine.

640 horsepower vs. 379.

0-60 mph in 2.4 seconds vs 4.0.

The Turbo S is a supercar. The Carrera is a nice daily.

From ten feet away you’d never know.

But the second you hit the gas?

The Turbo S launches.

The Carrera just… moves.

That’s the power of what’s under the hood.

In the coaching space, your product is your engine.

And most people forget about it.

A good product means sexier marketing.

Your testimonials are your rims, wheels, and headlights.

You can coast with a shit product…

Until you floor it next to someone with real horsepower.

Then you blow up.

Artisan Lab is finally to the point where it feels like a V10.

When I started coaching, it was just a private group and a few
calls.

I let in 20 people and used it as a test run.

Took the feedback.

Built out a full course.

Rebranded it from The Bader Group to Artisan Lab.

That’s where most people stop.

They build the course, toss in some weekly calls, and shift all
attention to marketing.

But here’s the truth:

If your product isn’t improving, it’s deteriorating.

So I kept going:

* I update the content constantly based on where people get stuck
* Every call is recorded and labeled inside a searchable vault
* I bring in 7–8 figure entrepreneurs twice a month for guest
sessions
* I paid one of my star students to build an outreach course, and
my sales guy to build a sales management course
* Sean — one of the best marketers I know — runs weekly calls and
offers 1-1 support
* And as of yesterday, Jace (you’ve probably seen him in a
testimonial) is now running an additional weekly group call

Here’s the current engine:

Content – funnels, copywriting, sales, acquisition, personal
brand & everything in between

1-1 Support – from me and Sean

Active 24/7 Community – no idiots allowed, only winners

Coaching – 3 weekly calls, led by me, Sean, and Jace (plus
bi-weekly guest calls)

Plus plug and play SOPs, frameworks, and all the other more
boring stuff...

This has inadvertently turned into a pitch.

But that’s kinda the point.

When your product is actually good, you don’t need to force a
transition or do some weird NLP sales voodoo.

You just talk about it.

Because you’re proud of the engine you’ve built.

​Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh633kk9b9hzexx633fw/48hvhehmp06834bx/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) is the engine.

Everything else is just the body kit.

And if you want to go fast, you’re gonna need something under the
hood that doesn’t explode when it gets on the highway.

​Apply here if you want to build your own Turbo S. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh633kk9b9hzexx633fw/48hvhehmp06834bx/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Not a Corolla with a spoiler (or God forbid a corvette C8).

Ben

​
​
​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh633kk9b9hzexx633fw
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh633kk9b9hzexx633fw
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: How to get a client in the next 7 days
body:
Idleness is the root of suffering.

That’s it.

Maybe that’s what the Buddha meant to say too but it got lost in
translation.

The life changes you think will make you happy?

Illusions.

You're convinced the issue is your job, your city, your
relationship, or your (smol) bank account.

But it's not.

You feel like shit because you're stagnant.

The human mind wasn't designed to be still.

You were designed to hunt, build, pursue, do.

When you stop moving, that energy has nowhere to go, so it turns
inward.

Next thing you know, you’ll be a depressed 47 year old, substance
addicted, beer-bellied, bitter, man-child. And your wife will
beat you.

Is that what you want?

I doubt it.

The voice in your mind that's constantly displeased gets quiet
when you start moving.

Action is the only answer.

Even when you don't know where to go, what to do, and you feel
like you're in over your head.

You can’t think your way out of a rut.

You have to move your way out.

That’s the whole game.

Ben

P.S. I Just dropped a ​new video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlok7wwurh8gxxv99bm/58hvh7hgnm7zq2a6/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vR0N1TVpv
)​ with two members in Artisan Lab.

They quit their jobs. Got their first client in a week. Now doing
$30K/month.

It’s simple this is when you take action Check it out. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlok7wwurh8gxxv99bm/58hvh7hgnm7zq2a6/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vR0N1TVpv
)​

subject: Be more impulsive
body:
Good morning and happy Monday.

A man in his mid-30’s just walked by me in a button down and tie
that looked like it was choking the life out of him.

I assume he’s on his way to the office.

And once again, I’m reminded to be grateful for my impulsiveness.

I remember the exact moment I decided not to be a wagie slave for
the rest of my existence.

There I was, in my sophomore year of college at frat party #397
of the semester.

As I drunkenly looked around at everyone having fun, I thought to
myself “yeah, no thanks.”

Here’s a picture from that night:

​
The next day I started planning my escape.

I’m gonna drop out and move to Mexico once the semester is up.

It was a decision I made on a whim… kinda.

Sometimes impulsivity is the only way things actually happen.

There’d been a lingering voice in my head for a while.

And deep down, I always knew that the “can I take a vacation
please?” route wasn’t for me.

But it’s not official until it’s official.

Once I made a legitimate decision, unenrolled in classes, and
booked my flight to Tulum, it became real.

It was no longer a lingering thought — and my life changed for
the better.

So, what’s going on in your life that you know isn’t in alignment
with your soul?

It could be as grand as your career path or as small as your
social media addiction.

You know it needs to change and you keep telling yourself it
will.

But when?

That’s the million dollar question.

When the universe sends you a perfectly-timed, arbitrary wake-up
call?

Maybe.

Or maybe a month, a year, 10 years, or… never?

Maybe you need to be more impulsive. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhv3k070bghv4xx8llh9/n2hohvhvx62ekzc6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

​
I know this “us vs. the system" angle is incredibly overused and
if you want to be a normie, I’m not judging you.

But know there will probably come a time when you, too, are
wearing a button down and tie that’s way too tight on you and
some asshole kid writes an email about it.

And maybe the voice in your head that knows better will linger
forever.

Unless you act on it.

See you at the office, bo!

Ben

P.S. My calendar for Artisan Lab was full over the weekend so if
you tried to book and couldn’t I’m sorry. I opened it back up, so
you can apply here and book in now. (

)​

subject: Put lipstick on a pig with AI
body:
I officially became a nerd yesterday.

I went through what can be described as a business-tracking
crisis.

What doesn’t get tracked doesn’t improve – and I realized my
tracking is meh.

Frantically, I began building automations, SOP’s, and Google
Sheets.

I typically hate doing this type of stuff.

It feels like listening to a Miami girl talk about astrology,
minus the lip filler and silicone.

Painful.

But yesterday, I powered through it.

I set up new zaps, built a Slack channel, and made a tracking
sheet for my Artisan Lab members.

The sheet was the hardest of it all.

It required complex formulas and I’m a college dropout. Not a
good combo, typically.

But I had a cheat code.

Any time I got stuck, I’d turn to AI.

“Hello, my Glorious KingGPT. How do I sum an itemized list based
on certain criteria? Plz reply. Thx ily.”

AI would then give me the exact formula to plug in.

I’d follow its instructions.

And if anything broke, I’d simply take a screenshot and ask it
what went wrong.

With AI’s help, the sheet took me around 30 minutes to build.

Without it, it would’ve taken hours or I would’ve quit.

It also saved me time after a sales call yesterday.

My “AI Companion” joined my Zoom meeting with me.

The word companion makes me think of dogs, so I named him Buddy.

After the call, Buddy sent me a summary of everything we talked
about with a detailed plan outlining the next steps.

Simple things like this have been saving me hours.

Everyone (myself included) talks about writing copy with AI
because it sounds sexy.

But what might be even cooler, is it makes the boring stuff
easier.

Unless you had a Minecraft addiction and were nonverbal in groups
larger than 2 growing up, you probably hate automations,
tracking, and summarizing data.

AI makes this way less painful.

Don’t overlook using it to improve your workflow, outside of
writing copy.

That’s only the tip of the iceberg.

I break all this down (and more) for my coaching clients.

If you're building an info-product agency and want to save time,
make more money, and not cry while setting up Zapier... apply
here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h56p0x6bohp6ddokkh9/kkhmh6hn5m43e4sl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Gonna go play with Buddy,

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: How I escaped the guru hamster wheel
body:
“I just wanna make $5k per month,” I thought to myself.

It’s January 1st, 2020.

I’m sitting in my childhood bedroom with 6 Youtube tabs open on
my laptop.

One’s a dropshipping video, another’s about SMMA.

The rest are random business models I found on ads along the way.

This is what one may call shiny object syndrome maxxing.

I know something can work…

These gurus claim to be making so much money online.

I don’t completely trust them, but there has to be some level of
truth to it.

And they can’t be that much smarter than me, right?

I might not be the next Einstein, but I’m definitely not a
complete idiot.

And dedication isn’t the problem… I’m willing to work hard.

The problem is, I need to find the right outlet to channel my
ambition.

$5k per month. That’s all I need.

I’ll get my own apartment and have enough money for food and juul
pods.

What more does a 19 year old kid need?

Ok, maybe I’ll get a used 911 too.

But fuck, where do I start?

My head is beginning to hurt from all of the “best online
business model of 2020” videos.

There’s no way there are 36 “best” business models.

35 of you guys are lying.

I just need to find the one who’s telling the truth…

Or maybe the one that’s best for me…

Or maybe I shouldn’t drop out of colle– FUCK!

I can’t keep doing this.

I need to pick something and stick to it.

If I get burned by a guru, so be it – I’d rather go down
swinging.

Fast forward about a year, I’m… at the plate, you could say.

Not hitting much, but at least I’m trying.

I’ve now started a videography business, dropshipping store, ad
creative agency and high ticket sales…

Aaaand I’m still poor.

The previous handful of business attempts have beaten the idiot
out of me.

I’m ready to go all in on one thing…

Lead generation agency. For basketball trainers.

Good idea? No.

Good mindset? Yes.

Although it wasn’t the “best” business model I could’ve picked,
it began to work.

I stuck with it for over a year.

$5k months – check.

Drop out of college – check.

I moved to Mexico, kept building, and hit $10k months.

And then…

I stumbled into a much better way to make money online that
didn’t require me to beg broke people for $1k retainers.

So, here I am now.

The same kid who wrote this journal entry on January 8, 2021…

“I am lost… Do I want to start an agency? Do I want to be a
closer? Should I say fuck it and try something else? Do I need to
go back to school?”

This one’s getting long so I’ll leave you with this:

Close your Youtube tabs.

Pick one thing.

The best business model is the one you pick and commit to.

​I’ll help you here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpdwk30c5h2833kllfn/z2hghnhek00gw5fp/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpdwk30c5h2833kllfn
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpdwk30c5h2833kllfn
) | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: You're a millionaire
body:
I became a millionaire on paper about a year ago.

That didn’t really register until last week.

I looked at some numbers, thought “huh, that’s neat,” and went
back to scrolling Instagram.

A few years ago, that number felt like a pipe dream.

It was my endgame.

Now everyone and their grandma is a “millionaire” (at least in
YouTube thumbnails).

The pedestal disappears once you’re standing on it.

~A millionaire~

Such a broad term.

Someone making $100k/yr with a Saas can convince themselves
they’re a millionaire based on a hypothetical valuation of their
company.

That’s very different from someone with $5m liquid.

Most people are “millionaires” the same way someone’s a “business
owner” because they open an LLC.

Definitions get blurry when everyone starts flexing.

But really, the goal is to forget along the way.

Be so locked in on your vision, stacking cash and then one day
you realize you “made it.”

But by then, your idea of making it will have evolved a dozen
times and you’ll feel poor.

That’s where I’m at.

I know this reads like a humble brag, but I’m 24 – it’s really
not that impressive.

However, the 20 year old version of me who was just getting
started in online business would think it’s pretty cool.

Back then I didn’t fully believe any of this was possible.

Millionaire? Maybe one day.

But I just wanted to make enough money so that I didn’t have to
ask some dickhead for a day off.

“S..sss…Sir… I’m not feeling too well, can I—”

I’d rather sell my body on OF.

Anyway, it works.

This vision that plays in the back of your mind is real.

Not every guru is trying to fuck you over.

There are people just like you (and probably much dumber) who’ve
actualized their goals.

Stop listening to the sliver of doubt that creeps into your mind
whenever you’re about to take a leap.

​Just jump. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h25ggmdsqhpnkk733hr/e0hph7h7l6q3wqf8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

You’ll grow your wings on the way down…

And one day, you’ll look up and realize you did it.

But by then, it’ll feel normal – and you’ll know you’ve got so
much further to go.

Or you can ignore everything I said and just keep watching other
people win:

​
(that one's crazy ⬆)

​

​
​Up to you. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h25ggmdsqhpnkk733hr/e0hph7h7l6q3wqf8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

​
​

subject: Just move
body:
It’s 9:39am on a sunny Monday in Miami.

I just opened a Google doc to write to you.

Actually, that was a lie.

I’ve had this page open for about 20 minutes but I kept
distracting myself.

So now, my other tabs are closed and my phone is on DND.

Good morning, friend.

Today is one of those days where I just don’t want to do this.

But I know that if I succumb to that emotion, the rest of my day
will be even worse.

That is how losers are created – and I’m too blessed to be a
loser today.

If there’s one word that defines the lesser type, it’d be idle.

I’ve been there.

Waiting for inspiration to take action.

Thinking someone or something is gonna come to save me.

My foot would hover over the gas pedal, teasing the idea of
pressing down.

Some nights I’d even find a burst of inspiration after stumbling
down a YouTube rabbithole.

I’d swear that tomorrow would be the day everything changed.

But when morning came, I’d freeze again.

Scared of what might happen if I actually picked up speed.

Every time I got close to jumping, I bitched out.

And even when I did jump, I'd revert back to my old self the
second the excitement wore off.

This type of idleness is a surefire way to guarantee misery.

I’d rather be ignorant and oblivious than aware and idle.

Awareness without action is self-inflicted torture.

Desire sits in your soul for a reason.

When you want it badly enough to begin moving toward it, that
means you were destined to have it.

But you sit there…

Overthinking, waiting, and making excuses.

You let fear and doubt scramble your brain while life passes you
by.

The truth is – smart people don’t contemplate every move.

They’re smart enough to know what thoughts they shouldn’t listen
to.

At some point, as the great philosopher Socrates once said, “Fuck
it, we ball.”

Feel the fear.

subject: Just move
body:
It’s 9:39am on a sunny Monday in Miami.

 I just opened a Google doc to write to you.

 Actually, that was a lie.

 I’ve had this page open for about 20 minutes but I kept distracting myself.

 So now, my other tabs are closed and my phone is on DND.

 Good morning, {{ first_name | default: "friend" }}.

 Today is one of those days where I just don’t want to do this.

 But I know that if I succumb to that emotion, the rest of my day will be even worse.

 That is how losers are created – and I’m too blessed to be a loser today.

 If there’s one word that defines the lesser type, it’d be idle.

 I’ve been there.

 Waiting for inspiration to take action.

 Thinking someone or something is gonna come to save me.

 My foot would hover over the gas pedal, teasing the idea of pressing down.

 Some nights I’d even find a burst of inspiration after stumbling down a YouTube rabbithole.

 I’d swear that tomorrow would be the day everything changed.

 But when morning came, I’d freeze again.

 Scared of what might happen if I actually picked up speed.

 Every time I got close to jumping, I bitched out.

 And even when I did jump, I'd revert back to my old self the second the excitement wore off.

 This type of idleness is a surefire way to guarantee misery.

 I’d rather be ignorant and oblivious than aware and idle.

 Awareness without action is self-inflicted torture.

 Desire sits in your soul for a reason.

 When you want it badly enough to begin moving toward it, that means you were destined to have it.

 But you sit there…

 Overthinking, waiting, and making excuses.

 You let fear and doubt scramble your brain while life passes you by.

 The truth is – smart people don’t contemplate every move.

 They’re smart enough to know what thoughts they shouldn’t listen to.

 At some point, as the great philosopher Socrates once said, “Fuck it, we ball.”

 Feel the fear.

 ​ Hit the gas. ​

 And trust that you'll figure it out before you crash into a tree.

 Idleness is death,

 Ben

subject: "yOuR nEtwoRk iS yoUr NetWorTh"
body:
My least favorite word in the English dictionary is “networking.”

No brother, I do not want to connect for a virtual coffee.

That said, building a tribe of like-minded friends has been a big
reason I’ve succeeded.

When I first started taking online business seriously, I was
living in a frat house.

Most of my friends were supportive but they didn’t necessarily
get it.

I distinctly remember a conversation I had with a childhood
friend when I was home for the summer.

He was as skeptical as they come.

We went back and forth as he tried to poke holes in my plan and
deter me.

By the end of the conversation, he was angry.

The idea of me following a different path made him bitter.

Eventually, I just stopped trying to explain it to him.

Most of my closest friends now are people I met in coaching
programs or social media.

We’re all on the same path.

We push each other.

We’re not “networking,” we’re building together.

And occasionally that means we spend five figures on bottles at
LIV like it’s a tax write-off (it is).

So as corny as the “your network is your net worth” saying is…

It’s fairly accurate.

If you have no one to turn to when shit gets tough, you’re more
likely to talk yourself out of action.

Your standards come from proximity.

Surrounding yourself with people who make you feel like you’re
behind brings the best out of you.

Because deep down…

You know your idiot friend who fell in love with a stripper isn’t
smarter than you.

He’s just moving faster.

That’s why I built Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h52zmqzilhovxx277u8/kkhmh6hn5qpq45bl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

It’s not just about learning how to land a client or scale an
offer.

It’s about being in the right room where the standard is getting
results like this:

​

​

​
If you want to "level up your network" without chanting

We’re just getting warmed up.

Ben

subject: Boooringg
body:
I’ve been enjoying the boring stuff more recently.

Automations, SOP’s, and Google sheets have always been a fear of
mine.

The people who talk about these things online are always so
nerdy.

This made me think that building proper systems would turn me
into a virgin with blue light blockers glued to my face.

Luckily, that didn’t happen.

My systems have always been “good enough” but not great.

I relied heavily on the more fun side of the equation – content,
angles, offers, etc.

But what I’m realizing now more than ever, is that the boring
stuff makes the fun stuff funner.

Scaling feels better when you’re building on a solid foundation.

When your foundation is solid and your numbers are clear, your
bottlenecks become creative puzzles, not existential threats.

This stuff feels so miniscule but if you neglect it for too long,
it can burn down your business.

Most info-sellers build a course, set up a community, hire
coaches and call it a day.

It’s fine to start, but it must evolve.

Your product is a living, breathing organism.

If you’re not building systems that make it easier for members to
succeed.

And you don’t use tools to speed up their learning curve…

You’re simply being negligent.

Access will always be the core of the product, but why not use
tools to make everything else more efficient?

This is what I’m doing with Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlormvoarh8gxxv99bm/48hvhehmpd3zwqux/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

I began to think about what AI will do to online education and
realized…

We are not far away from a time where a non-AI powered product is
obsolete.

It’ll be like using a blackberry in 2025.

You’re a dinosaur.

Yes, the product is “boring.”

Yes, the systems are tedious.

But they’re part of the foundation.

And a solid foundation frees up your brain to go all-in on the
fun shit.

Content. Offers. Funnels. Vision.

Your program becomes something that doesn’t just look good… but
runs good.

And that’s why I put on my nerd hat and started building.

Because AI will make all this shit a necessity.

​Adapt or die. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlormvoarh8gxxv99bm/48hvhehmpd3zwqux/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​
​
​

​

subject: Why SMMA sucks
body:
I hate people.

Let me rephrase that:

I hate annoying people.

I hate managing people.

I hate babysitting people.

Despite these factors, I began my entrepreneurial career in the
SMMA space charging $1k monthly retainers.

This meant I had to get lots of clients and deal with lots of
people to make money.

But I was hungry enough to make it work.

After about a year, I was making around $15k/mo… with 15 clients.

In total, I worked with over 50 clients during that run.

That’s a lot of people for someone who hates people!

And every day, I’d wake up to fires…

Clients complaining, breaching our three month agreement, or
trying to add on services that were completely out of scope.

(Maybe the reason you’re not getting results is because you
haven’t replied to the 136 leads I’ve gotten you. And no, I will
not throw in email marketing for your baby mama’s nail salon).

I knew there had to be a better model.

Fewer clients, less churn, and more predictability.

And I’d finally discard the exhausting, ever present thought of
“this could burn down at any moment.”

My goal -- make $15k/mo with no more than 5 clients.

That’s when I started shifting to info-product businesses.

My first client was an online basketball trainer.

I sent him a voice memo offering to help with his funnel.

A few days later, I was on a call with his business partner.

I didn’t have a fancy pitch, I just told them I’d help however I
could.

Funnels, ads, email copy… I just wanted out of SMMA.

They brought me on to run ads.

I charged $1k/mo (I knew no better) and 10% of return on ad
spend.

That first month, they paid me $2,351 just from the rev share.

That was 2.35x more than I was used to.

This was the lightbulb moment.

Why was I still begging for $1k retainers when I could just get…
better clients?

I imagine this is how the man who invented sliced bread felt.

I’m a genius!

Five months later, I’d dropped nearly all of my SMMA clients.

Now I had five instead of 15, and made $16,290 that month.

I hit $25k two months later.

And $100k/mo a year after that, with just seven clients.

No chaos.

No babysitting.

The problem was never my skill set.

It was the vehicle.

And this is the one (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhv308krbghvq080llf9/owhkhqhw62eegztv/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) that finally worked.

Ben

​
​
​
​

​

) | Update your profile (

subject: Why you CAN trust strangers on the internet
body:
Is internet money actually real?

This question sat in the back of my mind for a while.

I wanted to believe it was real, but I had no first-hand data.

The guys I watched on Youtube sounded legit, but they’re still
strangers on the internet.

When I was little, I talked to “Megan Fox” on Facebook.

That’s how I learned to not trust strangers on the internet.

But sometimes, it’s not all bad.

Sometimes, talking to a stranger on the internet might make you
rich.

One of my first Artisan Lab members was this 18 year old kid
named Tomy.

Unlike most members, he had basically zero experience online.

I actually got a little annoyed with my closer when he joined
because I thought this might be too overwhelming for him.

Artisan Lab was brand new and not yet “beginner-proof.”

This was Tomy’s intro message when he joined:

​
I hopped on a 1-1 with him and gave him a roadmap.

To my surprise, he began following it to a T.

He showed up to every call, asked questions, kept me updated, and
even started posting on Twitter.

“This mf has that DAWG in him,” I thought to myself.

Despite this, he still struggled for a bit.

He dealt with a few crappy clients but finally found a solid one.

That client scaled to $50k/mo in just a few months.

And Tomy actually paid off Artisan Lab with the money he made
from that.

(I wouldn’t recommend doing this but like I said – Tomy is a
DAWG).

Yesterday, he posted a win inside the community that made me
smile like a serial killer.

​
It took him about 9 months.

From complete beginner, to his first $10k month.

That might not sound super sexy in a world where everyone
promises you “$10k/mo in 3 months or you don’t pay.”

That’s all bulshit.

When you’re completely new, you have to accept that it’s gonna be
a long, bumpy road in the beginning.

But when you get over that hump, things get fun.

And I’m excited to see how quickly Tomy is able to scale from
here.

Typically, the business that gets you to your first $10k/month
can’t take you much farther beyond that.

That’s not the case here.

The hardest part is over, and now he just has to double down.

Tomy, I’m proud of you bro.

And if you’re like him and you have that DAWG in you…

​Here, I’ll give you the same roadmap I gave him. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhx506nnu6h6pw5wgghl/8ghqhoho2r864guk/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

​

​

) | Update your profile (

subject: I <3 Whales
body:
Good morning.

It’s a sunny Monday in Miami.

I’m sitting outside of Starbucks thinking about how much I hate
outbound.

To put it bluntly — Trying to get clients absolutely blows dick
at first.

I spent my first two years in business on a client hamster wheel.

I’d send dozens of pitches.

Get on a few sales calls.

Close a couple clients.

And then most would leave after a few months.

The cycle then continued…

Until I found the Info-Agency model.

I started getting clients on rev shares which meant I could make
more money without getting more clients.

Instead I could just make them more money.

Pretty cool.

The best part is, this makes it easier to get clients.

After all, you don’t want to be DMing strangers, begging for a
crum of money forever.

You’d rather have them come to you.

The only way to do that, is to be someone others talk about.

And the only way to do that, is to get clients insane results.

(Which you’re incentivized to do when you have a rev share).

Here’s how this plays out:

The other day, I was at lunch with my friends Phillip and Jace
(both are members in Artisan Lab).

They told me how they had too many prospects wanting to work with
them and not enough bandwidth.

Both are working with whale clients only right now.

Jace has a single client paying him 6 figures in a month.

And Phillip’s smallest client paid him $30k last month.

Because they’re getting such good results, word spreads and they
have prospects lining up to work with them.

They don’t have to slide in DMs.

They don’t have to send hundreds of cold emails.

And they don’t have to deal with clients churning every month.

This is the difference between chasing clients… and *attracting
them.*

When you finally make that shift, business gets fun again.

The money's better.

The stress is lower.

And you’re perceived as a partner rather than a service provider.

If that’s what you want, Artisan Lab was built for you. (

subject: I <3 Whales
body:
Good morning.

 It’s a sunny Monday in Miami.

 I’m sitting outside of Starbucks thinking about how much I hate outbound.

 To put it bluntly — Trying to get clients absolutely blows dick at first.

 I spent my first two years in business on a client hamster wheel.

 I’d send dozens of pitches.

 Get on a few sales calls.

 Close a couple clients.

 And then most would leave after a few months.

 The cycle then continued…

 Until I found the Info-Agency model.

 I started getting clients on rev shares which meant I could make more money without getting more clients.

 Instead I could just make them more money.

 Pretty cool.

 The best part is, this makes it easier to get clients.

 After all, you don’t want to be DMing strangers, begging for a crum of money forever.

 You’d rather have them come to you.

 The only way to do that, is to be someone others talk about.

 And the only way to do that, is to get clients insane results.

 (Which you’re incentivized to do when you have a rev share).

 Here’s how this plays out:

 The other day, I was at lunch with my friends Phillip and Jace (both are members in Artisan Lab).

 They told me how they had too many prospects wanting to work with them and not enough bandwidth.

 Both are working with whale clients only right now.

 Jace has a single client paying him 6 figures in a month.

 And Phillip’s smallest client paid him $30k last month.

 Because they’re getting such good results, word spreads and they have prospects lining up to work with them.

 They don’t have to slide in DMs.

 They don’t have to send hundreds of cold emails.

 And they don’t have to deal with clients churning every month.

 This is the difference between chasing clients… and *attracting them.*

 When you finally make that shift, business gets fun again.

 The money's better. 

 The stress is lower.

 And you’re perceived as a partner rather than a service provider.

 If that’s what you want, Artisan Lab was built for you. ​

 I’ll help you land your first whale and keep ‘em forever.

 Ben

 ​
​
​

subject: I got a penthouse
body:
Goooood morning bo.

Here’s an unsolicited POV from my new penthouse in Miami:

​
I moved in yesterday and let me tell ya…

Moving sucks.

However, it gave me the opportunity to be a customer and client –
which is fun for me as a business owner.

I’m able to observe what it’s like from the other side.

I hired this moving company called “Piece Of Cake Moving.”

There’s a copywriting lesson in the name itself.

They have big pink trucks that stick out like an OF girl in a
church.

A quick Google search told me that this is a big company.

They have over 350 trucks, employ 800+ people, and handle over
100,000 moves a year.

This has made Mr. Piece Of Cake, a rich man – they made over
$100m in 203.

And after they helped me move, I can see why.

They were at the top of my Google search, so I clicked and filled
out a form outlining the items I had to move.

A few minutes later I had a quote for $450.

I didn’t have a ton of stuff but I had them pack it all up too,
so I found this to be incredibly cheap.

Appointment scheduled.

They followed up with me over the next couple of days, sent all
the insurance forms, and arrived on time.

My main mover was named Jason.

He now is the primary beneficiary in my will.

We coordinated everything and it was about as smooth and easy as
can be.

I ended up having extra items that I didn’t list in the initial
itinerary and he threw them in for me.

He moved everything, unpacked, and rearranged furniture in the
new place (which was outside of the job description).

Lastly, I had a few things that I was gonna take to a storage
unit after the move.

I mentioned this and he offered to take those items and meet me
over at the unit.

After all this, I ended up tipping him more than I paid for the
move.

This is what success looks like – both as a business and an
employee.

When you scale, attention to detail is everything.

Minor sloppiness creates huge problems when you have 350 pink
trucks around the globe.

My booking process was easy and the movers actually cared.

Jason went above and beyond to the point where I wrote an entire
email about it.

This sounds like a Yelp review from someone with far too much
time on their hands.

But as a business owner, it’s a great lesson.

If my customer experience was this good, on what was probably one
of their lowest ticket moves…

When they have 800+ employees…

Just imagine the level of attention to detail and care that the
CEO must have.

If your product isn’t so good that customers want to become your
marketing…

You’ve still got work to do.

And when you’re the one delivering a service?

Go above and beyond.

​Become the Jason of info-products here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh2pr523hkhklg5g99h3/25h2hoh3gv7lz6b3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​
​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh2pr523hkhklg5g99h3
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh2pr523hkhklg5g99h3
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: This is hard to do...
body:
In October 2021, I hit my first $10k month.

A year later, I hit $30k per month.

And 11 months after that, I hit my first $100k month.

That may sound like a relatively fast journey, but here’s what’s
not visible in those metrics:

Before I made any money, I wasted a year contemplating whether
this online business thing was actually real.

Even once I started taking action, it took me another year and a
half to get to $10k/mo.

So really, here’s how it went:

0-$10k, 2.5 years.

$10k-$30k, 1 year.

$30k-$100k, 11 months.

Without a doubt, the hardest and longest (pause) part was the
beginning.

I can viscerally remember how frustrated I’d get when seeing a
“0-$10k/mo in 30 days” case study.

“That [redacted] can’t be smarter than me,” I thought.

But here’s what I’ve realized:

Headlines and Youtube titles never tell the full story.

Yeah, they get clicks. And yeah, that’s part of the game.

But they rarely show you the late nights, identity crises, and
full-blown mental spirals it took to get there.

“He hit $50k/mo in 3 months” sounds a hell of a lot better than
“He finally hit $50k after spending three years depressed, lost,
and considering accepting the sugar baby offer in his DMs.”

But I’ll give it to you straight.

This game is difficult because you have to reprogram your
hardwiring.

You’ll get discouraged, distracted, almost quit, feel like an
idiot, and then…

Magic happens.

I was reminded of all this yesterday when I sat down with Heik —
one of the guys inside AL.

He joined six months ago making $2k/month.

Today, he’s doing $10k/month and just flew from Germany to Miami
to meet with clients.

His journey wasn’t linear or smooth.

But he stuck it out – even when it felt like nothing was
clicking.

I wanted to share our convo (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh63egexf9hz5d6d33cw/vqh3hrho4vprxrug/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vbFBmY3lp
) with you, not because Heik’s some unicorn…

But because his story is one you might see yourself in.

The first $10k always takes the longest.

But after that, the game gets fun.

​Watch the interview here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh63egexf9hz5d6d33cw/vqh3hrho4vprxrug/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vbFBmY3lp
)​

Ben

​
​
​

 A year later, I hit $30k per month.

 And 11 months after that, I hit my first $100k month.

 That may sound like a relatively fast journey, but here’s what’s not visible in those metrics:

 Before I made any money, I wasted a year contemplating whether this online business thing was actually real.

 Even once I started taking action, it took me another year and a half to get to $10k/mo.

 So really, here’s how it went:

 0-$10k, 2.5 years.

 $10k-$30k, 1 year.

 $30k-$100k, 11 months.

 I can viscerally remember how frustrated I’d get when seeing a “0-$10k/mo in 30 days” case study.

 “That [redacted] can’t be smarter than me,” I thought.

 But here’s what I’ve realized:

 Headlines and Youtube titles never tell the full story.

 Yeah, they get clicks. And yeah, that’s part of the game.

 But they rarely show you the late nights, identity crises, and full-blown mental spirals it took to get there.

 “He hit $50k/mo in 3 months” sounds a hell of a lot better than “He finally hit $50k after spending three years depressed, lost, and considering accepting the sugar baby offer in his DMs.”

 But I’ll give it to you straight.

 This game is difficult because you have to reprogram your hardwiring.

 You’ll get discouraged, distracted, almost quit, feel like an idiot, and then…

 Magic happens.

 I was reminded of all this yesterday when I sat down with Heik — one of the guys inside AL.

 He joined six months ago making $2k/month.

 Today, he’s doing $10k/month and just flew from Germany to Miami to meet with clients.

 His journey wasn’t linear or smooth.

 But he stuck it out – even when it felt like nothing was clicking.

 I wanted to share our convo with you, not because Heik’s some unicorn…

 But because his story is one you might see yourself in.

 The first $10k always takes the longest.

 But after that, the game gets fun.

 ​ Watch the interview here. ​

 Ben

subject: Inertia and hangovers
body:
I have a slight hangover but it was for a good cause…

We celebrated Cardinal Mason’s 26th birthday last night and I
don’t recall much after midnight.

Hence the later email today.

Anyway, I’ve been enjoying business a lot recently.

A few clients are ripping. Artisan Lab is scaling. Members are
crushing.

And the best part of all – work doesn’t feel like a chore.

Most of 2024, I wasn’t very engaged in my businesses.

For the two years before that, almost all I did was work.

This was great to build a foundation but life just felt dull
after a while.

Why would I make more money if I don’t know how to spend it?

So, I learned how to make tens of thousands of dollars disappear.
Fast.

But I’m out of coast mode now.

I feel more in control of my business, and there’s this level of
fulfillment that’s met by forward progress.

Scaling feels like creative problem solving rather than an
intimidating headache.

Instead of dreading calls and items on my to do list, I look
forward to (most of) them.

I like sitting down at my desk.

It’d been a while since I had this type of energy and I forgot
how incredible it is.

So, if you’re in an era where opening your laptop feels
equivalent to being stuck in a closet with Lizzo…

Here’s my advice to you:

First – you have to really try.

Profound, right?

Seriously though, it might just be difficult because you're not
building any momentum.

Get organized, take some baby steps, and see where you’re at in a
week.

For 95% of people reading this, that’s the fix.

But if you’re where I was, and you can’t even bear the thought of
work…

You have to shake the snowglobe.

I am advising you to crash out (potentially).

Move to a new city, change up your routine, spend more money, try
new hobbies, do ayahuasca in a forest… idk just do something
different.

Follow your natural curiosity.

I don’t know if this is sound advice, but it worked for me.

I had to sidequest-maxx to show myself how fun life can be.

This made it feel like clicking buttons in exchange for a larger
number on a screen is worth it again.

Now, quick disclaimer:

Do not take this as an excuse to crash out because you’re
avoiding sending outbound messages.

There will always be parts of business that aren’t fun.

Sometimes the answer is to power through.

There are always parts of business that suck.

But here’s the truth:

Inertia = resistance to change.

An object at rest stays at rest. An object in motion stays in
motion.

So if you’re stuck…

​Just start moving. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhkrz3wvbphwzgng00f6/25h2hoh3gg2o79f3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​
​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhkrz3wvbphwzgng00f6
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhkrz3wvbphwzgng00f6

subject: My first chargeback = your $500 discount
body:
It's pouring rain in Miami.

I ordered coffee to my door to avoid walking in such a
treacherous condition.

David Goggins would have a temper tantrum reading that.

Anyway, I lost my virginity the other day…

I got my first ever chargeback on Artisan Lab.

After 160 happy customers, it happened.

This really pissed me off...

I take pride in the quality of members that we allow inside.

AL is more close knit than most info-products and I talk to many
of the members on a daily basis.

Because of this, I don’t let stupid people in.

Dealing with “the stupids” makes me feel like a camp counselor
running around with a bunch of snotty children.

I’m too pretentious for that.

I’d rather make less money and protect the aura inside my
program.

But this time, I was deceived.

My community was infiltrated by someone who should’ve been
sitting on the stairs outside the club with vodka spilled on his
shirt after getting denied at the door.

Here’s what happened:

George (not his real name) applied for AL about a month ago.

The calendar was full at the time he applied, so he sent me an
email saying “I want to give you money” (yes that’s a direct
quote).

He got connected with my team and got on a call.

Initially it looked like a good fit – he was newer to the agency
world but seemed to have his head screwed on straight.

We offered him a spot and he joined.

The next day he hopped on a 1-1 with Sean, one of my coaches
inside.

No red flags yet.

A few days later, I had an hour-long 1-1 call with him.

He expressed some doubt, so I walked him through everything that
he’d need to do step-by-step.

By the end of our call, he was incredibly thankful and appeared
motivated.

I had faith in him.

The next day, he said he had a change of heart and requested a
refund.

He’d been in the community for a little under a week, hopped on
two 1-1 calls and two group calls.

At that point it’s as if he’d eaten three quarters of a sandwich
and tried to send it back.

I have a strict no refund policy, but being the reasonable person
I am, I offered him a partial refund anyway.

He declined and opened a dispute three weeks later.

Here’s why I’m telling you all this:

George is not an idiot.

He made an investment in himself that could’ve changed the
trajectory of his life for the better.

But he let that scared little voice inside his head talk him out
of it.

I empathize with him, as it’s a voice we all have.

Winners overcome it.

Losers allow it to control them.

So, in honor of George’s swift exit and the restoration of peace
in Artisan Lab…

I’m offering $500 off for anyone reading this who doesn’t flake
on their goals the second things get uncomfortable.

No sob stories.

No refund requests after two 1-1 calls and a panic attack.

Just hungry people who want to win.

If that’s you – reply to this email with “Winner” and I’ll get
you the link to book in with a $500 discount.

You’ve got 24 hours.

Ben

P.S. George – no hard feelings. I found something more your
speed: Careers at McDonalds. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hq7k9wdhmhrn2l2qqt3/kkhmh6hne34mg7sl/aHR0cHM6Ly9jYXJlZXJzLm1jZG9uYWxkcy5jb20v
)​

​
​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hq7k9wdhmhrn2l2qqt3
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hq7k9wdhmhrn2l2qqt3
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: The South Park business model
body:
I began writing a South Park episode in my head last night.

Bear with me for a sec…

Imagine Cartman gets a bad case of “shiny object syndrome.”

Kyle walks into his room…

He’s sitting there with blue-light blockers on and six laptops
open.

Alex Becker on one screen. Iman, Hormozi, Grant Cardone, Tai
Lopez, and Sophie Rain(?) on the others.

Boxes are scattered throughout the room with failed dropshipping
products.

When Kyle tries talking to him he says… “Fuck off you normie
cuck! Go back to your little slave job, I’m escaping the matrix.”

Cartman slams the door so hard that The 4-Hour Workweek falls
from his desk.

He’s “tried” eight different business models in the past six
months.

And although he doesn’t show it, his skepticism grows with each
failed attempt…

“Maybe I’m not cut out for this.”

“I can’t keep wasting time.”

“What if this only works for people with better skills, luck, or
connections?”

Despite the doubt, there’s an inkling of hope underneath it all.

Cartman knows he has the potential.

He knows he’s not a complete idiot.

And he’s willing to work hard.

But he’s directionless and distracted.

He feels like he’s always almost figuring it out.

But almost doesn’t cut it.

Cartman closes five of the six laptops.

“I'm just gonna pick one thing and stick to it,” he thinks to
himself.

That’s when he goes all in.

This time, he’s smart enough to ignore the voice in his head that
attempts to talk him into a different opportunity.

Two weeks later, he’s getting on sales calls.

A couple weeks after that, he gets his first client.

And next thing you know, he’s making $10k/month.

Finally, he’s cured of his shiny object syndrome.

He didn’t need another guru.

He didn’t need another YouTube video.

He didn’t need to optimize his cold plunge routine.

He just needed to make a decision.

And when he finally did, things started happening.

If you’re still stuck cycling through new ideas, hoping the next
one will magically “feel right”…

You’re not looking for the right model.

You’re looking for a way to avoid committing.

​Be like Cartman. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh3e23ogu2hdwnzn66h7/e0hph7h7en5kg6f8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Pick something.

Stick to it.

Anything works, if you work.

Just don’t be like Cartman was in Season 1 – fat, lazy, and
blaming the Jews.

Be Season 26 Cartman:

​
A little older. Slightly wiser.

Still kind of a dick… but finally making money. (

)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

subject: I owe the nerds an apology...
body:
I’m becoming more of what I used to hate.

When AI first came out, I thought it was for dorks.

“HeY acTuAlLy DiD yOu kNoW yoU coULd AuTomAte ThAt wiTh AI.”

Shut up.

To be fair – the only people talking about it were nerdy, boring
agency guys.

And somehow they all lived in Tampa.

But I guess there’s a lesson there…

“Don’t judge a dork by his blue light blockers,” as Socrates once
said.

I use AI on a daily basis, but yesterday I began to realize how
much I’m still underutilizing it.

I need to fully integrate it into everything.

That doesn’t mean replacing my own creativity, just enhancing it.

Repurposing my best ideas, maximizing every input, and increasing
efficiency…

I sound like a nerd but it’s for good reason.

This is the dot com bubble of our generation.

In the internet marketing world, AI and online coaching are the
modern day gold rushes.

Everyone is a coach. And everyone is building a stupid AI tool no
one wants.

While most will fail, there’ll be some big winners.

And those who win, will find their ideas in the trenches.

They’ll be working on an optimization in their business, run into
a problem, realize it’s a common problem in their industry, and
build something that solves it.

Next thing you know you’re Alex Becker and you just sold Hyros
for $100m.

The more I go down the AI rabbithole, the more I’m realizing…

This may be the greatest era of opportunity in my lifetime.

And an afternoon of deep work could result in a nine-figure idea.

In 1994, a VP at a hedge fund noticed the internet was growing at
2,300% per year.

He capitalized on this and started selling books online.

And that little company became something you may have heard of –
Amazon.

“When I’m 80, I want to have minimized the number of regrets. I
knew I might fail, but I also knew I wouldn’t regret trying.” -
Jeff Bezos

Anyway, I say all this not to romanticize tech or pretend I’m the
next Bezos.

But to remind myself (and maybe you too) that
once-in-a-generation windows don’t stay open forever.

You can either keep scrolling, keep judging, keep saying “AI is
cringe”...

​Or you can build. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h535evwulhoqr2r77b8/dpheh0hekqrvklum/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Your call.

Ben

P.S. Somewhat unrelated but funny story:

One time I got denied at the door of a Miami club as the bouncer
told us there’s a high profile celebrity in there and they can’t
let anyone else in.

I jokingly said “who tf is it Lebron James.”

A few moments later, a bald veiny man named Jeff walked out with
his security.

​
​
​

​

subject: I got married to an AI bot
body:
I have a confession…

My agency basically runs on auto-pilot at this point.

We have a small (but dialed) team and a couple really solid
clients.

It’s a great set up.

But due to my lack of involvement in the operations, it’s been a
while since I’ve been in the back-end trenches.

I’m locked in, scaling Artisan Lab – but I started to miss being
the wizard behind the scenes.

Sometimes it’s cooler to be the lazy, fat puppet master than the
puppet.
So a little over a month ago, I had the idea to take on some 1-1
clients.

My goal was to find a few early stage info-businesses I could get
a large stake in.

I posted a call to action on my Instagram story.

Next thing you know, I have what I would describe as a “portfolio
company” if I were trying to impress someone.

I began building the full system for one of these portfolio
clients yesterday.

Quick context – this client just recently started making content.

He built a blue collar business, makes good money doing it, and
is now stepping into guru-world.

As of a few weeks ago, we had nothing but a social media account
with a calendly link in the bio.

I wanted to first see if his audience was ready to buy anything
from him.

We started booking calls and pitched 1-1 coaching.

No course, no community, just calls with my client so we can get
testimonials.

We filled up ten spots way quicker than I anticipated.

Now, we’re building out the course, setting up all the softwares
and backend stuff so we can do a real launch.

This will probably take about a week.

In the meantime, I needed a way to nurture the audience.

I used [an AI tool I won’t disclose publicly until they give me
better affiliate terms] to make a free lead magnet…

I took five of my clients' videos, the software transcribed them,
and I was done in 30 seconds.

It gave me a full 12 page breakdown of the business model and my
client’s journey.

Then I went over to my friend Chat GPT.

I made a new project, gave it the PDF, and asked it to write the
copy for the opt-in page.

Done in 10 seconds.

I threw the copy on a landing page and now I just need to write a
welcome sequence…

[Read in southern accent for full effect]

Back in the old days, when I first started – this would be a two
hour project.

I’d need to manually ideate each email, type away on my little
keyboard, and finally I’d be done.

But I didn’t have what you now have…

A muthafuckin I.

I went back and forth with Mr.GPT for about five minutes.

My goal was to have it write in my style but my client’s voice.

My instructions were clear and he began typing away.

First email done. Banger.

Second email, banger.

Third, fourth, fifth… holy fuckin shit Chat GPT I love you to
death.

[Ok, no more southern accent]

My full welcome sequence was done in three minutes.

And it wasn’t some generic, AI sounding copy.

The writing had a real voice, humor, and maintained the tone in
my client's content.

All in, it took maybe 10 minutes.

Offer, lead magnet, landing page, welcome sequence.

AI didn’t just help – it did the damn thing (because I used it
correctly).

This is the game now.

If you want to build a lean info-agency using tools like this,

It’s never been easier…

​And Artisan Lab is where I show you how. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h404x4eclh87dwdkkc4/48hvhehm9rrre2fx/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben (not AI, I promise)

​
​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h404x4eclh87dwdkkc4
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h404x4eclh87dwdkkc4
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: The best job in the world
body:
I never really wanted to sell my own coaching.

It was awesome when I was just the guy behind the scenes.

I’d be moderating a client's webinar, watching the money roll in
as they’d smile on camera.

The audience didn’t know I was the one turning the dials, but
others in this space did.

This gained me respect from the right people and kept me away
from the general public.

As an ambitious and pretentious young man – it was a great place
to be.

This also made it so that all of the content I’d create was
purely for fun.

I wasn’t selling anything of my own, but I was making money as if
I was.

I had the upside of running a coaching business *without* running
one.

For about a year and a half, I made between $80-$125k/mo strictly
from my agency.

I didn’t have the pressure to create content myself.

I didn’t have to manage a big team.

And I didn’t have to deal with thousands of customers.

My routine was as follows:

Wake up at 8am.

Make sure nothing is on fire.

Gym.

Coffee.

Text client “we’re fucking rich.”

Lunch.

Walk.

Schedule client’s emails for tomorrow.

Moderate a webinar.

Dinner, sleep.

I’d make $5k from my rev shares that day without doing anything
but management.

It’s kind of like being a backup quarterback in the NFL.

I imagine this is one of the best jobs in the world.

Unless your QB1 gets his leg snapped in half by a 300-lb lineman,
your sole job is to make sure he’s prepared.

You get all the perks, make $2-4m/yr on average…

And you don’t have to run for your life every Sunday.

Now, I’m not saying running an info-agency means you don’t work
at all.

But if you’re efficient with your work, you properly use AI, and
you set up some automations…

There’s not a ton for you to do other than stand there with a
fire extinguisher.

So, although I love coaching and helping members in Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h2l5kp9sqhpe07033hr/wnh2hghq4qwz5qh7/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) get rich, my agency comes with fewer headaches.

And being the puppet master is pretty fuckin cool.

Here are some recent wins from the QB2’s inside AL...

Manoj made $14k profit in three days and is so rich he forgot to
share it:

​
Khesraw made $10k profit from one client last month:

​
Vander kicked off the month with a new client:

​
And Humayoun and Josh sent some wholesome messages that made me
smile:

​

​
​This is where you can join them. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/p9urk7dqlxh9h2l5kp9sqhpe07033hr/wnh2hghq4qwz5qh7/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Your guru’s guru,

Ben

​

subject: AHHHH
body:
I have a mountain of things on my to-do list today.

So many that I might end up doing nothing.

That’s the worst outcome, so I’m trying to avoid the nothing
part.

But I already wasted 30 minutes talking to ChatGPT and scrolling
on Amazon.

My office in the new place is still cluttered and echoey.

I need to move a dresser, add a couch, install new curtains, and
text my undocumented amigo to do all of that for me.

The couch was supposed to get here days ago but it got delayed.

Mr. GPT told me a more plush rug would help with the echo, so
that’s on the way too.

But now I’m sitting here, blaming my lack of focus on the
disorganization of this room.

If I were to give advice to myself, it’d be this:

“Are you a toddler? You can’t work because your office isn’t
perfect? Grow up.”

Sound advice.

But instead, I’ll just complain to thousands of strangers on the
internet.

I’ve now written 178 words here and still said nothing of value.

At least you know this isn’t AI because AI isn’t dumb enough to
write like this.

I could connect the intro to a lesson on ignoring mental excuses
or creating a peaceful work environment.

But I won’t.

It’s Monday.

You’re alive.

You’ve got working senses, a smartphone, and internet access.

And someday in the future, you’ll wish you could relive this
exact day.

You don’t need me to give you advice.

You just need to move.

This the youngest and handsomest you’ll ever be.

So let’s make the most of it.

Stop blaming your productivity problems on curtain rods and go
make some money.

Deal?

Deal.

​Let’s get rich. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhvddqplaghvq080llf9/7qh7h8h98zlqxwuz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

​

 If I were to give advice to myself, it’d be this:

 “Are you a toddler? You can’t work because your office isn’t perfect? Grow up.”

 Sound advice.

 But instead, I’ll just complain to thousands of strangers on the internet.

 I’ve now written 178 words here and still said nothing of value.

 At least you know this isn’t AI because AI isn’t dumb enough to write like this.

 I could connect the intro to a lesson on ignoring mental excuses or creating a peaceful work environment.

 But I won’t.

 It’s Monday.

 You’re alive.

 You’ve got working senses, a smartphone, and internet access.

 And someday in the future, you’ll wish you could relive this exact day.

 You don’t need me to give you advice.

 You just need to move.

 This the youngest and handsomest you’ll ever be.

 So let’s make the most of it.

 Stop blaming your productivity problems on curtain rods and go make some money.

 Deal?

 Deal.

 ​ Let’s get rich. ​

 Ben

 ​
​

 ​

subject: How to spot a fake guru
body:
I have another incredibly boring email for you today.

It’s about a stupid little topic called "product.”

80% of the info gurus just clicked away.

So now that it’s just you and me, I’ll be incredibly honest here:

I used to not give a solitary shit about this side of the
business.

It wasn’t in my job description to care.

I was the marketer.

The rainmaker.

The guy behind the scenes who’ll never deal with the customers.

My job was to sell.

So as long as my clients weren’t absolute scumbags – I’d do just
that.

But after running my own info-business, that’s changed.

People turn their hard earned money into my money.

They trust me to care about them and deliver on my promises.

And I’d be an absolute shithead not to.

This is gonna feel like I’m indirectly pitching you.

I’m not, but I kind of am too.

Artisan Lab isn’t perfect, but it’s always improving.

I personally talk to every member, have incredible coaches, bring
on guests, and add more content.

Yesterday, a new member joined who we’ll call Joe.

Before joining, Joe DM’d nearly everyone he could find in the
program.

Because I’m not a sleazy, lying, piece of shit, the responses he
got were overwhelmingly positive.

Here’s what he said in his intro message:

​
(he joined on his bday so we sang to him on the group call lol).

I say all this because I truly don’t understand how people can
sell something they know isn’t up to par.

They’ll do anything to get the deal done, but once you buy,
you’ll never hear from them again.

And perhaps the worst part – they get people to take out a loan
to buy their shit product.

There is a special place in hell for you people.

Sure, not everyone will succeed.

subject: People dumber than you are getting rich
body:
Good morning bo.

Here’s our affirmation for the day:

“The world is full of money. Some of it has my name on it. All I
have to do is collect it.”

Felix Dennis told me to say this to myself, so I figured I’d
share it with you.

Today I'm thinking about dumb people.

More specifically, how people who are dumber than me are richer
than me.

That’s wack.

Now I’m not a genius…

I can’t change a tire, I’m severely directionally challenged, and
I often misspell simple words.

But everyone has their pitfalls.

Strip Elon Musk of his fame and put him at LIV in Miami.

He’d look like the kid who gets picked last in high school gym
class.

Everyone has their strengths and weaknesses.

Your job is to lean into what you’re good at and stop wasting
time pretending to be someone you’re not.

Let me show you what I mean.

I have two friends – let’s call them Nikola and Anthony
(Basketball fans, you already get the analogy).

Nikola’s an operator.

He’s analytical and calculated.

Excel sheets give him an erection and he uses Zapier to automate
his breakfast order and bathroom schedule.

But if you put him in a room full of people, he’ll complain about
how he wants to go home.

He has trouble making eye contact with women and freezes up on
camera.

Still, he’s rich.

He’s the COO of an 8 figure eCom brand.

Anthony’s the opposite.

He’s incredibly articulate, he can simplify complex ideas, and he
loves the spotlight.

But if you told him to build a funnel or set up an automation…
it’d take him 6 hours, 3 breakdowns, and a YouTube tutorial.

So he doesn’t.

He stays on camera, grabs attention, and outsources the rest.

Both are successful. Because they play their role.

Most people try to “fix” their weaknesses instead of weaponizing
their strengths.

Don’t be like most people.

Figure out your edge. Go all in on it.

And if you suck at the rest, improve it or get help.

​Now go collect what’s already yours. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh674mrkavhq2w7wrrho/l2hehmhl4qr9z3i6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

subject: This self-help guru scammed me
body:
I got scammed by Mark Manson this morning.

The first thing I saw after opening my eyes was a charge for
$79.99 – MarkManson.net.

I guess I signed up for his paid newsletter three years ago.

Haven’t opened a single email other than the payment receipts I
just found.

This makes me wonder what other subscriptions I forgot I’m paying
for.

I’d make a great target for a blackhat MRR scammer.

Anyway, I read The Subtle Art Of Not Giving A F*ck a few years
ago.

I hate admitting this because Mr.Manson has turned into a corny,
platitude writing, lesbian…

But that book began to open my eyes.

It’s one of three books that I recall having an impact on my mini
spiritual awakening.

Millionaire Fastlane and Think And Grow Rich are the other two.

All three are fairly broad money/self help books, but at the time
that’s exactly what I needed.

So, I’m gonna continue my donation to marklesbian.net as a thank
you.

There’ve been so many books that helped me over the years.

And the fact that you can just buy someone's brain for sub $20 is
a cheat code.

Books changed my life.

But eventually, I needed proximity.

Real conversations with people more successful than me.

I found this through online communities and recreated it inside
Artisan Lab.

Twice a month, I bring in people from my network for a guest
call.

These are friends who’ve built multi-million dollar software
companies, scaled offers to $500k+/mo, and built huge audiences.

We’ve had Cardinal Mason break down how he built Copy MBA.

Pierre Khoury went over how he scaled his info-agency to 7
figures.

And 20+ others who’re incredibly good at what they do.

Next Wednesday, Rob Oliver (@robthebank) is coming on to talk
about how he’s built and sold 8-figure eCom brands, grown a
massive audience, and more.

This kind of access is rare.

And it’s one of my favorite bonuses we have inside the community.

So, I’ll keep funding Mark’s retirement as a thank you.

But if you want to learn from killers actively building – apply
here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl208p5h8h8dowo22cl/dpheh0hekv563pam/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Rob’s on next Wednesday. Don’t miss it.

Ben

​

subject: How I hit $100K months (after hating my life)
body:
Happy Memorial Day.

Over the past few years, I’ve subscribed to countless
newsletters.

So many that I don’t remember a lot of the names I see in my
inbox.

But this morning, one of them stood out.

They said “we’re discounting our price from $7995 to just $995
for the next 48 hours!”

I understand Holidays are great excuses to run discounts – and
much respect to all of those who’ve served in the military.

But my brother in Christ…

SEVEN THOUSAND DOLLARS OFF?

For Memorial Day??

Are you gonna throw in a free hand job for customers during
Christmas???

Shit like that just makes me laugh.

Anyway, here’s what I really wanted to talk about today:

“What you’re aware of you’re in control of, what you’re not aware
of controls you.” - Anthony de Mello

This obviously applies to the big decisions in life.

But just as important, are the small ones.

You can “escape the matrix,” create your own income, and travel
the world… and still be asleep at the wheel.

You look free, but you’re more enslaved than the guy who’s stoked
for his day off today.

Here’s what’s easy to forget:

Everything is a conscious decision.

If you want your life to look different, you have to change it
(duh).

But if you don’t define what change looks like, you’ll drift.

You’ll be aware enough to know something’s off, but too unclear
to do anything about it.

I found myself in this very position about two years ago.

I’d been living in Miami for just under a year and was starting
to make some real money.

My income climbed from $15k/mo to $70k/mo (thanks to my Info
Agency).

But I wasn’t enjoying it at all.

Here’s an excerpt from my journal entry in August 2023:

“I feel uninspired. Almost like I was sold a lie. I go accomplish
all these things, hit numbers, buy fancy shit — and my life would
feel a whole lot different. But I’m here and it doesn’t live up
to that.”

What I didn’t understand then, was that the same way making money
is a conscious decision…

So was my lifestyle.

I didn’t have any hobbies.

I didn’t make a conscious effort to meet new people.

I didn’t design my life outside of the money part.

So there I was. Making more money than I knew what to do with…
But no motion.

And then, I regained consciousness.

Started boxing. Started going out. Started playing tennis.

Two months later, my lifestyle was exactly the way I envisioned.

Plus I hit my first $100k month and bought my dream car.

All of it came from conscious decisions…

And the same system I now teach inside Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh67ox0whvhq2w7wrrho/7qh7h8h987qr09hz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

It’s what let me charge $10k+ per client, build real freedom, and
actually enjoy the life I worked for.

The price goes up June 1st.

​If you’ve been waiting for a sign, this is it. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/o8uvdq4g0psqh67ox0whvhq2w7wrrho/7qh7h8h987qr09hz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk soon,

Ben

​
​
​

​

subject: I woke up at 5am for nothing
body:
There was a stretch in high school when I’d wake up at 5am to get
shots up before class.

I wasn’t naturally gifted or the most athletic.

But I figured if I outworked everyone, I’d win.

The gym was cold and dark because I’d get there before they
turned the lights on.

Every single morning was a battle.

“Why the fuck are you doing this?” I’d think when my alarm
sounded.

The sound called “Bulletin” brings up horrid memories.

But I’d get up, put a hoodie on, and walk out the door with a
little mantra in my head:

“If I don’t do this I’m gay a bitch.

So I did.

And I fully convinced myself that if I just worked harder than
everyone else, I’d play D1 basketball.

I was wrong.

I didn’t end up playing past high school.

But do you know what happens when you actually try?

When you actually give something your all?

The forces of the universe begin working in your favor.

One door closes, another opens.

Basketball ended.

But discipline was instilled forever.

I learned to ignore the voice in my head who wanted to hit
snooze.

It’s the same voice who doesn’t want to send outbound, turn on
the camera, or get on a sales call.

It’ll keep you stuck until you realize you don’t have to listen
to it.

You’ll wait another week…

Then another month…

Then wonder why nothing changed at the end of the year.

So here’s my push to get you moving:

Artisan Lab is going up in price June 1st.

If you’re serious about building an info agency where:

You can make $10k/mo+ from just one client.

You don’t have to send hundreds of outbound messages.

You don’t have to build a huge team to scale.

And you work with clients who become friends…

​This (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hnz37q5b6h9mlvl44tn/m2h7h5h39dv5rxam/aHR0cHM6Ly9kb2NzLmdvb2dsZS5jb20vZG9jdW1lbnQvZC8xZkNVaGxwMGpwOTFvN3JTT05Ud1h2NnhNTXdrekgta0xmU0RmNnpqcDZUay9lZGl0P3VzcD1zaGFyaW5n
) is for you.

I threw together a doc that breaks everything down -- what you
get, how it works, and what it costs.

​You can check it out here. (

subject: The 2025 online business power rankings
body:
This is a longer one so strap in, bo.

Let’s break down the popular online business models in 2025.

Here are the main ones that come to mind:

* Dropshipping
* High ticket sales
* Trading
* “AI Copywriting”
* “AI Automation”
* Being a TikTok Shop creator
* Aaaand Info Agency

Obviously I have a bias for the Info Agency, but I’ll be as
objective as possible here.

Ranking from worst to best:

Trading takes the major L.

It’s a casino.

I’ve met many of the trading influencers and they all made their
money from the 2020 crypto bull run, selling info, or owning a
prop firm.

Almost none of them are profitable traders.

You simply have to be world class to make money – but I will say
the upside is tremendous.

If you are 1/10,000 who becomes really good, it can and will make
you rich.

But there is a 99.9% chance you never get there and waste all
your money.

Dropshipping is my second worst on the list here.

It can work, but similar to trading, most eCom gurus made their
money from courses.

And the successful ones, nine times out of ten are running a
blackhat MRR scam.

Cons:
Many skills to learn, low margins, excess variables outside of
your control.

Pros:

Scales fast IF you crack it (most don’t) and has enterprise value
(most won’t get there).

To be entirely fair – trading and dropshipping both have about as
high of an upside as any other model on the list.

But they generally require more capital and higher business
acumen.

Next up, “AI Automation.”

It’s just SMMA repackaged with AI in the title.

Decent for beginners because you’ll learn some core skills.

But I hope you’re ready to deal with shitty clients, constant
churn, and build a big team.

You’ll need dozens of clients to make real money and will have to
work with dentists, realtors, or some other industry you likely
know nothing about.

It can work, but it’s definitely a grind.

Next, TikTok shop creator.

It was an infinite money glitch a year ago.

Absolute monkey buffoon retards were getting rich.

But the faucet has started to turn off.

It’s basically like playing the lottery now.

If you’re consistent, you make really good content, and you keep
iterating, eventually you’ll go viral and make money.

Most will quit before that happens and I’ve also heard some
nightmares about not getting paid out commissions.

It can be decent cash flow but it’s declining and you don’t learn
any real valuable skills.

Moving on, we’ve reached the top three:

AI Copywriting, High Ticket Sales, and Info Agency.

“AI Copywriting” is not a business model, it’s a skill.

The application of said skill determines how much money you make.

Sales is similar – get good, find a good offer and you’ll make
solid cash.

Both of these are incredible things to learn.

But they both end up pointing to the Info Agency model.

Learn “AI Copywriting” – who are the best clients to work with?

Info sellers.

Learn sales – who are you closing for?

Info sellers.

So why not skip the line?

Fuck being the copywriting intern.

Fuck closing leads for someone else’s offer.

Just build the machine yourself.

Control the funnel.

Control the offer.

Control the money.

That’s the Info Agency.

It’s the only model where:

· You don’t need 20 clients to scale

· You don’t need a ton of capital

· You don’t need to sell "AI lead gen" to boomers

And you can scale to $50k/mo+ with one Google folder, one system,
and one client.

It’s not as sexy as some of the other models.

But it’s effective – if you’re willing to work.

So if you want to learn how to build one that doesn’t suck…

​You know where to find me. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hoh8e6okls3hg63w344hg/p8heh9h4dq87pmtq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

P.S. Price goes up in three days.

If you’re even thinking about doing this, now’s the time to move.

After that, it’s gonna cost more. Simple as that.

If you want a full breakdown of what's inside, go here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hoh8e6okls3hg63w344hg/x0hph6hezqx742t5/aHR0cHM6Ly9kb2NzLmdvb2dsZS5jb20vZG9jdW1lbnQvZC8xZkNVaGxwMGpwOTFvN3JTT05Ud1h2NnhNTXdrekgta0xmU0RmNnpqcDZUay9lZGl0P3VzcD1zaGFyaW5n
)​
