subject: The banana bread problem
body:
Get in bo, we’re going to the store.

We’re making banana bread and have one very simple goal:

Get three overripe bananas.

They need to be the color of black coffee because that’s when
they’re the most flavorful.

We walk into Publix and head to the produce section.

There, we see two overripe bananas.

We grab them and toss in a third that’s just yellow.

Close enough.

We hop in the car, go home, and make the bread.

It’s good.

Not quite as good as it could’ve been, but only a banana bread
purist (fuckin weirdo) would notice.

Fast forward a month.

Same plan.

This time, there’s only one overripe banana.

We grab it, plus two yellow ones.

Close enough.

Get home, make the bread, it’s decent.

Now, fast forward a year.

We head to the store and buy the shitty Publix brand bread in a
plastic container.

It’s aiight… if you’re high.

Close enough.

Here’s what these bananas mean to you:

Your tolerance for misalignment determines your life.

There is a version of you, buried in there, that just knows.

When you do things that betray that intuition, it knows.

At first, it’s subtle.

But eventually, you’re living a life that doesn’t feel like
yours.

You’ll convince yourself it’s fine.

Not great, not awful. Just…

Close enough.

Or…

You can have a low tolerance for misalignment.

When it doesn’t feel right, you change it.

Whether it’s your career path, where you live, or even your
routine.

It’s up to you.

And you know the answer, even if it’s buried under a mountain of
excuses.

So my friend, here’s the pitch:

Do you want to keep settling for close enough?

Or do you want to make the change?

You already know the life you want.

The question is how long you’ll pretend that shitty banana bread
is enough.

​Price of Artisan Lab goes up in 2 days. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hnzxz59f6h9mlvl44tn/n2hohvhvglr664u6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

If you’re gonna move, move now.

Ben

P.S. If you’d rather skip the application process because the
clock is ticking here…

​This doc will go over what’s inside and pricing. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hnzxz59f6h9mlvl44tn/wnh2hghq4lgxg9b7/aHR0cHM6Ly9kb2NzLmdvb2dsZS5jb20vZG9jdW1lbnQvZC8xZkNVaGxwMGpwOTFvN3JTT05Ud1h2NnhNTXdrekgta0xmU0RmNnpqcDZUay9lZGl0P3VzcD1zaGFyaW5n

subject: This might not work
body:
Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich.

Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich.

Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich.

“Ben, why are you saying that on the day of the price increase?”

Great question, bo.

On April 25th, 2020 I hopped on my first ever sales call.

Not as a closer. As a prospect.

It was for Nate Schmidt’s eCom mentorship, “Boss Builder.”

I paced around my childhood bedroom on the call.

When we got to the pitch and he dropped the price… I hesitated.

“Is there any way that I won’t succeed if I do everything in the
program?” I asked.

Quite a silly question, as no one has a crystal ball.

But here’s how I’d answer it today, if I could talk to my 19 year
old self:

Yes.

It’s entirely possible that you follow every step and don’t get
the outcome you want.

There are variables that neither me, you, or Lebron James could
possibly foresee.

Also possible, is that you have an easier time than most.

Your first product could be a winner and next thing you know
you’re sitting in the frunk of your Huracan in a Chrome Hearts
hoodie.

I can’t predict your future.

But what I can tell you is this:

If you follow a proven roadmap that’s worked for others…

You show up every single day, even when you want to quit…

And you don’t get discouraged if things happen slower than you’d
like…

Your success becomes inevitable.

I didn’t end up buying that eCom program.

subject: This might not work
body:
Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich. 

 Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich. 

 Buying Artisan Lab will not make you rich. 

 “Ben, why are you saying that on the day of the price increase?”

 Great question, {{ subscriber.first_name | fallback: "friend" }}.

 On April 25th, 2020 I hopped on my first ever sales call.

 Not as a closer. As a prospect.

 It was for Nate Schmidt’s eCom mentorship, “Boss Builder.”

 I paced around my childhood bedroom on the call.

 When we got to the pitch and he dropped the price… I hesitated.

 “Is there any way that I won’t succeed if I do everything in the program?” I asked.

 Quite a silly question, as no one has a crystal ball.

 But here’s how I’d answer it today, if I could talk to my 19 year old self:

 Yes. 

 It’s entirely possible that you follow every step and don’t get the outcome you want.

 There are variables that neither me, you, or Lebron James could possibly foresee.

 Also possible, is that you have an easier time than most.

 Your first product could be a winner and next thing you know you’re sitting in the frunk of your Huracan in a Chrome Hearts hoodie.

 I can’t predict your future.

 But what I can tell you is this:

 If you follow a proven roadmap that’s worked for others…

 You show up every single day, even when you want to quit…

 And you don’t get discouraged if things happen slower than you’d like…

 Your success becomes inevitable.

 I didn’t end up buying that eCom program.

 Not because I didn’t believe in it.

 But because I didn’t believe in me.

 About a year later, I mustered up the conviction to buy an SMMA program.

 Fast forward to now and I’m writing this at my desk in my Miami penthouse.

 So no, {{ subscriber.first_name | fallback: "friend" }} I can’t promise you that Artisan Lab will make you rich.

 You will.

 If you’ve got the balls to commit.

 If you stop overthinking.

 And if you finally decide to bet on yourself.

 Not just in your head, but with your actions.

 Because the only thing standing between you and the life you want…

 Is the version of you that keeps hesitating.

 ​ Let him die here. ​

 I’ll hand you the same blueprint that changed my life and dozens of others.

 ​ Go here now before the price goes up at midnight.

 Ben

subject: You’re not burnt out, you’re just overthinking
body:
It’s rare I open a Google doc and can’t think of a topic to write
about within a few minutes.

But today, it’s not working.

It’s been 27 minutes and this is all I got.

Maybe it’s over.

Maybe I’ve told you everything of value I have to say.

Maybe I should sell my car and move back home with my parents.

Or maybe, it’s just a mini, temporary hurdle.

There’s a book called “Don’t Sweat The Small Stuff – and It’s All
Small Stuff.”

I haven’t read it but I think I got the gist from the title.

Small problems feel like big ones when you look at them under a
microscope.

An issue that would’ve taken 30 minutes to resolve can turn into
a month, year, or lifetime.

Let’s say there’s something you’re struggling to complete.

Maybe it’s outreach, content, or in my case, this very email.

Instead of powering through it, you convince yourself it means
you’re misaligned.

You create a mental narrative of “this business isn’t for me, I
need to do something else.”

The next day, it’s time to do the thing you don’t wanna do again.

That narrative acts as a parasite in your mind.

“This isn’t for me!” it screams, so you don’t do it.

By the following week, you’re completely disengaged and trying to
find a new “passion.”

You’ll dress it up with logic and fool most people.

But in reality, all it took was a brief moment of concentrated
effort.

You don’t have to reroute your entire career.

You just have to finish your cold brew, grab a zyn, and write the
fucking email.

I’ve bailed on businesses and ideas that could’ve been really
fruitful.

I’ve gone through the entire story I laid above.

I’ve convinced myself it was “inauthentic” and found data to back
it up.

But it was all a lie.

You know when something is actually misaligned.

And you know when you’re convincing yourself of it.

So no, I’m not moving back in with my parents.

I’m just finishing the email.

Because not everything needs to feel inspired.

Sometimes it just needs to be done.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. For those of you who joined Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h405reehlh870qkkkb4/reh8hohmv99xmzs2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) before the price went up – congrats on taking the leap.

For those who didn’t – congrats on not giving in to FOMO.

That said, the price didn’t just go up for fun.

We added another coach (Kabrin), a 4th weekly call, and a deeper
level of support than ever before.

It’ll cost you about the price of a steak dinner more.

But if you actually use it, you’ll still feel like you’re robbing
me.

​Apply here if you're done hesitating. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h405reehlh870qkkkb4/reh8hohmv99xmzs2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

​
​
​

​

​

) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/qdurvx4oenh7h405reehlh870qkkkb4

subject: I got punched in the face
body:
I started boxing about a year and half ago.

My original trainer was… a homie.

He was a super funny dude and a really good fighter.

But he wasn’t very technical.

When we first started training, I remember feeling like we
skipped the basics.

I barely knew how to throw a punch and he had me learning
Mayweather combos.

Even still, I got a lot better.

Well… so I thought.

As I continued working with him, my suspicion in his expertise
grew.

But I didn’t have anything to compare him to…

Until I worked out with Rob Oliver and his trainer.

I’d throw a jab, he’d tap me on the cheek so I knew I dropped my
right hand.

I’d throw a hook, same thing.

He’d point out when I was off balance – which was quite often.

By the end of the workout, my head was spinning.

Not from getting hit, but from realizing how many things I’d been
doing wrong.

Like most things in life, the difference is in the details.

You can get away with being sloppy for a bit.

It’s “no big deal” until one day you drop your guard and get hit
with a hook that makes you see God.

It’s “no big deal” until you realize your business is leaking
money.

It’s “no big deal” until you end up living a life you never
wanted because you weren’t meticulous.

The longer you ignore the details, the shakier your foundation
gets.

Everything feels fine, until it doesn’t.

I recently started boxing again with a new trainer.

I’m discarding all of my bad habits and replacing them with a
more solid foundation.

And honestly it sucks.

There’s nothing sexy about going slow and fixing your
fundamentals.

But I know it’s required if I actually want to improve.

It’s the same in business.

You might be making some money right now.

You might even feel like you’re “pretty good.”

But if your backend systems are messy…

If you’re guessing instead of tracking…

If you’re winging it on client work, outreach, or systems…

Then you’re basically shadowboxing with your eyes closed.

Artisan Lab was built for this exact phase.

I won't teach you hacks or gimmicks.

I'll be in your corner, holding you accountable to the shit that
actually matters.

​Join me here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5d8lprtohpx5wkkkh9/dpheh0hew4ok8gcm/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​
​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5d8lprtohpx5wkkkh9
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5d8lprtohpx5wkkkh9

subject: AI is gonna steal your girl
body:
Good morning.

It’s raining today so I was forced to split test my routine.

Typically I like to start the day off with a quick walk to
Soybucks.

But obviously, I’m not gonna venture out in the rain.

So I clicked a couple buttons, spent $21.46, and 20 minutes later
a coffee was at my door.

“Ben why don’t you just make it at ho–”

Shut up.

Anyway,

AI is gonna steal your girl.

Impregnate your mom.

Make you the family pet.

And if you’re lucky, he’ll serve you Chipotle twice a day in a
bowl labeled “human.”

Extra chicken if you don’t complain.

That’s not even the scary part.

The scary part is how stupidly simple it is to use this stuff if
you actually know how.

Let’s say you wanted to land a client this week.

Here’s what that could look like:

You pop a prompt into ChatGPT – something like “Give me 20 less
popular niches where people sell $2k+ coaching or courses and
post content regularly.”

Boom, it spits out a list.

Pick one.

Go find someone on Instagram or YouTube who fits the mold.

Take a couple of their posts or scripts.

Drop that content into AI.

Add the right copy prompts (like the ones I give you in here (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxkzo7os6h6pxmgggtl/58hvh7hgonvn2pb6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)).

And watch what comes out.

Your emails, VSL, and even a sales call framework can be done in
20 minutes.

“But Ben, if it’s so easy, why would they hire me?”

Same reason I didn’t make my own coffee this morning.

Not because I couldn’t.

Because I didn’t want to.

And here’s the cool part…

Most creators don’t even know what levers to pull.

They have traffic, content, and followers…

But no system.

You walk in with a few AI prompts and a baseline level of
competence.

And you become the operator.

You’re the missing piece – the guy who turns eyeballs into
dollars.

So everyone’s yapping about AI and you might be sick of it…

But the truth is, you don’t need to build some complex AI bot.

You just need to use it to compliment what’s already working.

In a Gold Rush… sell the AI-powered shovels.

Or sit by the door and hope someone tosses you scraps.

Up to you,

Ben

P.S. I actually did this exact process yesterday for a YouTube
video.

If you’re curious what it actually looks like in action, you can
go watch it here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxkzo7os6h6pxmgggtl/25h2hoh308v8wva3/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vU010a25a
)​

It’s not sexy, but it’s the most in depth video I’ve made to
date.

​
​
​
​
​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxkzo7os6h6pxmgggtl

subject: The "AI Agency" model is likely not for you
body:
I’m starting a revolution.

Two weeks ago, this 15 year old kid named Rocco joined Artisan
Lab.

He’d been running an “AI Agency” but began to realize all of the
real money was in info.

So he made the pivot.

Just seven days in, he’s signed two clients:

​
This got me thinking about the whole AI Agency/AI Automation
model.

On paper, it sounds great.

Learn a few AI tools.

(Chatbots, automated callers, facebook ads, etc.)

Find boomer businesses that would need them.

Charge a few grand to install.

And then slap a monthly retainer to keep it going.

It’s basically the SMMA model with AI wrapping paper.

Sounds easy, right?

Well, the service delivery part is.

Spend 30 minutes on Google and you’ll figure it out.

But getting clients?

Keeping clients?

Building and managing your team?

Spending your days talking to roofers, plumbers, or realtors?

Sounds… interesting.

Now don’t get me wrong, this model can work.

But it becomes a logistical nightmare as you scale.

You’ll need dozens (if not hundreds) of clients.

A big team, dialed systems, and you'll likely hate your life.

Most of the guys I know who’ve scaled AI Agencies either…

* Built themselves a 9-5 job…
* Or they're incredibly autistic.

I mean that in the nicest way possible -- you have to be
obsessive, systematic and nerdy.

The kind of person who goes nonverbal in social settings.

So why are there so many people trying to build AI powered SMMAs?

Especially when you can use a very similar skill set…

Apply it to an industry that’s growing rapidly…

Work with “clients” who typically become your friends…

And make as much money with one client as you would with a
football team worth of plumbers.

Unless you exclusively wear button ups, you get a boner when
someone says “automation,” and you haven’t touched a woman since
birth…

Let’s build a cool business, (

) shall we?

Revolution commenced,

Ben

subject: What no one tells you about ‘making it’
body:
“This car will be a Porsche 911 and I’ll have the top down,
cruising around LA…”

I said to the girl in the passenger seat of my Honda Civic.

She replied “And the girl next to you will probably be way hotter
than me.”

I laughed but the voice in my head agreed. She was right.

It was early 2021.

I’d just started my agency and decided I was gonna drop out of
college.

All I wanted was freedom..

And a 911…

And a dozen girlfriends…

Aaand to never have to take orders from some skinny-fat fucktard.

Lol.

I’d watched the show Californication a few too many times and I
was set.

That was gonna be my life.

About two and half years later, it was – just swap LA for Miami.

I have the top down in my nardo grey 911 Turbo.

The girl in my passenger seat is indeed hotter.

And I’m going on my third consecutive $100k month.

Life is good… at least from the outside.

I hadn’t really thought this far ahead.

Like, what happens when you actually get all the superficial shit
that you want?

It’s not quite the life you see on TV.

The scene you don’t see is the existential crisis you have when
looking at yourself in the mirror.

You realize the version of life you sold yourself isn’t the
utopia you thought it’d be.

You’ve still got problems.

There’s still things you don’t wanna do.

And you’re still you.

Now you gotta figure out what your next goal is – and this time,
maybe dig a little deeper.

So I’m not telling you to not go after the more shallow stuff.

Actually, if you take a look at Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, it’s
sort of a rite of passage.

Your physiological needs (food, shelter, water) are covered.

Your safety needs are next, then you move on to belongingness and
love…

And finally your esteem needs – feeling of accomplishment.

I’d climbed the ladder to this point, but I didn’t account for
the top ring.

Self-actualization.

I began asking questions like:

Who am I?

What’s my deeper purpose?

Was I led astray?

I had to climb the superficial ladder to reach a point where I
could think on these clearly.

Although it felt like a quarter life crisis…

It was the greatest gift I could give myself.

And it’s something you owe to yourself.

So yeah, chase the car, the girl, and whatever else you fantasize
about.

Just know that if you’re lucky enough to catch it, there’s a new
game waiting for you on the other side.

A quieter one.

Where the scoreboard isn’t just revenue or the hotness of the
girl next to you.

It’s purpose.

It’s waking up and actually liking who you are when no one’s
watching.

And funny enough…

That might be the real flex after all.

If that’s the direction you’re trying to head in, I can help you
here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/lmun5487w2hmhnzd4zdt6h895z000bg/x0hph6hedz4goot5/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​
​

​

subject: Getting rich is boring
body:
Over the weekend, I got lunch with my friend Tim.

Tim runs an 8-figure info business.

Up until recently, he’d been a ghost online.

No content, no personal brand, and no rented Huracan…

Doing $10m+ in annual revenue.

His business was built by giving Zuckerberg a dollar and getting
a few bucks back.

As he sat there, with a red Richard Mille on his wrist, it became
clear to me why he’s so successful.

This guy knew just about every metric off the top of his head.

Not just the basic show up rate, close rate, etc.

But all the stuff most people wouldn’t even think to track.

The percentage of people who watch until a certain minute in the
VSL and how it correlates to lead quality.

Percentages based on days, times, and periods of the calendar
year.

He had a crystal clear pulse on everything.

Data, tracking, analytics, all of this shit sounds boring and
tedious.

Marketing is fun.

Closing deals is fun.

Crafting a new killer angle that you’re sure will be your ticket
to the promised land is fun.

But you won’t know what’s working (and what isn’t) if you don’t
track it.

If you’re willing to obsess over things most people overlook…

That’s how you scale predictably with longevity.

And that’s how you’re able to take nearly a full month off to get
fucked up at Coachella like Tim did last month lol.

My main point (and reminder to myself) is this:

Data isn't boring when it's making you rich.

Every metric you track provides clarity on the lever that needs
to be pulled.

Most throw spaghetti at the wall, find something that sort of
works, and then react when it stops working…

But if you’re willing to be a nerd sometimes, you stay proactive.

And you build a better foundation.

This Thursday, Tim’s running a guest call inside of Artisan Lab.
(
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxk4ddes6h6pxmgggtl/9qhzhnhd323752u9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

He’ll be sharing the exact playbook he used to build an 8-figure
business in his 20’s.

​Would be a shame if you missed it :) (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxk4ddes6h6pxmgggtl/9qhzhnhd323752u9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​

​
​

​

subject: Buy info
body:
This is gonna sound like a pitch but it’s not.

Well, technically it is.

But non-technically, it’s merely an observation of highly
successful people.

Alright, you ready?

Good.

You are a fucking idiot if you don’t invest in coaching and
courses.

You are dumber than sheep. And sheep are so dumb that they follow
each other off cliffs.

I know that’s incredibly convenient for me to say considering I
sell coaching (hence the pitch warning).

But I was once one of the idiot sheep.

Now, I can’t name a single rich friend of mine who hasn’t paid
for information.

Off the top of my head, here are some of the bigger things I’ve
invested in over the past few years:

SMMA coaching: $5k (I spent all the money I had on it)

High ticket sales coaching: $2k

Jeremy Haynes Inner Circle: I’ve been paying him for over 2.5
years. I don’t want to do the math, but it’s close to six
figures.

Iman Gadzhi’s 8FL: $18k

1-1 coaching: $10k ++

I’m definitely forgetting a handful of others, but there’s my
diploma.

Not once have I felt ripped off, even when I didn’t end up
utilizing much of a program.

Because you're not just buying information -- you're bullying
yourself into an identity shift.

I don’t know if I would’ve ever ‘made it’ online without doing
that.

When you start paying for info, it's scary.

The online cattle love to tell you that all courses are scams.

They comment “nice try Diddy” and “put the fries in the bag.”

Your family members and friends will think you’re involved in a
pyramid scheme.

But to the universe – and to yourself…

It’s a declaration of change.

As you type your card info into a Whop checkout page, as some
sweaty 19 year old closer prays you don't leave the zoom call…

A part of your soul becomes free.

You’ll feel a rush of anxiety and excitement.

You went against what 95% of people believe to be the norm.

You bet on yourself and spent an uncomfortable amount of money to
solidify that commitment. (

)​

Hopefully you didn’t buy some bullshit. Lol.

But even if you did, it’ll make for a good story.

Because now you’re in the arena.

It takes courage to reject the opinion of the masses – the same
way it takes courage to build a successful business.

So, that concludes my indirect pitch.

​Buy info, retard friend. (

subject: Second-order thinking
body:
“And then what?”

That simple question can be the difference between prosperity and
poverty.

It can lead you to potential problems before anyone else finds
them.

If you solve those problems, you might get rich.

But most people never think deeply enough to consider second
order consequences.

Here’s an example…

First-order consequence:

“This girl is hot. I want to date her.”

Second-order consequence:

“She keyed my car, stole my Rolex and threw a chair off my
balcony.”

If you considered the second order consequence from the
beginning, you probably wouldn’t have made decision number one.

Make sense?

Cool.

The same principle applies to business, especially with AI.

Hold on now, don't click off yet – I know you’re probably sick of
those two letters.

Most agency owners, copywriters, and marketers are thinking…

“Oh this is really cool, AI will do my work for me hurr durr.”

And what’s the reaction to this?

Their clients realize they don’t need them.

Low skill, basic service providers get replaced.

But this doesn’t mean you’re doomed…

Because high level service providers become indispensable.

An online coach (or really any business owner) doesn’t need
doers.

They need thinkers who can identify bottlenecks, strategize, and
steer the ship…

While leveraging AI to improve efficiency, quality, and
everything in between.

In simple terms, this means…

Information gets commoditized.

Everyone will have the same tools.

“I can build your funnel” is not a MOAT.

And differentiation comes through thinking, experience, and
context.

People who understand psychology, systems, and nuances will use
AI to multiply their impact.

Everyone else will get drowned out.

Pricing power shifts to those who own outcomes, not just provide
services.

Imagine you build and manage the entire back-end of a $200k/month
info biz.

You track KPIs, manage the team, improve conversions, and build
the whole system.

You’re not an expense, you’re a partner.

And that’s why they’ll pay you $40k/mo, instead of $2k/mo.

Meanwhile, the “AI agency, copywriter and arbitrageurs ” are
fighting over scraps, praying someone throws them a $1,500 bone.

All the tools are accessible now. The difference is the
application and positioning.

If you can tie yourself to revenue, AI becomes your leverage not
your replacement.

​Go here if you wanna stay ahead of the curve. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh359pz5f2hdwlk666s7hwpom6/dpheh0hew0m8xghm/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: The worst idea of all time
body:
Every morning, I ask myself…

“What am I gonna write about today?”

I wake up, do the usual routine -- brush teeth, shave, make sure
business isn’t on fire.

Then I walk to get coffee.

That’s usually when the ideas start spawning.

I observed my thoughts as I went back up the elevator – iced
latte in hand.

I’d probably considered ten different potential angles.

“That one’s good, but I can do better.”

“Eh, that’s too similar to what I wrote about yesterday.”

“Nah, that’s too boring.”

As the elevator took me up to the top floor, I picked the idea
that you’re now reading about.

You don’t need a great idea.

You need a good enough idea and the balls to go all in.

“Ideas are not worth anything. The ability to execute them is
worth millions.” - Felix Dennis

There comes a point where you have to accept “good enough.”

I know this is ironic considering I frequently say good enough
will make you miserable.

But in the context of business and creativity, something being
“great” is subjective.

You take a good enough idea and make it great.

Not through contemplation but by putting your gloves on and
getting in the ring.

You can waste a lifetime trying to pick the best idea.

They’re endless.

They all could work.

And that’s the problem.

I made my first $100k selling leads to basketball trainers.

That was a horrible idea.

But I made it work because I executed.

And it gave me the skills to spot (and sell) much better ideas
later on.

Like selling money to money-hungry gurus.

Could I have started there? Sure.

Would I have had the same level of grit and competence to
capitalize on it the way I did?

Nope.

So, my friend…

Stop fooling yourself into thinking you need a better idea.

A better business model.

A better mentor.

A better whatever.

Perhaps you’ll find something that aligns almost perfectly down
the line.

But you’ll only get there by taking the first imperfect step.

Anyway, here’s a bright idea for ya (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlzd52xhrh87m0999bmh7qno0/kkhmh6hn2nedlrsl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) if you want to make money selling shovels in a Gold Rush.

Later,

Ben

​

​
​

​

subject: Avoid this type of person at all costs
body:
I don’t like poor people.

“Ben, that’s insensiti—“

Shut up.

Being poor is a paradigm, not a financial state.

I know a guy who sold a brand for several million dollars in his
early twenties.

That same guy measured his bedroom down to the inch so he could
argue his roommates should pay more rent.

No matter how rich he gets, he’ll always be poor.

I stay far away from people like that.

It’s like an infectious disease that I don’t wanna catch.

A friend of mine recently learned this the hard way.

He has a big audience on social media.

Last year, he wanted to launch his first offer, so we hopped on a
call.

He was torn between low ticket or high ticket.

I implored him to launch a $5k+ offer for entrepreneurs and high
achievers.

He didn’t listen.

Instead, he went with a $30/month discord.

The launch flopped.

Less than 50 people joined and many were constantly complaining.

He shut down the group and refunded everyone within a week.

Not long after, he launched a high ticket offer.

He made nearly 100x the money and attracted quality customers who
are loving the community.

This is why I don’t sell a low ticket offer.

Artisan Lab was built for winners.

My members move fast and execute.

They understand that success is reserved for those who fully
commit.

Marcus closed a $3k + 15% deal with a big influencer.

subject: $250k months from ONE client
body:
It’s 9:47am on a Monday.

I have one sip left in my iced latte.

And Chat GPT just made this image for me:

​
You may have seen this concept before…

The emotional cycle of change.

Almost five years ago, I sat in my college dorm room watching a
Jason Capital video.

As he articulated this concept, it matched up perfectly with my
endeavours over the previous year.

Everything I tried, I failed.

Well… I’d quit and start something new before I could really
fail.

But as I learned about the five stages of change, I finally felt
understood.

I thought I was broken…

It felt like this whole online business thing worked for everyone
but me.

And only now, did I learn that what I experienced was normal.

1. Uninformed optimism

“This new business is gonna print and I’ll be in a red LaFerrari
with a baddie in the passenger seat in no time.”

2. Informed pessimism

“Uhhhh why is no one replying to my outreach messages? I thought
this was gonna be easy.

3. Valley of despair

“Maybe I’m not cut out for this… Or maybe I just need to try a
different business model. Yes, that’s it! I’m gonna be an AI
Fighter Jet pilot.”

4. Informed optimism

“Nah, I’m gonna stick this out. I know it’ll be difficult but I
can do it.”

5. Success and fulfillment

“Hello, MTV welcome to my Penthouse.”

If you’re in stage three right now, here are my words of
encouragement.

Over the weekend, I recorded this interview (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlzogd0hrh87m0999bmh7qno0/m2h7h5h30w2k82am/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vTFBzZWtU
) with Artisan Lab member, Brady.

He’s made $250,000 from one client… in the past 30 days.

Yes, you read that right.

After we did the interview, he told me that he almost quit a year
ago.

He was grinding but making no money -- and fell deep into the
valley of despair.

Around that time, I made a Youtube video about the emotional
cycle of change.

He said that video convinced him to keep pushing…

Fast forward just one year, and he’s hitting six figure months.

If you’re stuck in the trenches, this might be the push you need
-- watch Brady’s full story here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlzogd0hrh87m0999bmh7qno0/m2h7h5h30w2k82am/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vTFBzZWtU
)​

Ben

P.S. This (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hlzogd0hrh87m0999bmh7qno0/e0hph7h7w5m90vb8/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vdG5Ga0pZ
) is the original video I made last year that helped him.

​
​
​

​

​

subject: How to escape the outbound trenches
body:
Doing outbound sucks.

It’s arguably the worst part of starting a service based
business.

You sit there typing, pitching, and praying someone will reply
with words other than “fuck off.”

Finally you get some replies, go back and forth, and get ghosted.

Maybe you get a call scheduled… only for it to get rescheduled
for next week (which is code for “fuck off").

But if you do it the right way, this period doesn’t last forever.

It’s a temporary phase that you look back on and laugh about.

Over time, it becomes easier to get clients – assuming you even
want more after you get one or two good ones.

However most people never get out of the “I hate my life,
outbound is so difficult, no one replies to me” phase.

And that’s simply because they’re doing it wrong.

Instead of turning this email into an outbound masterclass, I’ll
give you one piece of advice that’ll be just as effective:

If you do what everyone else does and expect a different result,
you are either stupid, lazy, or you don’t actually want to make
money.

Maybe a combination of all three.

Personally, I get hundreds of pitches a week.

I skim through all of them.

99% are copy and pasted.

They get ignored.

In the rare event I get a pitch that’s real and considerate –
like a Loom showing how my YouTube funnel could double call
bookings by fixing the drop-off at minute 3…

I’ll actually take a look.

But that only happens when it’s clear they did their homework and
found a real gap.

When people say “send personalized messages,” that doesn’t mean
offer some random, retarded compliment like…

“Hey Ben, I saw you played basketball in high school! Anyway, do
you want a clipping army that’ll make you an extra $7.56 a
month!”

Fuck off.

Stop being an idiot.

Stop the spray and pray approach.

And stop offering irrelevant compliments.

Be normal, creative, and lead with a solution to their potential
problems.

There’s your stupid little masterclass.

​Join Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hqn725vumhrn6gqqqs3hwod56/e0hph7h7wm6ed9b8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) if you don’t want to spam strangers in DMs forever like a
monkey with an iPhone.

Ben

​

​

​
​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hqn725vumhrn6gqqqs3hwod56
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/mvu840onxvs5hqn725vumhrn6gqqqs3hwod56
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: Two truths and a lie (sales edition)
body:
Let’s play a game.

I’m gonna tell you three statements you’ve probably heard on the
internet.

Two of them are true, one is a lie.

Ready?

1. High ticket sales is a great way to stack cash.

2. Good sales people are in high demand.

3. If you get into sales, you can make your own hours and work
from the beach.

Could you spot the lie?

Many sales guys have joined Artisan Lab in the past few months.

I hear the same story time and time again.

Someone gets started in sales.

They find a good offer to close for.

They spend all day on zoom persuading prospects into pulling out
their credit card.

Maybe they get to $10k, $20k, or in rare cases, even $30k+
monthly.

But eventually, they hit a ceiling.

Their income stagnates.

Every day becomes the same.

They begin to hate it.

They got into online business because they wanted freedom…

But they've worked themselves into a high paying job with no
leverage and no upside.

Now they're stuck asking themselves:

“What’s next?”

Now this isn’t a bad spot to be in.

But there’s a smarter play if you really want freedom and
leverage.

Instead of spending your days on Zoom, hoping you don’t see
another +91 on your calendar…

What if you owned the system itself?

This is the logical next step if you're capped in sales.

You already know how to close.

You already understand buyer psychology.

Now you just need to control more of the process and get a bigger
piece of the pie.

With an info agency, you help the same entrepreneurs you're
closing for by:

Scripting VSLs.

Building funnels.

Writing emails.

Optimizing backend systems.

And thanks to AI, learning these skills has literally never been
easier.

You can go from one-trick pony to a capable operator in weeks.

Then use your existing sales skills to close a client or two…

And welcome to the side of the game where the real money (and
freedom) is made.

If you're ready to stop chasing commission checks...

​Here where you can build something that actually scales. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhvkkgkzhghvqe5llls9hkmlpo/58hvh7hgoqlkq8f6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

subject: Why staying poor is unethical
body:
I ran into my rich friend Josh at the coffee shop this morning.

He’s this southern guy in his mid-thirties who sold a
manufacturing company a few years ago.

He’s been retired since.

I sat with him and chatted for a bit.

“You can only sip so many margaritas on the beach, buy a few
supercars, and stack the watch collection… until it gets boring,”
he said.

He wasn’t complaining, just being honest.

He’d spent the past few years floating around Europe with nothing
to do and unlimited money.

And now, he’s restless.

He wants to build again.

The game continues…

Even when you win, you still have to figure out who you are.

Money buys freedom.

But it doesn’t tell you what to do with it.

Real life starts after you “make it.”

Success removes your excuses.

And suddenly you’re forced to confront the question you’ve been
avoiding:

“What do I actually want?”

Unless you’re a monk or some kind of hippy, you have to buy the
right to have this sort of internal clarity.

One of my mentors once told me, “making money is such a waste of
time… but you have to do it.”

At first I didn’t get it.

But now I do.

Because until you make money, you’re not really thinking clearly.

You’re just reacting.

Money (or the lack of it) makes all of your decisions.

But once you’ve made it and the noise quiets down…

That’s when the real questions start to surface.

What do I actually care about?

What do I want to spend my time on?

What kind of life do I want to wake up and live every day?

You don’t get honest answers to those questions when you’re
broke.

Maybe chasing money is a waste of time.

But avoiding it guarantees you’ll be lost forever.

It’s your duty to get rich.

Not just for the lifestyle, or the validation, or the Patek.

But because it’s the only way to earn the clarity required to
live on your own terms.

You can’t build a life you love if you’re stuck in survival mode.

So go get the money. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hoh8o722pi3hg6nx444hghqekg3/n2hohvhv5qvmlla6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Buy the clarity.

And then decide what really matters.

Ben

​

​

​
​

subject: Why staying poor is unethical
body:
I ran into my rich friend Josh at the coffee shop this morning.

 He’s this southern guy in his mid-thirties who sold a manufacturing company a few years ago.

 He’s been retired since.

 I sat with him and chatted for a bit.

 “You can only sip so many margaritas on the beach, buy a few supercars, and stack the watch collection… until it gets boring,” he said.

 He wasn’t complaining, just being honest.

 He’d spent the past few years floating around Europe with nothing to do and unlimited money.

 And now, he’s restless.

 He wants to build again.

 The game continues…

 Even when you win, you still have to figure out who you are.

 Money buys freedom.

 But it doesn’t tell you what to do with it.

 Real life starts after you “make it.”

 Success removes your excuses.

 And suddenly you’re forced to confront the question you’ve been avoiding:

 “What do I actually want?”

 Unless you’re a monk or some kind of hippy, you have to buy the right to have this sort of internal clarity.

 One of my mentors once told me, “making money is such a waste of time… but you have to do it.”

 At first I didn’t get it.

 But now I do.

 Because until you make money, you’re not really thinking clearly.

 You’re just reacting.

 Money (or the lack of it) makes all of your decisions.

 But once you’ve made it and the noise quiets down…

 That’s when the real questions start to surface.

 What do I actually care about?

 What do I want to spend my time on?

 What kind of life do I want to wake up and live every day?

 You don’t get honest answers to those questions when you’re broke.

 Maybe chasing money is a waste of time.

 But avoiding it guarantees you’ll be lost forever.

 It’s your duty to get rich.

 Not just for the lifestyle, or the validation, or the Patek.

 But because it’s the only way to earn the clarity required to live on your own terms.

 You can’t build a life you love if you’re stuck in survival mode.

 So go get the money. ​

 Buy the clarity.

 And then decide what really matters.

 Ben

 ​

 ​

 ​
​

subject: The bag is right in front of you, bo
body:
Getting rich is easy, actually.

Find a problem, create a solution, and sell.

Sounds braindead simple to me.

The hard part is deprogramming old habits and standards to
replace them with new ones.

For some, this seems to happen fast.

For others, it can be a few months or a couple years.

And for most, it never really happens, and they stay miserable.

Don’t do that.

One of the most prevalent paradigm shifts you have to make is the
ability to identify and seize opportunities.

Most people don’t think critically enough to do this.

They think,”hurr durr dis not working right now, maybe i do
something else.”

A few years ago, my inner dialogue sounded something like the
above.

I ran a marketing agency for basketball trainers and just
couldn’t seem to scale.

No matter what I tried, nothing worked.

But then I spotted a better lane.

I applied my skill set to digital products instead of local
businesses…

I got a couple big clients…

And even though I felt like I was in way over my head, I worked
like a dog.

I took every chance to prove myself.

I did more than what was asked.

And said yes to things I didn’t know how to do.

That season of being overworked and underpaid is what set me up
for everything I have now.

A few months ago, my top sales guy on one of my offers was in the
same spot.

It was a newer offer and he wasn’t making a ton of money at
first.

Despite this, he went above and beyond to help the business grow.

Not only did he do his job well, but he also spent hours building
systems, creating tracking sheets, and making course content.

No one asked him to do any of this, but his income grew as a
result.

Now, he’s working for one of the most famous marketers in the
world.

And unsurprisingly, he's now their top sales guy.

Had he not maximized a lesser opportunity, he wouldn't have been
competent enough to get that role.

But he did. And now, he will quite literally be set up for life.

Ask yourself what you would’ve done in that position.

You’re underpaid.

Your income doesn’t reflect your skill set.

And no one is asking you to take any initiative.

Would you go above and beyond?

Or would you get complacent?

The answer to that question determines the rest of your life.

There’s no secret.

​Just a moment where you decide (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh25q24nhkhkl8x999c3hmgxon/3ohphkh395x55dsr/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) to act like the person you want to become.

No pressure,

Ben

P.S. “Opportunities are all around you, you’re just too fucking
retarded to spot them.” - Socrates

​
​

​

​

subject: Get off the rollercoaster
body:
“My confidence isn’t a rollercoaster,” my high school basketball
teammate said.

I’d asked him how he stays consistent when shots aren’t falling.

That simple answer is a big reason why he became the all time
leading scorer at our school.

He was the type of athlete that would just win.

No matter what was going on, how big the moment was, or even how
he was playing up until that point…

There was this ever-present stillness in his demeanor.

Every game he’d show up, do what’s needed, and go home.

Completely emotionless.

And although he wasn’t exceptionally athletic or way more skilled
than everyone else…

He did the basics a whole lot better.

Almost a decade after that conversation, I’ve watched this same
principle make a lot of people rich.

Those who win in business aren’t the ones constantly jumping from
one thing to the next.

They’re the quiet, consistent killers who execute the basics day
after day.

And their confidence isn’t tied to immediate results.

If you can wake up each morning, do what’s needed, and move
forward…

Maintain consistency, even when you hit setbacks or your outreach
is met with silence.

You will win.

Because business, like sports – is often a war of attrition.

Consistency wins.

Show up and do the simple things repeatedly.

Even when it’s boring, difficult, and when no one is watching.

And the next time your confidence feels like it’s on a
rollercoaster, remember this:

You are being tested by the universe.

Will bo execute relentlessly, despite that fact that you’re not
getting the result you want?

Or will you be like the masses and quit or jump to a different
shiny object?

The answer to that question will determine everything about your
future.

Someone has to put the fries in the bag.

​Don’t let that person be you. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hn97v92t6h9m8n444tnh4p03v/48hvhehmq4k94ncx/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

subject: The difference between $10k & $100k/month
body:
I have good news and bad news.

The bad news:

If you want to get rich, you have to get lucky.

The good news:

You can rig luck in your favor.

Consistent hard work plus a decent skill set will ensure some
success.

Even if you have a room temperature IQ, you can brute force your
way to low six-figs a year.

But beyond that?

You need leverage.

I’ve had calls with two new Artisan Lab members recently where
this stood out to me.

One of them is a sales guy.

He’s closing on one of the best offers you can be on in the info
space.

Making good money, but spending 8+ hours a day on zoom.

The other guy is running a content agency.

He’s got almost 10 clients on monthly retainers and is crushing
it for them.

His systems are incredibly detailed and he has a decent sized
team.

Both are hard-working, smart, and have the talent they need to
get to six-figure months.

But they don’t have much leverage.

They’re making commissions or flat fees and getting paid for
effort, instead of outcomes.

That’s the cap.

Those who break through to $100k/month aren’t necessarily better.

They’re just riding a better vehicle -- a business model that
multiplies their output.

That’s what changed everything for me.

I went from $15k/month with my SMMA to $120k/month within a year.

Not because I learned new skills.

Not because I worked harder.

Because I switched vehicles.

If you want to be “lucky,” this is how you do it. (

)​

Ben

subject: Tell better stories
body:
“What story or analogy can I use to articulate this idea?”

That’s the question I ask myself at the beginning of every piece
of copy I write.

Coming up with the idea is the easy part.

Wrapping It up into a 400 word hero's-journey is the trickier
part.

The best marketers on the planet are just really good
storytellers.

I was first exposed to this subconsciously.

Right before I dropped out of college, I was watching Jason
Capital videos religiously.

I’d sit at the desk in my bedroom of the frat house.

I had this white and black gaming chair and notebook in front of
me.

I’d take pages of notes and even started using flashcards to
memorize marketing and psychology principles.

Off the top of my head, I can’t remember a single concept I wrote
down.

But what I can remember is the story…

He quits college basketball, gets into online marketing, pays
Craig Ballantyne who writes down a business plan on a napkin…

Then starts making $20k/mo in his dorm room…

Leaves college, lives at the Ritz Carlton, blah blah, blah.

Similarly, I’ve watched a good amount of Hormozi content and
can’t recite many of his lessons.

But I vividly remember the beginning of $100M Offers.

Four years ago, I opened that big ass purple book.

It was the second month after I dropped out of college, as I sat
in this knit chair on the balcony of my villa in Tulum, Mexico.

He starts by telling the story of how a business partner stole
all his money.

At his girlfriend's parents' house, he told her what happened and
said he wouldn’t blame her if she left him.

She replied, “I’d sleep under a bridge with you.”

I remember all of that off the dome.

And I promise I’m not a weirdo, that's just how our brains are
wired.

We remember stories.

The better stories you tell, the better marketer you will be.

If you’ve been reading my newsletter or watching my content for a
while, what do you remember?

Probably not much.

But hopefully a few stories if I did my job well.

So next time you’re at an impasse, thinking about taking a leap…

Maybe just do it (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/n4u0kgn5wzhvhxoez43c6h6pxmgggtlh72vgw/e0hph7h7wdk3m9a8/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) for the plot.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben
​
​
​

​
​

subject: You’re early
body:
Have you ever watched someone do something so well that it sort
of made you want to quit?

They perform at a level that seems inconceivable to reach.

It makes you feel like you’re lightyears behind…

And you should pack it up and do something else with your life.

Sometimes that signal is accurate.

The game is rigged in their favor and they have a natural ability
that you don’t.

The first time I ever watched an NBA player workout, I realized I
wasn’t going to the NBA.

But most of the time -- especially in a business setting…

The people who seem to be on another level are normal.

They’re absent of advantages… other than hundreds or thousands of
reps and split tests.

Data is the difference.

And life is basically an ad campaign.

When you set up a campaign on Meta, its AI has a general
understanding of who you’re targeting based on what you say in
the ad.

As you start spending money, it gets more data.

That data indicates “yes, this is the type of prospect we are
looking for…”

Or “no, this person is homeless and addicted to fent, he probably
can’t invest $25k into a DFY AI Arbitrage Agency.”

Meta’s machine learning adapts and stops looking for unqualified
drug addicts.

The more money you spend, the more data it gets, and the faster
it knows exactly who to target.

Think of yourself like an AI machine.

You can master anything if you input enough data.

Speaking, dating, business, copy, sales, boxing… the list goes
on.

Your rate of improvement is dependent on the amount of reps you
get in the allotted time.

If you send 100 outbound messages in a week…

You test different styles and approaches…

You listen to the data and adapt…

You will basically be a different person than you were 7 days
prior.

Extrapolate this to anything in life -- and work towards mastery.

And when you feel behind…

Don’t quit the game.

Just double the spend -- figuratively or literally.

More reps, more data, more progress.

Because most of the time, the people ahead of you aren’t
superhuman, they’re just further into the campaign.

With enough inputs, your results will catch up.

Just don’t close your laptop before you learn how to deter
homeless people from booking a call on your sales team's
calendar.

​Start your campaign here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/4zupx8r403sehp2wxklsxh64z5777t5hmzg69/x0hph6hedmnp39h5/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

subject: How Chrome Hearts ruined online coaching
body:
Good morning, happy Monday.

Let’s talk about the “trust recession.”

You’ve probably heard marketers throw this term around recently.

Consumers are more skeptical than ever and there’s data to back
it up.

In hindsight, it seems obvious as to why.

Remember the “automation” phase a few years ago?

People started slinging “DFY passive income streams” for
multi-five figures a pop.

Imagine you’re a depressed middle aged man named Jerry.

You live paycheck to paycheck in Gary, Indiana with your 248lb
wife.

On a random Tuesday night, you’re scrolling through Instagram.

You see a 30-second ad from a tattooed man, draped in Chrome
Hearts standing in front of a Huracan.

He says “we’ll build you an Amazon store and guarantee $15k/mo in
90 days!”

You’re hooked.

You get on a sales call with some 19-year-old kid who convinces
you to take out a loan.

After spending $40k that you don’t have, 90 days later you’ve
made nothing and can’t get a hold of the automation company.

No shit there’s a trust recession!

Thousands of people, like our friend Jerry, are now in
generational debt.

Rightfully so, events like this have given online coaching a bad
rap.

But I still believe it’s one of the most ethical and impactful
businesses…

*If you do it the right way* (most don’t).

When there’s something you want to master, having a coach makes
it infinitely easier.

Someone taught you how to drive.

Someone taught you how to play an instrument.

Someone taught you how to shoot a jump shot.

You could’ve figured all of these things out on your own, but
that’d be illogical.

It would take you exponentially longer, and you know that.

So, you take a shortcut – you get help from someone who’s done
what you’re trying to do.

Making money is no different.

Over the past year I’ve invested close to six figures to learn
from people like Jeremy Haynes, William Brown, Taylor Allan and
Iman Gadzhi.

Could I learn everything they’ve taught me through Youtube plus
trial and error?

Maybe.

But why would I take the longer road, when an express lane is
available?

That’s what idiots do. And I don’t consider myself an idiot.

So bo, I’m imploring you to get coaching.

Whether it’s from me or someone else, I’m pitching you for your
sake.

​Go here and buy this. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh62w536i9hz5l2333fwh9e0z6/p8heh9h4lk06pmiq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Or go somewhere else and buy something else (preferably not from
someone wearing Chrome).

Just don’t end up like Jerry.

And don’t buy anything with automation in the title.

Alright bye,

Ben

​
​
​
​

​

subject: The most pretentious email you'll read today
body:
I have a flight to New York in a few hours and I still need to
pack.

This is unfortunate, because I hate packing.

Even more unfortunate, is that I’m flying commercial!

It’s Phillips' birthday tomorrow so we’re celebrating in NYC and
then heading to the Hamptons for the 4th of July.

Danny, who you may recognize from my Youtube, is coming along as
well.

At first I was fine with flying commercial.

It’s not thaaaat bad…

But I texted my jet guy last minute for the hell of it.

He found a solid deal that would get us from Opa Locka to
Teterboro airport for under $20k.

I’m not one to pass up a half decent deal.

So I texted Phillip and Danny to see if they’d be down to split
it…

And they said no.

Phillip spent his last dollar on another pair of Chrome jeans and
Danny just bought a Patek.

You’d think when you rescue people from poverty and help them
make $100k/mo+ they’d be a bit more eager to split a jet right?

I guess not.

But it’s crazy to me that all three of us run info agencies.

Danny has one great client who he’s helped scale to multi-seven
figures and personally nets six-figures a month from his rev
share.

Phillip got off sales calls five months ago, and hit his first
$100k month last month, with just three clients.

This is a business model I randomly stumbled into three years
ago.

It worked for me, but I thought I was the anomaly.

I had a decent network and a vast skill set.

Because of this, I never imagined this model would work for
others the way it has for me.

So even though Phillip and Danny are being frugal today, it’s
cool to see.

But maybe they’re anomalies too…

Maybe we all just got lucky and the stars aligned for us.

Just like they did for Elijah, who made $25k+ from one rev share
client last month:

​
Or Alo, who made $34k from one client...

​
Or Khesraw who had record months with two clients and will make
over $15k from his rev share.

​
We all got lucky.

We're all anomalies.

Or maybe we just stopped overcomplicating things and picked the
right vehicle. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h97r52malhvmerk55fnhxm59l/dpheh0hem4vwgmfm/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Alright, I gotta go pack.

See you on Delta,

Ben

​

​

​

​

subject: I lied again!
body:
I lied to you.

In yesterday’s email (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhkdvxd9sphwzk8500t6hxp290/owhkhqhw76dd06sv/aHR0cHM6Ly9ja2FyY2hpdmUuY29tL2Ivcjh1OGhvaDM1enJtcWE0OG5uZzgzc2R3djhtNjZmN2h3cG9tNg==
) I told you I was about to fly to New York with my friends
Phillip and Danny.

30 minutes later, our flight got delayed from 3pm to 8pm.

Delays always scare me because there never seems to be just one.

First it’s 8pm, then 10pm, and then somehow you’re leaving at 1am
and going to Kazakhstan instead of JFK.

I did not want to end up in Kazakhstan.

So after a dozen phone calls, a lot of convincing, and a five
figure wire…

Our new flight now takes off in an hour and 45 minutes.

And instead of Delta, well…

It’s a jet.

“Wow bro you’re so cool! Stupid ass guru.”

Thank you.

Anyway, I gotta finish packing and don’t have any lessons for you
today…

(Other than don’t stay in school and say maybe to drugs.)

But I don’t want to leave you empty handed so here’s a video (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/zluew470l3hnhkdvxd9sphwzk8500t6hxp290/z2hghnhe8kxxm7cp/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vb2NkYXNZ
) I made recently about how business gets easier over time.

If you’re in the trenches right now…

And you’re reading this email from some pretentious asshole
bragging about flying private…

Just know, it gets easier.

You’re in the part that sucks.

It's a training camp that everyone has to go through.

You’re earning stripes every day that you show up and blindly
throw spaghetti at the wall.

Even though you might have nothing to show for it and feel like
you’re spinning in circles…

There will come a time where things click.

I can’t tell you when, how, or why.

But if you just stick it out for long enough, eventually the
universe will decide:

bo's ready now.

You won’t be flying commercial forever.

See you at Opa-Locka Airport,

Ben

P.S. If you read this one and want to chat about anything, hit
reply. I’ve got three hours to kill on this flight.

​

​

​
​

subject: Spent all my money & now I'm sad :(
body:
I had a quarter-life crisis yesterday.

As I sat in 2A on my flight home from the Hamptons, I got this
pit in my stomach.

Not because I was on a commercial flight.

And not because my friends and I spent an accountant's annual
salary over the past four days.

Let me rewind a bit…

We flew to New York on a jet (I know, I know – I’ve rinsed this
story. Last time I mention it lol).

We stayed at the St. Regis – one of the nicest hotels in the
city.

We celebrated my friend Phillip’s birthday at a restaurant you
typically have to reserve a year in advance.

The next day, we were driven to Montauk, where we stayed in a
beautiful AirBNB right on the beach.

Over the following two nights, we spent five figures at the club.

And on our last night, we went to the biggest, most exclusive
party in the Hamptons.

Phillip was on stage next to Livvy Dunne and Bobby Shmurda (lol)
and I said cancelable things on Sneako’s stream.

If you told me this was my life four years ago, I’d be over the
moon.

But on the flight home, I felt numb.

“What the fuck is wrong with me?” I thought.

I just went on this amazing trip.

And everything in my life is objectively great right now.

I’ve hit a new record in my business each of the past three
months.

I’ve helped people make their first dollar online – and others
hit their first six figure month.

I have my dream car, an incredible circle of friends, and a close
relationship with my family.

But it all just feels… normal.

What the fuck.

I thought every day would be blissful.

I thought everything would feel perfect.

I thought my only problem would be choosing between the blonde or
brunette.

But I was wrong.

That’s not how life works.

As you reach new levels, your standards rise.

The jet is just a flight.

The supercar is just a car.

The penthouse is just an apartment.

And you…

Are still you.

It feels incredible to earn a lifestyle you dreamt of.

But probably not as incredible as the Utopia you created in your
head.

This is not a “sell your things and live like a monk” email.

Nor is it a cry for help.

Just a reminder that even as you start to get the things you
want…

The best part of your day will likely be something simple.

A peaceful walk.

A conversation with a friend.

Or a morning coffee and email to your list.

Life is amazing, don’t forget to appreciate it.

​And keep getting richer (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hp747mka5h273rzllsnhv48px/vqh3hrhodnoex3ag/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) just so you can know for sure that it won’t fix everything :)

Alright, glad to be back.

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. If you liked this one, reply and let me know ​
​

​

​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hp747mka5h273rzllsnhv48px

subject: The only "manifestation strategy" that works
body:
“I manifested this shit!”

Says the black-hat MRR scammer turned grifter who’s financing a
Huracan on a balloon loan.

He'll default on his payment and make a story post saying…

“God gives his toughest battles to his strongest soldiers.”

No retard, you just have a 27% chargeback rate because you sell
air for $8k.

Not long ago, I began to hate “manifestation” because I
associated it with those guys.

And then I remembered how I got here.

During my last year in college (before I dropped out) I entered
my “spiritual entrepreneur” phase.

I had sticky notes with affirmations scattered around my room.

“Money flows to me easily.”

“I am not chopped.”

“I make $10k/month effortlessly.”

There were incense sticks next to my bed and a vision board on my
Notion homepage.

Although, there was still a little voice in my head saying:

“This is gay.”

But I kept doing it.

Because everyone I followed said that’s how success happens.

I was confused why selling leads to basketball trainers required
me to become one with the Universe.

Years later when the goals actually started coming true, I
realized manifestation is just a rebranded version of planning.

It only looks magical from the outside.

Because when you set a specific target, train your brain to see
it constantly, and take relentless action toward it…

Things start to work out.

It’s not some mythical awakening but rather the compound interest
of commitment.

So here’s the “law of attraction” in simple terms:

1. Set precise goals.

“Land one client on a 20% rev share, get them to $100k/mo.”

2. Reverse engineer it.

How many outbound messages do I need to send daily to get a
client?

3. Execute.

Actually do it.

There’s your spiritual alignment manifestation guru guide – no
crystals required.

Just set a goal, make a plan, and do the work.

If you want to manifest $20k/month without becoming a hippy, join
me here. (

)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. I just dropped a new YouTube video on how AI is doing 90% of
my client work. Check it out here. (

)​

subject: I got scammed for $5k and filed a dispute
body:
I filed my first ever dispute yesterday.

After 24 years on this beautiful Earth, I finally had to do it.

Here’s what happened:

On our way to the Hamptons, we had a driver take us from NYC to
Montauk.

He showed up on time and his car was clean…

But the second I got in his black suburban, I regretted it.

This fucker smelled like he’d just eaten a bowl of curry and ran
a marathon to 7/11, where he then bought a bag of beef jerky.

My shirt was over my nose and I had the window open for the
majority of the ride.

It was still torture – I wouldn’t even wish such a thing on
George (my enemy from previous emails if you remember that dork).

That said, at least he got us there safely.

I didn’t chargeback on the guy just because he smelled like a
math convention.

But that ride left a bad smell in my nose.

So on the way back, I decided we’d take a helicopter to NYC and
then catch our flight at JFK.

It was about 10x the price but 1/5th of the time and had a lower
likelihood of a smelly driver.

Worth every penny in my humble opinion.

On the morning of our flight, I got an email from the helicopter
company.

It said if we had any luggage over 25 lbs, we’d have to schedule
a car service.

The only way to do so was to call them.

First of all, why was I not prompted to do this until 3 hours
before we’re scheduled to leave?

Whatever.

I give them a call, the guy tells me the bags might not arrive on
time, so he’d have to check and call me back.

We go back and forth for the next hour as he gives me a dozen
different answers.

Basically it’d be $500 to send the luggage to the airport for us
and he was unsure if it would arrive on time for our flight.

Finally, I’m fed up so I told him to cancel it and I booked a
driver.

“I’m sorry sir, your flight is non-refundable.”

I end up talking to his supervisor, go back and forth, they won’t
budge, and basically tell me to get fucked.

So we didn’t take the $5,000 helicopter and now it’s in Amex’s
hands.

It felt kind of cool clicking the dispute charge button.

Now I understand what it’s like to be poor.

If I win, it’s a free $5k, if I lose, I’ll have forgotten about
it by the time they make a decision.

I guess there’s no lesson in here for you today, I just wanted to
tell you that I’m now a proud member of the dispute club.

Later,

Ben

P.S. Artisan Lab’s (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hle7llotrh87xl699cmh7qno0/owhkhqhw7gpekruv/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) 1 year anniversary is coming up in 2 days.

I asked our members to leave a quick review and wanted to share
this one from Jack:

“48 hours into Artisan Lab hands down one of if not the best
purchases in my life. I know I’m glazing rn but honestly wtf it’s
gone to a point of over delivering. It’s not just info, it’s
every single skill it takes to make money online in one package.”

If only the helicopter company over delivered half as much as we
do inside Artisan Lab…

​Join us here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/gku0o3gldmh5hle7llotrh87xl699cmh7qno0/owhkhqhw7gpekruv/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

​
​

​

​

​

​

I’m a scammer.

Not just a couple bucks, but multiple thousands each.

Eight of my victims have gone on to hit $100k/mo+.

Nearly 30 have hit their first $10k month.

Several are in the $20k-$50k range.

And many are building the skill set that’ll allow them to reach
the numbers above.

Quite a fruitful scam if you ask me.

Exactly a year ago tomorrow, Artisan Lab was born.

For the anniversary, I asked all the members to fill out a
feedback survey and incentivized them with free prizes.

(Yes, this is me telling you I bribed them).

Bribe or not, here’s what they’re saying about their experience:

* "I transitioned from low to high ticket model since being in
AL. I’ve generated roughly $100k for my clients, left my job in
the Australian Navy, and now I’m traveling the world... Hands
down best community in the info space." – Ellis Deakin

​

* "I started at $3K/mo. Hit $15K/mo in my 4th month. Just signed
someone who did $1.6M last month. Haven’t done outreach in a
month and probably never will again." – Dominic Morrell

home $7.5K—and it’s growing. I’ve leveraged that case study to

If there’s one thing I’ve learned this year, it’s that change can
happen fast…

For the right person.

If you have a bit of foundation underneath you, all you need is

Environment + skill + pressure = results.

That’s the formula.

If you’re already in motion, all you need is the right room and

subject: Do you actually want to make more money?
body:
“You’re making a measly $100k/month and you’re comfortable!” he
told me.

Over the weekend, I went to Jeremy Haynes’ Mastermind.

You may have seen him on YouTube yelling about hitting million
dollar months.

For two and a half years now, I’ve been in his Inner Circle
program.

I’ve been to countless of his quarterly in-person events and he
never disappoints.

Jeremy is a very intense person.

He gets hypnotized every year to “get richer.”

I thought that was bullshit until I saw how disgusted he is with
stagnation.

My friend Mason told me Jeremy almost made him cry on a 1-1 call
recently.

Mason is a 26 year old making $5m+ per year.

If you’re settling, Jeremy will call you out on it.

Three months ago at the last Mastermind, he did just that.

I’m walking around, making small talk and enjoying the food.

Jeremy comes up and a few of us start talking.

Then he looks me dead in the eyes and says…

“Are you still doing pussy numbers?”

Uh oh.

He’s known to do this thing where he’ll just berate you if he
thinks you need it.

And in this moment, I realize I might be today's target. Gulp.

“Uhh ye… yeah I’m working man” I respond.

Wrong answer.

You can’t do that with him.

If you try to virtue signal, he sees that as a personal attack in
his “get richer" culture.

For the next 5-10 minutes, this guy just goes in on me (pause).

“You’ve been making the same amount of money for two fucking
years!”

I honestly don’t remember much else of what he said because I
think my brain categorized this as a traumatic event.

But I know it was all out of love.

Or maybe disgust.

Afterwards, he messaged me and said:

“Send me the reasons you’d want the revenue to grow. You’re sold
on current reasons to stay where you’re at for perspective to
reflect on.”

I started thinking.

“What would I actually do with 3x the money?” I considered.

I made a list.

The first things on there were superficial lifestyle upgrades.

Second were long term investing goals.

And third were more personal desires.

I sent them to Jeremy and he replied, “If you don’t see a lift in
productivity and revenue, you’ll know you don’t care about these
things listed.”

Over the following three months, I’ve kept this list top of mind.

My income has grown, I’ve seized new opportunities, and have felt
more in control.

So bo, I encourage you to ask yourself the same question…

Why do you want to make more money?

Get crystal clear on this and write down a list.

These reasons should provoke emotion when you think about them.

And next time you don’t feel like doing something you know you
should, take a look at that list.

There’s the advice I had to get yelled at for.

If you want more lessons from me that I learned the hard way…

​Join me here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5p5mdwaohpxdqnkkh9h79pno/58hvh7hgzq3x99c6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Happy Money Monday,

Ben

​
​

​

​

​

 And in this moment, I realize I might be today's target. Gulp.

 “Uhh ye… yeah I’m working man” I respond.

 Wrong answer.

 You can’t do that with him.

 If you try to virtue signal, he sees that as a personal attack in his “ get richer" culture.

 For the next 5-10 minutes, this guy just goes in on me (pause).

 “You’ve been making the same amount of money for two fucking years!”

 I honestly don’t remember much else of what he said because I think my brain categorized this as a traumatic event.

 But I know it was all out of love.

 Or maybe disgust.

 Afterwards, he messaged me and said:

 “Send me the reasons you’d want the revenue to grow. You’re sold on current reasons to stay where you’re at for perspective to reflect on.”

 I started thinking.

 “What would I actually do with 3x the money?” I considered.

 I made a list.

 The first things on there were superficial lifestyle upgrades.

 Second were long term investing goals.

 And third were more personal desires.

 I sent them to Jeremy and he replied, “If you don’t see a lift in productivity and revenue, you’ll know you don’t care about these things listed.”

 Over the following three months, I’ve kept this list top of mind.

 My income has grown, I’ve seized new opportunities, and have felt more in control.

 So {{ subscriber.first_name | default: "friend" }}, I encourage you to ask yourself the same question…

 Why do you want to make more money?

 Get crystal clear on this and write down a list.

 These reasons should provoke emotion when you think about them.

 And next time you don’t feel like doing something you know you should, take a look at that list.

 There’s the advice I had to get yelled at for.

 If you want more lessons from me that I learned the hard way…

 ​ Join me here. ​

 Happy Money Monday,

 Ben

 ​
​

 ​

 ​

 ​

subject: The 3 phase path to six-figure months
body:
One of my first clients texted me the other day.

It reminded me just how far things have come…

He said: “Hey brother, hope you are great. Just sending a message
your way to say how cool it is seeing you grow. You’re crushing
it.”

This was from Mike, a basketball shooting coach who I worked with
a few years ago.

He was one of my first few info clients.

I built a low ticket ascension funnel for him in March, 2022 and
ran ads for a handful of months after that.

That was a pivotal era in my journey.

I’d begun dropping my local business clients and replacing them
with info guys.

At the start of that year, I had 14 local clients and somehow
only made $10k in January.

By June, I had five info clients and made $16k.

Three of my clients were the top personal brands in online
basketball training.

Another was a YouTuber with over 500k subs who I used to be a fan
of.

And the last was one of my best friends at the time, selling a
high ticket sales coaching offer.

This was phase one of my info business.

I’ll refer to it as the “freelancer model.”

I hadn't really tapped into rev shares yet, but I was charging
higher prices.

I’d offer anything copy related – emails, ads, funnels, and
VSL’s.

By October 2022, I got to $28k/mo this way.

But two months later, I found an even better model and entered
phase two…

The “partner model.”

This is where I went all in on rev shares.

Because of that, my biggest client in December 2022 paid me
$12,900.

In total, I made $31k that month with just six clients.

Check out what happened next:

​
This new partner model got me as high as $124k profit in one
month by the end of 2023.

I’d have 5-8 clients at a time, who I’d typically become friends
with.

Using this model, I’d make between $80k-$120k/mo for the
following 12 months.

Since then, I’ve entered phase 3 which I’ll call the “owner
model.”

Although I still have a few partner clients – I’ve built my own
offer in Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhvn47g3ughvqxpmllf9hkmlpo/g3hnh5hmk9g8k4ir/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) and have majority share in a couple other offers.

This seems to be a common progression.

You start off by offering anything you can – prove that you can
be trusted to not run away after someone gives you money.

Once you do that, you gain confidence in your skillset and start
getting a piece of the pie.

You now have a handful of clients on 10-30% rev shares.

This alone can get you to $100k/mo+ as it has for me and many
members in AL.

I’m not saying this is the only path.

But if you’re trying to escape the client hamster wheel and build
something meaningful…

This is the one I’d bet on.

* Start by doing great work for cheap
* Build real skill and trust
* Shift into higher-paying, higher-leverage partnerships
* Eventually own the assets yourself

Three years ago, I was charging as low as $1k/mo to write emails
for clients.

Now I’ve had clients happily send $50k wires.

If you don’t wanna wait three years to figure this out the hard
way…

​Join me here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhvn47g3ughvqxpmllf9hkmlpo/g3hnh5hmk9g8k4ir/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

​

​

​

​

https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/v8ur65e8vghrhvn47g3ughvqxpmllf9hkmlpo
