subject: Business is like hot wheels (Certified Hood Classic)
body:
Today's email is a CHC (Certified Hood Classic) originally sent
Dec 28th, 2024.

It might be my most replied-to email of all time. It's a bit
unhinged, but a good read.

Quick reminder before we get into it -- I'm hosting a free live
webinar next Wednesday where I'll give you the exact playbook you
need to sign a $10k/mo client. Sign up here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8h6opodnbzhwlrvr66tnhowm53/25h2hoh3ox5wgrh3/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
)​

Alight, enjoy:

I want you to think of business success like a battery powered
toy car.

Imagine you’re an 8 year old with snot on your face.

For Christmas, you got a miniature brown Bugatti with a bald
action figure sitting in the passenger seat.

You rip it out of the box and put it on the ground.

Excitedly, you click the “on” button and…

Nothing happens.

You turn it off and on again…

Nothing.

And then something clicks inside your little pea brain.

Batteries!

Your Bugatti needs 2 double A batteries.

You run upstairs and say “Mom! Get me some fucking double A
batteries ASAP no rocky!”

To your disappointment, your Mom is hammered.

She caught your Dad cheating on her with your Uncle so she’s
numbing the pain with two bottles of Rosé.

“Dammit! She won’t be able to drive to the store,” you think to
yourself.

Time to take matters into your own hands.

You scour the house for batteries, opening the back of every TV
remote.

None of them fit into your car.

You’d ask your Dad for help but he’s upstairs with Uncle Timmy.

So you decide to hop in his Ford F-150 and drive to the store
yourself.

You can barely see over the steering wheel so you grab a pipe
from the garage as an extension to your foot.

Next thing you know you’re pulling out of the driveway.

Luckily you’ve played a lot of GTA.

By some miracle, you make it to the store, find the batteries,
check out, and make it back home.

Finally you pop the batteries in the bottom of the car and you’re
off to the races.

Congrats kid.

Now b you’re probably thinking...

“Are you going anywhere with this or are you just telling me a
fabricated, alarming story about an unsupervised child due to his
alcoholic mother and gay father?”

Here’s how this relates to you and your business success:

Right now, you’re that toy Bugatti.

If you’re a complete beginner, you have to get batteries before
you can start moving.

Go down Youtube rabbit holes, read books, watch courses, and
start practicing your skills.

The car won’t start moving yet (you won’t make any money).

But you’re installing the necessary batteries that will allow you
to go fast.

Welcome to the trenches :)

It’s impossible to say how much time you’ll spend here, but I can
promise you that on the other side is everything you’ve ever
wanted.

Once you get through, you’ll hit the gas. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8h6opodnbzhwlrvr66tnhowm53/qvh8h7hd63xpv7bl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

And finally, you’ll be rewarded for all of your previously
unrewarded effort.

Just don’t quit before you even get the batteries.

Let me know if you read this one,

Ben

​
​

​

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8h6opodnbzhwlrvr66tnhowm53
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/75u8gdmwq5s8h6opodnbzhwlrvr66tnhowm53
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: Thank you, Money
body:
Having money is overrated.

When I was at 0, I thought $5k/mo would solve all my problems.

When I hit $5k/mo I thought $10k/mo would finally do so.

Fast forward past $100k/mo, and I have more problems than I ever
did before.

What a scam!

Every day, I extinguish between 1 and 20 fires in my business.

I have more problems than I can count and new ones popping up
daily.

There’s a constant pressure to go faster.

Need to fix things.

Need to start new things.

Need to buy more expensive things because the old things got
boring.

I guess Jay Z was right when he said “more money, more problems.”

But ya know what makes it worth it?

The problems get better.

The other day, my friends and I decided we wanted to go to the
Weeknd concert.

I texted my “ticket plug” and asked if he had any suites left.

“Yep, one more 20 person suite for $7k.”

Honestly I was shocked.

He could’ve told me it was $15k and I would’ve thought it was a
steal.

Money sent.

He told me Ubering would be a nightmare and gave me a parking
pass.

The only problem is my 911 Turbo fits two normal sized adults.

Maybe two vertically challenged ones in the back.

But we had 12.

So, my friend Jimmy called the sprinter guy.

$1k for the night, can fit up to 18 people.

Money sent.

We pulled up and were escorted to the “VIP Parking area.”

After a two minute walk through security, we were at our private
suite.

Food and drinks were delivered directly to us, and the driver
took us to the club after.

I’m not telling you this just to brag about how cool my life is.

More so to explain that one of the best things money does is
eliminate inconveniences.

Without spending $8k to go to that concert, everything would’ve
been a headache.

Ubering, finding the seats, getting food, the noise, the heat,
the crowd, etc.

Instead it was easy.

Thank you, money.

The poorer you are, the more decisions money makes for you.

It decides where you live, what you eat, and what you do.

But the more money you accumulate, the less power it holds.

Decisions flip from “can I afford this?” to “will this make my
life easier or better?”

If the answer is yes, you send the money.

It doesn’t remove all problems, it changes which ones you deal
with.

So b… let’s get rich. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0n26kt8h86oko22blh26gvn/wnh2hghqr5zor7a7/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. My free live webinar (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0n26kt8h86oko22blh26gvn/reh8hohmq285qza2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
) is coming up in two days… If you’re not signed up yet (and you
want to learn how to make $10k/mo from one client) go here now. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0n26kt8h86oko22blh26gvn/reh8hohmq285qza2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
)​

​

​

​

​

​
​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0n26kt8h86oko22blh26gvn
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0n26kt8h86oko22blh26gvn

 But the more money you accumulate, the less power it holds.

 Decisions flip from “can I afford this?” to “will this make my life easier or better?”

 If the answer is yes, you send the money.

 It doesn’t remove all problems, it changes which ones you deal with.

 So {{ subscriber.first_name }}… let’s get rich. ​

 Talk tomorrow,

 Ben

 P.S. My free live webinar is coming up in two days… If you’re not signed up yet (and you want to learn how to make $10k/mo from one client) go here now. ​

subject: Most questions are stupid, here’s why
body:
The only dumb questions are the ones you don’t ask yourself (or
ChatGPT) first.

If there’s one trait that contributes to success above all
others, it’s:

Your figure-it-out-ability.

There’s probably a much better word for that.

But if you refuse to think for yourself, you will never win.

Last night I was watching the new season of Dexter.

There’s this billionaire midget in the show named Max.

His assistant came to him complaining about being unable to
complete a task he’d given her.

In return Max said, “I hired you to make problems go away… did I
make a mistake?”

She nodded and understood the assignment…

Figure it out.

Treat your own life as if you have a billionaire midget boss
who’ll kill you if you disappoint him.

Whoever said “there is no such thing as a stupid question” is a
liar.

There are plenty of them.

I see DM’s and comments every day that would fall under that
category.

What makes a question stupid, is the complete outsourcing of
critical thought.

Let’s use the example question, “how do I do outreach?”

Ask yourself…

“If I were my prospect, what would pique my curiosity?”

By simply pondering for a few minutes, you’re ahead of 80%.

Only then should you consider your accessible resources.

What videos can you watch about the subject?

Is there an all-knowing, all powerful robot anywhere that might
be able to help you out?

Yes! There's this thing called ChatGPT.

You can go to it and say…

“Here’s my goal, here’s the context, here’s what I think would be
the best strategy.

Analyze and critique my plan.”

There you go!

You’re now a 160 IQ giga-brained genius.

All that’s left to do is take action.

Act, get data, adjust.

That’s how you ask smarter questions and get better answers.

And when you pair the right strategy, (

) with figure-it-out-ability…

The world is yours.

If you’ve got the drive to think for yourself, tomorrow night at
7pm EST I’ll give you the framework that makes the figuring-out
part a whole lot faster.

Spots are limited to 500 on this one – lock yours in here. (

)​

Ben

subject: Why my webinar will be waste of your time
body:
Tonight I’m giving you everything you need to get your first
$10k/mo client. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9dd9nnalhv083855snhxm59l/6qheh8hlp6klewho/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
)​

You’ll know exactly who to pitch…

Where to find them online…

How to use AI to send 10/10 pitches in minutes…

And it won’t matter at all.

You won’t do anything with it.

Once the dopamine high wears off after a few days, you’ll quit.

“Ben, shouldn't you be telling me that it’s so simple and easy
that anyone can do it?”

Yes, I should be.

And while the above is true, it doesn’t work that way.

Your success is contingent on a separate element…

Obsession.

Jeff Bezos could dedicate the rest of his life to making you
rich, but without obsession…

You’d still fail.

I know that probably sounds daunting – especially when all you
really want is some extra cash.

But it’s actually quite simple.

Obsession is the only thing that’ll carry you through the process
of growth.

And the best part is, it takes life from black and white to
color.

Think back to a time in your life where you were obsessed with
something.

It could be as simple as a video game, the gym, a sports team, TV
series, etc.

Whatever it was, consider how you felt in that process.

You thought about it constantly, studied it, lived it…

That’s the feeling you need here.

You must become a student of the game – not just because of the
goal, but because it makes you feel alive.

So if you’re looking for the “easiest way to make money online,”
this isn’t for you.

You’ll have a better chance gambling on meme coins or sports
betting.

But if you’re looking for a new reality…

Where every day, the first thought on your mind is how you can
move the needle forward…

And you’re dying to fully commit to the pursuit of a goal…

​This can be the catalyst. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9dd9nnalhv083855snhxm59l/6qheh8hlp6klewho/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
)​

If you’re ready, I’ll see ya tonight at 7pm EST.

If not, go place a futures bet on the Bengals to win the Super
Bowl (literally free money).

Ben

subject: b we're going to Vietnam (CHC)
body:
I have another CHC (Certified Hood Classic) for you today --
originally sent Aug 15th, 2024.

If you don't like me, this is a good one to screenshot in case
you ever need to get me canceled.

​See you on the other side:

Good morning b.

I went for a run and then tried to meditate but it didn’t really
work.

Now I’m here, typing to you.

I’m actually sitting at the desk in my “office,” which is really
just a den.

Since I moved about three weeks ago, this has been the last area
of my new apartment that still needs work.

The lighting in here is kind of depressing and I have a bunch of
random belongings on the floor.

Because of this, I’ve avoided this room.

My phone is in the kitchen because I’ve been really addicted to
it recently.

It’s cool that you can get rich and all from your fingertips but
wow can that device be destructive.

On my run earlier, I thought about what it must’ve been like to
be a young man who was shipped off to fight in the Vietnam war.

Imagine you’re a 19 year old kid, fresh out of high school.

You’re awakened in the middle of the night by Forrest Gump.

He grabs you by the ear and takes you with him.

Next thing you know you have an AK-47 in your hands and you’re
shooting at anyone who has squinty eyes.

What a turn of events, huh?

All of the problems you had prior to being drafted have now
vanished.

You’re no longer worried about what career you’re gonna go into.

You stopped thinking about what to say to the girl you have a
crush on.

And you couldn’t give a singular shit about the decor in home or
clothes on your back.

You now have one goal;

Survive.

If you’re reading this, I assume that the Vietnamese are not
currently trying to blow your head off.

What a lucky guy (or girl) you are.

I’m in the same boat.

And although this is obviously a privilege, it comes with
consequences.

Naturally, you want a war.

You want a mountain to climb, and a communist to shoot at.

But because life is relatively easy, you have to avoid the trap
of getting caught up in bullshit problems so that you feel like
you’re progressing.

In other words, don’t stress about inconsequential things because
you don’t have a life or death thing.

You need to find your Vietnam war.

Actually, let me rephrase that.

You need to make your life the Vietnam war.

Build businesses, go hard in the gym, nurture beautiful
relationships, get famous, fight a homeless man (lol), travel the
globe…

Just do something.

Preferably something that’s actually productive instead of
worrying about things that have little impact on your life.

That’s how you avoid becoming a Karen who gets mad at kids for
skateboarding on the sidewalk.

Or becoming a fat incel whose only joy is yelling racial slurs at
the TV.

Or even a manic 46 year old housewife who yells at the gardener
because he missed a blade of grass.

You need real(er) problems.

Stuff that’s actually worth stressing about.

And you’re likely not gonna get sent to Vietnam any time soon so
you have to bring Nam’ to you.

You’re lucky. Don’t waste your luck. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh30mo2df2hden4n66h7hwpom6/reh8hohmqeggqxf2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

P.S. Let me know if you made it all the way down here, solider.
If you liked this one -- and you're enjoying the CHC's I'll make
it a weekly thing. Have a good weekend :)

​

​

​

​

​

https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh30mo2df2hden4n66h7hwpom6
) | Update your profile (

subject: 5 years ago today, I almost quit
body:
It’s August 25th 2025.

IT’S AUGUST 25TH 2025!

This year is flying by.

Exactly five years ago today I started my “sophomore” year of
college.

“Sophomore” is in quotes because it was really a continuation of
my freshman year based on credit hours.

When you have a 1.1 GPA for a semester, I guess that really sets
you back.

But I knew I’d be out of there soon and mentally, I already was.

I was only taking one class to keep my parents happy because it
meant I was still enrolled.

This gave me plenty of time to work on my “business.”

Well, it wasn’t really a business yet but I was getting there.

I was doing freelance videography, making about $1k per month —
which was an interesting phase.

This was my “I finally found some direction but now I’m even more
lost than I was before” era.

But in between bong rips and frat parties, I was grinding.

The only problem was that bong rips and frat parties were a
frequent occurrence, so I wasn’t growing very fast.

By the end of the year I was in peak shiny object syndrome form.

Between juggling a dozen situationships in college and a dozen
more in half-baked businesses, I was overwhelmed.

I had a few videography clients, bought an SMMA course, bought a
sales course, got an appointment setter role, and quit after a
day.

Here were my exact words from a journal entry on Jan 8, 2021:

“Feeling a little defeated. More confused, and making less money
than I did prior. Ugh. Maybe this online biz thing isn’t for me…
Maybe I was born to be a dreamer. Get stuck in the 9-5 with all
these big ideas that never come to fruition. Maybe. Or maybe I
just need to commit to something.”

That last line was wise, young Ben.

My two main problems were:

1. Although I was lost, life was still relatively comfortable. I
didn’t feel enough urgency because of this.

2. I lacked internal conviction. This made me continually find
problems with each business model because in reality I didn’t
believe in myself.

If this sounds at all familiar, congratulations.

You have entered the era that will likely determine the rest of
your life.

No pressure, b.

Looking back, here’s what I did that got me through it…

The obvious answer is I finally picked one business model and
stuck to it.

But it was deeper than that.

I had to become the person capable of the success I wanted.

Small daily habits I adopted were a big reason I could do that.

I journaled almost every day and treated each entry as a mini
sparring session with myself.

On January 27th, 2021, about a month before I got my first SMMA
client, I wrote:

“Be the person who is becoming the person you want to be, and you
will become the person you want to be.

subject: 5 years ago today, I almost quit
body:
It’s August 25th 2025.

 IT’S AUGUST 25TH 2025!

 This year is flying by.

 Exactly five years ago today I started my “sophomore” year of college.

 “Sophomore” is in quotes because it was really a continuation of my freshman year based on credit hours.

 When you have a 1.1 GPA for a semester, I guess that really sets you back.

 But I knew I’d be out of there soon and mentally, I already was.

 I was only taking one class to keep my parents happy because it meant I was still enrolled.

 This gave me plenty of time to work on my “business.”

 Well, it wasn’t really a business yet but I was getting there.

 I was doing freelance videography, making about $1k per month — which was an interesting phase.

 This was my “I finally found some direction but now I’m even more lost than I was before” era.

 But in between bong rips and frat parties, I was grinding.

 The only problem was that bong rips and frat parties were a frequent occurrence, so I wasn’t growing very fast.

 By the end of the year I was in peak shiny object syndrome form.

 Between juggling a dozen situationships in college and a dozen more in half-baked businesses, I was overwhelmed.

 I had a few videography clients, bought an SMMA course, bought a sales course, got an appointment setter role, and quit after a day.

 Here were my exact words from a journal entry on Jan 8, 2021:

 “Feeling a little defeated. More confused, and making less money than I did prior. Ugh. Maybe this online biz thing isn’t for me… Maybe I was born to be a dreamer. Get stuck in the 9-5 with all these big ideas that never come to fruition. Maybe. Or maybe I just need to commit to something.” 

 That last line was wise, young Ben.

 My two main problems were:

 1. Although I was lost, life was still relatively comfortable. I didn’t feel enough urgency because of this.

 2. I lacked internal conviction. This made me continually find problems with each business model because in reality I didn’t believe in myself.

 If this sounds at all familiar, congratulations.

 You have entered the era that will likely determine the rest of your life.

 No pressure, {{ subscriber.first_name }}.

 Looking back, here’s what I did that got me through it…

 The obvious answer is I finally picked one business model and stuck to it.

 But it was deeper than that.

 I had to become the person capable of the success I wanted.

 Small daily habits I adopted were a big reason I could do that.

 I journaled almost every day and treated each entry as a mini sparring session with myself.

 On January 27th, 2021, about a month before I got my first SMMA client, I wrote: 

 “Be the person who is becoming the person you want to be, and you will become the person you want to be. 

 Be the average person who wants to become great in the future, and you will stay the average person who wants to become great in the future.” 

 That first line might be hard to read, but here’s what I meant:

 Think like your future self, act like your future self, and you’ll become them faster than you think.

 What habits do they have?

 How would they act in the situation you’re currently in?

 Get a clear picture.

 And today, choose to act like that version of yourself you’re aiming to become.

 Only then, will reality begin to catch up.

 Eventually you’ll look back at your frat-boy-self with a 1.1 GPA and laugh at how far you’ve come.

 But only if you start today. ​

 Happy Monday,

 Ben

 ​

 ​

 ​

subject: Got caught in rain with homeless ppl
body:
Oh no.

It’s finally happened.

I’ve run out of things to write about.

12 minutes staring at this blank page and still nothing.

Maybe the words will write themselves.

The other day, I got caught in the rain.

I was sitting outside the coffee shop and got distracted.

A man picked up a piece of paper that someone littered and threw
it in the trash.

He was completely alone and I was the only person who saw.

I was in awe.

What a guy! If I did that, I'd at least make an Instagram reel
about it.

Or maybe wait until I’m walking with someone I want to impress.

“Wow you’re so thoughtful and kind for taking care of the planet!

No bitch I just want to hit.

Hahahaha.

A couple minutes later it started drizzling.

Miami does this thing where it’ll rain for a sec and stop five
minutes later.

I figured it would pass.

I waited 5…10… then 20 minutes.

The light rain turned into a downpour.

The weather app said it wouldn’t stop for another hour.

I couldn’t just sit at the cafe all day. I had to get back to my
desk.

So I booked it.

It was like the part of a romcom where the two main characters
dance and sing in the rain.

Except it was just me and homeless people, who were singing to
the imaginary friends in their heads.

I got back to my place after a few minutes, soaking wet.

Then it stopped raining.

Normally that would piss off but I kind of enjoyed it.

I guess there’s a lesson in here.

Run in the rain with homeless people.

Or maybe the rainbow comes after the rain.

Or the calm comes after the storm!

I don’t know…

Insert some corny quote that the 8x vaxxed 150 body health
influencer chick would have in her Instagram bio.

No lesson today – unless you count, don't trust Miami weather and
don’t wait for inspiration to strike.

Just start moving (or writing).

If you made it this far, you’re either entertained or bored and
loyal.

Either way, here’s the part where you buy from me. (
https://click.kit-mail1.com/qdurvx4oenh7h4rqk3zclh89d6dkkb4h4xo86/x0hph6henewm4zu5/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Will try again tomorrow,

Ben

​

​

​

subject: How to speedrun a $100k/mo info business
body:
No clever hook today, I’m in a rush.

My good friend Jeremy Moser, who runs a $450k/mo info agency is
graciously hosting a guest call in Artisan Lab in 30 minutes.

So I’ve gotta speedrun this email about how to speedrun an info
business.

On January 2nd of this year I got DM from this guy who said he
had a successful blue-collar business and wanted to start selling
info.

He had no audience and no idea where to start.

I gave him very simple direction and said “start with short form
on Tik Tok and IG.”

And guess what?

The guy actually listened.

Four months later he started to get the hang of content.

He only had 1,500 followers, but his videos were getting solid
views and he was growing.

I could see the potential and took him on as a client.

Within a week we had everything built out.

Lead magnet in the bio collecting emails, campaigns sending,
structured the offer, etc.

We launched three months ago.

This month we’ll make about $70k.

Not bad for a guy who had never posted a TikTok before January.

While it’s not an insane amount of money in the info world…
remember, this guy had no followers, no content, no offer, and no
clue where to start.

Fast forward to today, we will soon hit $100k/mo.

So here are the steps we followed to spawn a soon-to-be 7-figure
business:

* Content: Four months posting short form every day. 2-3x/day on
TikTok. 1-2x/day on IG.
* Warm up: Lead magnet in the bio, built a list and started
nurturing the audience further.
* Launch: VSL scripted and recorded, call funnel built, closer
onboarded and ready.
* Break everything and fix it: We didn’t try to perfect the
launch. We had the barebones in place for everything.

Since then, we’ve revised the VSL, the funnel cycled through
closers and setters, adjusted the pitch, the offer, and so on.

Now our backend foundation is solid and scaling to six figure
months is mostly a matter of more traffic.

If it sounds like I’m over simplifying it, I’m really not.

All you need is traffic, a funnel, and an offer.

God bless info.

Okay I gotta get on this call – Go here to see how we spawn seven
figure info businesses from scratch. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/92ung4ow87hnh6p45w9i9hzpdrd33iwh9e0z6/reh8hohmqwx6pws2/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Bye,

Ben

​

subject: Got lost in Chicago and now speak German
body:
I’m in downtown Chicago, sitting in a coffee shop that doubles as
a bar.

It looks exactly how you’d imagine.

Dark walls, wooden tables, and barstools that look easy to pick
up and swing at someone’s head.

They’re playing Mr. Blue Sky on the speaker. Forgotten banger.

It took me 22 minutes to get here, although it’s only a 3 minute
walk from my hotel.

I asked the receptionist “What’s the best coffee shop around
here?”

“Jründgen ven” she said.

She had a German(?) accent that seemed to only be thick when
pronouncing the name of the cafe.

I mostly understood the rest of her directions but wasn’t really
paying attention because I was trying to make out what Jrüdgen
ven was.

She said something about going to the left and taking an
elevator. I think.

Drunken Bean!

That’s what Jrüdgen ven means.

Ok easy enough, I’ll just put in my trusted google maps - no need
for Nazi directions.

2 minutes later I was at Drunken Bean.

Well, my phone said I was. But unless it was hidden inside a fire
station, the GPS was wrong.

So I just started walking aimlessly.

I figured I’d either finally find the elusive little bean (pun
intended) or I’d stumble into a different cafe.

After 15 minutes, I was basically back where I started.

Just as I was about to give up and Uber to a different cafe, I
looked to my right and saw…

An elevator.

It was practically glowing. Like when you find a gold scar in
Fortnite.

I didn’t know where it would take me or why it was on the middle
of the sidewalk.

But I knew I had to get in it.

I put my faith in the elevator and finally a minute later the
words, “Iced latte with vanilla. Actually make it a double,
bitch” came out of my mouth.

So as I sit here, trying to extrapolate a lesson from this heroic
journey, here’s what I got for ya:

Just move — even if you’re directionless.

Your whole life was designed for you to think that you start with
a map.

Go through grade school, pick a major, stay the course…

Internship, entry level job, marry the chubby 4, live the same
day for 30 years, retire, and die.

Sorry I’m being a harsh asshole.

But if that sounds as miserable to you as it does to me,
developing a high tolerance for uncertainty is your savior.

If you want to carve your own path, you must accept that 90% of
the time it’ll feel like you’re running through a dark forest
with a toothbrush as your defense weapon.

You’ll almost never be able to accurately predict what the next
few years of your life will look like.

Which is okay – as long as you’re in motion.

Just keep walking, turning, looking…

And eventually your golden elevator (
https://click.kit-mail1.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpw25xoi5h2pd5dllanhv48px/m2h7h5h3ow5o4lsm/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) will appear.

See you at the Jründgen ven.

Ben

​

​

​

​
​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.kit-mail1.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpw25xoi5h2pd5dllanhv48px
) | Update your profile (

) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: The easiest time of year to get rich
body:
Happy Labor Day b, I hope you’re laboring.

I didn’t realize today was a national holiday until I got to the
coffee shop.

People who’d normally be frantically scootering to the office
were just sitting there…

Leisurely… Enjoying their coffee.

What the fuck.

It’s Monday morning, shouldn’t they be asking for permission to
go to the bathroom right now?

That’s when I connected the dots and realized it’s a holiday.

I promise I’m not this pretentious in real life.

Well, at least not until I throw some feelers out there to figure
out who I’m talking to.

Only then do I let it fly.

But since you’re on my email list, we're basically best friends
already.

Anyway, it’s crazy that we’re nearing the end of the year and the
real holiday season.

If you were reading my emails two Christmas’s ago, you might
remember one titled “Holidays are for women, children and
wagies.”

That’s how I’ve always felt.

You can really only enjoy them if you’re pure enough to be
excited about pretty lights, family time, and tradition…

Or if you’re miserable enough that a two week vacation is the
highlight of your year.

I don’t fall into either of those categories unfortunately.

But I do love this season for a different reason.

September-December has always been my biggest growth window.

* First $15k month: November 2021
* First $25k month: September 2022
* First $100k month: September 2023

Something about this stretch puts pressure on you.

You look up, realize the year’s basically over, and either feel
like a lazy piece of shit…

Or you lock in and cram 12 months of progress into the last 4.

Q4 is the easiest time of year to make money.

And right now, it’s Q4 eve.

So if you’ve been slacking, good news: doesn’t matter.

You’ve got 4 months.

They’ll decide how you look back on 2025, and how much momentum
you carry into 2026.

​Let’s get to laboring. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/d0u9zn358qs0ho0g9rxtmhzn73444hlhndgov/owhkhqhw499w5kav/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

P.S. If you're ready to lock in, here's what can happen:

James hit his first $20k month (he was at $2k a few months ago).

Jayden closed another client...

​
And Alo closed an *inbound* client with some help from our
referral network...

​

subject: How to go from good to great (CHC)
body:
Certified Hood Classic today -- originally sent June 25th, 2024.

**WARNING: This one might turn you into a super-genius.

Enjoy:

I cracked the code.

It’s summer 2015.

An hour in to a grueling basketball workout, my trainer makes a
new rule.

“If the ball hits the rim it counts as a miss and you have to run
sprints. Swishes only.”

I think to myself “this mf crazy, I need a new trainer.”

But I keep shooting, now aiming only for nylon.

The ball hits the back of the rim and goes in. Doesn’t count.

Front rim. Side rim. Rattles in off the glass.

Doesn’t matter, I’m running.

“This is ridiculous. I’m literally making these shots and still
being forced to run,” I complain to myself.

But then something cool happens.

I find the sweet spot and the ball stops hitting the rim.

body:

subject: Why you should shatter your phone
body:
I was playing catch with my phone yesterday.

My goal was to throw it as close as possible to the ceiling
without touching it.

I had the accuracy of prime Aaron Rodgers.

With each throw, I progressively got closer.

There had to be less than a centimeter of space between my phone
and the drywall.

And then…

I put too much power on it.

My phone hit the ceiling and started wobbling down to me.

It was spinning as fast as it was falling.

I reached out and got a finger on it but couldn’t reel it in (not
even prime Odell Beckham Jr. could’ve caught it).

It hit the porcelain tile, bounced, and landed face down.

“Finally! It’s gotta be broken,” I thought.

I picked it up and looked at the screen.

To my surprise, it was in perfect condition. Not a single crack
or dent.

I sighed, put it in my pocket and got back to work.

I was hoping it was damaged because then I’d have to get a new
one.

You might be thinking, “Ben, I thought you were rich, can’t you
just buy one?”

The money isn’t the issue.

It’s the friction that comes with it.

Getting a new phone means transferring all my data.

I know this can be simple, but what if something goes wrong?

That would mean I have to make a visit to one of my least
favorite establishments on Earth…

The Apple store.

I just hate everything about it.

The lights, the people, the smell…

I’d walk in, go up to one of the virgins at the “genius bar” and
they’d say…

“Sir you need an appointment” under their COVID mask.

Then I’d have to wait 30 minutes for the little genius to finish
teaching a grandma how to take a photo.

Finally, buddy would waddle over to me and say, “what’s the
issue, pal?”

The first issue is my phone doesn’t work. The second issue is you
calling me “pal.”

Then I’d wait for him to do whatever virgin witchcraft is
necessary to set up my phone, and finally I’d be outta there.

That’s just not an experience I’m willing to go through –
especially when my current phone is functional.

That’s why I was hoping it was broken.

Because only then, would the pain of doing nothing outweigh the
cost of change.

In life, it’s pretty easy to be comfortable.

Even if you’re fairly miserable in your current situation.

If you have food on the table, a girl above a 4 who lets you hit,
and there’s football on TV…

It’s not that bad, right?

So despite the fact that you want to change, you’re not in enough
pain to sacrifice the comfort.

Such is life.

This is typically the part where we come to a resolution.

I give you some advice that wraps it all up into a positive
light.

But today, the answer doesn’t come from me.

It comes from how much pain you’re willing to create for
yourself.

Maybe that means you intentionally destroy your life.

Or perhaps you just needed to throw on a David Goggins video.

Hope you can figure it out!

​I’ll be here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/0vukr0nl6oh9h9d3540flhv0g2555fnhxm59l/p8heh9h49w2ndmcq/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​
​

​

​

​
​

subject: How to make "big" feel small (lol)
body:
$100,000 in one month.

That number used to sound unattainable.

I’d hear other people talk about it, but couldn’t conceptualize
making it myself.

Then I pivoted from SMMA to info.

My first handful of clients sold online basketball training.

In our biggest months, we made around $50k–$75k.

That was their revenue not mine – but being part of it made me
realize that kind of money didn’t require solving world hunger.

It was simpler than I thought.

A little over a year later, I made $102,238 in one month (at 90%
margins).

I wasn’t some radically more skilled version of myself.

But I was accustomed to seeing bigger numbers.

The difference was my perception.

Numbers only feel “big” until you spend time around people who
make them feel small.

When you see your idiot friend pull it off, you’re like…

“Oh, if that retard can do it, maybe it’s easier than I thought.”

This again leads me to why paying to join masterminds and
communities is a must.

I’ll save you the full spiel – but you can imagine how when
Artisan Lab members see there’s a 16 year old kid in there making
$10k/mo, it sounds a bit more feasible.

It’s clear data indicating it’s possible.

) breaking down the four phases I went through to hit $100k/mo

See you over there,

Ben

subject: How to stop wasting so much time
body:
I once broke a world record.

When I was in the beginning stages of my info agency, I’d spend
almost all day at my desk.

Outside of going to the gym, I basically never left.

Although I was locked in, I found myself in a predicament.

When considering what I actually accomplished each day, I could
think of maybe one or two things.

12 hours at my desk and I…

Sent an email…

Fixed an automation…

Changed the copy on a headline…

And uhhhh… scrolled social media I guess.

This shouldn’t take longer than an hour.

Where did the other 11 hours of my day go?

And how the fuck did I manage to not complete any of my highest
priority tasks?

I was a master at inefficient output.

No one could spend as much time as me “working” without getting
anything done.

This is a discouraging feeling.

A couple days ago, an Artisan Lab (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0do5lb8h86gl222ilh26gvn/58hvh7hg56kmx8t6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) member told me this is exactly how he felt.

He wants to be productive but…

He’ll get caught up doing random shit all day.

One small task turns into a two hour job.

A quick IG scroll turns into the sun going down.

Then he feels guilty for not being productive which leads to
anxiety, and the cycle continues.

If this sounds at all familiar, congratulations.

You’re a normal human with normal emotions and obstacles.

Here’s the advice I gave him:

Stop being a pussy.

1. Make a clear daily routine with dedicated work blocks for
different tasks. Highest priority tasks are first thing in the
morning (duh).

2. Use tools/apps to limit distractions. Put your phone in
another room – or lend it to a homeless man who’s instructed to
only give it back if you give him $100 each day.

3. Understand that your negative thoughts are not reality. When
you take action instead of listening to them, they lose power
over you (don’t be a pussy).

4. Habits and rituals outweigh relying solely on willpower. Make
“discipline” easy – give yourself a reward after completing tasks
(i.e. after I send outreach, I will do crack).

5. Focus on the feeling of accomplishment after completing
difficult tasks, not just the tasks themselves.

Boom.

Two days after I gave him this advice, he said “Guys outreach is
fking easy” and closed a new client:

​
If you’re tired of breaking my record for most hours wasted in a
day, go here and I’ll fix it with you inside Artisan Lab. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/e5uxd6r2vzs7hl0do5lb8h86gl222ilh26gvn/58hvh7hg56kmx8t6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Have a good weekend,

Ben

​

​

​

​
​
​

subject: How sports betting made me a better entrepreneur
body:
My name is Ben Bader and I’m an addict.

Over the past four days, I’ve placed a total of 24 bets on NFL
football.

Yes, twenty four.

I’m what experienced sports bettors would call a “square.”

A square is defined as “a casual bettor who follows gut feelings,
popular opinion, or media hype rather than doing sharp analysis.”

Bingo!

The online betting platforms love me.

If you want to know exactly what you shouldn’t do, just look at
their advertising.

All popular sportsbooks heavily promote parlays – A parlay is a
single bet that links two or more wagers together.

Meaning for you to win, multiple things have to occur.

It's higher risk, but on the odd chance that you effectively
guess correctly, it’s a thrill.

Just imagine…

You’re sitting on the couch watching a game you normally wouldn’t
give a shit about.

There’s two minutes left.

One team’s leading by 17, so it’s basically over anyways.

But not for you, you piece of shit degenerate.

You bet on the Texans third string wide receiver to have over 2
receptions.

It’s the last leg of your parlay.

All you need is number 81 to catch one more inconsequential pass
and you’ll turn $100 into $925.

It would make up for the 12 other bets you placed that missed
today.

Your eyes are glued to the TV.

The Texans run the ball.

“Why the fuck are you running the ball!? You’re down 17 with a
minute 24 on the clock!” you yell, somehow not knowing they can’t
hear you.

And then, with 19 seconds left in the game, it happens.

The quarterback throws the ball across the middle to number 81
for 7 yards.

It’s a meaningless play, the clock runs out, and the Texans lose.

But it meant everything to you.

That single catch means you’re not only back to breakeven, but
you’re in the green!

One event made up for all of your losses.

Business is the same way — especially in the beginning.

Most days it’s just pain.

One loss after another, your hard work is unrewarded, you want to
quit…

But then…

After 3 months of sending outbound messages with no luck, you get
a banger client.

After posting 150 videos that flop, you go viral and it explodes
your business.

After approaching 7,321 women in the street, one finally doesn’t
run away.

You need to adopt the mindset of the addicted gambler.

They will not stop.

The hole will get deeper and deeper…

Until one day…

​One win makes up for everything. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/xmum20qvx9u6hpwgv9gf5h2pxnlllbnhv48px/kkhmh6hn87kk5rhl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

TOUCHDOWN!

Ben

P.S. This is not an endorsement of sports betting. If you’re
gonna gamble, only do so with a sum you’re comfortable losing.

P.P.S. Justin Jefferson any time TD, Caleb Williams O 218.5
passing yards, Rome Odunze any time TD (not financial advice).

​
​
​

​

​
​
​
​

subject: 9 yards short
body:
I did something irresponsible.

At the very bottom of yesterday’s email, I gave you a parlay.

The odds on it were +1200 – Meaning $100 wins you $1,200 if it
hits.

There were three legs to it.

Two players needed to score touchdowns and the Bears QB needed to
throw for at least 219 yards.

Going into the 4th quarter, neither player had scored.

Three minutes later, touchdown Justin Jefferson.

One down, two to go. Still improbable.

Then with just two minutes left in the game, Rome Odunze scored.

Oh shit.

I’d sort of given up on the bet by halftime but it looks like it
might hit.

Those two legs were the underdogs.

The bet with the highest statistical probability was the only one
left.

With just 5 seconds to go, Caleb Willliams is 17 yards shy of the
magic 219 number.

Sooo you’re saying there’s a chance…

The Bears have one play to go the length of the field.

They snap the ball, Williams throws for 8 yards.

The ball gets lateraled to a different player who runs for
another 13.

That’s 21 yards!

Game over, parlay hits…

Right?

Uhhh, no.

Officially, Caleb only gets credit for 8.

Lateral yards don’t count for passing stats.

So he finished the game with 210 yards.

Just 9 short of the magic number that would’ve turned our $100
bet into $1,200.

That’s the painful beauty of a parlay.

Being “close” yields you nothing means nothing.

You can’t carry any momentum into the next bet.

But in business, you can.

When you’re nine yards short in business, it means you’re
learning.

Your outreach is sharper.

Your content is starting to hit.

You’re stacking reps and getting closer to gold.

Every near miss is just proof that you’re on the right track.

Keep going…

And go here (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h5ngxd0ilhokz6777i8hgk6z5/3ohphkh37oo567br/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) if you want me in your corner.

Ben

​

subject: Advice from our founding fathers
body:
I got lost in an Instagram reel vortex yesterday.

You know when you go to check your phone for “a minute” and three
hours later you’ve been hypnotized by the algorithm?

Same.

I stumbled on this niche where some dude stands outside filming
random people.

I don’t know his name but 90% chance it’s Kyle based on his
appearance.

Obviously nobody likes being filmed, so it sparks heated
interactions.

Cops show up, Kyle refuses to answer questions, eventually they
leave.

Then he turns the camera on himself and says something like:

“HeLl yEaH! I OwNeD tHeM!”

The point was to “stress test” the 1st amendment, Freedom Of The
Press.

It’s not illegal to film in public.

And Kyle really wants to make sure people know that.

I’m no founding father, but they’re probably rolling in their
graves watching this shit.

“I gave ya’ll all these rights and this fuckin idiot decides to
spend his time ragebaiting boomers. I’d rather you do OnlyFans or
blackhat MRR!” – James Madison

This is what happens when ambition doesn’t have a positive
outlet.

Everyone wants to feel like they’re doing something.

That’s why people get lost in sports, politics, or Kyle’s
ragebait niche.

Choose your obsession wisely.

Do you want to be a guy in an Ohio suburb with fucked up teeth
spending your days filming strangers?

Do you want to be a purple haired gender activist with 17 cats?

Or do you want to get rich on the internet and build an amazing
life for yourself and the people around you?

I’ll take option number three.

The time’s gonna pass anyway.

You might as well obsess over something that yields the highest
quality of life.

If you’re gonna be addicted to anything, let it be building
skills that print money.

​I’ll teach you here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghkq528lf7hn6gpxxxh8hqxl4v/6qheh8hl7573d4ao/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Back to scrolling,

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: b - let's compromise (CHC)
body:
“If you believe in something, you need to have the courage to
fight for those ideas — not run away from them or try and silence
them." - Charlie Kirk

Rest In Peace, Charlie.

On the topic of courage, today's email is a Certified Hood
Classic originally sent April 3rd, 2025

Enjoy:

Fair and noble people make compromises.

Life is not like Burger King.

You can’t always have it your way…

Fuck. That.

This way of thinking is for the mentally enslaved.

But you b, as a reader of the best newsletter on the internet,
deserve better…

You owe yourself better.

When you’re quick to make compromises, here’s what happens:

Your Ferrari dreams turn into a Corolla (or perhaps you buy a
corvette C8 when you’re 68 and try to convince yourself it’s a
real supercar).

Your supermodel wife turns into a plus sized hand model. Or your
“rich husband” turns into a guy that makes $105k/yr and loves to
say he makes six figures.

Your dream of waking up to the sound of the waves crashing on the
shore only happens 3 days a year. And you’re on vacation in
Myrtle Beach, not Honolulu.

I know this sounds a bit dramatic, but making compromises when it
comes to your desires is a slippery slope.

You need to be militant.

You need to be stubborn.

You need to aim for what you actually want.

When others tell you to be reasonable, or when you begin to hear
a voice in your head negotiating with you, shut it out.

I’d rather be an insane, unreasonable, stubborn asshole than a
chubby balding middle aged man… in a COROLLA!

Do not tolerate behavior that doesn’t align with your goals.

When you make a plan, stick to it as if you are following orders
from God.

There is no negotiating, there is no settling, and when you find
yourself exchanging “great” for “good enough,” stop yourself.

If you compromise, I guess I’ll send you a postcard from
Honolulu.

That’s basically the real thing isn’t it! LOL!

No. Stop.

It’s not the real thing. And a C8 isn’t a supercar. And fuck
Mrytle Beach.

Their rules and standards are meant to be broken. Yours aren’t.

See you in a Ferrari with a supermodel in your passenger seat.

To the stubborn and unreasonable – I will help you win. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh2o3dwxukhkr8v999b3hmgxon/7qh7h8h9opdll0uz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Nature loves courage,

Ben

P.S. I’d feel slightly irresponsible by not clarifying some
nuance here.

Not compromising doesn’t mean you refuse to turn up the
temperature when you set it at 67 and your girl wants it at 72.

It also doesn’t mean that there is only one way to accomplish a
goal and the route can’t be adjusted.

But when it comes to the real shit you want…

Don’t let anyone talk you out of it (including yourself).

​This is for those who refuse to compromise. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/8kue9mz0kxhoh2o3dwxukhkr8v999b3hmgxon/7qh7h8h9opdll0uz/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

​
​

​

​

​

​

subject: Bread, circuses, and misery
body:
“Give them bread and circuses and they will never revolt.” -
Juvenal

Juvenal had a point.

I spent all day yesterday on the couch watching football.

Sufficiently fed and distracted…

Until I wasn’t.

You see, this Juvenal fucker never experienced the misery of
being a fan of an “almost” team.

A team that sucks for years, finally turns it around, but
someway, somehow…

They always find a way to fuck it up.

I’m a closeted Cincinnati Bengals fan.

It’s my biggest normie vice.

They moved to 2-0 on the season yesterday…

But there’s a big problem.

Their star quarterback — the most important position in football
— likely needs surgery on his toe.

A fucking toe.

At worst his season is over and at best he limps back with a few
games to go in the year.

So Mr. Juvenal, “never revolt” you say?

That’s where you’re wrong.

If I were a 32-year-old making $73k/yr at a corporate job in
Cincinnati, with football as my only escape?

I’d be storming Paycor Stadium right now with pit stains in my
button-down.

Some poor bastard is sitting in a cubicle at 9:57am on a Monday
morning, down horrendous.

Fortunately that’s not my reality.

While I’m bummed, my life doesn’t rise and fall with Joe Burrow’s
toe.

My time, freedom, and energy are mine.

And I get to click buttons on my laptop from a Miami penthouse,
with my dream car in the garage…

While making six figures a month in profit.

Could be worse, I guess.

No torn ligament can take that away.

If you don’t want your whole year hinging on someone else’s toe…

I just made a new video where I’ll show you how I’m using AI to
build 7-figure info businesses. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh3med44b2hdel5666h7hwpom6/qvh8h7hdr8dglqbl/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vblpiRUdk
)​

Talk toemorrow.

Sorry that was a bad Dad joke.

Bye,

Ben

P.S. I’m coping.

No amount of money can make up for this.

Season’s over. My life’s in shambles. At least the NBA season is
starting soonish.

Maybe I should become a Ravens fan instead.

Maybe I should go on a meditation retreat.

Maybe I should move to Bali and eat bugs.

Maybe you should stop reading this and instead watch this video.
(
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/r8u0o3z624hoh3med44b2hdel5666h7hwpom6/qvh8h7hdr8dglqbl/aHR0cHM6Ly9saW5rdHcuaW4vblpiRUdk
)​

​

​

​

​
​
​

subject: I'm lazy
body:
It’s so easy to be lazy.

Like why would I be productive, when being lazy is so much
easier?

That’s the question…

Laziness is sort of like sleeping with hookers.

It feels good in the moment but you’ll soon be disgusted with
yourself.

Although sometimes, that’s exactly what you need…

I’ve never been a 5am, cold-shower, rigid-routine type of guy.

But I work relatively hard.

And every so often, I just don’t want to do anything.

Usually I snap out of it by telling myself:

“Stop being a bitch. Do you want to be poor? No? Okay, grow up
and do the work.”

That works 9 times out of 10.

But sometimes I’d rather sit in a middle seat between two Lizzo’s
than power through it.

That’s when I turn to “lazy-maxxing.”

I give in.

For a few days to a week, I let the laziness win.

I experience the thrill of rebuilding an NFL team on Madden,
playing a full season in one day, and seeing my guys lift the
Lombardi.

Hormozi could never.

But after a brief period of being a bum, I hate myself so much
that I reset.

I become more conscious of all the little things…

Waking up earlier, taking walks, less scrolling, and so on.

Then I go back to work, reinvigorated.

Now, I’m not encouraging this strategy.

There are probably many better ways to fix yourself.

And there’s a 90% chance that you simply need to be more
disciplined.

But if you really just can’t muster up the ambition to get shit
done…

Maybe try lazy-maxxing. (I’m not liable if you get addicted to
drugs or prostitutes).

Just don’t stay there too long.

The reset only works if you channel it into something productive.

Here are some non-lazy winners inside Artisan Lab: (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghkqo2qrt7hn6gpxxxh8hqxl4v/dpheh0he00rgvwfm/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Lloyd's first $10k month (only halfway through September)...

​
Khesraw made $20k from one client...

​
Jayden closed a whale client...

​
​Join them here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/wvunperxzdhghkqo2qrt7hn6gpxxxh8hqxl4v/dpheh0he00rgvwfm/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Talk tomorrow,

Ben

​
​

​

​

subject: Re: your first 5 figure client
body:
One of the hardest things you’ll ever do in business is switch
vehicles.

Especially when your current vehicle is “working.”

I remember when I was stuck at $15k-$20k/month with my SMMA.

That business allowed me to drop out of college, save up six
figures, and have complete time/location freedom.

But it was a constant headache.

Just the thought of scaling it gave me anxiety.

So I stayed half-in, half-out for almost a year.

I was too nervous to shut it down, and didn't have the clarity to
go all in.

Eventually, I pulled the trigger.

I started to get info-product clients, realized it was way
better, and the rest is history.

Now we’re here.

And over the past 6 months, I’ve watched one of my Artisan Lab
members go through a similar transition.

This is Lloyd:

​
Fun fact: His name is actually Michael but when he was pledging a
fraternity everyone said he looked like Lloyd from the show
Entourage.

I guess he liked that name better so he ran with it.

Anyway, he had a cool gig working as a videographer for
SteveWillDoIt.

He was paid well and that job provided a pretty sick lifestyle.

But he wanted to build his own thing.

So he joined AL and decided to get some info-product clients.

Within about 6 months, he hit his first $10k month outside of
videography:

​
If scaling feels impossible, it might just be time for a better
vehicle.

subject: Re: your first 5 figure client
body:
One of the hardest things you’ll ever do in business is switch vehicles.

 Especially when your current vehicle is “working.”

 I remember when I was stuck at $15k-$20k/month with my SMMA.

 That business allowed me to drop out of college, save up six figures, and have complete time/location freedom.

 But it was a constant headache.

 Just the thought of scaling it gave me anxiety.

 So I stayed half-in, half-out for almost a year.

 I was too nervous to shut it down, and didn't have the clarity to go all in.

 Eventually, I pulled the trigger.

 I started to get info-product clients, realized it was way better, and the rest is history.

 Now we’re here.

 And over the past 6 months, I’ve watched one of my Artisan Lab members go through a similar transition.

 This is Lloyd:

 ​ Fun fact: His name is actually Michael but when he was pledging a fraternity everyone said he looked like Lloyd from the show Entourage.

 I guess he liked that name better so he ran with it.

 Anyway, he had a cool gig working as a videographer for SteveWillDoIt.

 He was paid well and that job provided a pretty sick lifestyle.

 But he wanted to build his own thing.

 So he joined AL and decided to get some info-product clients.

 Within about 6 months, he hit his first $10k month outside of videography:

 ​ If scaling feels impossible, it might just be time for a better vehicle.

 That’s exactly what Lloyd realized.

 And it’s the same thing I’ll be breaking down for you live this Wednesday at 7pm EST.

 I’m running a free webinar on how to land your first $10k/month info client and start building something that actually scales.

 ​ Sign up here. ​

 See you Wednesday,

 Ben

 ​

 ​

 ​

subject: Why, b? (CHC)
body:
Certified Hood Classic for you today -- Originally sent Dec 12,
2024

Before we get into it, go here to sign up for my free live
training (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5llmn3fohpl5rkkkh9h79pno/kkhmh6hnlmxewnfl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
) this Wednesday.

Alrighty, enjoy:

The other day, a member in Artisan Lab told me that he was having
trouble staying motivated.

He asked me, “What's your why?” (meaning the deeper motivating
purpose that drives me to succeed).

Here’s my answer:

When I first started in online business, I just wanted to make
money.

Not having to work a 9-5 sounded cool.

Traveling sounded cool.

Having the freedom to create my own schedule sounded cool.

My “why” was mostly made up of self-serving factors.

I didn’t have to rescue my family from poverty and I didn’t have
a grand vision to save endangered turtles.

I wanted money because it looked fucking sick.

And the idea of clocking in and out for the better half of my
life sounded wayyyy less sick.

Sickening, if you will.

Furthermore, I had this feeling in my gut that you’re likely
familiar with.

It’s the feeling that told me that I couldn’t live a dull life.

I’d try to suppress it sometimes, but it never worked.

I simply knew that if I didn’t take a chance and at least attempt
to gain full agency over my life, I’d be absolutely miserable.

I’d rather end up homeless.

So when I looked at it that way, there was one glaringly obvious
option…

Build the life that I actually wanted to live.

Not for anyone else. Not for a greater purpose. But for me.

I wanted to escape the inevitable future pain of mediocrity.

Is that selfish? Sure.

But had I deluded myself into believing that I needed a stronger
“why,” perhaps I never would’ve started.

I could’ve rationalized, “I’m not motivated and I can’t work
because my life is decent as it is.”

Don’t let Simon Sinek (author of It Starts With Why) fool you.

Your “why” can be ripping an SVJ through the Hollywood hills.

Your “why” can be having the autonomy to wake up at noon every
day.

Your “why” can be club-hopping in Ibiza with a bunch of
ungrateful models.

My point is stop worrying about your fucking “why” and make
money.

Do you want to be miserable?

Do you want to be poor?

Do you want to be an incel?

No?

Okay! Then what the fuck else are you gonna do with your time?
Lol.

Eventually, your motivating factors will naturally evolve.

Once you check off the superficial desires, perhaps your focus
will shift to retiring your parents, setting up future
generations, or saving the Goddamn turtles.

But right now, you probably don’t care much about any of that.

If you’re honest with yourself, you just don’t want to worry
about spending money.

And that’s completely fine.

You don’t need to find some moral justification to stay
motivated.

It’s okay to want something, simply because you want to prove to
yourself that you can get it.

​Ready to get rich now? (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5llmn3fohpl5rkkkh9h79pno/58hvh7hgm760xkc6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

See you at the top,

Ben

​

​

​

​

​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5llmn3fohpl5rkkkh9h79pno
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/68u8vxpw9qs8h5llmn3fohpl5rkkkh9h79pno
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

subject: 9,131 days on Earth distilled into one lesson
body:
I’m getting old.

Today I turn 25.

Despite my senior citizen status, I still don’t have chest hair.

I also don’t know how to spell the word “restaurant” without
auto-correct and I can’t change a tire.

I thought these things would be programmed into me by the time my
brain was fully developed.

Guess I was wrong.

However, I’ve learned a few things that may be useful to you.

And because it’s my birthday, I feel obligated to distill 9,131
days on Earth into one lesson.

That’s a lot of pressure.

Ummm…

Wear a rubber and don’t get in the car with female Uber drivers.

Sorry that was mean, let me try again:

Five years ago, I was starting my sophomore year of college.

I’d made $1k that month as a freelance videographer but felt
directionless.

In my journal I wrote in all caps:

“IDK WHAT I WANNA DO BUT I CAN’T DO NOTHING.”

That sentence beautifully articulates a constant battle we all
face:

The tendency to drift.

I remember sitting in my dorm, debating between taking a bong rip
or going down a YouTube rabbithole.

I thought about my life at 25.

Either I take control now, or I wake up in a reality I didn’t
choose.

A job I hate. No motion. And a Toyota Corolla.

That night, I chose the bong rip and pushed this existential
crisis to tomorrow.

That was a dangerous decision I made more times than I should’ve.

But luckily I snapped out of it.

I’ve wrestled this tendency to drift for years.

And I won just enough times to get me here.

So I guess my lesson for you today is this:

You don’t have to be perfect.

You don’t have to sacrifice everything.

And you don’t even need a David Goggins poster on your wall.

You just need to notice when you’re misaligned – and have the
courage to do something about it.

Those moments when you hear that voice inside – that’s a breaking
point.

It first whispers, “this isn’t what you want. What are you
doing?”

Ignore it long enough and it yells…

“Wake the fuck up!”

If you hear that voice, you’re one of the lucky ones.

You haven’t let the world beat the light out of you yet.

But it’s up to you to follow it.

So here I am.

Twenty-five, no chest hair, still spelling “restaurant” wrong.

But I’m grateful I listened to that voice in my head a few times
more than I ignored it.

Because those few decisions compounded into the life I get to
live now.

If you take anything from this ramble, let it be this:

Your intuition is a compass.

Most people bury it under weekends and half naked women on social
media.

If you can keep yours alive and actually act on it…

You’ll end up somewhere worth being.

Here’s to the next 9,131 days.

Ben

P.S. This Wednesday at 7pm EST I’m running a free live training
where I’ll show you how to use AI to land, operate, and scale
with info-product clients.

Instead of stacking tiny retainers, you’ll learn how to close
clients that can pay you $10k+/mo.

​Register here. (
https://click.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hoh83d5g6s3hgqnd444hghqekg3/z2hghnhe3690wqcp/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vcmVnaXN0ZXI=
)​

​
​
​

​
​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hoh83d5g6s3hgqnd444hghqekg3
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.convertkit-mail2.com/27ukzem834hoh83d5g6s3hgqnd444hghqekg3
) | 2125 Biscayne Blvd, Ste 204, Miami, FL 33137

body:
Before we get into it, my free live training is tonight at 7pm

Everybody wants to sell info.

Why wouldn’t you?

It’s one of the simplest, highest margin businesses on earth.

You live your life, record videos, and people send you money.

All the benefits of OF without showing your tits.

But there’s a problem:

Info is a privileged business.

You have to earn your way in.

Sure there are some successful grifters…

But most of the time, if you’re not really good at what you’re
teaching – you won’t last.

So if you’re an early stage entrepreneur, you likely have no
“knowledge” to sell.

And the actual “best business model online” isn’t feasible for
you.

That’s why the Info-Agency model just makes sense.

Over the past few years, I’ve watched nearly all of my
agency/sales friends transition to it.

Because once you see how much money is flying around the info
space, you realize there’s no comparison.

Why would you beg boomers for little retainers for your “AI
Agency” (SMMA)...

When you could just plug into a business that already has
unlimited demand, proven offers, and an audience ready to buy.

Stop cold emailing dentists.

Start slinging info.

Info is the top of the food chain, and the only way to get in
early is by running the backend for people who already have the
leverage.

subject: I'm officially a guru
body:
One million dollars.

I used to think that was “never-have-to-work-again” type of
money.

I guess it can be if you want to live modestly.

But me?

Noooo.

I’m far too pretentious and egotistical to settle for a measly
$1m.

Last week, I got this stupid little plaque in the mail:

​
It’s the Clickfunnels Two Comma Club award.

When you make $1m using their software, they graciously let you
pay them $500 to get one of these.

They built their entire business off this thing.

The software sucks.

It has random bugs, it’s incredibly limited, and the funnels just
look scammy.

But everyone seems to accept that it’s part of the game in
pursuit of the guru plaques.

This is my second one with my name on it — though the first was
for a client who was nice enough to throw me on there.

But this one is just me.

I remember the first time I met someone with a 2CC award.

It was this guy I was working with on a basketball training
offer.

Every time we’d hop on Zoom, I’d see this shiny plaque sitting
behind him on the wall.

At the time, I was aiming for my first $20k month.

I couldn’t even imagine making $1m in a year.

That award felt like the pinnacle of success.

Fast forward a few years and now I’ve got two of them.

Like most arbitrary milestones, neither feel like I thought they
would.

That’s just how it goes.

You work really hard chasing what you think you want, only to get
there and realize it’s not all it’s cracked up to be.

I guess what’s cooler than this plaque are the lives changed in
its pursuit.

I’ve helped 18 year old kids make their first $10k online.

Just the other day Joao, one of our earliest members sent me this
message:

​
He lives in Portugal, joined with very little experience, and is
now hitting $14k/mo.

On top of that, nine members of Artisan Lab (
https://click.kit-mail1.com/k0udqe8rwzs6h5nroezclhokz6777i8hgk6z5/9qhzhnhdpvz0rvt9/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
) have hit their first $100k months.

And in early November I’m hosting my first ever in person
mastermind, exclusively for AL members. (

subject: I'm officially a guru
body:
One million dollars.

 I used to think that was “never-have-to-work-again” type of money.

 I guess it can be if you want to live modestly.

 But me?

 Noooo.

 I’m far too pretentious and egotistical to settle for a measly $1m.

 Last week, I got this stupid little plaque in the mail:

 ​ It’s the Clickfunnels Two Comma Club award.

 When you make $1m using their software, they graciously let you pay them $500 to get one of these.

 They built their entire business off this thing.

 The software sucks.

 It has random bugs, it’s incredibly limited, and the funnels just look scammy.

 But everyone seems to accept that it’s part of the game in pursuit of the guru plaques.

 This is my second one with my name on it — though the first was for a client who was nice enough to throw me on there.

 But this one is just me.

 I remember the first time I met someone with a 2CC award.

 It was this guy I was working with on a basketball training offer.

 Every time we’d hop on Zoom, I’d see this shiny plaque sitting behind him on the wall.

 At the time, I was aiming for my first $20k month.

 I couldn’t even imagine making $1m in a year.

 That award felt like the pinnacle of success.

 Fast forward a few years and now I’ve got two of them.

 Like most arbitrary milestones, neither feel like I thought they would.

 That’s just how it goes.

 You work really hard chasing what you think you want, only to get there and realize it’s not all it’s cracked up to be.

 I guess what’s cooler than this plaque are the lives changed in its pursuit.

 I’ve helped 18 year old kids make their first $10k online.

 Just the other day Joao, one of our earliest members sent me this message:

 ​ He lives in Portugal, joined with very little experience, and is now hitting $14k/mo.

 On top of that, nine members of Artisan Lab have hit their first $100k months.

 And in early November I’m hosting my first ever in person mastermind, exclusively for AL members. ​

 We’ll have a couple dozen info-agency owners at the PH for a two day info-bender.

 Now that is pretty cool.

 Meanwhile I’ll throw this award in the closet to collect dust next to its counterpart.

 To slinging info,

 Ben

 ​

 ​

 ​

 ​

 ​
​

subject: (1) Ben messaged you
body:
{{ subscriber.first_name }}, what’s wrong? You barely touched your webinar discount + bonuses. ​

 It’s been two days now…

 This is usually the part where I start pulling on your heart strings.

 I’ve written so many emails like this for my clients that it’s second nature now.

 First I would reward you for taking the initial action (coming to the webinar).

 Then I would bridge to the problem…

 “95% of people will do nothing with the information I showed you the other night.” 

 And I’d dig that pain a bit so you feel it…

 Here’s a direct quote I write in all post webinar sequences for my clients:

 “Your life will become a perpetual cycle of "almost." 

 You'll almost start a business. 

 You'll almost approach the pretty girl. 

 You'll almost become the person you know you can be. 

 But you won't. 

 You'll be stuck watching videos about how to make money, how to improve your relationships, and how to stop your lingering anxiety... 

 Because knowledge means NOTHING without the appropriate action.” 

 Did that make you feel any pressure?

 If so, go here and apply to join me inside Artisan Lab. ​

 If not, keep reading.

 You’re a skeptic.

 Maybe you want to try it on your own.

 Maybe you still don’t believe me – despite the fact that I showed you countless examples of people running it the fuck up.

 Or maybe you’re just funnel hacking and stealing my copy.

 Either way, I’ll skip the emotional build up and just give you the facts:

 9 members of Artisan Lab have hit $100k months.

 Over two dozen have reached $20k/mo+.

 The online education industry is growing at over 10% per year and it’s projected to reach $280B by 2029.

 You can sit on the sideline and complain.

 Or you can get in the game and capitalize.

 That’s a choice only you can make.

 So if you want my help…

 Plus a nearly $1k discount, a free 1-1 with me, and guest lessons from some of the biggest names in the info-product space…

 ​ Go here now. ​

 Talk soon,

 Ben

 P.S. If you're like me and you hate calls -- or you have questions you want answered before booking, just reply to this email and lmk.

 I'll personally hit you back (as long as you don't ask me for a 90% discount).

subject: How to buy a $10M mansion (Tutorial)
body:
I’ve started a bad habit.

Well, I have many bad habits.

But this is a new one. And it actually isn’t all bad.

53 minutes ago, I sat down to write this email.

That means what you’re reading right now is 53 minutes worth of
work.

On my way here, I got distracted by something shiny…

Zillow.

Do you know $5m in Miami Beach gets you?

A mansion on the water.

Butler included.

And playboy models feeding you grapes!

Just kidding.

For 5 MILLION DOLLARS…

You can get a shack.

You’ll have to share this shack with four homeless people.

They don’t bite but you have to feed them occasionally and put a
needle in their arms regularly.

I’m only half kidding.

You can get a nice place for $2-$5m.

It’s not the type of house where you’d walk in and hear an echo
as you say “wowwww!”

But it’s cute.

You only enter “wow” territory if you spend around $10m+.

I feel poor.

“Well Ben, you don’t need a mansion in Miami, you can get a
beautiful place in Kansas for $1.5m!” Blah blah.

I don’t wanna live in Kansas.

So I guess my lesson for you today is:

If you want to stretch your relationship with money, go to
Zillow.

Pick your dream location and look at some houses.

This will likely result in you considering how you can accumulate
a lot more money a lot quicker.

Then – once you’ve had your existential crisis – start an AI lead
gen agency for dentists.

Close every dentist in your state for $1k/mo.

Take that money straight to the casino.

Put it all on black.

If it hits, congrats.

You can now almost afford a shack in Kansas.

See you in Miami Beach.

Ben

P.S. If you don't wanna live in a shack, go here. (
https://click.kit-mail1.com/d0u9zn358qs0hoe6x00bmhzn73444hlhndgov/58hvh7hgmr3o3ef6/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

P.P.S. If you made it all the way down here, reply and lmk :)
​
​
​
​
​
​
​

subject: How to turn a bad idea into a good email
body:
Good morning, happy Monday.

We’re gonna try a fun experiment today:

You and I are gonna write this email together.

If it sucks, it’s your fault.

If it’s great, it was all me.

Ready?

Alright…

On my walk back from the coffee shop, I came up with the lesson
for this email.

It’s kind of basic, so we’re gonna have to dress it up.

The core message I want to articulate is this:

To get what you want out of life, you simply have to ask for it.

Well, and you have to work towards it.

Oh… and you can’t be a complete idiot.

This idea sucks.

We sound like if Mark Manson had a baby with a reformed hoe who
turned into a self-improvement podcaster.

I don’t think you can say hoe in an email b, that’s offensive.

We should delete this.

No, no.

We just need to start off with a story.

You: Got anything?

Uhhh I guess the other night when I was at dinner.

Go on…

They tried to seat me with the poor people.

You can’t say that.

Sorry, they tried to seat me on the terrace and I wanted to be in
the main dining room.

Okay…?

I said to the GM “hey brother, any chance you can move us to the
main dining room?”

He said “let me check,” and walked to the host stand.

20 seconds later he took us to our new and improved table.

And then what?

Uhh that’s it.

That’s your whole story?

Yes.

And you think we can write an email about that?

Well, it’s deeper than that – we just have to explain it to the
reader.

How so?

When you want something, you don’t settle.

You don’t buy the Corvette C8 when you really wanted the Ferrari
F8.

You don’t stop following up with the prospect until they tell you
to fuck off.

You don’t accept a life that’s “good enough.”

Sure, sitting on the terrace would've been fine.

They’ll still bring us the same food.

The atmosphere is almost as good.

But it’s not what I wanted.

So I asked.

And sometimes, that’s all you need to do.

Winners don’t settle.

That's the whole lesson – it’s simple, obvious, and easy to
forget.

But you might just settle your way into a life you didn’t want.

Would ya look at that! We turned a shitty idea into a decent
email.

Good work, my friend.

To building a life we actually want, (
https://click.kit-mail1.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hng8e0ma6h9k8e444cnh4p03v/08hwh9h2d4gvqnfl/aHR0cHM6Ly9nby5iZW5iYWRlci5jb20vdGhlLWFydGlzYW4tbGFi
)​

Ben

​

​

​

​
​

​Unsubscribe (
https://unsubscribe.kit-mail1.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hng8e0ma6h9k8e444cnh4p03v
) | Update your profile (
https://preferences.kit-mail1.com/5qu8dq3lkes7hng8e0ma6h9k8e444cnh4p03v
